properties.Victim: Verina L. Coy, 33 year old female, Madison, WIInjuries: Puncture wound to back of thigh, Bruised forehead, laceration to bridge of nose requiring stitches, bruises & abrasions to face/eyes/arms and lower torso areas.
properties.Details: On 3/15/2007 at approximately 4:38AM, Madison Police responded to 825 Hughes Place (Madison Police South District Station) reference a 33-year-old female who frantically reported having been stabbed & battered in the 2100 blk of Fisher Street.  Officers immediately noticed a puncture wound & blood to the thigh of the victim (Coy), and immediately summoned Madison Fire Rescue for treatment and transport to a local hospital.  The acquainted parties seemed to have gotten into an argument where Musillami got extremely upset, and while holding a switchblade knife to the throat of Coy, continued to make death threats as he physically battered her.  Coy managed to jump out of an apartment window with no shoes, and ran to a nearby street sweeper that happened to be operational near Park Street and Buick Street.  The victim refused to exit the street sweeper vehicle after having surprised the operator, and demanded to be taken to the Madison Police South District Station; where police would later talk to her about this incident. The victim reported having been struck at least 50 times, and stated Musillami denied her the opportunity to leave the assault location.  She also reported being stabbed in the thigh by Musillami after he allegedly had "Gone into a rage".  Police obtained detailed information as to the location of Musillami and responded immediately to his residence.  Musillami could not give police any reasonable explanation for the numerous injuries the victim sustained on this date.  Musillami would later be arrested on felony charges (listed above). Coy was treated at an area hospital for non-life threatening injuries and released without further incident.  PO Howard Payne

properties.Details: On 5/11/2008, shortly after 5PM, a Madison Police Detective in conjunction with The Community Policing Team (CPT) of the North District attempted to contact Richard D. Johnson in the 2800 Block of Moland Street reference a felony probation violation.  After checking a residence where Johnson was allegedly thought to be, Johnson would drive past officers attempting to flee arrest and a high-speed pursuit would commence.  This pursuit would continue through neighborhoods in and around this area for approximately 9 minutes, and based on due regard for safety, Police would terminate the pursuit to keep the public safe from the erratic driving behavior of Johnson running a number of stop signs in his attempt to elude police!Police having knowledge that this pursuit and contact with Johnson had proven unsuccessful just weeks before, attempted to contact Johnson on 5/27/2008 shortly after 9PM based on surveillance and the probability that Johnson was once again in the area (2800 Moland St).  Police would stop a vehicle that was connected to Johnson and find him hiding from view in the front passenger seat of the car.  Conscientious officers made an arrest after a "Lengthy delay" by Johnson to exit the vehicle.  The driver of the vehicle was subsequently charged with obstructing for not providing information to police about where Johnson was located after being asked specific questions.This case shows restraint by officers in the initial pursuit, keeping in mind the best interest of public safety as a number one priority.  It also reflects a commitment by officers to continue to work minute pieces of information until the case could be furthered; eventually ending in the arrest of an individual with no intentions of compliance!PO Howard Payne

properties.Details: (UPDATED FRIDAY AUGUST 1, 2008)The Madison Police Department (MPD) is seeking women were victimized by a suspect who was recently taking covert photographs at the Shopko store on Zeirer Road.  The victims likely have no idea this suspect was using his cell phone camera to surreptitiously gather images by snapping photos up skirts or dresses.Arrested for Disorderly Conduct is Ryan Y. Przedwiecki, age 32, Madison.Additional charges are possible, and the MPD is specifically seeking to identify the following victims:·	A white female with a medium build who had her hair up, and was wearing what appears to be a black and white polka dot dress, who was at the Shopko between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. on July 21, 2008. ·	A white female with blonde – just below shoulder length - hair with bangs. She maybe pregnant. The woman was wearing a black colored t-shirt or blouse with short sleeves, a floral or light colored skirt, and sandals. She was also carrying a striped purse. This victim had with her two children. One as a little girl with blond hair. This child was in a shopping cart. A second little girl had on a blue bandana, a pink top and blue shorts. This victim would have been at Shopko on July 30, 2008 between noon and 1:00 p.m., and would have spent time in the office and school supply sections of the store.·	A white female with a thin to medium build with dark hair. She was wearing a white baseball cap, and had on a red & white, or pink & white striped top, a jean skirt, and flip-flops. This shopper would have been at Shopko on July 27, 2008 between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m.  This case came to light because of a very aware and proactive loss prevention officer at Shopko. The Madison Police Department commends this employee for her efforts.The Madison Police detective working this case urges all women to be “ aware of their surroundings ALL THE TIME. All the women he followed in stores appear to be unaware of his presence, even though he was acting suspiciously. “Anyone with information on these specific women, or on any others, who may have been victimized, would be urged to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and maybe eligible for up to a $1,000 reward.-------------------------------------------------------(ORIGINAL RELEASE)On Wednesday afternoon, at 12:52 p.m., Madison police were sent to the Shopko on Zeier Road after store security spotted a man taking snapshots up women's skirts with his cell phone camera. Victims had no idea he was engaged in this covert activity. The suspect was arrested and investigators discovered numerous "up skirt photos” housed in the camera’s memory. It’s believed the suspect may have committed similar crimes in other Madison area stores. A Madison Police detective has been assigned to the case.

DELIVERY NOTICES FOR UNPAID PARKING TICKETS   The Madison Police Department, as a normal business process, mails out hundreds of parking notices each month.  For most of this past winter, however, many late payment notices have not been mailed, at least not out until now.  In early December, the Wisconsin Dept of Transporation "upgraded" the computer systems that maintain the vehicle registration and license files.  When this change was implemented the week of December 13, MPD found that DOT had changed the data formats sent back to law enforcement agencies who make electronic inquires of these files. Subsequently automated programs written by MPD's records mangement system vendor to identify license plates and VIN#'s with unpaid parking tickets no longer worked.  Over the past two months, MPD's vendor and MPD Information Management & Technology staff have worked to re-write the interface application, and just recently began sending out large volumes of late payment notices.    MPD wishes to advise the public, particularly their "repeat customers" who have received several parking tickets over the winter, that the U.S. Post Office will be delivering several thousand notices over the next few weeks as we attempt to get our late payment processing back on track.

properties.Details: The Madison Police Department, along with other local and national law enforcement agencies, will participate in the CLICK IT OR TICKET MOBILIZATION 2005 efforts, May 23-June 5, 2005.   Extra officer patrols will start on May 23, 2005.  These patrols will occur on various dates and times throughout the campaign period.  The focus on the extra patrols is to intensify enforcement of child passenger safety and safety belt laws to help save lives.  In 2004, WI Department of Transportation reported that seatbelt use varies more than 7% across the state.  The Madison area is highest at 75.6 % and the Milwaukee area is lowest at 68.1%.  Other research shows occupants of vans (80.5%)were more likely to use their seatbelts than occupants of pickup trucks (58.2%).  Females were also more likely to wear their safety belt than males.  The national seatbelt use, based on last years successful Click It or Ticket campaign, was 80%. During the mobilization officers will concentrate on safety belt use by all vehicle occupants, regardless of age.  The Madison Police Departments wants to increase the use of safety belts up to the national average during this campaign.  Although the public knows it should buckle up, many people dont take the 2 seconds needed to so.  Increased enforcement, with aggressive publicity highlighting enforcement efforts, is an effective tool to increase compliance.

properties.Details: At approximately 12:57 pm on this date, Madison Police responded to assist Dane County Deputies and weapons screeners at the City-County Building's Carroll St entrance. The Madison Police Department’s K9 officers have been on the streets for only half a year; yet they are already have a significant impact in helping keep Madison safe.  Madison K9 officers are actively involved in locating dangerous weapons and drugs, and have resulted in numerous arrests.  K9 officers have helped located dangerous felony suspects, missing or lost persons, and valuable evidence.  K9 officers routinely assist patrol officers search buildings and track and apprehend potentially dangerous suspects, greatly improving the safety of patrol officers on these types of calls.  K9 officers have also made over 20 educational presentations and demonstrations in the Madison area.K9 officers have been directly involved in locating over 81 pounds of marijuana and 856 grams of cocaine.  They have located several dangerous weapons including a 9 mm, a 357 and a .380 handgun, all loaded and associated with drug trafficking.  In addition to removing drugs with a street value in excess of $140,000 from Madison streets, K9 officers have resulted in the seizure of over $25,000 in cash and 1 SUV.Although the K9 officers have been very active so far, additional K9 officers are needed to meet the increasing demand for the services these teams provide.  Madison Police currently have just four K9 officers and patrol officers and sergeants have often requested the assistance of a K9 officer only to be told they are not working that day or shift, or are already helping other officers.  The Madison Police Department hopes to add an additional three K9 teams but with an estimated cost of $50,000 per K9, all funded by donations through a non-profit organization, they are looking for the community’s help.  Anyone interested in making donations or supporting the Madison Police Department K9 program can go to www.capitalk9s.org or contact Lt. Vic Wahl or Sergeant Chris Boyd.

properties.Details: At approximately 10:10 a.m. a disturbance broke out in a crowded hallway at Memorial High School.  Eight to ten students were involved.  The disturbance turned into three to five physical fights in the hallway.  The individual participants have been identified.  They were separated and removed from the school.  Charges are pending.  A short time later, a staff member asked a student to remove a hat.  The student responded by striking the staff member in the face.  That student has been identified and charges are pending in that matter.  At approximately 11:30 a.m. a student became verbally abusive and threatening to a teacher.  That student was cited for disorderly conduct.  At some point during the initial disturbance an officer inadvertently touched a fire alarm, setting the alarm off.  It is not known to what degree the incidents may be related.  The cases remain under investigation.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: As of 3:00 a.m., State St mirrored a typical Friday night.  There were no reports of major disturbances as the crowd was lawful and ended peacefully.  There were over 125 arrests, down from last year's Friday night. Most of the arrests were alcohol related.  Field commanders report a crowd of approximately 25,000 people attended the State Street event.  "I appreciate the work of the Madison Police Department and other law enforcement agencies and the responsibility of the students, as we expect this well-behaved crowd to carry over into Saturday night," stated Madison Mayor Dave Cieslewicz.  By 3 a.m. most officers working the event started to end their shift.  "The success of tonight illustrates the comprehensive law enforcement plan, combined with students embracing responsibility for this event.  We expect Saturday night will be similar to Friday, but just with more people", stated Madison Police Chief Noble Wray.

Six house parties have been broken up for alcohol related violations and most of those are occurring north of Gilman St and near Langdon.  No major injuries or property damage has been reported at this time.

properties.Arrested: Halloween Event
properties.Details: This is a copy of the press release issued at 4:30 a.m. on 10/30/2005 by Public Information Officer Mike Hanson. Please note more information will be available tomorrow, Monday, 10/31/2005. "While a solid plan and good execution resulted in improvement, Madison Mayor Dave Cieslewicz and Madison Police Chief Noble Wray agreed that it is time for the Madison Community to take a hard look at whether Halloween on State Street should continue.Two of the four measures of success established prior to the event were met - there were no serious injuries or major property damage. But for the fourth year in a row, police had to wear hard gear and deploy pepper spray to clear a disorderly and dangerous crowd.'The Madison Police Department and other law enforcement agencies deserve credit for acting quickly to prevent injury and property damage', Cieslewicz said. 'But when we spend approximately $350.000, when 447 (178 Fri, 269 Sat) people are arrested, when Detox is filled, we can't characterize this as a successful event.'Chief Wray was proud of the fact the event was executed according to plan, yet also questions its future. 'I was proud of the officers and commanders exection of the comprehensive plan. Although we have plans in place, for the fourth year in a row we have people coming to State Street to cause disruption and put my officer's safety at risk.'

properties.Details: On November 10th, 2005, Officers were dispatched to the 4500 Blk of Verona Road reference a male subject that attempted to obtain money from individuals in the area, based on his claim that his vehicle was disabled.  This subject had been seen by witnesses pouring liquid on top of his engine and underneath his vehicle to make it seem as if his vehicle was experiencing mechanical problems.  He then used his creative misfortune to get unsuspecting bystanders to give him money that would allegedly aid him in repairing his car.  People throughout the City of Madison should be extremely careful when approaching individuals they do not know, and although this is the season of giving people should not actively give money to individuals that are unfamiliar to them.  The Madison Police Department will continue to actively monitor scenarios such as this to keep all citizens safe.

properties.Details: Officer Involved Shooting Info·	On April 12th at 8:09 am, Madison Police Officers Kip Kellogg and Kirby Harless responded to the BP Station at 1130 Williamson St. for a man who had locked himself in the bathroom.  The man had called 911 and said that people were trying to kidnap him.  The caller verbally identified himself as Victor Montero-Diaz.·	Upon officer’s arrival, a station employee confirmed a man had been in the bathroom for about 20 minutes.  The officers tried to get Montero-Diaz to come out of the bathroom, but he refused.  Officers obtained a key and unlocked the door.  Montero-Diaz came out of the bathroom and rushed the uniformed officers.   Officer Kellogg deployed a taser that had no effect.·	The officers continued to physically struggle with the man. They realized the man had a large knife in his hand.  During the struggle, Officer Harless suffered serious bite wounds to both arms.  Officer Kellogg was stabbed once in the right bicep.  They were unable to subdue or disarm the man who continued to come at the officers brandishing the knife.  Officer Kellogg drew and fired 3 rounds.  ·	A bystander coming to aid the officers was hit by one of the rounds, or a ricochet of one of the rounds.   Officer Kellogg provided basic medical aid to him until paramedics arrived.  The by-stander was treated and released from University Hospital.  Officer Harless attempted life-saving aid to Montero-Diaz.  ·	Both Officer Harless and Kellogg were treated at Meriter Hospital.  Officer Harless was treated and released.  Officer Kellogg was admitted, but released early this afternoon.A number of interviews have taken place and will continue with both witnesses to the incident, and those who knew the deceased.  The investigation at this point leads us to believe Montero-Diaz was suffering from some hallucinations or delusions just prior to this incident.  This case remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Estimados amigos:En los últimos días, han estado circulando en nuestra comunidad rumores de que agencias policíacas y federales han estado realizando redadas para la captura de inmigrantes indocumentados.  Primeramente, deseamos comunicar que todas las fuentes a nuestro alcance indican que esta información no es cierta, y que en nuestra comunidad no se estan llevando a cabo tales operativos.  Segundo, aunque estos rumores son falsos, vale la pena aprovechar esta oportunidad para nuevamente recalcar que el Departamento de Policía de Madison tiene una tradición y tambien un reglamento interno que claramente destacan que nuestros oficiales no indagan sobre el estado migratorio de los miembros de nuestra comunidad.  Esto es parte de la filosofía de nuestro gobierno municipal de que asuntos de ley migratoria son asuntos primordialmente del gobierno federal, y que actuar de otra forma pondría en riesgo la importante relación de confianza que siempre queremos cultivar con toda la comunidad.A continuación les envío una comunicación directamente del Departamento de Policía de Madison relacionada a este tema.Atentamente,Dave CieslewiczALCALDE----------------------------------------------------------------El Departamento de Policía de Madison no ha asistido en la planificación o ejecución de redadas migratorias por las autoridades federales.  El Departamento de Policía de Madison ha recibido comunicaciones preocupadas por tal participación potencial de nuestro Departamento, per es nuestra intención aclarar que no ha existido tal participación.    “Yo he escuchado del temor en la comunidad Hispana que nuestros oficiales han ayudado a oficiales de Inmigración con operativos de deportación,” señaló el Jefe de la Policía de Madison Noble Wray.  “Nuestro reglamento interno indica claramente que nuestro departamento no le notificará a agencias federales del estado migratorio de un individuo al tratarse asuntos policíacos locales.”  Según el Reglamento Interno del Departamento de Policía de Madison: “El Departamento de Policía de Madison cooperará con el Servicio de Inmigración y Naturalización (INS [por sus siglas en Inglés]) tal como lo haría con cualquier otra agencia policíaca.  Sin embargo, es la política de este departamento que sus oficiales no arrestarán o detendrán a cualquier persona por solamente por sospecha de una violación de leyes de Inmigración, excepto tras una petición del INS.“Los oficiales no le pedirán a ninguna persona que presente su Tarjeta de Registro de Extranjero (Tarjeta Verde)  u otro documento de inmigración, excepto cuando se esté asistiendo al INS. Dear friends:In the last few days, rumors have been circulating in our community that law enforcement and federal officials have been conducting raids aimed at capturing undocumented immigrants.  First, we want to let you know that all sources within our reach indicate that this information is false, and that no such operations are taking place in our community.  Secondly, although these rumors are false, it is worth taking this opportunity to emphasize again that the Madison Police Department has a tradition and also a formal policy that clearly provides that our officers will not inquire into the immigration status of our residents.  This is part of a philosophy of our municipal government that immigration law matters are primarily a federal government matter, and that to act otherwise would jeopardize the important trust relationship that we endeavor to cultivate with our community.  I include below a communication from the Madison Police Department related to this matter.Sincerely,Dave CieslewiczMAYOR --------------------------------------------------------------------------The Madison Police Department has not assisted in any planning or execution of Immigration raids by federal authorities.  Concerns have been raised to the Madison Police Department about potential involvement and it is our intention to make it clear that we have not participated.   “I have heard of fear in the Hispanic community that our officers are assisting Immigration officials with deportation measures,” stated Madison Police Chief Noble Wray.  “Our policy clearly indicates that our department will not notify federal authorities of one’s immigration status when dealing with local police matters.”   Per Madison Police Department policy: “The Madison Police Department will cooperate with the Immigration and Naturalization Services (INS) as it would with any other law enforcement agency.  However, it is the policy of this department that its officers shall not arrest or detain any person solely for a suspected violation of immigration laws, except upon the request of INS.” “Officers shall not ask any person to produce an Alien Registration Card (Green Card) or other immigration document except when assisting the INS.”

properties.Details: There is further information the Madison Police Department is making public regarding the officer involved shooting at the BP gas station on April 12, 2006.  Victor Monterro-Diaz’s probation agent told Madison Police Officers on April 12th that Monterro-Diaz did not have a history of mental health illness and that he did have a history of cocaine use.  Madison Police also spoke with Dane County Mental Health and learned they had not had any contact at all with Montero-Diaz.  Additionally, the Dane County Coroner’s Office has informed the Madison Police Department that preliminary toxicology results are positive for the presence of cocaine and cocaine metabolites.

properties.Arrested: 22 Stops, 26 citations
properties.Details: On Tuesday 5/9/06 from approximately 7 a.m. to 1 p.m. over 10 Madison Police Officers participated in a traffic enforcement initiative for the Beltline Hwy.  Twenty-two stops were made in using only the "shadow" car and not laser or radar.  From these stops, twenty-six citations were issued.  The first two stops led officers all the way to the Interstate.  The shadow car was trailing a vehicle traveling 75 m.p.h. on the Beltline and eventually 80 m.p.h. on the interstate.  While trailing this vehicle, another vehicle passed both the shadow and suspect vehicle, eventually reaching 90 m.p.h.  Officers were able to pull over both vehicles.  Most of the citations were for speed, following too close and unsafe lane changes.  This will be an ongoing enforcement effort on the Beltline.

properties.Details: In response to an escalation in weapon violations, ranging from shots being fired to injured persons from gunshots on Allied Drive; the Madison Police Department organized a Command Post at the West Police District to deal with this on-going issue.  Efforts to identify suspects and solve these cases have been significantly hampered by a lack of witness and victim cooperation.  Dedicated to the Command Post are resources including detectives, a criminal intelligence specialist, neighborhood officers, the South/West Community Police Team and other law enforcement agencies.  The purpose is to gather intelligence concerning the Allied Drive neighborhood and make arrests of those committing the most serious crimes including weapon violation, illegal weapon sales and drug trafficking.

There have been numerous reports of stolen mopeds in the downtown area since classes resumed.  It is estimated that between 20-30 mopeds have been stolen so far as reported to MPD, which would not include UWPD's statistics.  Mopeds have been "hot wired", rolled away, put in other vehicles and taken out of sight.  The Madison Police Department advises moped owners to safeguard them by using locking devices around the wheels, securing them to a fix object, incorporating a security device outfitted by the dealership and other measures that would prevent theft.  Oftentimes these reports are reviewed, but little follow-up is done due to lack of evidence, suspect information and resources.

After a third public hearing in June 2006 the Madison Common Council supported the resolution, "Regulation of Private Alarm Systems" (Verified Response) with support of 14 alders and Mayor Cieslewicz.  One of the purposes of this new ordinance was to efficiently use police resources, while maintaining public safety.  The process for this ordinance included a lengthy study (illustrating how over 95% of the alarm calls police respond to are false), public hearings and support from the Common Council.   During the process, the Madison Police Department listened to concerns from the community, businesses and alders and supported changes to the evolving ordinance.  In response, the Madison Police Department worked with Council members and made adjustments related to the ordinance, which are outlined below:-As practiced before the Verified Response Ordinance, Madison Police Officers will still respond, unconditionally, to all residential alarms.  These alarms make up 12% of all false alarms.  -Madison Police will respond to any commercial burglar alarm once verification takes place indicating a crime or irregularity is or may have taken place.  -When a mechanically activated commercial burglar alarm is received by the 911 Center, the information will be broadcast over police radio to officers working in the vicinity.  There will be no expectation that a police response will occur.  A police response is generally based on the number of circumstances from call-load, frequency of the business's false alarms, proximity, availability and other situations.  -Madison Police will continue to respond to any human activated alarm whether it originates from an individual, a residence or a business.  Panic, duress and robbery alarms are NOT affected by the ordinance change.  The Madison Police Department will provide a year-end report of this new ordinance to the Madison Common Council.

properties.Victim: 22-year-old female resident of Madison. Not injured.
properties.Details: Victim reported to Madison Police that at approximately 8:50 a.m. she was walking to work and was near West High School. She indicated as she was on Highland Ave near the football fields, she noticed the above two suspects. She indicated she crossed the street and the subjects followed her. As she was walking, suspect #1 caught up to her  grabbed her forcefully and indicated that she was to come with them. The victim was able to pull free and continued to walk to work, where she called the police. Anyone with information about this incident should call crime stoppers at 266-6014.

The driver of the car traveling southbound on S. Whitney Way prior to being struck has died.  Brian McNally, 26, of Waunakee died 12/29/06 at 7:45 p.m. in the hospital.  Please see previous Madison Police news releases posted under this case number for further details about the crash.

The Madison Police Department continues to advise people to use caution when selling/purchasing items over the internet.  In the past, there was the "Nigerian" scam in which Madisonians lost thousands of dollars in an internet scam from "Nigeria".  Although frustrating, there is little, if any follow-up the Madison Police Department can provide.  The latest possible scam comes from Canada, with the same theme.  An individual selling their vehicle on-line is told that a Church in Canada has decided to purchase the vehicle.  In doing so, they send a "check" for more than the asking price (to handle what are believed to be taxes, shipping and handling, etc) and then eventually ask for a returned cashier's check from the seller, typically for thousands of dollars.  To our knowledge, this does not appear to be a legitimate cause and citizens should be cautious of strangers sending you "money" and then asking for money in return.

properties.Address: Student Spring Party on Mifflin St.  **4 p.m. UPDATE ***7PM UPDATE***9:15 PM UPDATE--Final
properties.Details: As of approximately 1:30 p.m. there were 21 arrests for city ordinance violations, with some still waiting in the arrest processing center.  Field commanders estimate the crowd to be around 4,000 and growing.  There have not been any major incidents reported.  This site will be updated around 4 p.m.*** 4 P.M. UPDATE ***Crowd is estimated to be around 10,000 people.  Over 80 arrests, mostly alcohol related, have been reported.  The crowd still has a "party" demeanor.  Horse patrol began at 2:00 p.m.   No major incidents reported at this time. ***7:15 P.M. UPDATE ****  Crowd has signficantly lowered in size.  Some cross streets will open shortly.  Over 330 people arrested, with 7 of those arrested going to jail.  Those not going to jail were brought to the arrest processing center, cited and released.  The majority of the arrests were alcohol-related.  The crowd demeanor is considered to be cooperative at this point. ***9:15 PM UPDATE **** Mifflin Street is open to traffic.  No major incidents reported.  366 arrested, mostly alcohol related, cite & release.  Street sweepers have begun cleaning up.

If you see police tactical personnel in this area, understand that they are participating in a training exercise only. If you have questions, please call the Madison Police Department Officer-in-Charge at 266-4923.

This is a News Release coming from Chief Greg Leck of the McFarland Police Department. He is the Conference Chair. If you need more information Chief Leck can be reached at (608) 838-3151.------------------------------------------------------------The Dane County Chief’s of Police Association is pleased to announce they are hosting the 100th Annual Wisconsin Chief’s of Police Association Conference at Monona Terrace July 29 – August 1, 2007. The theme for this conference is “Celebrating our past - Envisioning our future” and is intended to both remind police administrators of the past accomplishments of law enforcement in Wisconsin and help them focus on the challenges of law enforcement in the 21st century. The Wisconsin Chiefs of Police Association was founded in 1907 when a group of Wisconsin Police Chiefs met to organize a statewide association to promote collegiality and professionalism among the highest ranks.  Today, celebrating its 100th birthday (1907-2007), the association is a strong, solvent, and progressive organization with over 500 members In attendance at the conference will be Chief Joseph C. Carter, Chief of Police for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority – the current president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police. During the conference the association will also be honoring University of Wisconsin Professor Herman Goldstein, who developed current Problem Oriented Policing practices now in place throughout the world. Over 300 police chiefs and command staff from around the State of Wisconsin will be in attendance at this conference and will have the opportunity to learn about current trends in police leadership, updated legal issues, and new product offerings from over 80 vendors who will be on sight showing the latest in law enforcement equipment and services.

properties.Arrested: Male, white, light brown shirt, possibly driving dark blue SUV type vehicle
properties.Details: On Sunday July 15th at 5:44 p.m. Madison Police were asked to contact a woman who was pulled over on East Washington Ave. earlier in the day (around 5:30 a.m.) She said she noticed flashing lights on a vehicle behind her, but was not sure they were squad car lights. She eventually did pull over, and reports that the blinking lights then became a blinding white light after the trailing vehicle stopped. She says a white male, wearing a light brown shirt, approached the driver's side of her car. The suspect never identified himself as a police officer, but began to ask her a volley of law enforcement type questions like, "do you know how fast you were going?" The woman says the man never asked for her identification, but did ask where she worked. The entire experience left her feeling very nervous. It should be noted that in the majority of traffic stops in Madison an officer would be wearing a full uniform. That uniform would include a badge and a department patch. Also a squad car should have lots of red and blue lights. Also, upon request, an officer should be able to produce a department issued identification card.(This report was just typed, and not discovered by the PIO until this date (July 24)

properties.Address: Downtown Safety Initiative Stats from this past weekend...
properties.Details: Last weekend, the MPD Central District implemented four Downtown Safety Initiative Special Operations over consecutive nights. The objective of the DSI Special Ops were on alcohol related behaviors, crime and disorder between 9pm and 3:00 a.m. over the long Labor Day holiday weekend in the downtown area. In addition to regular patrol staffing, the Central District Community Policing Team and nearly 200 hours of officer overtime were used to make 157 arrests for a wide variety of local ordinance and criminal offenses:  	30-Aug	31-Aug	1-Sep	2-Sep	Open Intox	3	4	13	2	Depositing Human Waste	3	2	12	2	Underage Alcohol	7	8	5	2	Dispensing Liquor Violations (Parties)	43	22			Misc Liquor Law Violation			2		Drug Offense			1		Criminal Damage			1		Disorderly Conduct		3	6		Obstructing/Resisting Arrest	1	1	3		OMVWI		1			Ped/Traffic Violations			1		Noise Violations	3	1			Detox Conveyances	1		3		Other			1													61	42	48	6	** 157(*8 different house parties in campus area ranging from 40 to over 100 underage attendees).(** This total represents what is known at present; final totals from this past weekend will be higher).The majority of the arrests at the house parties were UW Madison students.  However, less than 50% of all other DSI arrests in the State, Langdon, University Ave area were found to be UW students.  Over 30% of these DSI arrests were found not to be college students at all but older adults, alumni, out of town visitors, etc.).  The Central District intends to continue to execute DSI special operations over the next several weekends focusing on alcohol related crime and disorder. The Central District asks that young adults visiting the downtown entertainment district be aware of their environment, watch out for the safety of themselves and friends, drink responsibly and simply be good citizens. Downtown Madison should be safe and fun for everyone!  For further information regarding MPD's role in the Downtown Safety Initiative, please contact Central District Operations Lieutenant Joe Balles at 575-5005.

properties.Details: On September 7th, 2007 at 4:30pm, 7 anti-war protestors were arrested in the 10 block of W. All protestors were cooperative with police, cited and released at the scene.  The ages of the arrested protestors ranged from 22 years old to 77 years old.  Most of the arrested protestors are Madison residents.  Senator Kohl was not in his office at the time.

The Madison Police Department is participating in a NHTSA sponsored alcohol enforcement grant that is coordinated through the Department of Transportation, Bureau of Transporation Safety. Additional Madison Police Officers will be on patrol this weekend with the objective of detecting and apprehending vehicle operators who are under the influence of an intoxicant and/or controlled substance.In addition, The Madison Police Department, along with other area law enforcement agencies will be participating in the "Click It or Ticket" mobilization whose objective is to enforce Wisconsin's mandatory safety belt law.The Madison Police Department asks the motoring public to drive safely this Memorial Day holiday weekend and always remember to "buckle up" for safety.

The fifth annual Worthington Park Neighborhood Festival will be held tomorrow from 12 PM-4 PM. It will feature a live DJ, food, games and special guest "The Truly Remarkable Loon". Sponsors include the Worthington Park Neighborhood Association, Lowell Elementary School, O'Keefe Middle School, Midwest Patrol & Investigation, Salvation Army, Amcore Bank, MFD Sable Flames and others.

It was nearly one year ago that 22-year-old Kelly Nolan – a cherished daughter, sister, and friend - was last seen alive. As we approach the June 23rd anniversary, Kelly’s family and friends would like to join with the Madison Police Department in renewing requests for your help.Kelly had been socializing with friends in Madison’s downtown on Friday night, June 22, 2007.  At some point Kelly departed their company after deciding to stay out a bit longer. Detectives have talked with several people who had contact with Kelly later Friday night and into the early morning hours of Saturday, June 23, 2007. The investigators believe at some point Kelly left the Madison area – either consensually, or against her will - with someone who has yet to be identified.On July 9, 2007 Kelly’s body was found in a wooded area in the Town of Dunn just north of the Village of Oregon. Since that time there has been an active criminal investigation to determine who brought Kelly to that location.During  the past year approximately 590 individuals have been contacted by the Madison Police Department in regard to this investigation. Nearly 200 tips have been followed up on, and around 1,200 pages of reports have been generated. As Kelly’s family prepares to honor and celebrate her memory on this first anniversary of her passing, Madison Police detectives would like to ask people to consider whether they have noticed any sudden lifestyle changes in persons with whom they are acquainted, changes which would have surfaced since the time of Kelly Nolan’s disappearance on June 23, 2007.Some of these changes might include, but are not be limited to:a.	Relocation away from the Madison area on little or no notice.b.	Unexpectedly taking or seeking a new job prompting a move from the area.c.	Other abrupt lifestyle changes might include:i.	Suddenly joining the military or other organization which would involve relocation or extensive travelii.	Quitting school without prior problems or noticeiii.	Changing schools without good reason.d.	It could be a person is showing unusually keen interest in the news and Kelly’s case.i.	Paying excessive amounts of time and attention to Kelly’s death. ii.   There might be speculation of the events of the crime.ii.	Alternately, we would be interested in knowing about people who have been                                                    conspicuously ignoring the story or changing the subject when it comes upe.	There could also be a change in a person’s emotional or psychological behaviors;i.	Disruption of sleep pattern.ii.	Reoccurring dreams.iii.	Excessive drinking.iv.	Depression or crying episodes.v.	Change in grade or job performance. Investigators would like members of the public to think about such things.For Kelly’s family and friends it is impossible to express in words just how difficult the past year has been, as they have spent countless hours seeking answers to Kelly’s tragic death. Her mother, Mary Jane, wrote the following in an attempt to provide at least some perspective on her sorrow:I think about having Kelly taken physically out of my life every day, that is so physically and emotionally challenging I cry, want to work myself to exhaustion in my yard, pray the strength to believe there may be a day I can cope with better thoughts about the best things I shared with Kelly instead of nightmares about the tragedy.To sum up my sadness, daily I wish I would see her again, I wish she was with the family enjoying the good times we make with the love and joy of having one another to laugh with, talk about the good old days and the things Kelly said and did that reflected her gift to live each day to the fullest. Kelly always picked me up when I was down, talked with me about her goals and dreams, and also shared her challenges.I thank God; Candice, Brian and April (Kelly’s sisters & brother) have given me more than I could ever imagine helping me live with the loss of Kelly. Each has a special message for me, which focuses on the positive and putting the negative situation behind me. I want to avoid thoughts that keep me wondering who did it, why, and how they feel every day knowing they not only took Kelly from our family, but also a part of life she shared with everyone she knew.Since my tears are falling now I know it would be extremely difficult to extend these words publicly to those who would like to know how I feel. Perhaps if the murderer or someone who knows who did it, could see how much pain continues to be with me daily, facts would be forwarded to Crime Stoppers.Mary Jane NolanKelly’s Mom

On 3/5/05 at approximately 3:25 am, Madison Police Officers were dispatched to the 5800 block of Balsam Rd for people fighting.  When officers arrived they saw a large group of people appearing agitated and then officers heard what appeared to be gunshots fired behind a building.  Through the course of their investigation, one person was taken into custody regarding this incident.  If anyone has further information regarding this crime, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers where they can remain anonymous and possibly be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Sedrick A. Williams32 years old, MadisonDisorderly Conduct-While ArmedProbation Hold
properties.Details: On 4/8/2005 at approximately 1:44 a.m. several Madison Police Officers were called to the 100 block of King St. for a disturbance. An estimated 250 people had poured into the street at bar-time.  Officers noted that vehicles were unable to travel on King St and several fights had broken out.  Inside one of the bars, bouncers alerted officers that another fight had been broken up.  Williams was in a verbal argument with another individual and was being separated by bar staff.  Williams then took a bottle and smashed it across the face of the person he was arguing with.  This person fled the scene before police could identify him.  Williams was arrested and transported to the Dane County Jail.  Anyone who has additional information is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Five juveniles between the ages of fourteen and sixteen.  Charges are disorderly conduct for three, obstructing an officer for one, and for the last one, arrested on a warrant for robbery and battery, as well as a trespassing charge.  The first four were cited and released, the subject wanted on a warrent was taken into custody and taken to the Juvenile Reception Center.
properties.Details: On 05/17/05 at approximately 6 p.m., officers responded to the 1900 block of Baird Street regarding a disturbance.  They located a group of fifteen to twenty juveniles posturing for a fight.  The officers attempted to disburse the group, and the group responded by moving towards Park Street and then the south transfer point.  Different members of the group crossed Park Street in front of oncoming traffic, causing the traffic to either stop or slow down.  The disturbance continued in the area of the south transfer point and the McDonalds on Park Street.  Officers issued citations to the above juveniles, as well as arresting the one subject that was wanted on a warrant.

properties.Arrested: David Perez-Marchelli, 32, MadisonCharges:  Resist/Obstructing, Disorderly Conduct, Attempted Strong Armed Robbery
properties.Details: On 8/19/05 at approximately 2:39 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the area of Main St. and Broom St. for a disturbance.  It was learned that Perez-Marchelli attempted to disarm a security guard from a private company in a parking lot nearby.  Perez-Marchelli fled the scene shortly after.  Officers searched the area looking for Perez-Marchelli.  Perez-Marchelli was found hiding under an SUV in the 400 block of W. Main St.  Perez-Marchelli refused officer’s demands to come from hiding under the vehicle, so O.C. spray was deployed to gain compliance.  Perez-Marchelli was subsequently arrested and booked into the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Three juveniles cited/released to parents. Citations issued for Disorderly Conduct and Resisting.
properties.Details: On 9-16-2005 at 8:39pm, Madison Police received report of a large disturbance occurring at halftime of the Madison LaFollette, Madison East football game at Lussier Stadium. Officers from the Madison Police Department, as well as, officers from the Dane County Sheriffs Department, Monona Police Department, McFarland Police Department and Wisconsin State Patrol, responded. Approximately 100 individuals were reportedly involved in the disturbance, which included several incidences of fighting. No weapons were believed to have been used, and no injuries observed/reported.Police from the above agencies remained until after the conclusion of the football game to ensure order.

properties.Arrested: Booker T. Stanley, 22, Madison:  2nd deg. Reckless Endangering Safety, False Imprisonment, Battery (2 counts) and Intimidation of a Victim
properties.Details: On 12/21/05 at approximately 3:35 a.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to the 2300 block of University Avenue reference a disturbance.  It was learned that the suspect, Stanley, was involved in a disturbance where a female was battered and strangled at his residence.  An uninvolved person, not in Stanley's apartment, heard the disturbance and references to being strangled and called police.  Stanley was arrested on the above charges and transported to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: At approximately 11:01 am on 01/19/06, Madison police responded to a report of a disturbance at the West Transfer Point involving a large group of juveniles.  Callers reported that a group of 20 to 30 juveniles were fighting at the Transfer Point, and that some were armed with baseball bats.  Madison police arrived and noticed a group of 20 to 30 highschool-aged juveniles in the area.  They dispersed when officers arrived.
