properties.Arrested: Randall Weber, 46, Madison:  Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 1/25/06 at approximately 12:14 p.m. an off-duty Madison Police Detective was traveling eastbound on the Beltline approaching Greenway Blvd.  The driver of a Jeep Cherokee, Weber, honked his horn at the off-duty detective's car.  The detective did not recognize this person and continued driving.  Weber continued traveling along next to the detective's car, honking his horn and masturbating.  The detective obtained the offending vehicle's license plate and later confronted Weber.  Weber was arrested on the above charged and transported to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Justin J. Myers, M/W, 27yo, Madison ResidentCharged with Disorderly Conduct and Resisting/Obstructing a Peace Officer
properties.Details: On 2/3/06 at approximately 1:54 a.m. a Madison Police Sergeant was on routine patrol in the 200 block of King St.  The Sergeant observed a large piece of concrete being thrown from an alley on to the street.  Shortly after some wood was also being thrown from the alley on to the street, causing a safety hazzard.  The Sergeant confronted the individual inquiring what he was doing.  The Sergeant attempted to detain the male who would not cooperate and fled on foot.  A foot chase ensued and the male crossed E. Wilson and then John Nolen Drive near the east of the Monona Convention Center.  More officers responded to the scene and witnessed the male out on the thin ice of Lake Monona.  Officers tried to convince the male to return to shore due to the thin ice, but he refused and kept running eastbound about 100 yards off shore toward open water.  Officers tried to illuminate the male with their flashlights until he ran too far.  The Madison Fire Department's Lake Rescue Team and the Dane County Sheriff's Office airboat also assited in the search for the male on the lake. At this point the male subject has not been located and the search will continue today.  **UPDATE**  On 02-03-06, at 530pm, Justin J. Myers made phone contact with an officer and agreed to turn himself in.  He was uninjured and was booked and released from the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Christopher W. Melendrez, 25, Madison;Parole Violation, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Address: 5706 Odana Road, De Paul Building (Probation& Parole office)
properties.Details: On 2/7/06 at approximately 12:44p.m., several police officers were dispatched to an out of control client at the Probation and Parole Office at 5706 Odana Road. Melendrez had just been released from prison that morning after a stay of almost 4 years and was there for his first interview with his probation officer. Melendrez became very agitated and lost control of himself after he started demanding a check of his personal money from his account at prison. Eventually Melendrez was taken into custody and transported to the Dane County Jail without further incident.

properties.Arrested: Stephen A. Freer 58 year old m/w of Hillsboro Wisconsin
properties.Details: On March 18th, 2006 at approximately 9:20p.m, Madison Police were called to 201 State Street (Overture Center) reference a male causing a disturbance by making threats to blow up the building.  Officers contacted the suspect, Stephen A. Freer, 58-year-old m/w of Hillsboro Wisconsin, approximately 1 block away from the Overture Center after he communicated his displeasure with the performance the Center was showcasing for the day.  Freer made mention of how the production was fascist, and how he had significant issue with fascism in the world/country.  When Freer was confronted by police about whether he had made threats to “Blow up the building/center”, He stated that he was referring to “The fascists only”.  He also stated he felt that the police were fascists as well as those that worked in “The system”.Police arrested Freer on charges of a Bomb Scare (947.015), which is a class I felony offense!  This matter was dealt with in a serious manner, and the statement/actions on the part of Freer created a degree of discomfort both with Overture Center Staff and responding officers alike.  PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: Jeramie J. Mason, age 21 years old, Madison, Wisconsin, possession of THC and a parole hold. Galynese A. Conley-Williams, age 22, Madison, Wisconsin, charged with eluding an officer, second-degree reckless endangering, obstructing, and a probation hold. Both parties are in the Dane County Jail.
properties.Details: At approximately 2:45 a.m. on 04/01/2006, Madison police responded to a disturbance at the Amoco station located at 735 East Washington Avenue.  Upon arrival, officers observed the above-arrested parties getting into a vehicle. They ignored officer's orders to stop and drove away through the parking lot almost hitting an officer. A short pursuit followed.  The two subjects were taken into custody and charged with the above offenses.  It appears that a fight occurred prior to the officers arrival. The fight occurred inside the station and resulted in a great deal of merchandise and property being knocked over and made unsuitable for resale. The front doors of the business were also shattered.

properties.Arrested: 5 females arrested, including a 14 year-old, most issued citations for Disorderly Conduct and released (1 person taken to jail for a probation hold).
properties.Details: On 5/24/06 shortly after 6 p.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to a disturbance behind an apartment complex in the 2400 block of Allied Dr. Mostly females were fighting and arguing over pre-existing incidents.  Officers estimated 30-40 people had gathered to either participate or observe the large disturbance.

properties.Arrested: Shaquoia Hoffman, 17, Madison: Disorderly Conduct13 year-old male, Madison: Disorderly Conduct-Armed, Resisting, Capias
properties.Details: On 5/28/06 at approximately 9 p.m. several Madison Police Officers were providing high visibility in the Allied Drive neighborhood.  Officers observed an extremely large crowd, estimated to be 100-200 people, gathering and moving in between the 2300-2400 blocks of Allied Drive.  Officers ascertained that there were two potential problems within the group.  Allegedly there was a youthful person carrying a handgun.  Secondly, two individuals were arguing all day and were about to fight, hence the large group congregating.  Several officers walked through the group to gain intelligence and break up the crowd.  This tactic had little effect as the crowd was very agitated.  Concerned adults were coming out of their apartments because they also sensed the hostility.  Eventually, Hoffman was arrested as part of the cause for the disturbance.  Additionally, officers learned the whereabouts of the 13 year-old male believed to have a gun.  Upon seeing the youth, officers noticed the apartment he fled to, in which the tenants said they did not know him.  Officers, acting in due regard confronted the individual who was now in a strangers apartment, believed to have a weapon.  Officers kicked in the door to chase the youth who now jumped out of the window.  Several officers engaged in a foot-chase and eventually caught the youth.  He was taken to Juvenile Reception, while Hoffman was taken to jail.  Officers noted that the Allied Drive neighborhood was significantly calmer after this disturbance.

properties.Arrested: Matthew Seubert, 17, Madison: Disorderly Conduct (Jail)Male, 14, Madison: Disorderly Conduct (released to parent)
properties.Details: On 6/8/06 at approximately 3:12 p.m. Madison Police responded to a disturbance on Bluff Point Drive.  Madison Metro bus had picked up students at White Horse Middle School.  The eventual victim told the driver that a vehicle behind the bus was following him.  The bus driver notified his dispatch, which then notified police. The student exited the bus on Bluff Point Dr. and upon doing so, there were four passengers who exited the vehicle and battered him.  The bus driver broke up the fight and stabilized the scene until police arrived. The four suspects fled in the vehicle prior to police arrival. The male victim did not seek medical treatment.

properties.Arrested: Suspects: 3 W/M's all between 17-18 years old, 5'10"-6'01", 150-160lbs.
properties.Victim: 16 year old male resident of Madison, received some stab wounds. He is listed in stable condition at a local hospital.
properties.Details: A dispute among teenagers in the pkg lot of a west side fast food restaurant led to a fight involving as many as 5-7 w/m's which resulted in one of the victims receiving some stab wounds. Although the dispute started in the parking lot, the subsequent fight took place on the 1600 blk of Norman Way. The investigation is ongoing at this time and no names are being released.

properties.Arrested: Male, Hispanic, late teens-early 20's, 5'3, black hair, long white polo shirt, khaki or black pants, thick accent.
properties.Details: On 6/18/06 at approximately 3:48 a.m. a Madison Police Officer took a report of a female deploying pepper-spray on an unknown subject identified above.  The female stated she was walking to a home and as a short-cut went through some backyards between the 400 block of W. Dayton and W. Mifflin St.  While walking through the backyard, there were several people drinking alcohol nearby.  The victim felt uneasy about walking through the backyards and put her canister of pepper-spray in her hand to walk with as she felt someone was following her.  A male subject caught up to her and grabbed her shoulder area.  The victim initially struggled and then turned and deployed pepper-spray on the subject's face.  The subject ran one way and the victim ran another way.  This incident is under investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with further information is advised to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Henry Simmons, 41, Madison: Disorderly Conduct While ArmedAndre Patton, 25, Madison: Trespassing
properties.Details: On 7/7/06 at approximately 5:14 p.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to the 4700 block of Jenewein Rd to investigate a suspicious person.  As they were conversing, Simmons approached the officers and Patton with a 34-inch pipe.  Initially Simmons continued to advance at the officers and Patton and did not drop the pipe. After numerous warnings, Simmons was tased by an officer and eventually let go of the pipe and was arrested without incident.This could have had a far worse ending as the other officer had their service weapon drawn to the threat, yet the taser became a less lethal option.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: For the third time since 7/4/06 Madison Police Officers have had to request additional police resources to the Allied Drive neighborhood when making an arrest.  Officers report that crowds between 20-80 people have gathered as officers are arresting someone and then taunt the officers with profanity and cause hostilities.  This event then escalates as more people are drawn to the scene and begin yelling at officers.  Some have even pounded on the squad car as the arrest is being made.  More police officers are called into the scene and the situation is quickly resolved.  We urge that citizens do not actively interfere with police actions, as there is a more formal way to process a complaint.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: Adult female taken to detox. Minor facial injuries.
properties.Details: At approximately 1:03 p.m., Madison Police Officers responded to a report of a large disturbance in the 2300 block of Allied Dr.  Upon arrival officers located a disturbance involving 40 people.  As the officers approached, the people fled the area.  Officers did locate 1 adult female with minor facial injuries.  She was also intoxicated and taken to Detox.  Officers learned that a group of approximately 15 females attacked 2 females.  No further information at this time.

properties.Arrested: Multiple individuals involved in fights
properties.Details: At approximately 2:21 a.m., a Madison Police Officer was contacted in the 100 block of King St and told there was a fight in progress inside the Majestic Nightclub.  The officer entered the Majestic and noted individual involved in a fight.  As he tried to break this up, other fights broke out.  The officer reported that the fights then moved out on the street and noted that more people were becoming involved in fights on the street in front of the Majestic.

properties.Arrested: Tenesha Spinks, 18, Madison: Disorderly Conduct, Unlawful Trespass Cassandra Baker, 28, Madison: Disorderly Conduct, Unlawful Trespass
properties.Details: On 10/3/06 at approximately 10:10 p.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to the 2300 block of Allied Dr for a large disturbance.  Officers noted about 30-50 people engaged in this disturbance, even as they arrived with lights and siren. The officers observed Spinks and Baker actively fighting with a large group surrounding the disturbance.  As officers went in to separate and make an arrest, several individuals surrounded and taunted them.  At one point, while an officer was making the actual arrest, the other officer had to standby and illustrate/warn about the taser to prevent others from physically engaging.  More officers responded to the scene and it was quickly dispersed.  The officers learned the disturbance started with falsehoods about a male.

properties.Arrested: 1.  Jacquelyn L. Lightfoot, 37-year-old female of Madison (Charges –Disorderly Conduct 947.01, Resisting/Obstructing A Police Officer 946.41)2.  14-year-old female (10th grade Memorial HS Student) of Madison (Charges – Disorderly Conduct 947.01, Resisting/Obstructing A Police Officer 946.41)3.  15-year-old female (9th grade Memorial HS Student) of Madison (Charges – Disorderly Conduct 947.01, Resisting/Obstructing A Police Officer 946.41)
properties.Victim: Jacquelyn L. Lightfoot was evaluated at local hospital for treatment related to injuries sustained prior to this incident.
properties.Details: On 11/08/06 at approximately 11:29am, Educational Resource Officer (ERO) requested emergency backup at Memorial High School reference a belligerent parent that was out of control.  Upon arrival, it was determined that a 17-year-old male subject, who was not a student of the school, had been taken into custody by the ERO and was being cited/released on a municipal violation of possessing tobacco products.  Jacquelyn L. Lightfoot (parent of the 17-year-old male)  was made aware of the arrest scenario and responded to Memorial High School.    Lightfoot made her way to the office of the ERO and began to verbally attack the officer for the police action he was involved in concerning the 17-year-old male.  Lightfoot continually escalated her actions towards the officer and was told many times to calm down and cease her physical approach; as she demanded her son be released from custody immediately.  The ERO was then surrounded by Lightfoot and her two daughters in a confined area, and deeming Lightfoot the greatest threat, a Taser was utilized by the ERO to deescalate this threat to a manageable level.  It should be noted that the officer verbalized and used a physical separation technique before using the Taser as his last resort.  Jacquelyn L. Lightfoot and her two daughters were all arrested on charges of Disorderly Conduct and Resisting/Obstructing A Police Officer.  The situation that occurred was an isolated event that did not place the school in any harm at any time.  School officials were quick to act in this scenario, and it was resolved quickly after police arrived on scene.  It is understandable that parents would be concerned about the welfare of their children, but school officials and police would expect that parents would be appropriate in utilizing the correct mode of conflict resolution.  This is a case that all involved parties did not envision, but concerns by any interested person must be dealt with in an appropriate manner if the educational environment is to remain conducive to that of learning.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: Female, 12, (7th grade), Madison:  Attempted Robbery.
properties.Details: On 11/27/06 at 4:39 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to a disturbance in the 2100 block of Leland Dr.  Officers learned that an eight year-old girl who attended a nearby school's after school program was picked up, as routinely done, by her 16 year-old sister as they would walk home together.  As they were walking home, they noticed four females following them and were quickly approaching.  At one point the twelve year-old asked the sixteen year old if she had any money.  Sensing that she was going to be robbed or beaten up, the sixteen year old told her eight year-old sister to run home, which she did.  The victim was pushed to the ground and taunted as she did not have any money to give up.  The four girls ran off and the victim called police.  An officer made contact with two of the girls in the 5700 block of Russett Rd and the twelve year-old was eventually charged and brought to Juvenile Reception.

properties.Arrested: Male, 13, Madison:  Battery to School Employee, Criminal Damage to Property, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 11/29/06 at 1:04 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to Hoyt School for a disturbance. It was learned that the 13 year-old juvenile and another 11 year-old student exchanged words and led to a verbal argument with threats. The 13 year-old went into a rage and was initially restrained by staff.  The student broke free and continued his rage.  The student broke glass, waved a wooden stick in attempts to hit staff, threw a wood hat rack at staff, overturned desks and a bookshelf, resisted staff and was violent.  Staff were very concerned for the safety of others and for the 13 year-old.  The thirteen year-old was eventually handcuffed and taken into custody.

properties.Arrested: Female, LaFollette student, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 2/1/07 there was a basketball game between East and LaFollette high schools.  Three Madison Police Officers were working the game in an off-duty capacity.  The rivalry between the schools and past disturbances between the schools during athletic events called for precautionary measures.  School officials and police made sure both student bodies were separated during the game and left through opposite doors after the game.  There were no reports of disturbances in the gym.  Once outside officers noted a large confrontational crowd gathering.  At least seven officers were present to deal with the agitated crowd.  The female listed above did not stop her threatening behavior toward other females, even as policed told her to stop.  She was eventually led away and arrested for disorderly conduct.  After about 20 minutes of a disturbance with jeering, etc. it ended without further incident.  Officers noted the tension and large crowd gathered outside of the school.

properties.Arrested: Pam Edwards, 19, Madison: Resisting, Disorderly ConductDeArthur Edwards, 24, Madison: Resisting, Probation Hold
properties.Details: On 2/29/07 at 1:29 a.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to a report of a "riot" at the High Noon Saloon.  Officer reports indicated hostilities in a packed parking lot as the bar was closing down.  Officers that went into the bar reported several fights occurring inside, the odor of marijuana and broken glass all over. One officer noted there to be about 50 people inside the bar and actively fighting in different parts of the bar. Reports indicate that pool balls, chairs and glass bottles were being thrown during the disturbance.  A witness indicated the original scuffle led to a more and more fights breaking out.

properties.Arrested: Female, 15: Disorderly ConductFemale, 15: Disorderly Conduct, ObstructingFemale, 15: Disorderly ConductFemale, 15: Disorderly ConductFemale, 14, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 3/22/07 at 10:02 a.m. there was a large disturbance at LaFollette H.S.  A school administrator had noticed a large gathering of students and hostilities between some wanting to fight.  It was later learned that the disturbance was caused by three females confronting three other females to fight.  The Madison Police Department Education Resource Officer (ERO) noted that upon arriving to the scene several hundred students were watching the disturbance, clogging the hallway, and that 10-15 school officials had to restore order. A total of six Madison Police Officers were present in the school to help calm this disturbance. Eventually some students were detained and separated.  In one separation, two students went to an office and began fighting again.  Police had to respond to that office as well to break up the secondary fight.  The above-listed juveniles were arrested and placed in Juvenile Reception until parents were notified.

properties.Arrested: Mallory Schwenn, 22, Ft. Atkinson: Theft, Battery to a Police Officer, Disorderly Conduct, Resisting ArrestDanika Conkle, 21, Ft. Atkinson: Theft (Party to a Crime), Disorderly Conduct, Resisting ArrestPaul Thompson, 23, Ft. Atkinson: Obstructing justice
properties.Details: On 3/25/07 at 2:15 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the Club Five for a report of patrons stealing from the bartenders tip jar.  From the onset of the investigation, Schwenn was confrontational with the employees and later with the officers.  Schwenn was also causing a loud disturbance will officers were trying to conduct the investigation.  At one point, Schwenn forcibly kicked the arm of an investigating officer.  While Conkle and Schwenn were being transferred from the bar to the squad car, Thompson refused officer commands to stay away and eventually lunged in an attempt to free one of the suspects, causing his arrest.  All three individuals were taken to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Maurice Grant, 22, Madison:  Disorderly Conduct While Armed
properties.Details: On 4/14/07 at 1:20 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 300 block of W. Gorham for numerous fights.  The first officer who arrived estimated that there were 80-120 people engaged in a hostile environment; with three separate fights occurring.  The fights involved 6-10 males each, who did not yield to police presence or requests to stop.  Belts were used as weapons during the disturbance.  As some fights broke up, others started and it was noted that they were on the sidewalk and directly in the street.  Officers used a crowd control size canister of OC spray, for safety reasons, to eventually break up the crowd.  Grant was one person that was captured actively fighting by officers.  He was transported to the Dane County Jail without incident.  A second person was cited and released on scene for Disorderly Conduct.

properties.Arrested: Josh Humbach, 22, Madison: Resisting; Warrants for: Disorderly Conduct, OWI, Operating After Revocation and Probation & Parole
properties.Details: On 4/24/07 at 2:50 a.m. Madison Police responded to an apartment in the 6400 block of Bridge Rd.  Officers heard the disturbance as they approached the apartment.  Those inside did not initially cooperate and did not answer the door for police.  Intelligence was gathered from neighbors and police resources as to who lived there.  Eventually force was used to open the door to ensure the safety of everyone inside.  Humbach jumped from a window and fled on foot, not yielding to police commands to stop.  Several officers conducted a search of some nearby woods.  Monona Police assisted with their thermal imaging device and located Humback in the marsh nearby.

properties.Arrested: Justin Baker 22, Madison: Disorderly Conduct While Armed.Jeffrey Schorfheide, 20, Madison:  Disorderly Conduct While ArmedMatthew Christensen, 22, Madison:  ResistingGeorge Halkias, 22, Madison: Disorderly Conduct, Resisting
properties.Details: On 5/1/07 at 2:11 a.m. Madison Police responded to a report of disturbance of people fighting with a pitchfork and knife.  It was learned that the source of the fight was a large tent in front of a fraternity.  Some individuals started to tear down the tent and possibly vandalize it.  Residence of the fraternity heard the disturbance and came out with a machete and a pitchfork.  Threats and posturing occurred during the incident, but no one was injured.  Officers noted that someone yelled out, "I just had a pitchfork pulled on me" as they approached the scene.  Schorfheidi had the machete, while Baker had the pitchfork.  The disturbance quickly ended as police arrived on scene.  It appears alcohol was a common denominator.

properties.Arrested: Javander Williams, 30, Madison:  2nd Degree Reckless Endangering, Resisting Arrest, Disorderly Conduct, Casual Possession of Marijuana
properties.Details: On 5/14/07 at 8:28 p.m. Madison Police responded to a disturbance in the 3000 block of Ashford Lane.  As the first officer arrived on scene, Williams was acting in an aggressive manner as he immediately approached the officer's squad.  Williams was told several times to relax.  More officers responded to the scene as Williams was yelling, acting aggressive and causing a disturbance in the area.  Williams then grabbed a female that appeared to be a companion, and put his arms around her neck and shoulders to take her with him.  The officers did not know if this was consensual or not, so they began to triangulate and follow the two; demanding to know further circumstances.  Williams eventually let go of the female and punched her in the head area.  An officer used an electronic control device to stop Williams’ aggression.  After continuing to resist arrest, Williams was eventually taken into custody.

properties.Arrested: Jay Floyd (wanted) 37, Sun Prairie, WI.
properties.Details: On 5/23/07 at 8:48 p.m. Madison Police, Sun Prairie Police and the Dane County Sheriff's Office responded to County Hwy T for a report of an abduction.  Officers learned the victim was possibly placed in a trunk of a car from the east side of Madison and transported to this location.  It was also learned that the suspect, Floyd (who has not been arrested) had known the victim for over a week and had socially engaged with each other. The victim stated that after being placed in the trunk, she was able to break free by using equipment inside the trunk. Floyd is wanted on numerous warrants including battery to a police officer and recklessly endangering.  If anyone has information on Floyd's whereabouts, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Joel Savage, 54, MadisonNo Permanent Address2nd Degree Reckless Endangering SafetyDisorderly Conduct While ArmedFailure To Comply
properties.Details: Shortly after 4:00 p.m. on June 1 Madison Police responded to a domestic disturbance call. A woman who had been strangled by the suspect was able to get free from the suspect's van which had been parked near a storage facility where the suspect has a rental unit. The suspect yelled at responding officers to shoot him. The Emergency Response Team (ERT) was called to the scene, and a command post was established. Police had reason to believe the suspect was armed with a handgun. Every precaution was taken to protect both the life of the suspect and those of the responding officers. After 4 1/2 hours the suspect, following negotiations, handcuffed himself, with his own cuffs, and came out of the van, which he also uses as his home.

properties.Arrested: Samuel Henter, 17, Madison:  Battery, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 6/11/07 at 1:36 p.m. an MPD Parking Enforcement Officer (PEO) noticed a car parked illegally in a loading zone.  Noticing the driver and passenger nearby, the PEO simply warned the individuals about the illegally parked car and asked them to move it.  The educational opportunity was lost as obscenities were directed to the PEO.  Eventually the PEO issued a citation as the vehicle was never moved.  The PEO began to walk away but was followed and harassed verbally by Henter and a companion.  The two followed the PEO who completed his work and was trying to avoid the individuals.  As they reached Mifflin St, Henter struck the PEO on the back, with a fist.  Henter was later arrested on Gilman St without further incident.

Several officers reponded to a report of a fight at LaFollette High School.  Two (2) students were transported to an area hospital as a result of injuries sustained in the disturbance.  One student was stuck in the hand with a pen, the other sustained an injury to his nose.  The injuries were not life-threatening and the investigation remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: 5 MalesDriving in a green Intrepid
properties.Victim: Male, Age 20, MadisonCuts to faceStab wounds to back
properties.Details: On June 20, at 11:23, Madison Police responded to a local hospital where a stabbing victim was being treated. The victim reported that he and his brother had been driving on Buckeye Road that evening, listening to a new stereo system the victim had just installed in his car. He says another car, with five men inside, pulled up, and someone hurled a beer can at his car. Angry, he and his brother followed the offending vehicle to Camden Road. There parties from both cars got out, and a fistfight broke out. At some point the victim's brother noticed the five they were fighting had knives. Additionally, another individual, apparently a friend of the five arrived on scene with what looked like a rifle. At this point the brothers decided to get back in their car and leave the area. It was after that the victim realized he had been stabbed. His brother drove him to the hospital where he was treated for non-life threatening cuts.

properties.Arrested: 16 year old male booked into the Dane County Jail on a probation hold
properties.Victim: No staff or juvenile patients were injured as a result of the disturbance although there was some property damage
properties.Details: Madison Police called at the request of Mendota Mentota Mental Health Institute to assist them in controlling numerous juvenile male patients who were involved in a large disturbance in a wing of Lorenz Hall.  Officers on scene stood by and assisted as needed as Mendota staff secured the juveniles involved.  All juveniles involved were secured and order was restored within one hour of the original call for assistance.  The investigation is continuing.

properties.Arrested: Unidentifed at this time
properties.Details: Officers were dispatched to Vilas Park for a report of a man trying to steal a car.  When officers contacted the suspect a struggle ensued.  Several officers were involved in the attempt to take the suspect into custody.  Officers did deploy ECDs (Electronic Control Device)and the suspect was eventually handcuffed.  The suspect was taken to the hospital and admitted for observations not related to the struggle.

properties.Arrested: Kris S. Burke, Age 31, MadisonMadison Metro Bus DriverStatus: At LargeTentative Charge: 2nd Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety
properties.Details: On July 30th, shortly before 4:30 p.m., Madison Police were called to the Madison Metro bus headquarters on E. Washington Avenue to talk with a Metro supervisor about possible criminal charges against a Metro driver for an incident that took place on the driver's bus Sunday (July 29) afternoon. Officers would learn that the driver, Kris Burke, became angry after a passenger informed him that another rider had urinated in the back of the bus. Burke thought (and Metro officials say he was told)  the culprit was a guy who had just gotten off the bus. The passenger that Burke believed responsible for soiling the bus then tried to get back on a short time later. He was waiting at a stop after going to the Walgreen's on Verona Road to pick up some items (a water cooler, two pairs shorts, & toilet paper) for his wife. Driver Burke refused to let him back on the bus. The man, who had his wallet out and in hand, grabbed a hold of a bus mirror as the bus sped off heading for the West Beltline. The would-be passenger said he feared for his life as he clung to the mirror. He thought if he jumped a car might hit him. During his "ride", which he estimates was 12 to 14 blocks, he dropped his wallet. Video shows the bus reached speeds of around 35 M.P.H. The victim decided to jump off before the bus got up to the beltline. Metro officials say the bus had stopped when he made his departure. The victim complained of a sore back after making the leap. He never found his wallet, and by the time he returned to the bus stop the items he had purchased for his wife were gone. The victim denies he was responsible for the mess on the bus, and bus video is inconclusive

properties.Arrested: Douglas Nava, Age 17, MadisonRoxanna Nava, Age 20, MadisonFemale, Age 16, MadisonMaria Nava, Age 44All 4 tentatively charged with Disorderly Conduct and Resisting
properties.Details: On September 5th around 11:36 a.m. a Madison Police officer was attempting to determine if a young man, later identified as Douglas Nava, was an enrolled student at Madison Memorial High School. Nava was uncooperative, so the officer attempted to escort him outside of the building, or to his parent, who the teen said was in the school. While en route Nava became resistive and combative. Several of his family members were  present at the school registering for classes. The MPD officer warned them to stay back while he and a school security guard worked to gain control of the 17 year old. Despite the warnings, the family members, including Nava's mother, obstucted the police investigation. During the melee Nava's older sister Roxanna Nava was tasered as she fought with a school staff member. All four family members were arrested on the above tentative charges.

properties.Suspect: Corvell M. Bowens, male/black, DOB:02/20/1990 Charges Disorderly Conduct/Obstructing/Underage Alcohol
properties.Arrested: Juvenile Male Charges Disorderly Conduct/Resisting/Juvenile Alcohol
properties.Victim: Officer received an injury to a hand, was treated and released.
properties.Details: A caller reported a juvenile out of control. The juvenile slammed the Officer's hand into the side of a house and a taser was deployed. Bowens had created a disturbance and obstructed efforts to control the juvenile. There were numerous individuals in the residence.

Early Monday morning, around 3:00 a.m., Madison Police were dispatched to the area of  Hawkweed Lane where a naked man was reportedly screaming, yelling, and running around. The first officer responding to the scene observed the man walking toward Highpoint on Watts Road. As the officer attempted to determine what the man was doing he grabbed the officer’s face and she believed he was going to try to kiss her. The man also told the female officer he wanted to have sex with her. The officer ended up struggling with the man, and was backed up a short time later by other officers who were aided in getting him restrained. The man's female roommate reported that he had attacked her shortly before his encounter with the officer, and she (the roommate) said he was acting completely out of character. She did not know if he had taken some type of drug. The man is at a local hospital where he is being observed by medical staff. During the struggle with officers he pulled out hair from one, and bit another. He has not been arrested at this time, but could face tentative charges upon discharge from the hospital.

properties.Suspect: Kimyora S. Cross, age 33, no permanent addressMr. Cross was arrested and tentatively charged with Possession with Intent to Deliver THC, Disorderly Conduct, Parole Violation, and Unlawful Trespass.
properties.Details: Just before 12:15 a.m. Saturday morning Madison Police were summoned to the PDQ store on Fish Hatchery Road to deal with a man who was trying to meet women. An employee said the suspect was "hitting on" all females entering the store. The witness said the guy was following women around trying to get their phone numbers, and talking about having some sort of relationship with them. At one point the suspect sat on the checkout counter as one woman attempted to make her purchase. A store employee told him to hop down, and he responded by unleashing a barrage of obscenities, some of which were directed at the woman. That’s when police were called. When one officer arrived the suspect was sitting on another woman's SUV, which was parked at the pumps. Its owner was inside paying for gas, and indicated she would like the man removed from her hood. As police confronted him he made a "very angry-looking face" just before being handcuffed. Several individually wrapped packages of marijuana, and more than $150 in cash, were found in his pockets.

properties.Suspect: Anthony W. Dorsey, 33-year-old M/B of Stoughton WisconsinCharges:1.Disorderly Conduct2.Resisting An Officer3.Obstructing An Officer4.Criminal Damage To Property5.Probation Hold/Violation6.Possession Of Marijuana7.Possession Of Drug Paraphernalia
properties.Details: On 8/26/2008 at approximately 1:42am, The Madison Police Department was called to 1798 Thierer Road Denny’s Restaurant reference a fight in progress involving an armed subject.  Police would gather information through the dispatching center reference a white Chevy Impala leaving the restaurant, and a traffic stop would be made just blocks away from the establishment.  Police would contact an Anthony W. Dorsey and he would advise “He was just trying to leave the restaurant and had done nothing wrong.”  Officers interviewed witnesses that stated Dorsey had been doing pushups inside of the business just moments before confronting a 29-year-old male of Madison and challenging him to a fight outside.  When the victim did not accept the fight invitation, Dorsey spit in the face of the victim.  The victim held a knife in his hand as a defensive measure, but the antics would continue with Dorsey picking up a chair at one point.  Several people inside of the restaurant attempted to calm Dorsey, but it was not until the quick thinking victim pretended that he was going outside of the restuarant that Dorsey found himself on the other side of a locked door.After police stopped Dorsey a short distance away, he identified himself by an alias and was arrested.  Dorsey was not happy about the way in which things were progressing, and resisted police having been placed in restraints at one point before he would kick and damage the patrol squad door.  Police searched the vehicle the Dorsey was operating, and found marijuana and drug paraphernalia.  Dorsey was conveyed to the Dane County Jail, and the Movement Team was requested to deal with the violent manner in which Dorsey was acting.  It is unclear as to why an altercation of this nature started in the first place, but the behavior of Dorsey was less than appropriate based on witnesses’ accounts.  Alcohol was also thought to be a contributing factor.PO Howard Payne

On Saturday night, just after 10:00 p.m., a concerned resident on Littlemore Drive contacted Madison Police after observing  - what the caller thought to be  - several teens starting a small fire on a vacant lot. A responding officer discovered a small propane bottle with a flame emitting from it had been left at a construction site. The propane bottle had been wrapped in tape, and had some sort of fuse attached. It's believed those who placed it had hoped for some type of explosion, which did not happen. Neighbors observed a small black four-door car, possibly a Honda or Nissan, driving quickly from the area. They say it may have had a specialty Green Bay Packer license plate. Witnesses thought there were three people inside the car, and that the driver was possibly female.Anyone with information is urged to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Carlos A Rivas32 years old-Battery to a Police Officer-Resisting arrest-Criminal Damage to Property-OMVWI
properties.Details: On 3/4/05 at approximately 8:45 pm Madison Police responded to several hit and run crashes on the east side of Madison.  Dispatched advised that a man was attempting to change his flat tire after crashing into a sign and thought the individual needed to be checked.  After attempting dialogue to find out what happened, a struggle ensued when a Madison police officer made contact with the suspect.  The suspect resisted and tried to leave the scene as the officer was investigating what happened.  At one point the suspect scratched the officer in the face and broke the officers eyeglasses.  Eventually the officer was able to arrest the suspect and transport him to the Dane County Jail with the assistance of back-up officers.

properties.Arrested: Dakota Shayne Vot Emert Umphryes, m/b, 20 yrs oldCharges: Carrying a Concealed Weapon, Hit & Run, 0.00% BAC for Underage Driver (Not a Drop), Underage Drinking, and Operating without a Valid Driver's License
properties.Address: Northport Dr and N. Sherman Ave
properties.Details: On 08/05/06, Madison Police responded to Northport Dr and N. Sherman Ave to investigate a hit & run accident.  The suspect vehicle was outbound on Northport Dr when it struck a traffic light at N. Sherman Ave. The vehicle then fled the scene. The suspect vehicle was located a short time later in the vicinity of MFD Station #10.  A MFD firefighter reported that the driver who appeared to be sleeping, was sitting in his vehicle and reportedly had a handgun on his lap.MPD officers safely arrested the driver who was found to be in possession of a loaded semi-automatic handgun.The suspect is currently incarcerated at the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: UPDATE - 12:25 P.M. 10/8/06Madison Police are looking for two possible suspect vehicles.  One vehicle is described as a white Jeep Grand Cherokee type vehicle.  This vehicle may have some type of bush guard on the front of the vehicle.  The second vehicle is described as a black or dark blue 4-door vehicle.  Both these vehicles were seen on Green Ave. at the time of the accident.  It is quite possible that one or both has front end damage or undercarriage damage.  Anyone with information about this case should contact Crime Stoppers at 266-6014 or Hit & Run Investigator at 266-4060.
properties.Victim: Female bike rider with severe head and internal injuries.  Status unknown at this time, currently at a local hospital receiving treatment.  UPDATE--At this time it appears the injuries are not critical. The 38 year old female victims remains in  the hospital. She is a resident of Madison. Updated by Lt. Pat Malloy.
properties.Details: Officers were dispatched to the 4200 block of Green Ave. near Knutson Dr. reference a female bicyclist who had been struck by a vehicle.  The vehicle fled the scene without stopping or rendering aid.  The victim was transported to a local hospital with severe head and internal injuries.  Her current status is unknown at this time.  If anyone has any information relating to this accident and the vehicle involved please call Crime Stoppers (where you can remain annonymous) at 266-6014. The investigation continues.

properties.Arrested: Arrested person:  John F. Perry (m/b, 39 yoa)                  Rock County residentCharges: Hit and Run Attended Vehicle         Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent          Reckless Endangering Safety         Warrant for Parole Violation
properties.Victim: A driver of one of the vehicles had minor injuries which were treated at the scene.
properties.Details: On 11/18/2006, at approximately 8:13am, Madison Police responded to a report of a hit and run accident.  It is believed that the suspect had exited a vehicle that had been traveling eastbound in the 1200 block of E. Johnson Street.  The vehicle continued forward and would cross N. Baldwin Street and crash into two (2) vehicles that were traveling westbound on E. Johnson Street.  The vehicle continued, coming to rest on a median after crashing in to it, in the 1300 block of E. Johnson Street.  At least(3)vehicles were involved, including the suspect vehicle.  The suspect was not injured.   This incident remains under investigation.  For further details, please refer to the following news release provided by the Rock County Sheriff's Department. NEWS RELEASEParole NOW IN CUSTODY Who Yesterday Hijacked a Vehicle and Fled from Rock Valley Community Program Halfway House Facility in Rock CountyFor Immediate  Release                                                                       Contact PersonCase# 06-4537	Lt. Harper11/17/06 original – AMMENDED 11/18/06 at 2:40 PM	(608) 757-7907ADDENDUM:  The Madison (WI) Police Department advised us that John F. Perry was taken into custody this morning in Madison.  In addition to the charges listed below, initial information from MPD indicated that Perry was also arrested for Reckless Endangerment, Hit & Run-Injury, and Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner’s Consent, based on his actions in the City of Madison.  Further information will be released when reports are completed and approved.ORIGINAL RELEASE:  On 11/17/06 at approximately 8:17 PM, deputies from the Rock County Sheriff’s Department responded to the report of an injured person at the Rock Valley Community Program halfway house, located on Sunny Lane in between Beloit and Janesville.  Upon arrival, deputies learned that a 43 year-old female staff member driving a light blue 2003 Dodge Caravan (WI license plate UKJ696; registered to the Rock Valley program) had driven up to a parolee who had recently been transferred to the facility and was standing in the facility’s driveway entrance near Sunny Lane.  The parolee, John F. Perry (M/B; 04/08/67; 5-9; 140 lbs), forced his way into the vehicle and then tried to have the employee drive him away from the facility.  A struggle for control of the vehicle ensued.  The employee was eventually forced out of the vehicle while it was stationary on Sunny Lane.  Perry then fled westbound in the van toward USH 51.  Town of Beloit EMS transported the Rock Valley employee to Beloit Hospital for evaluation and initial indications are that she sustained bruises and muscle strains as a result of the incident.Perry is on parole, reportedly as a result of a past substantial battery conviction.  He has had past police contact in the Beloit area, may have ties to the Monroe area, and recently made statements to suggest that he could be headed toward Tennessee to visit relatives for the holidays.  While no photo is available at this time, one may be released in the next 12 hours if available.A felony apprehension request has been issued by Wisconsin Probation and Parole, and the Rock County Sheriff’s Department will have charges of false imprisonment, Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner’s Consent, and Battery.  Pursuant to the directive of the Wisconsin Supreme Court, as found in Supreme Court Rule 20:3.6 Trial Publicity, you are advised that a charge is merely an accusation and that a defendant is presumed innocent until and unless proven guilty.Further information will be released when the reports are completed and approved or via a follow-up press release if deemed appropriate.ERIC A. RUNAAS					SHERIFF						By:  Sgt. Michael Mugnani, 2nd Shift Patrol Division

properties.Details: On February 24th at 2:29 a.m. Madison Police were dispatched to a hit and run crash on University Avenue at Frances Street. Witnesses state that a large group of pedestrians had a walk light and were heading southbound across University. The driver of a '98 Olds Intrigue did not stop for a red light, and struck one of those in the cross walk while going about 25 m.p.h.  The victim flipped over the suspect's car. The vehicle did not stop, and one witness jumped on the back of the Intrigue by holding on to its spoiler. The witness banged on the car while yelling for the driver to stop. The Olds continue westbound on University for a short distance before a UW-Madison Police Officer pulled it over. The witness then jumped off and provided police with information on what had occurred. The victim suffered non-life threatening injuries.

properties.Suspect: Emmanuel NMI Juarez, age 17, Madison WisconsinCharges:  1. Reckless Endangering Safety (2 counts) - S.S. 941.30(2)2. Disorderly Conduct (2 counts) - S.S. 947.01
properties.Victim: 24 year old female of Madison Wisconsin
properties.Details: On 6/24/2008 at approximately 9:33PM, Madison Police Officers were dispatched to the 3700 block of East Washington Avenue reference a H&R investigation.  The victim in this matter was traveling westbound on East Washington Avenue near Mendota Street when a vehicle driven by Emmanuel Juarez pulled out directly in front of the victim.  The victim passes Juarez’s vehicle and just minutes later, Juarez would use the driver’s side of his vehicle (1989 Toyota Corolla) to ram the passenger side of the victim’s vehicle.  This startled the victim, but Juarez would drive off, continuing westbound on East Washington Avenue to North Street.  The victim followed Juarez and both parties would stop again in the 400 block of North Street.  Juarez would take a 2nd opportunity and proceeded to ram the opposite side of the victim’s vehicle.  Juarez drove away once again and went to the BP Gas Station located on Commercial Avenue.  Juarez would immediately get out of his vehicle and take his licenses plates off of his car.  Just seconds before police would arrive, Juarez and two passengers of his car would flee the scene into a field directly behind this gas station.  Police would give pursuit and detain all parties.  Juarez admitted to striking the victim’s vehicle due to “Being angry/upset over being passed by the victim.”  Due to officers having difficulty locating the missing license plate, a Canine Officer was summoned and the plate was located near 2618 Scofield Street.  This was an outstanding effort on the part of the victim and officers.  This was a rather dangerous situation where a vehicle was intentionally used to cause damage/harm to another, and these types of scenarios potentially have unintended consequences for bystanders/pedestrians.PO Howard PayneMadison Police Department

properties.Details: On July 22nd, at 6:17 p.m., Madison Police were called to a hit-and-run crash in the 3100 block of Monroe Street. A six-year-old girl was on a tag-along bike that was attached to her dad's bicycle. The 37-year-old father was going to cross Monroe Street at Chapman Street with hopes of pedaling onto Arbor Drive. As he and his daughter were heading across the street a car turned left from Arbor Drive on to Monroe Street. The father yelled out, but it was too late, the '98 Ford Taurus struck the tag-along sending his daughter tumbling into the street. She struck the pavement with enough force to knock off her bicycle helmet. At first the little girl could not breathe. Her dad leaped to her aid and could hear from the driver state, "Oh ----!" as he drove off. Nearby witnesses signaled for the motorist to stop, but he did not. Another motorist followed the suspect and got his license plate. Officers took this information and went to the man's residence where he was arrested. Madison Fire Rescue responded and provided medical assistance to the girl. She did not require a trip to the hospital.

properties.Arrested: DeWayne K Allen, 02-26-1957, resident of Madison. Charge: First Degree Intentional Homicide.
properties.Victim: Deceased. Identity withheld pending notification of family.
properties.Details: On 3-7-2005, at 8:06pm, Madison Police responded to the area of 4700 Cottage Grove Rd., reference an individual with a chest wound. This individual was transported to an area hospital, where he was later pronounced deceased. The suspect, identified as DeWayne K Allen, was contacted by officers upon arrival at the scene, and was taken into custody without incident. Pursuant to investigation by Madison Police officers and detectives, Allen was charged with First Degree Intentional Homicide, and booked into the Dane County Jail. No other suspects are believed involved, and it is not believed there is any further danger to the community.UPDATE:The Madison Police Department continues its investigation into the homicide on 3/7/05 on Cottage Grove Rd.  Shortly after the initial dispatch, that a person had been stabbed with a knife, Madison Police Officers were able to arrest DeWayne K. Allen.  Mr. Allen has been cooperative with investigators and is now charged with First Degree Intentional Homicide.  Mr. Allen was transported to the Dane County Jail without incident.  In addition, the knife used for the homicide was located and is now in police possession.  Although the motive for the homicide is still being learned, investigators believe this resulted from a heated argument between the two individuals.  The victim is a 41-year old white male who resided in Madison.  The victim was transported to UW Hospital where the Coroner pronounced his death.  Madison police do not believe the two males lived together.  Both individuals had numerous contacts with law enforcement over the years.  Furthermore, the Madison Police Department continues to investigate the citys first homicide and believes there is no continuing threat to the public regarding this case.

properties.Arrested: See below
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is assisting the Indian River County Sheriff's Office (Florida) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the death of Joann Gray.  Investigators from those agencies executed a search warrant on 2/4/06 at a storage facility located in the 4400 block of Remington Rd in Madison.  Inside the storage shed was a vehicle to which the body of Joann Gray was found.  The suspect in the death of Joann Gray, Louis D'Angelo, is in custody in Dodge County (WI) and will have a court appearance on 2/6/06.  This remains an ongoing investigation by the aforementioned law enforcement agencies working jointly.  For local media, the Madison Police Department will provide additional information as it becomes available.*** UPDATE  ***  see below news release:Sheriff Roy RaymondIndian River County, FloridaMEMBER FLORIDA SHERIFFS’ ASSOCIATION                                                MEMBER NATIONAL SHERIFFS’ ASSOCIATION____________________________________________________________ 4055 41st Avenue         Vero Beach, Florida 32960-1808        Phone 772-569-6700   Fax     772-569-8144  For Immediate ReleaseFebruary 5, 2006  Contact: Deputy Jeff Luther, PIOPhone: 772-978-6405Cell:  772-473-8782Fax:  772-569-8144E-mail: jluther@ircsheriff.org  MISSING PERSON UPDATE On Friday, February 3rd, 2006 Indian River County Sheriffs Detective Keith Harmon along with Special Agents of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) and the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI) interviewed Louis Dangelo in connection with the disappearance of Joann Gray at the Dodge County Sheriff’s Office (Wisconsin). Based on information provided during the interview, Louis Dangelo led investigators to a storage facility in Madison, Wisconsin, where the 1986 Maroon Jaguar was stored with the body of Joann Lynette Gray in the trunk. The storage facility was identified as Affordable Storage located at 4402 Remington Road, Madison, Wisconsin. On Sunday, February 05, 2006, Indian River County Sheriff’s Detective Keith Harmon, working with the City of Madison Police Department and the Dane County Coroner’s Office (Wisconsin), confirmed that the deceased body located in the trunk of a 1986 Maroon Jaguar stored at Affordable Storage, 4402 Remington Road, Madison, Wisconsin was that of Joann Lynette Gray. The Dane County Coroner’s Office completed an autopsy of Joann Gray. Preliminary autopsy findings confirm that Gray died as a result of a homicide. Specific details related to the cause of her death will not be released at this time, pending an ongoing homicide investigation. Louis Dangelo, W/M, DOB 06/16/1963 of 1618 Ferry Avenue, Apt #3, Niagara Falls, New York has been charged with Mutilating or Hiding a Corpse and Possession of Stolen Property. Mr. Dangelo is being held in the Dodge County Sheriff’s Office Jail, under NO BOND. All questions and any information reference this case should be directed to Deputy Jeff Luther at the above numbers. ##############

(Releases from 2007)

The family of Kelly Nolan issued this statement to be given to the media: "The Nolan family would like to thank everyone for their time and effort in helping us locate Kelly. We are appreciative for the concern and support from friends, family, and the community, but please understand that due to the overwhelming circumstances we might not be ready or able to talk. Because the investigation is still underway it is important that anybody with any information call the Crime Stoppers number 608-266-6014." New leads continue to arrive at the Madison Police Department. The investigative team is vigorously pursuing them. On Wednesday afternoon July 11 forensic work at the Schneider Drive recovery site in the Town of Dunn was completed. Schneider Drive has been re-opened to the public. Numerous leads continue to come into the department, and teams of detectives are busy pursuing them. Last night, Tuesday July 10th, Coroner John Stanley positively identified the recovered body as that of Kelly K. Nolan, age 22. The cause of death is still being pursued.
We all have a responsibility to do our part to help make our community a safe place. So, please if you know anything about this case, call MADISON AREA CRIME STOPPERS AT 608-266-6014. THANK YOU." (end of statement) The Madison Police Department would like to thank Wisconsin Department of Justice Division of Criminal Investigation's Clearinghouse for Missing and Exploited Children and Adults for generating a reward poster that is being circulated. The MPD also applauds Adams Outdoor Advertising for providing billboard space on which the reward, and Kelly's photos are posted. On Tuesday July 10 a team of forensic experts worked the recovery scene along Schneider Drive in the area of where yesterday's body was found. In addition, another team of Madison Police Officers and Detectives went shoulder to shoulder, on their hands and knees, inspecting a grassy area near the woods where the body was located. By mid-afternoon the body was removed from the scene and taken to the morgue for autopsy. Coroner John Stanley hopes to make a positive identification on the body. When that happens he will issue a written news release. Autopsy results are not likely to be forthcoming in the near future. Evidence found at the scene is being taken to the Wisconsin Crime Laboratory in Madison for examination. Beyond the recovery scene, teams of detectives were responding to new leads. Many new tips came in following the discovery of the body yesterday. The Nolan family is in seclusion and asking media to respect their privacy at this time. At approximately 8:45 a.m. on July 9 a search team, utilizing a K9, discovered a body in a wooded area, on private property, near Schneider Road. The property is situated in the Town of Dunn. Detectives determined, based on what they could observe of the body, that this is a homicide investigation. Shortly after the discovery, a command post was established along Schneider Road. A multi-jurisdictional forensic team will be brought in to process the scene. This could be a couple of day process, and during that time the public should note that Schneider Road would be closed. Police will remain on the scene throughout this stage of the investigation. At a news conference Monday afternoon Dane County Coroner John Stanley indicated the victim is likely female, and evidence would suggest it maybe Kelly Nolan. However, Coroner Stanley emphasized that positive identification has not been made. The Nolan family is aware of these developments. Madison Police Chief Noble Wray has confirmed that cell phone technology led investigators to this area. It should be noted, that this is an area where aerial and other searches had been made earlier to no avail. Detectives determined an extensive search was necessary (See earlier portion of this release. The results of that massive search resulted in the discovery of this body. The Madison Police Department would like to thank all of those who were part of this collaborative effort: The Salvation Army/University of Wisconsin Police Department/The Fitchburg Police Department/The Dane County 911 Center/The Madison Fire Department/The Dane County Sheriff's Department/The MATC Recruit Academy/The Mental Health Resource Team/The Dane County District Attorney's Victim-Witness Program/The Green County Sheriff's Office/The Columbia County Sheriff's Office/The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources/The Maple Bluff Police Department/Special Agents of the FBI/Retired Officer Advisory Resource (ROAR)/The Mount Horeb Police Department/The Town of Madison Police Department/The Wisconsin State Patrol/Dane County Emergency Management/The Wisconsin Department of Criminal Investigation/The Oregon Fire Department/The Verona Fire Department/The Dane County Coroner's Office/The Emergency Clinic for Animals/The Portage County Sheriff's Office/The State Crime Lab/Bucky's Rentals/Independent K9 handlers: Jody Disher, Dennis Schenk, Janet Anagnos/Father Bill Connell and the congregation at Holy Mother of Consolation Church. This homicide investigation is in its very early stages, and much of the information being gleaned by law enforcement will not be shared. The primary focus at this time is to use gathered evidence to identify a suspect. The Madison Police Department appreciates the public's understanding of the sensitive nature of this process. Joel DeSpain Public Information Officer Madison Police Department _____________________________________________________________________________ On Monday, July 9, starting at sunrise, the Madison Police Department conducted a geographical search in an area immediately north of the Village of Oregon, east of Highway 14. The mission of the search operation was to locate articles or other evidence related to the disappearance of Kelly Nolan. During the course of investigation into Nolan's disappearance, information was developed identifying a number of geographical areas worthy of extensive searching. The Oregon search area was approximately three square miles. The Madison Police Department was assisted in today's search operations by special agents from the F.B.I., the Dane County Sheriff's Department, and several other police agencies from throughout Wisconsin and Illinois, including K9 and horse search teams. In addition several volunteers were enlisted to support today's operation including retired MPD police officers, the Salvation Army, Father Bill Connell from the Holy Mother of Consolation Catholic Church. The Madison Police Department and the Nolan family are thankful to all who assisted in today's operation. Two press briefings will be held at 11:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. (if needed) at the Holy Mother of Consolation Catholic Church, 651 N Main Street in Oregon. Please contact Public Information Officer Joel Despain at 576-6626 who is on site in Oregon for further information. Lt Joe Balles Central Police District

properties.Arrested: Ee Lee, Age 23, MadisonTenative Charge: Physical Abuse of a Child
properties.Details: ****UPDATE FRIDAY JULY 13******Madison Police have arrested 23 year old Ee Lee, the victim's mother, and are holding her on a tentative charge of Physical Abuse of a Child.It is anticipated that additional charges will be added early next week when the investigation is complete and the case is forwarded to the District Attorney's office.At this time, Madison Police are not commenting on the nature of the injuries, or other details of the investigation.-------------------------------------------------------------------------On Wednesday afternoon, shortly before 5:00 p.m., Madison Police responded  to the UW Hospital’s emergency room regarding a deceased, 6-week old, female infant.  The victim had been transported from Moorland Road to the hospital by Madison Fire EMS. The subsequent investigation has revealed the victim suffered injuries indicative of intentional harm.  A person of interest has been identified.  This is an isolated incident and there is no threat to the community.  This investigation is on going.

properties.Arrested: No suspect description at this time.
properties.Victim: Deceased: Kevin K. Cobbins M/B (26 years old)  Pronounced dead at the scene.
properties.Details: A large gathering at this address was dispersing in the early morning, about 4AM.  Neighbors reported hearing what sounded like gunshots.  Many vehicles were leaving the area.  The victim was discovered outside.  The cause of death was determined to be multiple gunshot wounds.    Incident is under investigation.UPDATED INFORMATION:  As a result of the continuing investigation in this matter, an arrest warrant has been issued for James P. Bohanan M/B 05/06/73 for First Degree Intentional Homicide in the shooting death of Kevin Cobbins.  Anyone with information regarding Bohanan or his whereabouts is encouraged to call Madison Crimestoppers at 608-266-6014.

Kelly Nolan Update---------------------------It was a month ago today that the body of 22-year-old Kelly Nolan was discovered in a wooded area near Schneider Drive in the Town of Dunn. Investigators believe Nolan could have been brought to that area around the time that she disappeared from downtown Madison - that would have been the early morning hours of June 23rd. Nolan went missing on the same weekend as the Village of Oregon’s annual Summerfest celebration. There is no reason to believe Nolan attended that event, but we are using it as a benchmark for community members to test their recollection of that weekend. If anyone was in the Schneider Drive area that weekend of June 22, 23, 24, and saw anything that might aid in our investigation we ask that they call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Madison detectives continue to work this case full-time, and are appreciative of the help they are getting from the FBI, the Wisconsin Department of Criminal Investigation, the Dane County Sheriff’s Department, and the Fitchburg Police Department. The MPD would particularly like to thank the hard working analysts at the State Crime Laboratory in Madison who have been very responsive and attentive to the department’s needs in the Nolan investigation.

On 8/22/07 shortly after 10:00 a.m. Madison Police were dispatched to the Kings Inn (915 W. Beltline Hwy) to check on a room. The caller remained anonymous and did not give any details to the 9-1-1 Center. Upon checking the room, officers found the decedent. No one is in custody at this time. The coroner will release the name of the deceased and cause of death, when it is available. The Madison Police Department is treating this as a homicide and is encouraging anyone with further information to contact Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.
