properties.Details: On September 7th at 2:34 a.m. Madison Police responded to the intersection of Broadway and Bridge Road. At that location a 1993 Mercury Tracer had crashed into a light pole. A Monona Police Sgt. made contact with the driver who was walking away from the scene. He would later explain to police that he, and a lifelong friend, had been out drinking at several establishments, that the car belonged to his friend, and that he was trying to get his friend home. Both men were taken to a local hospital. The passenger did not survive. The driver was treated and released, then booked into the Dane County Jail

Madison Police responded to a shots fired call in the 2200 block of Cypress Way.  Upon arrival, officers discovered a male subject who had apparently been shot.  The individual was transported to a local hospital and later pronounced dead.  The name of the victim is not being released at this time.  No suspects are in custody and the investigation is on-going.UPDATEVictim is a 56 year old, M/B, who died of a single gunshot wound.  Persons of interest in this case described as:#1:  M/B 18-20 years of age, African American male,  6' to 6'5",  very light complected, brown hair. wearing a dark colored winter jacket with an all-over pattern#2:  M/B 18-20 years of age, 6ft, facial hair or a goatee, wearing all dark colored clothingUPDATE, 11/22/07 @ 3:30PMThe Madison Police Dept continues to investigate a homicide that occurred on 11/21/07 in the 2200 block of Cypress Way.  Updated infoformation regarding persons the police are attempting to locate regarding this investigation are:Suspect #1 M/B 18-20 years of age, 6'5", very light skin, wearing a dark winter jacket with cartoon characters.Suspect #2 M/B 18-20 years of age, 6'0", facial hair or goatee, wearing all dark colored clothing.The Madison Police Department requests that anyone having information concerning this case call 266-4275 or Crime Stoppers 266-6014

Update (12/07/07 @9:13a) Napoleon Elvord was located overnight. He has been questioned and released. Detectives remain very interested in having a conversation with Shari Broughton and continue to try to locate her. The person officers had hoped to find at the Doncaster Drive location was not found. Four people did come out of the home. They have been questioned, but were not arrested. The incident on Doncaster Drive had a peaceful resolution, which was a primary goal of the ERT.Update (12/06/07 @ 5:52p):  Officers are beginning to clear the scene.  Police are talking to a few citizens however, no one is currently under arrestOn December 6th, around 10:12 a.m., Madison Police responded to a home in the 4200 block of Doncaster Drive after receiving information that a person of interest in the Cypress Way homicide (see earlier incident report) might be found inside. The contact with the residence evolved into a standoff situation. A couple of people who were in the residence did come out and detectives are questioning those individuals. It is believed one, or more, may still be inside the residence. The Emergency Response Team is on scene. ERT members are proceeding carefully and methodically as to not put citizens, officers, or those who maybe inside the home at additional risk. It is believed there is no immediate danger to the neighborhood as this tactical event is targeted at one specific residence.Madison Police are also trying to locate two additional individuals who are also described as persons of interest in the Cypress homicide. Neither is the person who was being sought on Doncaster Drive (that name is not being released at this time). The “additional individuals” are: Shari L. Broughton (4-4-72) and Napoleon Elvord (8-12-54) Broughton is 5’9” and 130 lbs. Elvord is 6’0” and 230 lbs. Photos of Broughton and Elvord are attached to this release.

properties.Suspect: (UPDATED June 2008) Suspect has been arrested.UPDATED ... FEB. 26, 2008)Perpetrator is described as a male, white, male, 20's --possibly early 20's, 5'10" - 6'02", may have a thin build, believed to have blonde or light brown hair. He was last seen wearing a tan Carhartt type jacket and a white stocking cap with a red motion W on the front.
properties.Victim: Joel Marino, age 31, MadisonVictim was transported to a local hospital where he was pronounced dead.
properties.Details: On Monday, March 10, 2008, the Madison Police Department released new details in the Joel Marino homicide.  Based on forensic analysis performed by scientists at the Wisconsin State Crime Lab in Madison it has been determined that male DNA found on a knife recovered at the crime scene matches DNA found on a white cap and a backpack recovered shortly after the murder.  Detectives believe the DNA belongs to Marino’s killer.   On the day of the homicide, investigators believe Mr. Marino was home all morning and was stabbed in his house between 1:00 p.m. and 1:20 p.m.  In addition the probe indicates the suspect likely fled the Marino home and ran southbound on West Shore Drive.  During his flight he discarded the white cap and Puma backpack in the West Shore neighborhood.  The perpetrator was last seen near the intersection of South Park and Parr Streets. The knife – which is believed to the murder weapon -- is described as an “OXO” brand paring knife with a four inch silver blade.  A photo of the knife has been attached to this release. Detectives working the Marino case have determined the recovered backpack was bought at a State Street business on the afternoon of Friday, January 25th.  The assailant is believed to be the person who made the purchase.Police believe the perpetrator MAY live in, or perhaps associates with, the State Street area.  He is described as a white male, 5’10” – 6’2”, in his 20’s, with a thin build.  He was last seen wearing a tan Carhardt type jacket.  The MPD is seeking assistance in identifying this man. A reward of more than $40,000 is being offered for information.Callers can remain anonymous and should phone Madison Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.   UPDATED INFORMATION (posted 9:15 a.m. Tuesday, February 26, 2008)  Based on new evidence in the Joel Marino homicide, the Madison Police Department now believes the person of interest they were seeking is now directly involved in the murder of Joel Marino.  The Madison Police Department describes the suspect as a white male, in his twenties and possibly in his early twenties.  The suspect is believed to be between 5'10" and 6'02" and may have a thin build.  The suspect is also believed to have blonde or light brown hair.  This suspect was possibly seen in the State Street area on Friday, January 25th during the afternoon hours.  This suspect was last seen wearing a tan Carhartt type jacket and a white stocking cap with a red motion W on the front.  Anyone with information on the possible identity of this suspect is strongly encouraged to call Crimestoppers.   UPDATED INFORMATION (posted 1:00 p.m. Wednesday, January 30, 2008)Investigators working on the Joel Marino homicide have recovered a hat and a backpack. These items are believed to have been worn by a subject who has been described as a person of interest in this case. Photos of these items are attached to this incident release. Both were recovered during a search of the neighborhood on the day of the murder. At this hour Mr. Marino’s family, friends, and co-workers are working on getting a reward fund together. Details will be forthcoming.Many detectives continue to work the case, and items (including the hat and backpack) are being taken to the Wisconsin State Crime Laboratory for forensic tests.Residents from Mr. Marino’s neighborhood have been invited to attend a community meeting at St. Mary’s Hospital this evening. South District Captain Jim Wheeler will share with them what he can about the investigation. While the media are welcome to attend this gathering, it is not a news conference and is being orchestrated to help neighbors of Mr. Marino deal with this tragedy.UPDATED INFORMATION (posted 10:30 a.m. Tuesday Jan. 29)The victim of the January 28th homicide lived in the neighborhood where he was found, and Detectives believe the crime potentially happened inside his home. At this point they cannot rule out that this may have been a random act. A team of investigators continues to work out of a Command Post that has been set up at the South District of the Madison Police Department. They are requesting citizen help in locating a person of interest. This is a man who was seen in the area around the time of the crime. He is described as being 6’ to 6’1”. He was last seen wearing a white stocking cap with a red “W” on its front, and a tan sheepskin type jacket. In addition he was carrying a gray, new looking backpack. Anyone with information on this case is urged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.ORGINAL NEWS RELEASE (posted late Monday afternoon)On January 28th around 1:22 p.m. Madison police were called to an alley just off of the 700 block of South Park Street for a report of a man who was down. The first officer on the scene immediately called for the Madison Fire Department to send an ambulance. The victim was transported to a local hospital where he was pronounced dead. He is described as 31-year-old Madison area man. A Command Post has been established at the South District of the Madison Police Department and many detectives and patrol officers are currently working the case. The cause of death will be determined at autopsy and -- if appropriate -- be released by the Dane County Coroner. Madison Police are treating this as a homicide. It is unknown if the victim knew his attacker/attackers as this murder investigation is in its’ very early stages.

properties.Victim: Brittany Sue Zimmermann, age 21, Marshfield WI (Ms. Zimmermann was currently living in Madison at the West Doty Street Address while she attended UW-Madison)
properties.Details: BRITTANY ZIMMERMANN SCHOLARSHIP FUND (posted Wed. April 16th)-In the wake of her tragic death, the family of Brittany Zimmermann has announced that they are establishing a scholarship in Brittany's name and conducting a fund drive called "Dollars for Brittany".  A Marshfield credit union is facilitating the collection of funds.  Contributions can be sent to:Brittany Zimmermann Memorial FundC/O Marshfield Medical Center CUPO Box 279Marshfield, WI 54449(UPDATED Monday, April 14, 2008)The Madison Police Department is seeking additional information from people who were in the Bassett Neighborhood either on the day Brittany was killed, or on the day before her death. Specifically, detectives would like to speak with anyone who was solicited for money – or gave money to strangers - on either April 1st or April 2nd.  This would include citizens who were approached on the street, or at their homes, by one or more individuals. Investigators are focusing this effort on solicitations that were made on West Washington Ave., West Main St., West Wilson St., South Bedford St., South Bassett St., or West Doty Street.  The MPD would ask those with information to call Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014.(UPDATED FRIDAY APRIL 11, 2008)Posters seeking information in the Brittany Sue Zimmermann case will soon be posted by Madison Police Officers in the Bassett Neighborhood, and in other areas of the central city. A copy of the poster has been attached to this incident report. Madison Crime Stoppers has now received approximately 200 tips in the Zimmermann case. In addition, some 25 new tips have come in reference the Joel Marino homicide. Joel was murdered on January 28th, and prior to Brittany’s homicide around 70 tips had been received in the Marino investigation.There are some similarities in the cases. Both residents were killed inside their homes, during daylight hours, and no motive has been established in either case. There appears to be nothing in either victim’s background that would make them targets of violence. Still, investigators do not know if the cases are connected, and there are differences. For example, in the Zimmermann case there were signs of forced entry. There was no evidence of forced entry in the Marino case. Both Marino and Zimmermann lived in close proximity, perhaps a mile or so apart. Because of the closeness detectives working the Marino case are coming across information that may help the Zimmermann case. Conversely, detectives working the Zimmermann case are coming across information that may aid the Marino probe.Both cases remain very active investigations.(UPDATED MONDAY APRIL 7)Some members of the media have been inquiring about a man who was going to various locations in the downtown (including a residence on West Washington Avenue) soliciting money from residents on the day of Brittany's death. This person is in custody on a probation hold, and is one of many who have been arrested (for things like probation holds and unrelated crimes) during the Zimmermann investigation. No suspect has been identified in the murder of Brittany. Detectives are continuing to pursue a plethora of leads. The MPD appreciates all of those who have come forward with information, and encourages others to call Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014 as this remains a very active investigation. (UPDATED PRESS INFORMATION: RELEASED FRIDAY APRIL 4, 2008)The Madison Police Department, with assistance from the WI State Crime Laboratory, continued Friday to process the home of Brittany Sue Zimmermann. Forensic analysts at the Wisconsin State Crime Laboratory in Madison are already expediting the examination of some items found that may have evidentiary value.Meanwhile, the focus of the investigation continues on several fronts. Patrol officers and detectives have been talking with numerous people in the neighborhood including residents, commuters, business owners, and transients.   Police are seeking to speak with those who are willing to share information, and those who may be somewhat reluctant to contact police directly.   Police seek any information regarding activity in the area.   In the Zimmermann case, the MPD would like citizens to focus on the daytime – going into the nighttime hours -- of Wednesday April 2nd.   If anyone saw anything odd, strange, or out of the ordinary in the area of the crime scene—a call to Crime Stoppers (608-266-6014) would be appreciated.In the last 24 hours more than 75 tips have come in to Crime Stoppers. Many of those calls are from people who have had strangers come to their doors, or into their homes recently, or over the course of the past several months. Several callers said at the time they did not call police. The MPD would urge anyone, at anytime, encountering a similar situation to call. Other tips in the Zimmermann investigation have come from downtown residents who saw people going door to door asking for money on the day of the homicide. In at least one case a man entered a residence. Investigators have identified many of these people, and have talked with them. It is not unusual during such contacts that arrests are made for unrelated matters. For instance, some contacts are made with those who may have outstanding warrants, or are wanted on probation holds.At this hour the MPD does not have a suspect, or suspects identified in the Zimmermann homicide.  The Dane County Coroner has determined Brittany died from a “complexity of traumatic injuries.”  Investigators have not established a motive. Madison and UW police officers will continue increased foot patrols in the Bassett Street Neighborhood.(UPDATED THURSDAY APRIL 3 @ 12:20 p.m.)Investigators in the Brittany Zimmermann homicide have concluded that her boyfriend is not a suspect in this case. He has been -- and continues to be -- very helpful in providing information to the detective team.Many leads have come in, and detectives are pursuing them. No suspect has been identified.The search of Brittany's home -- and the area around it -- continues.  Items of possible evidentiary value are being taken to the Wisconsin State Crime Laboratory in Madison for analysis.A member of the Dane County's Victim/Witness unit is working with Brittany's family. She will be keeping them posted on developments in the case, and has informed the MPD that the family is asking for privacy as they continue to grieve.A good number of tips have come in to the MPD, and citizens with any information that may help lead to an arrest are encouraged to continue to call the Madison Police Crime Stoppers line at 608-266-6014.--------------------------------------------(ORIGINAL RELEASE)Shortly after 1:00 p.m. on Wednesday Madison Police were called to a residence in the 500 block of West Doty Street to check on a person. Ms. Zimmermann was found dead inside her home. Dane County Coroner John Stanley says a preliminary examination indicates the manner of death was homicide. The Madison Police Department is working in unison with the UW-Madison Police Department on this case, and a Command Post has been established inside the Central District station.Both Madison Police Chief Noble Wray, and UW Police Chief Susan Riseling have pledged extra patrols, and a heightened presence on Doty Street and surrounding areas for the time being.At this writing no suspects have been identified, and detectives have been unable to rule out that this may have been a random act.District Alderman Mike Verveer is looking to hold a community meeting this weekend to address concerns of residents.Meanwhile, a team of detectives will work the case around the clock, with patrol officers aiding in their efforts.Coroner Stanley has indicated a forensic examination will be done tomorrow morning at which time he may (or may not -- depending on consultation with investigators) release more information on the cause of death."This terrible crime is a tragedy, and my thoughts are with the victim's family and friends," said Mayor Dave Cieslewicz. "I am going to work closely with the Madison Police Department and other law enforcement authorities to provide the resources necessary to bring the perpetrator to justice and address the public safety needs of the community

UPDATE:Based on current investigative information, the homicides of Joel Marino and Brittany Zimmermann do not appear to be connected. However, we cannot totally rule out any connection between the cases based in part on the fact that there are similarities, such as:-Both Victims were murdered inside their homes during daylight hours.-Both crimes took place within a reasonably close geographic area.-There was nothing to suggest that either victim had enemies or were at risk due to their lifestyles.No further information will be released at this time.

The letter below was written by Amanda Miller, fiancee of Joel Marino who was tragically murdered on January 28th.  This letter was provided to the Madison Police Department who was asked to share it with the community.Joel Marino was the love of my life. We had been happily dating and planning our lives together until he was taken from me on January 28, 2008. Joel was a compassionate, attentive, and sincere person who possessed a contagious enthusiasm for life. Joel was my first introduction to the city of Madison. I was a nursing student living in Dubuque, Iowa, when we began dating. Each time I made a trip to Madison, Joel became my personal tour guide. He loved that Madison was a city in which so many cultures, artists, musicians and academics were embraced.  After graduation, I was easily persuaded to move to Madison and I have been proud to call this city my home ever since.It is through our conversations about work that I know Joel had a great deal of respect and admiration for the medical community within Madison.  Joel was an EMT in college, and then later continued his passion for the medical profession, as he worked with patients needing pacemakers and ICDs.  Joel had the opportunity to work with physicians in all of the hospitals in Madison.  I know that Joel recognized the importance of each facility and how it helped to serve the community.As an E.R. nurse working in Madison, I am intimately aware of the procedures and protocols that exist to save lives in an emergency.  I would like to thank those that cared for Joel during his last hours.  I can't say enough about the brave citizens who called 911. The 911 dispatcher was professional and efficient in guiding those that called to assist Joel.  I want to thank the EMS team and first responders that transported Joel and began working to save his life.  Working as an E.R. nurse in Madison, I am confident that Joel was taken to the only facility that would have been able to effectively care for him due to the trauma his body had suffered.  The UW Hospital Trauma Center did everything they could for Joel and he was treated by an outstanding medical team.  There should be no doubt that Joel was given the best possible care and that each decision made in the process to save his life was done appropriately.I believe that through the tragic loss of Joel, Brittany Zimmerman and Kelly Nolan our community needs to work together to find answers.  I believe that by placing blame we distract from finding the answers we need to bring justice for Joel, Brittany and Kelly. I'm hoping that for the sake of those that loved Joel, the media will not play or sensationalize the 911 call made by the brave citizens who found him. Out of respect for those lost and their families, I hope that as a community, we can move beyond incidental details that do nothing to progress the ongoing investigations.  I'm asking my fellow citizens to assist by simply being conscientious and to watch out for the safety of their neighbors, friends and family. I'm confident that as a community we can find answers that will help us put these murders to rest and regain the sense of security we lost.I never thought I would have to imagine a life in Madison without Joel. But, I am committed to this community, as Joel was in his lifetime. Joel was an amazing man who left behind a powerful example for all of us on how to live our lives. This tragedy not only affects those that knew and loved Joel, but resonates with an entire community. For that reason, I'm asking anyone who has information on Joel's murder or any of these murders, to please contact the Madison Police Department or Crime Stoppers.Thank you,Amanda Miller

properties.Suspect: Tammy L. Blizzard, age 46, Madison WisconsinCharges: Felony Homicide by Intox Use of Vehicle (2nd+) (S.S. 940.09 (1) (a), Felony Hit & Run-Involve Death (S.S. 346.67(1)
properties.Victim: David C. Schmidt - age 74 - Madison Wisconsin
properties.Details: On August 12th, 2007 after leaving a Madison Mallards Baseball Game (Warner Park), David C. Schmidt attempted to cross N. Sherman Avenue and was tragically struck by a SUV that fled the scene.  Police arrived on scene and through pointed investigative work on the part of officers, detectives, and investigators; a suspect was developed in the case.  Tammie L. Blizzard would later be arrested on charges listed above.  David C. Schmidt gallantly fought for his life for 37 agonizing days, but was sadly laid to rest on September 18th, 2007.  This particular case has impacted many individuals in a profound way, but the family has endured the most.  When friends and family speak of Schmidt, it is emphatically clear that he represented the utmost of a quality individual.On Sunday July 22nd, 2008 at (3:00PM) at The Madison Mallards Baseball Park (Warner Park), two of David C. Schmidt’s grandsons will throw out the ceremonial pitch in honor and memory of their loved one.  These types of events mean a lot as the family continues to deal with a rather difficult situation.  The Madison Police Department continues to stress the importance that drinking alcohol and operating a motor vehicle should never coincide with one another.  This horrific incident could have been prevented with a small degree of responsibility on the part of the driver of the SUV to simply not drive if alcohol was on board.  A sentencing hearing was tentatively scheduled today at 3:00PM at the Dane County Courthouse (8th Floor) in the matter of State of Wisconsin vs. Tammie L. Blizzard.

properties.Suspect: Arrest warrants have been issued for:Amir C. Furlow, age 19Promethius Brown, age 19 (see updated information posted below)
properties.Details: (UPDATED INFORMATION, MONDAY JULY 21, 2008)A Dane County Judge signed arrest warrants for two homicide suspects late Friday afternoon July 18, 2008. Mr. Promethius Brown, age 19, is wanted for Armed Burglary, and Felony Murder. Mr. Amir C. Furlow, age 19, is wanted for Armed Burglary, and First Degree Intentional Homicide. Both are believed to be in Chicago.  Information on the warrants was sent to Illinois authorities, including the U.S. Marshal’s Fugitive Task Force, with hopes that the suspects might be apprehended over the weekend. They remain at large as of Monday morning. The Madison Police Department’s West District detective team has been working very hard on this homicide and investigators would like to thank community members with being forthcoming with information that has helped the case progress to this point.It is still believed the suspects targeted their victim, but the exact motive is still under investigation.(ORIGINAL RELEASE)The Madison Police Department is investigating a homicide that occurred at a residence in the 7100 block of Tempe Drive late last night. Officers were sent to the residence reference a person being shot. The victim was transported to a local hospital where he succumbed to his injuries. This is believed not to be a random crime.  The two suspects remain at large.

properties.Suspect: Daniel Lee Wright Black Male 48 years old, Madison resident Charges 1st Degree Intentional Homicide, 2 counts of bail Jumping and Operating After Revocation 4th offense. The suspect was conveyed from the hospital to the Dane County Public Safety Building. No further details available at this time.
properties.Details: (UPDATED JULY 16TH)Detectives do not believe a third party was involved in yesterday's crime. This appears to have been a domestic fight between Daniel L. Wright, age 50, Madison, and the deceased. An autopsy is scheduled for this morning, and it will be up to the Dane County Coroner to establish a cause of death, and to release the victim's name. At this point Mr. Wright is in custody on outstanding warrants. He remains hospitalized, and investigators have not yet been able to speak with him. He has not, at this point, been arrested on any tentative charges pertaining to the death.-----------------------------------------------(ORIGINAL RELEASE)On July 15th, around 1:52 p.m., Madison Police were called to an apartment inside 910 West Badger Road to investigate a reported stabbing. An adult woman was found dead inside the residence. Her death is being treated as a homicide. A man, who was also inside the same apartment, has been taken to a local hospital after suffering apparent stab wounds. The wounds are not believed to be life threatening. Detectives believe this was not a random crime, and say there is no ongoing risk to the greater community.  At this early stage of the investigation it is not known whether a third party maybe involved, or whether the man and woman were the only ones inside the apartment at the time of the crime.. They - the injured man and deceased woman - had been in a domestic relationship with one another.

properties.Suspect: Justin R. Stout, age 31, MadisonMr. Stout has been arrested and is tentatively charged with 1st Degree Intentional Homicide.
properties.Address: 319 N. Henry Street outside of the Plaza Tavern
properties.Victim: Juan J. Bernal, age 22, Madison NOT a UW-Madison studentMr. Bernal suffered two stab wounds to the chest. He was taken to a local hospital and was initially listed in critical condition. He passed away early this morning September 4th.
properties.Details: .UPDATE #2Detectives say it does not appear that Mr. Bernal and Mr. Stout knew one another. UPDATE #1The victim in this case has died at a local hospital, and this is now a homicide investigation.________________________ORIGINAL RELEASEWednesday night, at 11:38 p.m., Madison Police responded to an area outside of the Plaza Tavern, 319 N. Henry Street, following a stabbing. Witnesses report that two groups of men got into a dispute inside the bar, and that led to a 22-year old Madison man being stabbed outside the bar. He suffered two stab wounds to the chest, and is currently in critical condition at a local hospital. Bar patrons trailed the suspect, and another man down the street. They detained the man who had been with the suspect until officers arrived. Further police investigation led officers to a downtown residence where the suspect was taken into custody. He is Justin R. Stout, age 32, Madison. Mr. Stout will be tentatively charged with 1st Degree Reckless Endangering Safety. The investigation into what led to the violence is continuing.

properties.Victim: Salvador Tellez-Giron, age 66, MadisonDeceasedViviana Tellez-Giron, age 33, FitchburgDeceased
properties.Details: UPDATED MONDAY AFTERNOON, OCTOBER 6______________________________________________________ Statement on behalf of the Téllez-Girón Salazar Family:The Téllez-Girón Salazar family would like to thank you all for your thoughts and prayers at this time of enormous grief. They recognize the enormous loss suffered by Viviana’s family & friends and are committed to providing her family with any needed support to carry out her family's wishes for a fitting burial.  We will be sharing with you information about the funeral services for Salvador as soon as they are available. The family asks that you respect their privacy at this time. To honor the family’s wishes, no further public statements will be made by family and friends in the immediate future. Shiva Bidar-Sielaff Friend of the Téllez-Girón Salazar Family UPDATED MONDAY MORNING, OCTOBER 6On Saturday evening, around 6:23 p.m., Madison Police were called to a condominium in the 700 block of Kottke Drive after a family member found a husband and wife deceased in the unit. Preliminary autopsy results, released by the Dane County Coroner, indicate the husband died from a "self-inflicted hanging," and the wife from "multiple blunt-force injuries." -MPD is conducting a death investigation in the 700 block of Kottke Drive. A man and a woman have been found deceased in a residence. The investigation initially indicates that there is no danger to the general public. The incident remains under investigation.UPDATEPreliminary indications are that this incident is a domestic homicide/suicide.  The two parties involved are well known to one-another and there does not appear to be a danger to the general public.  The incident remains under investigation and names are being withheld pending notification of family members.

properties.Details: On 3/7/05 at approximately 9:22 am MPD officers responded to a report of an elderly female with mental health problems who walked away from her residence and had been missing for about an hour.  The female's condition was such that she was confused and disoriented, and was also supposed to be on oxygen.  "Johnny", a recently commissioned K-9 for the Madison Police Department, responded with his handler.  "Johnny" was able to obtain a scent from the elderly person's clothing in the home and tracked the path of the female.   Within five minutes "Johnny" and his handler found the missing adult several blocks away that was disorientated and cold due to the temperatures outside.

properties.Details: Officers responded to 947 E Johnson for a report of several tenants beating up a landlord. After officers arrived one of the suspects fought with officers and another suspect attacked officers. One officer was struck in the head and another, Officer Laura Walker, was knocked to the ground striking the curb and possibly breaking her forearm. A juvenile and an adult were arrested. The 14-year-old juvenile was taken to the Juvenile Reception Center and charged with battery, resisting officers, obstructing officers. The officer who was punched in the head near his eye, did not have any substantial injuries but had a contact lens knocked out. The adult, Deanna Lynn Sanger of Waunakee, was booked into the Dane County Jail on tentative charges of battery to a police officer, obstructing an officer, resisting an officer and disorderly conduct.

properties.Details: A MPD officer observed a pickup driving recklessly the officer stopped the pickup on E. Johnson near Fordem. As the officer approached the pickup to contact the driver, the pickup fled. The officer decided not to pursue but to follow due to weather and traffic conditions. The pick up drove into a small parking lot at Gilman and Butler with only 1 entrance/exit. The officer was joined by a 2nd MPD officer at that location. The pickup turned around facing the two officers. The officers instructed the driver to stop the pickup and exit the vehicle. The driver refused and accelerated towards the officers barely missing them, during this incident the officers fired their weapons at the pickup. The pick up was struck and tires were flattened. The vehicle left the area and continued to Howard Pl. were it stopped. The driver, Mourfield, ran and was apprehended nearby. This incident is being investigated by MPD.

Madison Police are investigating this case as a possible hate crime.

She was carrying a wallet in her hand.  The 11-year old reached out and grabbed the wallet and tried to yank it out of her hand.  She retained possession of the wallet and tried to walk into a nearby Walgreens.  One of the juveniles threatened to knock her to the ground and take her wallet.  She managed to get into the Walgreens store and the Police were called.  The juveniles followed her into the store.  They were located by Officers in the area.  No injuries reported. properties.Details: On Saturday night, at 9:22 p.m. Madison Police responded to East Towne Mall for a strong armed robbery. Two sisters reported that while talking in the parking lot they were accosted by a purse thief. After the suspect grabbed the women's purses they decided to chase. One jumped on the hood of the suspect's car (older model Chevy Beretta) , while the other dove into an open window. Eventually both were half way in the car with their legs dangling outside of it. One victim reports that she repeatedly jabbed the suspect in the neck with her keys, while punching him with her other hand. She also tried to bite him. Meanwhile her older sister tried to grab the steering wheel. While this was happening the suspect was driving in circles, hitting medians and curbs in an attempt to shake the sisters. Both did, in time, fall off, and were transported to a local hospital for treatment of cuts and bruises. One sister also sustained a broken ankle. Suspect vehicle has been recovered. A 47-year-old man had called 911 after being attacked while walking home from a convenience store. He says two suspects approached him and asked for a light. As the victim reached into his pocket for some matches one suspect punched him in the eye. The victim says he blocked a second punch, and then started fighting back. He says the suspects ran west on Raymond and he called 911. The victim did not lose any of his possessions, and was treated and released for a cut above his eye.

properties.Details: On September 20th around 11:56 p.m. Madison Police responded to South Randall and Mound Streets. Two college students, who had been walking southbound on South Randall from the area of the Open Pantry, reported that they had just been put in headlocks by two strong-armed robbers. The female victim reports that she was also struck in the face at least three times by her assailant. The suspects got away with the woman's purse, and cash from the male victim's pocket.

properties.Arrested: Male, Black
properties.Details: On September 26th, around 5:23 p.m., a Madison Police officer, while on routine patrol, was flagged down by a private security officer who works at the East Madison Neighborhood Center. He said a strong-armed robbery had just occurred outside of the center, and that the victim was now inside the center. The officer made contact with a 91-year-old woman who was nursing a cut finger. She indicated it was cut when someone grabbed her purse and took off running. The victim said she was just getting out of her car, which she had parked in front of the center, and was on her way to her weekly game of afternoon cards, when someone grabbed her purse. She says her car door was open, but she had not yet gotten her feet on the ground, when the snatch was made. Her finger was cut by the purse strap. She indicated she pulled on the strap in a futile attempt to maintain possession of her belongings. She then began yelling, "help, help!" She told police, "her whole life was in that purse," including old photographs of her children and her address book. Staff from the neighborhood center went out to pursue suspects, but police were not able to make any arrests for the strong-armed robbery.  It is not known whether this crime is connected to other strong-armed robberies that took place last week.

properties.Details: On Friday afternoon September 28th a Madison police officer, who was working the West High Homecoming Parade, received information that a student had been punched (away from school) and was now in the nurse's office. The victim states that he, two other male students, and three female students, were walking towards school on Chamberlain near Ash Street around 1:15 p.m. He says while walking, two or three black males ran up from behind them and he was hit. He says the blow caused him to hit his head on a parked car, and during this episode he dropped his backpack. Police then interviewed the other two young men who had been walking with victim #1. Both of these young men also reported being struck from behind. One also said he was hit a second time with a punch to the face. This victim (the one punched in the face) also dropped his backpack. He witnessed one of the suspects taking his backpack. The backpack belonging to victim #1 was also stolen. Both bags were recovered later in the afternoon in the 2400 block of Kendall Avenue.

She says the suspects knocked her to the ground, and punched her numerous times in the face as she tried to call for help. They stole her wallet and her beer. She was taken to a local emergency room for treatment of a facial cut. It required several stitches. The suspects were last seen running toward E. Johnson Street.

properties.Details: On March 20th, 2008 at approximately 2:07am, The Madison Police Department responded to the intersection of W. Doty Street & Bedford Street reference a strong-armed robbery.  Upon arrival they would contact the 47-year-old victim who works for the City of Madison, and was at this location dealing with maintenance on street sweeper equipment.   The victim would all of a sudden feel a hard object in his back, and a voice saying, “Give me your wallet”.  The victim refused to relent to this demand for his wallet, and proceeded to not only verbalize the fact he was not going to comply, but punched the suspect in the nose.  The victim felt he may have broken the nose of the suspect, and this quickly convinced the suspect to flee the scene towards the direction of Brittingham Park.  The suspect has been described as a M/B in his 20’s, approximately 6’00, 200lbs wearing a black jacket with a white stocking cap.   The victim in this matter acted in a valiant manner, and his quick response changed the agenda of the suspect attempting to take his property.  Madison Police did set up a perimeter in the area, utilizing a K-9 for searching purposes, but were unsuccessful in locating a suspect in this matter.  The public is reminded to pay particular attention to any individuals who are unknown to them; especially in areas that are not well lit or traveled.   Being aware of your environment at all times is utterly important in making sure you are not victimized.

properties.Details: On July 3, 2008, around 3:25 p.m., a Madison Police South District Officer saw a young man walking away from Penn Park towards Park Street. The officer had just reviewed a surveillance tape of a strong-armed robbery that had occurred at the South Transfer Point on the night of June 30th. The officer recognized the young man as being one of several perpetrators involved in the June 30th attack. In that crime, an 18-year-old Fitchburg man was punched, kicked and robbed of his bus pass and cell phone at 10:35 p.m. The teen was arrested for Strong-Armed Robbery. Officers of the South District are in the process of identifying others involved in the crime, and say images taken by surveillance cameras at the South Transfer Point are greatly aiding in their investigation.

An officer asked why she waited until the 16th to report the crime and she stated she was afraid and not sure what to do.

properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is continuing the investigation into residential burglaries occurring on the west side of Madison.  Extreme force has been used to break into the front door of both homes and condominiums.  Once inside the person(s) is targeting quick-valued items such as cash and jewelry.  Since August 26, investigators have been working 12 cases that have typically occurred Monday - Friday during daylight hours.  On 9/28/05 Madison Police Officers responded to another burglary in which a condominium on Hickory Hollow Dr had been broken into by way of brute force to the front door.  It is believed this occurred during daylight hours and it appears jewelry was stolen.  Residents are encouraged to report suspicious activity and loud, suspicious bangs (like a door being broken down) to the police department.

properties.Details: At approximately 12:28 pm this date, Madison Police responded to the 100 block of S Brooks St. reference a burglary.  Upon arrival in the area they located the above arrested party being detained by a citizen.  Investigation determined that the arrested party had been helping to clean apartments on the 4th floor of an apartment building.  At some point he left the 4th floor and went to the 1st floor of the building where he entered an unlocked apartment.  A student with her father's help was actually moving into the apartment at the time.  The father told police he entered the apartment and noted the suspect.  He also noted that his wallet (father's) which had been left in the apartment was on the floor and the cash was gone.  At this point Wilson fled out of the apartment with the father in pursuit.  The father was able to catch Wilson and detain him until police arrived.  There were no injuries reported.  The suspect was arrested and conveyed to the Dane County Jail.

Although no items were taken from the house this time, the same residence had been burglarized approximately two weeks earlier.  The suspects were taken to the Juvenile Reception Center and charged with the burglary.

properties.Arrested: 3 male juveniles, all 3 are 14 years old, all of Madison, all taken to the Dane County Juvenile Reception Center with charges related to the burglary and OMVWOC.
properties.Details: On 10/30/06, at 11:56 a.m., West District officers were dispatched to a residence on Hammersley Rd. reference a residential burglary.  Although the suspects were gone, information was aired about them and that vehicles had been stolen from the residence.  The residents were gone at the time of the burglary, but neighbors and a landscaper assisted police officers.  Other officers and detectives were involved and thanks to their efforts, the vehicles were recovered and the suspects apprehended.  The suspects, all juveniles have been implicated in a string of burglaries(8 of them) which have occurred over the last 2 weeks.  In these, 3 vehicles and 2 weapons(rifles) were stolen.  These items have been recovered.  It should be mentioned that their mode of operation was to ring doorbells or knock on doors looking to see if the residents were home.

properties.Arrested: A male Hispanic, mid 30's, 5'06", average build, last seen wearing a beanie, black hooded sweatshirt, blue jeans, and brown boots. He had acne or scarring on his face. Status: still at large
properties.Victim: Female, 19 yrs old, of MadisonNot injured
properties.Details: On 11/01/06, at 1:17 a.m., officers were dispatched to an apartment on the 100 blk. of N. Brooks St., reference an unknown male inside the apartment with a knife.  Once officers arrived, they found the patio door slightly open, the apartment was cleared and the suspect was no longer there.  The victim stated that she had fallen asleep on the couch with all the lights on and that she had left the patio door unlocked.  The victim advised that she woke up and noticed an unknown man kneeling next to her holding a knife in his left hand, although not in a threatening manner. The victim pretended that she was still asleep by closing her eyes, but she then felt the suspect's hand touching one of her breasts over her clothing. The victim then jumped off the couch and started running toward one of the bedrooms screaming and yelling that there was someone in the house. There were other roommates in the house but everybody else was sleeping at the time of the incident. The suspect apparently exited the residence at this point. A search of the area was not successful in locating the suspect. However, a security guard recovered a backpack belonging to a friend of one of the victim's roommates and also a laptop computer belonging to another of the victim's roommates, not too far from the apartment.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is alerting residents in the downtown area to a high volume of burglaries that have occurred since the beginning of the school year.  Initially officers took reports in which the suspect(s) entered through an unlocked door or window to steal laptops and ipods.  Within the last few weeks, reports have come in where force, breaking a window, etc. was used to gain entry into an apartment or house in the downtown area.  From 10/31-11/10 officers took 11 separate burglary reports in which mostly electronics were stolen, ranging from DVD's to CD's to laptops and ipods.  The majority of these burglaries occurred west of the Capitol, in the downtown area within student housing.  Additionally, over 25 laptops have been stolen since September and that does not include reports that have not been entered yet into the records system.  The Madison Police Department is actively investigating this problem and recognizes this is a nation-wide issue.  The Madison Police Department reminds the community that laptops, ipods and other electronic items are easy targets for thieves.  To protect your possessions please keep the following in mind:a) don't keep unattended valuables in plain viewb) record your driver's license/State on your valuables, not your Social Security numberc) lock all doors and windowsd) back up all important documents on disks stored separatelye) report suspicious activity (some burglars have been caught in the house saying they were contractors or workers "and must have got the address wrong")f) if storing valuables in your car, put them in the trunkg) have a sign-in system or video in your buildingh) obtain a lock and cable if you do need to leave your laptop unattended.

properties.Arrested: Daryl W. Chatfield, age 53, Madison, WI.  CHARGES: Burglary, Probation Violation, currently being held in the Dane County Jail
properties.Victim: Resident of the 600-blk of Pine St.
properties.Details: At approx. 8:03 p.m. on 11/23/06, Madison police officers responded to a report of a possible burglary in the 600-blk of Pine St.  On arrival officers observed a suspect leaving the area and were able to take him into custody in a backyard.  AFter investigation, officers determined that the suspect had been involved in a residential burglary in the 600-blk of Pine St.  Officers determined that the residents had been away for the Thanksgiving holiday.  Mr. Chatfield is currently in the Dane County Jail on the above charges.As always the Madison Police Department encourages people to take note of suspicious activity and call the police immediately if any is observed.

properties.Arrested: Garrett Haselton, 17, Madison: Burglary, Carrying a Concealed Weapon, Theft
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department has been investigating residential burglaries in the Violet Lane/Daffodil Lane area on the east side for several weeks.  In some cases entry is made or attempted and jewelry, electronics, DVD's and such have been stolen.  Homeowners have been helpful to police in providing information of suspicious activity, people and vehicles in the area.  A suspect drawing was even produced after a resident confronted the suspect.  On 11/30/06 an alert neighbor witnessed Haselton snooping around a house and called police.  Officers and detectives worked the house with the homeowner who returned and noticed things of value missing.  A suspect description and vehicle description was aired to other officers.  By chance an officer spotted a suspect vehicle and noticed the driver appeared to match the description.  A traffic stop was made and stolen goods were located in the vehicle.  Detectives are working this case with the hope of solving most of the residential burglaries that have occurred in this area of the city.  Haselton was arrested and transported to the Dane Co Jail without incident.

properties.Arrested: Eric Sturkey, 35, Madison:  Burglary, Possession of Drug Paraphernalia
properties.Details: On 12/11/06 at approximately 12:50 p.m. Madison Police responded to a residential burglary in the 500 block of W. Dayton.  One roommate was asleep while the home he lived in was being burglarized.  A second roommate came home from classes to see two individuals (Sturkey) inside their home stealing a laptop and video game equipment.  The roommate who came home from class screamed and gave chase to the fleeing suspects while the second roommate called 9-1-1.  Both suspects fled and a foot chase ensued.  One roommate caught Sturkey and detained him until police arrived. The other suspect fled.  While this was occurring, officers responded to at least two other locations in the Central District for burglary complaints.  In one instance a resident interrupted the burglary and the suspect asked "is this (blank)'s home" and when learning "it wasn't" quickly fled.  Those reports are not available at this time.  Entry into these homes has been through unlocked doors or windows.  Again, as good practice and in the interest of sound public safety, it is strongly recommended to lock your doors and window to help prevent crime.  There have been numerous reports of laptop and electronic equipment stolen in the student housing areas of the Mifflin/Dayton corridor.

properties.Arrested: possibly 2-3 males
properties.Details: On 12/10/06 at approximately 7:07 p.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to a report of a home invasion in the 1000 block of Seminole Hwy.  It was learned that an elderly female was in her home, watching tv with a caregiver, when one individual appeared in the living room.  The resident was surprised to see this unknown individual and threatened to call police.  Upon reaching for the phone, the suspect grabbed it and another phone the victim had reached for, in order for her not to make a phone call.  An unknown amount of other males came from upstairs and left the home with the original suspect.  This remains an ongoing investigation by the Madison Police Department as detectives are following up on this case.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 12/10/06 at approximately 7:20 a.m. a Madison Police Officer took a residential burglary report.  A window was pushed in to gain access to an apartment.  The thief made out with a UW Men's National Championship Hockey Ring, 2 laptops, portable DVD and other items.  If anyone has information about this crime, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Since February, the Madison Police Department has been investigating a series of residential burglaries in the Regent and Dungeon-Monroe Neighborhoods.  The burglaries have shown a consistent pattern of entry through unlocked doors and in the same general area.  To date seven residential burglaries have been reported.  In some cases citizens heard suspicious behavior or noticed an attempted break in, to report it later to police.  The Madison Police Department needs citizens of these neighborhoods to report suspicious activity (including dogs barking at unusual hours of the night) to police (9-1-1) for us to investigate.

properties.Arrested: Arrest Person: Laura A. Walker, 36-year-old female of Blanchardville, WI Charges:  Burglary, 2nd Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety, Criminal Damage To Property & Intimidation Of A Witness
properties.Details: On March 31st, 2007 at approximately 2:06am, Madison Police were dispatched reference a 911 disconnect to the 400 block of N. Sherman Avenue.  After police arrived, they contacted a 35-year-old male of Madison Wisconsin who advised he was the victim of a burglary.  Responding officers investigated the incident, and the victim stated that he was awaken from his sleep by the sounds of what he believed to be someone forcing their way into his residence.  He struggled with the suspect, was subsequently knocked to the floor and strangled.   Walker threatened to kill the victim if he called police to report the incident.The Madison Police Department along with the assistance of The Green County Sheriff’s Department arrested Walker on 3/31/07  shortly after 2pm.  Walker was booked into the Dane County Jail on the above charges, pending review of The Dane County District Attorney’s Office.  A criminal complaint will be on file for additional details related to all specified charges listed.  Laura Walker was employed as a Madison Police Officer from May of 1999 until she resigned in December 2006.

properties.Arrested: Male, black ski mask, dark blue hoodie, blue jeansMale, blue ski mask, dark brown sweatshirt, blue jeans
properties.Details: On 4/9/07 at 12:58 p.m. Madison Police responded to a home invasion in the 1400 block of Droster Rd.  Officers learned the female victim had returned to her residence to find two males inside, wearing ski masks.  The female was bound, eventually broke free after the suspects left and called police. The victim was treated at the scene by MFD for minor injuries, but was not conveyed to a hospital.  It is believed that this was a targeted address as this remains under investigation by the Madison Police Department.

properties.Arrested: 3 black males wearing ski masks
properties.Details: On 4/10/07 at 10:45 a.m. Madison Police responded to a home invasion on N. Pinckney St.  It was learned that a victim awoke to three males who entered the residence demanding goods before fleeing the area.  Stolen was money and electronic equipment.  No injuries were reported.  It does appear that this was a targeted address by the suspects.  This remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: Arrested Suspect: Nathan J Castner, 20 years old, UW Student
properties.Details: On 4/29/07, at approximately 2:30am, officers were sent to the 100 block of Langdon Street for a possible burglary in progress.  Officers found a security door with a broken pane of glass, and learned that a possible suspect had fled from the building.  Officers then located Castner a short time later on W. Gilman Street.  Stolen items were located on the suspect that matched what was taken from the apartment.  Another burglary on Langdon was reported while Castner was being transported to the Dane County Jail in which he might be the suspect.  The investigation is ongoing.

properties.Arrested: Juveniles
properties.Details: Over the past few weeks Madison Police have seen a rash of residential burglaries occurring in the North and East Districts. A large percentage of these burglaries have occurred during daytime hours when residents are not at home. Entry is usually gained through the screen of a window that has been left open or an unlocked door. Juveniles are knocking or ringing the doorbell to determine if someone is home.  They then look for an open door or window and remove or cut the screen.Madison Police want to remind residents to lock doors and windows when away from home, even for short periods.  Also close garage doors and lock doors when working outside in your backyard. It only takes minutes to become the victim of a burglary.Please keep an eye on your neighborhood and your neighbor's residences, especially if you know they are not home. If you see anyone suspicious or anything out of the ordinary it is important that you call 911 so we can respond. We need the involvement of the community to help us identify and apprehend those responsible.

UPDATE(Tuesday, June 5) There was another similar burglary in the East District in the past 24 hours, and two more attempted burglaries in the East District during the same time period.------------------------------------Over the past few weeks Madison Police have seen a rash of residential burglaries occurring in the North and East Districts. A large percentage of these burglaries have occurred during daytime hours when residents are not at home. Entry is usually gained through the screen of a window that has been left open or an unlocked door. Juveniles are knocking or ringing the doorbell to determine if someone is home.  They then look for an open door or window and remove or cut the screen.Madison Police want to remind residents to lock doors and windows when away from home, even for short periods.  Also close garage doors and lock doors when working outside in your backyard. It only takes minutes to become the victim of a burglary.Please keep an eye on your neighborhood and your neighbor's residences, especially if you know they are not home. If you see anyone suspicious or anything out of the ordinary it is important that you call 911 so we can respond. We need the involvement of the community to help us identify and apprehend those responsible.

properties.Arrested: Male, 15, Madison
properties.Details: As previously released, the north and east side of Madison had a rash of residential burglaries. The suspect would ring doorbells to see if anyone was home and if not, search the house for the easiest path inside (unlocked doors, open windows, etc).  Madison Police warned this part of the city of the rash of break-ins and to be observant and notify police of suspicious behavior.  This warning paid off.  On Sunday 6/10 a suspect was arrested and that male was taken into juvenile custody.  After being released, the suspect began to commit more burglaries via the same method.  On Monday an alert resident noticed this male suspect in the neighborhood, ringing doorbells.  As the suspect walked around the house, the observant neighbor called police.  The suspect was caught inside the house, befriending a pitbull.  The juvenile is now in an unsecured location under court order not to leave.  At this point, the Madison Police Department is investigating how many burglaries this individual may be responsible for.

On Tuesday July 31st Madison Police were called to a N. Seventh Street residence for a report of a burglary. It was apparent that the front door had been kicked in. Stereo and TV equipment had been stolen. Also missing was a 13-year-old tabby cat. It's unknown if the thief was also a cat burglar, or if the tabby scooted out when the crook broke in.

properties.Suspect: Ashley D. Weaver, age 19, MadisonTentative charges: Burglary, Probation Violation, & Bail Jumping.
properties.Details: On Sunday October 28th, around 7:36 a.m., a Madison police officer was dispatched to a parking complaint. While responding the officer was next notified of a burglary in progress. The address of the burglary was just two blocks from the officer's location. The officer arrived and found Mr. Weaver inside an East Johnson street residence. Weaver had a duffle bag containing items that were not his. He is being looked at as a suspect in other recent area burglaries

properties.Suspect: Roosevelt Price, Age 42, MadisonArrested for Burglary
properties.Details: On Monday October 29th at 10:50 a.m. Madison police, along with Shorewood police, responded to Bluff Street. An alert neighbor had witnessed a burglar break the window of the home next-door. As officers arrived the caller indicated the criminal was still inside the residence. Officers set up a perimeter. A short time later Mr. Price ran out of a porch door and down the driveway. He was stopped at gunpoint. Money and jewelry from the home was found in his possession. Madison police would like to thank the concerned citizen for getting officers quickly to the scene, and Shorewood police for helping establish a secure perimeter.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator #1 is described as a male, white, 25-35, 6'00", 250 to 300 pounds, medium length dark brown greasy hair, goatee or beard, disheveled looking, wearing black Columbia type coat.Perpetrator #2 is described as a male, white, 23 to 28 years old, 6'2", short blonde hair wearing a gray sweatshirt.
properties.Details: Around 10:42 p.m. on Saturday February 9th Madison Police responded to an attempted burglary on North Frances Street. Two women, ages 19 and 20, were exiting an apartment bathroom when they saw the two perpetrators walking out of a bedroom. They confronted the men, and they took off, but not before the victims could wrestle a backpack off of perp #1. In it were items stolen during a burglary that had occurred a short time earlier in the same neighborhood.  Among recovered items were a video game player, and video games. Another neighbor reported hearing a "soft" knock on the door during the same time period. Shortly after the knock a guy matching the description of perp #2 started to walk in. He quickly departed after realizing someone was in the apartment.The MPD would like to remind residents to lock their doors -- even when they are at home.

properties.Suspect: 5 juveniles, ages from 13-17years old4 male/blacks1 male/whiteall Madison residents
properties.Victim: Various homeowners on the north side of Madison
properties.Details: Five juveniles were detained by Madison Police Officers after being observed fleeing from a north side residence after kicking in the back door.  The home owner called police, and while looking for the multiple suspects, officers received another call from a different north side residence reporting another burglary.  While investigating the second burglary, officers located and detained five male juveniles.  One juvenile had stolen property from the first burglary on his person.  Dets. and officers are continuing to investigate these burglaries.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator was described as a male, white, 6'2", heavy build, wearing glasses, a lightweight jacket, and blue jeans.
properties.Details: On Friday evening Madison Police took a report from a resident on Acewood Blvd. who said that minutes earlier, around 7:47 p.m., someone broke into her home. The woman says she had been sleeping, and awoke when someone started knocking loudly at the front door. Next she heard a crashing noise. She walked to the foyer to see what had happened and ended up confronting an unknown man. He walked back out of the front door and left the area. Responding officers determined the locked door had been forced open. Nothing was taken from the residence.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, 50's, 6'2", medium build with black hair and a possible fat lip or other mouth injury. He was last seen wearing glasses, and a brown coat.
properties.Details: On March 30th at 6:09 p.m. Madison Police were dispatched to a home on Elinor Street where the owner had just punched a possible burglar. The victim says he was in the bathroom when he heard someone knocking loudly at the backdoor. Before he could respond the door was being forced open. The homeowner confronted the perpetrator asking, "What are you doing in my house?" He did not wait for an answer punching the intruder in the mouth. Next he grabbed the stranger by his jacket and tossed him into a shelving unit. The man then ran from the house and was last seen in the area of Claire Street.

(UPDATE) Trixie has been found and returned to her owner, who is now not sure whether she was stolen or just got out of the house. All is well that ends well.------------------------------------------------On April 10th Madison Police responded to a home on Buckingham Lane from which a five-month-old Pomeranian female named "Trixie" had been stolen. A resident told police he heard the backdoor to his home open around the noon hour and assumed it was his wife. He later discovered his male Pomeranian barking outside of the back door. This seemed strange since he had not let his two dogs out. He also said his Pomeranians are inseparable, and never leave each other's side. At this point he realized someone had stolen his female Pomeranian. Anyone with information is urged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

A Madison West Lawn Avenue resident reported his $8,000 dollar Trek racing bike was stolen from a three-season porch on April 12th or 13th. The citizen indicated he had forgotten to bring the bicycle inside his home - which is his normal procedure - on the afternoon of the 12th. The bike is a '07 Trek Madone 6.5SSL. It is black with silver letters. Anyone with information on this crime is urged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Suspect: Byron C. Shaw, age 18, DeerfieldJonathan J. Taylor, age 18, MadisonMale, age 16, MadisonThe three suspects were arrested and all tentatively charged with Party to a Crime - Burglary. Mr. Shaw and Mr. Taylor were also tentatively charged with Obstructing.
properties.Details: Around 11:43 Sunday night Madison police were called to the 500 block of Diving Hawk Trail after a homeowner reported a burglary in progress at his residence. He said someone was ringing the doorbell, while - at the same time - there was banging going on at the back of the house, and a rattling at a backdoor. Responding officers found a back window had been broken. The suspects evidently were scared off and did not enter the home. Thanks to information provided by the victim, and other neighbors, police were able to pick up the trail of the fleeing suspects and arrest them. Two were taken into custody on Settlement Drive, and the third was found hiding behind some homes on Lone Eagle Drive.

properties.Suspect: Wilkie L. Johnson, age 43, No Permanent AddressMr. Johnson was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, Criminal Damage to Property, Resisting an Officer, Obstructing an Officer, Unlawful Trespass, and a Probation Violation.
properties.Address: 237 Langdon Street (Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity house)
properties.Details: On Wednesday, around 6:42 p.m., Madison Police officers were called to the Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity house on Langdon Street for a report of a burglar inside the residence. Members of the MPD were on the scene in less than one minute, and did see a man inside the campus area fraternity house. Officers ordered him to come out, and he tried to flee from them by going out of a side door. The suspect was found to be in possession of an iPod that smelled of smoke, and appeared to be water damaged. He was arrested on a volley of tentative charges. The Sigma Phi Epsilon house suffered heavy fire damage earlier this week, and remains fenced off to the public.

properties.Suspect: Morris E. Brown, Jr., age 23, MadisonMr. Brown was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, Possession of a Firearm by a Felon, Possession of Marijuana, Criminal Damage to Property, and a Probation Hold.
properties.Details: Around 1:20 a.m. on Tuesday morning Madison Police Officers were dispatched to the same residence where shots had been fired into a sliding glass door two nights prior. The resident was not home at the time of this morning's call, but a neighbor heard the sound of breaking glass, and called to report a burglary in progress. The witness saw a man carrying a bag and leaving his neighbor's unoccupied apartment prior to the arrival of officers. The witness was able to provide officers with information about a getaway car, and that information led police to an apartment in the 3700 block of East Karstens Drive. The suspect was located in that apartment and arrested for the burglary that had just occurred. The shooting from July 6th (see Incident Report for case #2008-188821) is still under investigation. A .22-calibre shell casing was recovered from that crime scene. Mr. Brown was in possession of a .22-calibre semiautomatic pistol at the time of his arrest.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator #1 is a male, Hispanic, 6' - 6'2", 19 - 23 years old, heavy build, blue eyes, brown hair, wearing khaki green t-shirt, blue jeans and tennis shoes.Perpetrator #2 is a male, Hispanic, 6'2" - 6'3", 150 - 180 lbs., 20- 25 years old, thin build, goatee, wearing printed shirt with flames on it, blue jeans, and tennis shoes.Perpetrator #3 is a female, Hispanic, 5'10" to 6', 18-23 years old, 200-240 pounds, long brown hair, wearing long gray t-shirt, blue jeans, and tennis shoes.
properties.Details: Shortly before noon on Tuesday a resident who lives on Alder Road called Madison Police about a burglary that was in progress at a neighbor's home. Officers arrived to find that a back door had been forced open, and a jewelry box inside the home was open. The resident who called dispatch gave a good description of the burglars and the van in which they had been traveling. But it was the resident's wife who provided the best leads. She used a high-end digital camera to take some very good photographs of the criminals, and their van. Investigators are currently using these images with hopes of developing suspects. The Madison Police Department cannot keep the peace without the help of the citizenry – it takes a team effort – and in several recent cases, including this one, it is heartening to see so many taking a stake in the community in which they live.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator #1 is described as a male, white, 25, short blonde hair, wearing a white t-shirt, and light colored pants.Perpetrator #2 is described as male.Both were last seen fleeing in a smaller silver SUV, which the victim said looked sort of like a RAV4.
properties.Details: Early Friday morning, around 3:41, Madison Police responded to an attempted burglary on Pebble Beach Drive. The homeowner awoke after hearing someone messing around at his sliding glass door. The victim also spotted a probable accomplice on the front lawn. The perpetrators were scared off and fled in a smaller silver SUV, which the victim thought looked similar to a RAV4.

properties.Suspect: Curtis Anthony Bonds, age 21, Sun PrairieMr. Bonds was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, and a Probation Hold.
properties.Details: On Sunday morning, at 12:28 a.m., Madison Police were called to an apartment on Webb Avenue following a burglary. A man in his 30's said someone had cut a screen and entered his residence stealing small electronics, cigarettes, cash, and two bottles of cologne. About 20 to 25 minutes after an officer cleared the scene, another call came in from the same victim. He had been at the Mobil Mart, 3019 East Washington Avenue, when he saw a man come in with some items stolen during the burglary. A clerk said the suspect was attempting to trade a remote control, and a electronic bartender device for a cigar. The officer confronted the suspect and found he also had a package of DVDs  taken in the burglary.

properties.Suspect: Suspect: M/B approximately 6'00, 130-140lbs slender build last seen wearing dark clothing.
properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: On 8/26/2008, The Madison Police Department was dispatched to the 3200 block of Sunbrook Road reference a residential burglary.  Officers would arrive on scene shortly after 1:30am to canvass the area in search of the suspect.  The 18-year-old female victim was in the kitchen area of her residence when she heard what sounded like someone moving quietly around the house.  Upon further inspection, she would confront an unknown male subject in the hallway of the residence wearing dark clothing.  After demanding he “Get out of the house”, she would return to the kitchen to get a pair of scissors for protection.  The suspect would run past the victim, down the stairs, and into the garage attempting to flee the scene.  As other family members were awakened by the commotion, the suspect would proceed to break out a garage window, and escaped the residence.  No weapon was ever seen.  Police processed the scene and searched for items of evidentiary value.  A window screen was located on the residence that had been cut, and this possibly allowed access to the suspect through this initial entry point.  Motive for entry into this residence is unknown, but The Madison Police Department ask that windows, doors, and any entryway into your homes be checked on a routine basis and appropriately locked.  Any person with information about this or any other crime should contact The Madison Police Department or Crime Stoppers 608 266-6014 immediately.PO Howard Payne

properties.Suspect: Fontaine D. Dillard, age 21, MadisonMr. Dillard was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, and casual possession of Marijuana.
properties.Details: On Saturday, August 30, 2008, Madison Police responded to an apartment in the 400 block of West Wilson Street. Residents had just returned home to find they had been burglarized, and that someone had cut the screen to an open living room window to get inside. Money and valuables, including a wristwatch, had been stolen. A few minutes later a dispatcher advised there was a suspicious man in the 500 block of West Wilson Street. He appeared to be checking doors on houses. The suspect was stopped and arrested after stolen items, including the aforementioned watch, were found in his pockets.

properties.Suspect: William M. Waddingham, age 51, no permanent addressMr. Waddingham was arrested and tentatively charged with Attempted Burglary, and a Probation Violation.
properties.Details: Early Friday morning, around 1:08 a.m., Madison Police were notified of a burglary in progress. A homeowner in the 500 block of North Seventh Street could hear someone trying to break a back window after removing a screen. Officers arrived in minutes and spotted a man going southbound on North Seventh. He was carrying a blue bag, and wearing a backpack. The suspect told an officer, "You got me." He said he needed money and that was why he was trying to get in the house.

properties.Suspect: James Stewart, Jr., age 48, MadisonMr. Stewart was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary. He also had warrants for Retail Theft, Bail Jumping, and Non-Support
properties.Details: On Wednesday afternoon, at 4:30 p.m., several Madison Police officers responded to a residence in the 900 block of Drake Street for a report of a burglary in progress. A neighbor provided dispatch with the description of a man seen leaving the home. Officers were quickly on the scene and took him into custody. It was later determined that a resident had likely interrupted the burglary as a laptop computer was found in a bag inside the home. The resident had come in through a back door, and the suspect fled out of a front door. The resident walked into the home and saw broken glass, and went to a neighbor's home to call 911. That neighbor was the same person who had just seen the departing suspect. He gave a good description of the suspect, and a solid direction of travel, and these leads enabled officers to make the arrest.

properties.Suspect: Samuel L. Coffee III, age 39, no permanent addressMr. Coffee was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, and six counts of Bail Jumping.
properties.Details: On Wednesday night, two Madison Police officers were on routine patrol when they were dispatched to a burglary that was happening in the 500 block of State Street. A man reported that he had been inside his apartment when he heard someone outside, in the area of a fire escape, trying to cut or rip his window screen. The resident looked out, and saw the suspect. He yelled at him to stop, but the suspect kept on trying to remove the screen. After accomplishing that task, the suspect then started to try to remove a window fan. Frightened, the victim fled his apartment and called police. Officers tracked the suspect down a couple of blocks up State Street toward the State Capitol. A backpack containing his identification was found outside the victim's window. The arresting officer reported the suspect's breath smelled of intoxicants, and his speech was slurred. A data check indicated the man has six open misdemeanor cases with restrictions not to consume alcohol, or commit further crimes.

properties.Suspect: Clifton Jones, age 20, MadisonMr. Jones was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, and Attempted Burglary.
properties.Details: On October 1, 2008, around 12:35 a.m., Madison Police officers responded to the 800 block of Mayfair Avenue for a report of a possible burglary in progress. A resident reported a stranger had entered her kitchen as she and her husband were in the living room watching TV. She yelled, and the suspect fled. Officers later determined he had also accessed a neighboring residence by removing a window screen. No one was home at the time of that burglary, and a couple of rooms were ransacked. Among items stolen was a DVD, which was found in the burglar's pocket as he attempted to flee the area.

properties.Suspect: see incident report with same case # posted 10-7
properties.Arrested: Juvenile,Male, Madison Resident charged with residential burglary
properties.Details: The caller reported someone had just broken into their house. The caller confronted two suspects climbing out of a window, who then dropped a stereo and fled on foot towards Raymond Road. The investigation led to the arrest of Floyd and a malejuvenile. No further information at this time.
