properties.Suspect: Taurus S. Bowdry, age 34, MadisonMr. Bowdry was arrested and tentatively charged with Residential Burglary, Battery to a Law Enforcement Officer, Resisting a Law Enforcement Officer, and a Parole Hold.
properties.Details: On Monday afternoon, around 5:42 p.m., a Madison Police officer was parked in James Madison Park - typing reports. The officer heard citizens shouting about a suspect who was on the run with a stolen laptop computer. The officer saw there was a foot chase nearby and drove - red lights and siren - in the direction of the pursuit. Next the officer observed the stolen laptop was now in the hands of the guy who was just chasing the suspect. A witnessed flagged the officer down and said the suspect was now running toward Lake Mendota at the far end of the park. The officer drove and spotted the culprit. This became a foot chase, which ended when the suspect arrived at a six-foot chain link fence. He was attempting to climb it when the officer grabbed his jacket and pants and pulled him down. The suspect and officer struggled, and the suspect broke free after elbowing the officer in the chest. Another citizen - a former wrestler with 13 years of grappling experience - next tackled the suspect. This citizen later told officers he knew if he put an elbow near the side of the suspect's face that the suspect would be pinned and unable to move. A backup officer arrived on the scene and the citizen stepped back. The suspect continued to struggle until being hit with an Electronic Control Device Taser. He had more than 500 cash in his socks. Officers also recovered a pair of brown gloves. The original victim told police he was in his apartment, with opera music playing on his laptop computer, when he heard some rustling at the window. It is near a table, and on top of that table, was the laptop. The victim stood up and saw the suspect reach through a freshly cut window screen and grab his computer. The victim said others joined him as he chased the suspect down. He got his laptop back, and this was just about the time the officer started pursuing the suspect.

properties.Suspect: Nathen F. properties.Details: On Monday afternoon, around 4:10 p.m., a Madison woman was in the basement of her home watching TV when she heard noise coming from the upstairs. She went to investigate, and saw two suspects crawling out of a bedroom window. She had left it open to let in the fresh air of a warm October day. The woman yelled at the suspects, and they ran off, leaving some of her family's stereo equipment just outside of the window. Several Madison Police officers swarmed the area and they were able to find - and arrest - the suspects.

Two white males came up to the front steps and then went around to the side of the house. They were entering the house when the male juvenile who was in the residence took a BB gun and shot one of the males, possibly in the shoulder. The suspects then fled from the area on foot. The juvenile male had called his sister and then his father. The father then called the police. Suspect #1 described as male white, 18 years old, 6 feet, 210 pounds, wearing a white winter hat, a black long sleeve shirt and blue jeans. Suspect #2 was described as a white male, 18 years old, wearing a white short sleeve t-shirt, blue jeans, black shoes and it appeared he had something metallic in his hand.

properties.Suspect: Ryan K. properties.Details: On October 10, 2008, at 9:15 a.m., Madison Police responded to a Falmouth Court for an attempted burglary. A resident reported being in the basement when he heard the front door open. The citizen went upstairs to discover the door was now open. He also spotted a suspect outside his patio door trying to get in. When that suspect saw the resident he ran towards the front of the house. The victim then watched as both the suspect – who had been at the rear of the home - took off with a second suspect – who had come from the front of the home. Both suspects were on foot heading toward Park Ridge Drive. The victim quickly called police with a description of the suspects, and responding officers were able to locate and arrest them.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, 5'5", 150 lbs., thin, with short hair.
properties.Details: On October 13th, at 4:28 p.m., a woman reported there had been an attempted burglary at her apartment over the past weekend. She says she yelled at a man who had gotten into her apartment around 3:00 a.m. Saturday morning. She says the perpetrator ran out a back door. The victim says she has a pet bunny that thumps its' foot when someone is in, or around, her residence. And it was the thumping of the bunny's foot that woke her up, and enabled her to quickly scare off the intruder. Nothing was missing from her home.

properties.Details: At approximately 1:25pm on 4-13-05, Madison Officers responded to a report of an accident in the 1200 block of N. Sherman. The accident occurred as the wheelchair-bound female was crossing in a crosswalk in front of the pickup truck.  The female driver of the pickup truck was slowly exiting the parking lot, but did not see the woman in front of her.  The impact knocked over the wheelchair, injuring the victim.  The victim had a small dog riding in her lap at the time of the incident.  The pickup truck was a large and high vehicle, and apparently the driver did not see the person in the wheelchair.  The pet dog was not injured.   CORRECTION -- UPDATE---------- The dog involved was a 50 pound service dog(lab) walking next to the wheelchair. The dog was on a leash.The leash was attached to the wheelchair. The dog was not injured.

properties.Details: At approximately 10:50 am, Madison Police reponded to Woodman's East regarding an accident.  Upon arrival, officers learned that a ten-year-old male had been the driver of the involved vehicle.  The vehicle was a van that belonged to the ten-year-old's family.  It had been serviced at the oil change facility and was parked outside of the business.  The ten-year-old entered the vehicle, got in the driver's seat and started the vehicle.  He then backed up through the glass overhead door and crashed into another vehicle that was being serviced.  It was at this time the employee was injured.  After hitting the first car, the ten-year-old put the vehicle in drive and proceeded 68 feet into a parked pickup truck which was gassing at one of the pumps.  The pickup truck took the brunt of the impact, and the pump was not damaged.  An off-duty Dane County deputy was able to reach in and turn the vehicle off.  At this time, there is no additional information.  The young driver was released to his family.

properties.Details: On 6/21/2005 at approximately 9:35 p.m. Madison Police responded to a report of a juvenile being dragged by a car in the 1600 block of N. Mendota Ave.  It was learned that the juvenile had been walking when an acquaintance had pulled up, stopped the vehicle and asked for help with some stereo components.  The victim assessed the situation and tried to help.  After the discussion on what may have been wrong ensued, the driver sped off with the victim holding on.  The victim did not let go, as he feared for his safety.  The passengers in the car were pleading with the driver to stop.  Eventually the victim let go when he was near some grass, in an attempt to let go safely.  Officers measured the drag to be approximately 15/100 of a mile, from part of Lien Rd to the 1600 block of Mendota Ave.  The victim did not seek medical attention.  This incident is being investigated by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with additional information is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Just prior to the crash, neighbors heard the sound of a vehicle accelerating rapidly.  It is believed that speed and alcohol may be factors in this crash.  The driver was wearing his seatbelt and the airbag deployed.  The vehicle is an older model Buick Skylark.  It appears the vehicle was headed westbound on East Dean Avenue when the crash happened. properties.Details: Officers were dispatched to a report of a pedestrian hit by a pick up truck on Highway 30 near N. Fair Oaks Avenue.  Officers arrived to find the pedestrian obviously deceased at the scene.  Madison Fire Department personnel had to extricate the deceased from the crash.  The driver of the truck involved in the collision had been eastbound on Highway 30 when three pedestrians began running across the highway.  The driver could not avoid the collision.  The driver immediately stopped and attempted to render aid while his passenger jumped out of the truck and yelled at the other two pedestrians to stop and even tried to catch them as they fled.  They yelled back that they had to catch a bus and refused to stop, leaving their companion at the scene and continuing to flee.  The driver of the pick up truck was fully cooperative with the accident investigation and several other witnesses also stayed to assist.  The accident remains under investigation.  The driver of the truck and his passenger were uninjured and were wearing seat belts at the time of the crash. Alcohol was not a factor for the driver; toxicology results pending on the deceased.  The driver was released after giving a statement to the police. Investigators are still attempting to contact the other two pedestrians.

properties.Arrested: Male, 14, Madison, 8th grade: Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Consent, Operating While Suspended, Safety Belt Use Required.  Male, 13, Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Consent.
properties.Details: On 9/24/06 at approximately 6:34 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 1300 block of Loreen Dr for a vehicle crash.  Through the investigation officers learned that the two males described above had stolen a car and crashed it into a parked vehicle on Loreen Dr.  The two males, along with five other friends, were in West Towne Mall when they noticed a set of keys next to a candy machine.  One key was for a KIA vehicle, so the group took the key to several KIA's in the mall parking lot until they found a match.  In doing so, the seven individuals stole the KIA and drove around for two hours.  They dumped some personal belongings out in a dumpster, which officers recovered for the victim.  Eventually they were traveling on Loreen and noticed a girl they recognized.  In waving to the girl, the driver lost sight of the road and crashed into a parked, unoccupied vehicle (Toyota Tercel) and in doing so moved it over 10 feet.  Everyone inside the KIA fled on foot.  One person was injured because when the crash occurred he wasn't wearing a seatbelt and hit his head into the windshield.  Fire/Rescue responded and determined the injury to be minor and the juvenile was not transported to a hospital.

properties.Victim: 20 Year old male, treated at an area hospital for non-life threatening(Head/leg)injuries.
properties.Details: On 10/09/06 at approximately 9:48am, The Madison Police Department responded to an accident with injuries at 200 N. Park Street.  Dispatchers conveyed to responding officers, based on numerous calls, that there was a car vs. moped collision.  Upon arrival, The Madison Fire Department and Madison Police found an unconscious 20 year old male (who had been operating the moped) with head/leg injuries after initially traveling south bound on N.Park.  After officers investigated this matter, it was determined that the moped operator made an indiscriminate left turn (east bound) and was impacted by an oncoming car traveling north bound on N.Park Street.  The 20-year-old moped operator did not yield to oncoming traffic, and after being initially impacted by the car, subsequently impacted the windshield of that vehicle.  The driver of the car did not sustain any injuries whatsoever.  The moped operator was cited/found at fault for this accident upon the completion of the investigation. The Madison Police Department continues to alert all roadway operators to pay particular attention at busy intersections, and to use extra precautions when making decisions of crossing the pathway of oncoming vehicles.  Based on information we have at this time, no life threatening injures resulted in this matter, but taking additional steps to evaluate every action is always the safest way to proceed.PO Howard Payne

properties.Details: At 10:15p on 12/25/06, Madison Police and Madison Fire/Rescue responded to the scene of a motor vehicle accident on S. Whitney Way at Hammersley Rd. Two vehicles, containing five occupants, were involved in the accident. All occupants of the vehicles were transported to area hospitals. One of the injured occupants, a 21 year old female, was later pronounced deceased. The driver of one of the vehicles was admitted to a local hospital with serious injuries. The driver of the other vehicle was also admitted to a local hospital for treatment of injuries received in the accident, and is being tentatively charged with Homocide by Intoxicated Use of a Motor Vehicle. Two other passengers were treated and released from the hospital. The intersection of S. Whitney Way and Hammersley Rd. was closed to traffic for approximately five hours while the accident scene was processed.Speed and alcohol are believed to be contributing factors in the accident.

properties.Arrested: See narrative below!
properties.Details: On Dec 25th, 2006 at approximately 10:15pm, Madison Police were dispatched to the 5700 blk of Hammersley Road & S. Whitney Way to an accident with injuries.  Officers arrived on scene and found 5 individuals that were all occupants of 2 vehicles that required immediate medical attention.  Investigators at the scene, taking into account witness statements and physical evidence, determined that a 2002 Chevy Impala was traveling east bound on Hammersley Road and impacted a 1998 BMW traveling south bound on S. Whitney Way.  As a result of the accident, the two occupants of the BMW {Brian P McNally 26-year-old male of Waunakee Wisconsin who sustained multiple internal injuries that are deemed as potentially life threatening & and Megan T. McNally 20-year-old female of Nashotah Wisconsin who sustained minor injuries} were both treated as a local hospital.  Brian McNally is still listed in critical condition.The Chevy Impala containing 3 passengers; Dedonta J Davis, 18-year-old male of Madison, WI who was treated for minor injuries at a local hospital & Rikita L. Lee, 21- year-old female of Madison who was ejected from the vehicle and pronounced dead at UW Hospital on 12/25/06 per the Office of the Dane County Coroner.  The driver of this vehicle Ian M. Bowers, 19-year-old male of Madison has been tentatively charged with Homicide By Intoxicated Use Of A Vehicle (Wis State Statue 940.09(1)(1) – Felony), but since this is an ongoing investigation additional charges could be imminent.  The Madison Police Department in conjunction with the Dane County District Attorney Office will continue to collaborate in determining what charges are most appropriate in this scenario. The Madison Police department would point to this tragic reminder that a combination of alcohol, excessive speed, and the lack of utilizing seat restraints contributed to the accident occurring and injuries having been sustained.  It goes without saying that with the New Year holiday quickly approaching, we would hope that all citizens of this city and abroad pay special attention to these all to important factors that resulted in a tragic event.   We would hope that everyone would make all concerted efforts to use sound judgment when operating a motor vehicle at all times.  People sometimes forget that all roadways can only remain safe if we personally take responsibility and follow simple rules relating to the safe operation of a motor vehicle.   **  The McNally family has no public comment to make at this time. We request that the press and other interested parties respect our privacy at this difficult time!  **PO Howard Payne

properties.Details: On July 1st at 2:04 a.m. Madison Police responded to a moped accident on campus. Witnesses report Mr. Schrack was eastbound on Langdon when he pulled into a driveway. Schrack flipped over the handlebars of the scooter as he entered the drive and his head hit a metal stake that was protruding from a wall. He was taken to a local hospital with a serious head injury.

Madison Police responded to the 6700 blk of Schroeder Road today reference a two-year-old child who had fallen from a moving vehicle.  Officers learned that the vehicle the child was traveling in made a turn onto Schroeder and during the turn, a door to the vehicle opened and the child fell out onto the roadway.  The child had not been properly restrained with an approved child safety restraint system.  The child was treated and released from an area hospital.  Madison Police would like to remind all drivers that children must be in a car seat until they reach age 4 and in a booster seat until they reach age 8.  The tiered structure that now applies as law:-Less than 1 year old, or less than 20 lbs. must be in a rear-facing child seat in the back seat (if so equipped) -Age 1 to age 4, or less than 40 lbs. must be in a forward-facing child seat in the back seat (if so equipped) -Age 4 to age 8, between 40-80 lbs., and no more than 4 ft. 9 ins. must be in a booster seat The driver was cited for "Child Safety Restraint System Required".

A fatal crash occurred Thursday on Mineral Point Rd. The driver of a motorcycle was westbound on Mineral Point Rd when he struck the side of an SUV leaving a driveway. The victim was conveyed by Fire Rescue to UW ER but did not survive. The name of the victim is not being released pending notification of family.Neither speed nor impairment were factors in the crash.

properties.Arrested: Marco Antonio Romero Toxqui, age 24, BellevilleTentative Charge:Homicide by the Intoxicated Use of a Motor Vehicle
properties.Address: Midvale Blvd/Mineral Point Road (UPDATED MONDAY MORNING)
properties.Victim: Vehicle 1: Three occupants: One (front passenger) was pronounced dead at local hospital (his name will have to come from the coroner) Backseat passenger is Jaime Vazquez-Martinez, age 26, Belleville. He is in stable and improving condition at a local hospital. Driver (listed above) is in jail.Vehicle 2: Female, age 66, Madison, is being treated at a local hospital for non-life threatening injuries.
properties.Details: UPDATE:Vehicle 1 was a '94 Honda Civic. Vehicle 2 was a 2002 Chrysler. Vehicle 1 was northbound in the 200 block of Midvale, just past Mineral Point Road, heading toward Hilldale Mall, when its driver lost control.  The Civic jumped the grassy median and slammed in to the Chrysler.------------------------------------------------------------------------------Two vehicles were involved in a crash near this intersection.  Vehicle 1 was traveling N/B on Midvale at a high rate of speed lost control and crashed into Vehicle 2, which was traveling S/B on Midvale.  All were transported to area hospitals.  One of the occupants in Vehicle 1 was later pronounced at the hospital. The investigation is currently on going. Midvale Blvd. is temporarily closed between Mineral Point Road and Hillcrest

Vehicle 1 was travelling on Millpond Road towards US 12/18, crossed the center line and crashed into Vehicle 2 travelling in the oncoming lane.  The driver of Vehicle 1 was pinned and had to be extricated.  He was taken by Medflight to UW Hospital.  The 2 occupants of Vehicle 2 were taken by ambulance to St. Mary's.  All appear to have non-life threatening injuries.  Speed appears to be a factor in the crash.  The investigation is still on-going.

properties.Address: 6500 Cottage Grove Rd. at Sprecher Rd.
properties.Victim: 50yoa Male - Pronounced deceased at scene (Motorcylist)28yoa Male - Minor cuts and scrapes (Car operator)2 other passengers - Minor injuries, no transport to medical facility
properties.Details: A car traveling East on Cottage Grove rd. making turning movment North onto Sprecher collided with a motorcycle traveling West on Cottage Grove rd.  Unknown if speed or alcohol were cause - awaiting autopsy and blood results.  Believed motorcyclist was not wearing helmet.  Investigative efforts continuing.

properties.Arrested: Tammie L. Blizzard, Age 45, MadisonArrested & Tentatively Charged with Causing Great Bodily Harm by Operating a Motor Vehicle while Intoxicated
properties.Address: 2600 Bl. N. Sherman Ave. (UPDATED MONDAY AFTERNOON AUGUST 13)
properties.Victim: 74 yoa MaleTransported to local hospital for serious, possibly life-threatening, injuries.
properties.Details: A Madison woman driving with her husband heard a "thump" at the time of the collision. She instructed her husband to exit the vehicle and render aid to the victim. Meanwhile she followed the suspect's SUV (2002 Chevy Suburban). As she did this she was honking her horn and flashing her lights trying to get the driver to stop. The citizen witness was able to get a good description of the suspect's SUV and a license plate number. This enabled police to find the suspect's address where the arrest was made and the SUV was confiscated.  Madison Police Investigator Frank Chandler (267-1189) is seeking the help of other citizen witnesses who may have observed the suspect vehicle before, during, or after the crash. The victim (who had just watched the Mallard’s season finale) was walking in a cross walk, and was in a well-lit intersection, when he was struck. It should be noted that the suspect was not at the Mallard's game, and that additional charges are probable.------------------------------------------------------Male subject walking with group from Mallard's Game crossing N. Sherman Ave. near Trailsway was struck by an SUV operating North on Sherman.  Suspect vehicle fled scene, Officers did locate suspect and vehicle.  Suspect arrested, alcohol believed to be a factor.  Investigation continues

properties.Address: 4902 Verona Road (near intersection with Raymond Road) ***UPDATE 10:30 a.m.****
properties.Victim: Female transported with life threatening injuries.  No further status available.  Names are not being released at this time.Injurred pedestrian: status unknown, Female, 39, MadisonDriver: Robert Gavigan, 71, Madison
properties.Details: Vehicle is travelling outbound/south on Verona Road (US 151) near the intersection with Raymond Road.  A female pedestrian is crossing the roadway in the rain.  Driver apparently did not see the female and hits her.  The driver was uninjured and the female transported to the hospital.  The investigation is on-going.  As a result, Verona Road out-bound is currently shut down south of Raymond Road and traffic is being rerouted.  Unknown at this time how long this will be closed.***UPDATE***:  Victim is in the hospital with serious injuries.  No charges filed or even pending as this investigation continues.

At 7:13 a.m. on Monday September 10th Madison Police were called to the Cherokee Middle School at 4301 Cherokee Drive for a report of a pedestrian versus motor vehicle crash.The preliminary investigation shows that a parent driving a red SUV dropped off a student in front of the school. As this was happening, school staff member Becky Sue Buchmann, Age 48, from Oregon WI, was walking across Cherokee Drive while on her way to the school. The driver of the SUV, after dropping off his son, pulled out and struck Ms. Buchmann. She was transported to a local hospital where she was later pronounced dead.This case remains under investigation. The driver, at this point, has not been arrested and his name is not being released.It is possible that there are witnesses to this crash who have yet to be identified and Madison Police are asking anyone with information to call our traffic department tips line at 266-8626.

properties.Arrested: Joey D Hagen, Age 39, CambridgeTentative Charge: Homicide by Intoxicated use of a Motor Vehicle
properties.Address: Intersection of Cottage Grove & Dempsey Roads (UPDATED WEDNESDAY 9/12)
properties.Victim: Alvin J. Sandness Jr., Age 69, Marion North DakotaPronounced dead at U.W. Hospital
properties.Details: Around 7:58 a.m., on the morning of September 11th, Madison Police responded to the intersection of Cottage Grove and Dempsey Roads following reports of a crash. Investigators believe the driver of a VW Jetta rear-ended a van that was in the westbound lanes of Cottage Grove road. The van's driver appears to have been stopped at a red light (at the intersection of Dempsey Road) when his vehicle was struck. The van was pushed across the intersection and collided with a traffic sign. Its driver was taken to a local hospital where he was pronounced dead. The driver of the VW is being treated for non-life threatening injuries. The crash is under investigation; however, at the time of this release no arrest has been made nor any citations issued.

properties.Address: E. Johnson Street @ N. Paterson Street
properties.Victim: One person sustained serious injuries, conveyed to local hospital.
properties.Details: Madison Police responded to a two-car crash at the intersection of E. Johnson Street and N. Paterson Street today at 12:23pm.  One vehicle was traveling EB on E. Johnson and the other NB on N. Paterson when the two collided.  One occupant sustained serious injuries and was conveyed to an area hospital.  Names are being withheld at this time pending family notification.  The investigation is on-going and we ask that if anyone witnessed this crash that they call 266-5981.

properties.Arrested: Nurlan Gurbanov, M/W, 19 YOA, MadisonCHARGE: Operating with a Suspended Drivers License
properties.Address: East Bound Hwy 12 Between Verona Road & S. Whitney Way
properties.Victim: Same as Above/Minor Injuries thanks to wearing a seatbelt.
properties.Details: Gurbanov and witnesses state he was EB Hwy 12 when an unidentified silver colored car was observed traveling at a high rate of speed and cutting in and out of traffic. Gurbanov attempted to move away from the vehicle, and apparently lost control on the shoulder, causing his Vehicle (Volvo) to roll approximately 3 times across the median and come to a rest upside down within the WB lanes of Hwy 12. Gurbanov was wearing a seatbelt and was able to extricate himself from the vehicle. Due to Gurbanov operating on a Suspended License, he was issued a citation. Gurbanov was later conveyed to a local hospital and treated for minor injuries.

properties.Victim: One female transported to a local hospital for minor injuries.
properties.Details: On the above date and time, there was a stalled vehicle in one of the center lanes in the 4000 Blk. of E. Washington Ave. The stalled owner of the motor vehicle had a friend behind he/she with a truck to assist with protecting the vehicle. Later at approx. 6:14 p.m. a large Dodge truck struck a Nissan Maxima, causing the Maxima to collide into a 1982 VW vehicle, causing the VW to collide into a Jeep Cherokee, causing the Cherokee to collide into the truck that was assisting the stalled vehicle. There were 5 total vehicles damaged. One driver was transported for minor injuries. The 1982 VW vehicle apparently has been converted into a vehicle that runs on vegetable oil and the collision caused over 20 gallons of oil to spread over the street causing a hazard. The road is shut down until further notice to get sand on the oil.

properties.Victim: Female, age 11, Madison middle school student,Suffered a broken arm.
properties.Details: On October 31st around 7:13 a.m. Madison police responded to a report of an injured child in the area of Ardmore Drive and Rusk Avenue. An eleven-year-old middle school student was late for her bus. She tried to chase the bus as it was pulling away. The girl tripped and fell alongside the bus, and a bus tire rolled over her arm.

A 21 yr old bicylist crossing the road was struck by a motorist.  The motorist stopped a short distance away to report.  The bicyclist was transported to the hospital for non-life threatening injuries.  On going investigation.

properties.Suspect: Rogelio D. Rico Hernandez, Age 33, MadisonOperating Motor Vehicle While Under the Influence (2nd offense)
properties.Address: Highway 12/18 (Westbound Beltline Highway near Gammon Road)
properties.Victim: Male white, Age 39, Monroe WITreated & released from a local hospital.
properties.Details: On 11/28/2007 around 10:18 p.m. Madison police officers were sent to investigate a crash that had just occurred on Highways 12 & 18 (beltline) near Gammon Road. They discovered two vehicles had gone off the highway, past a fence line, and were now in a field near Odana Road. A Monroe man was inside a 1999 Ford truck, which was now on its side. He had been wearing a seatbelt and suffered only minor injuries. He told police he had just gotten off work at a local grocery store and was on his way home when he spotted in his rearview mirror a vehicle rapidly coming up behind him. Since it was traveling fast in the left lane he assumed it would just pass him as he was in the right lane. However; the vehicle, a 2001 Chevy Suburban, instead turned sharply his way careening into the rear end of his truck. The driver of the Suburban was ejected from the Chevy during the crash. He was taken to a local hospital with multiple injuries and was listed in critical condition. Madison police investigators are also looking to see if the Suburban was involved in a hit-and-run collision that took place in a parking lot on Park Street a short time before the beltline crash. The hit-and-run involved someone backing a Suburban into a parked vehicle. Additional charges in this case are possible.

properties.Suspect: Gaudencio Carranza-Morales
properties.Address: N. Gammon Rd at Colony Dr.
properties.Details: At 5:59 pm there was a two car crash on N. Gammon Rd. at Colony Dr.The offending vehicle, after stopping at the stop sign at Colony Dr., continued eastbound into the intersection, apparently not seeing the northbound vehicle.  The insuing collision resulted in injuries to the occupants of the offending vehicle.  The driver and his wife were transported to a local hospital where the wife underwent emergency surgery for numberous medical issues.  Her current condition is unknown at this time.  For his part in the accident, the driver was issued a citation for failure to yield right of way.The driver of the other vehicle, Carranza-Morales, was arrested and charged with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence and causing injury by intoxicated use of a vehicle.  He was subsequently booked into the Dane County Jail.

properties.Suspect: Dana M. Raker
properties.Address: Old Sauk and West Beltline Hwy
properties.Victim: Unable to ID at this time
properties.Details: Two vehicle accident at the above address. It appears both vehicles were traveling westbound and that one vehicle (suspect) contacted the other vehicle (victim). The impact then caused the victim vehicle to go off roadway and collided with a fixed object. The passenger of the victim vehicle was pronounced dead at the scene. The driver of the suspect vehicle was identified as Dana M. Raker. Raker was charged with Homicide by intoxicated use of a motor vehicle and booked into Dane County Jail.

Bestor was travelling eastbound on the bridge over Highway 30 when he hit a patch of black ice causing the vehicle to rollover.  The driver sustained very minor injuries and was not transported. Bestor is a resident of Waunakee.

Madison Police and Dane County deputies were sent to the above address for the report of a one vehicle rollover crash.  Upon arrival, officers discovered the victim partially ejected from the vehicle.  The victim was pronounced dead at the scene.  The investigation is continuiing.

properties.Suspect: Nicole L. Endres, F/W 6-25-79 - of Deforest, WICharge: Homicide By Negligent Use Of A Vehicle
properties.Arrested: Jan E. Pilon, F/W 8-26-75 - of Madison, WICharge: Party To A Crime - Homicide By Negligent Use Of A Vehicle
properties.Victim: Craig S. Sawicki, 26 yr old male of Beloit, WI
properties.Details: At approximately 12:58AM on 2/16/08 officers, through a multi-jurisdictional effort involving both The Dane County Sheriffs Office and The Madison Police Department, were dispatched to the intersection of Felland Road & County Trunk T reference a vehicular crash.  Officers would arrive on scene and find a male (Craig S. Sawicki - 26yr old M/W of Beloit WI) who was ejected from & pinned beneath a vehicle that allegedly rolled several times before coming to its final resting place in a field near the intersection.  Sawicki was a passenger in a 2007 Nissan Altima.  Allegedly this vehicle was being driven by a female (Nicole L. Endres - 28yr old F/W of Madison WI).An associate of Sawicki/Endres (Jan E Pilon –32 yr old F/W of Madison) would pull up to the accident scene shortly after it occurred. Preliminary reports reflect both Endres and Pilon being contacted at Pilon’s residence a short time after authorities would deal with this unfortunate fatality accident.Endres is being tentatively charged with Homicide By Negligent Use of a Vehicle and Pilon is tentatively charged with Party To A Crime for allegedly transporting Endres from the scene of the accident.  The Dane County Coroner's Office made a timely notification of the deceased (Craig S. Sawicki), and The Madison Police Department Accident Investigators are continuing to gather details.  Both speed and alcohol are thought to have been contributing factors in this accident.PO Howard Payne

properties.Suspect: Richard N. Kudish 58 yr old, White/MaleSun Prairie addressCharges 2 cts Child Enticement, 3 cts Recklessly Endangering Safety, Eluding, No D.L.
properties.Victim: Two Juveniles (13 yr old &15 yr old)Two MPD Employees ( One Officer & One Sgt.) both were treated and released.
properties.Details: Officer observed a suspect for which we had probable cause for child enticement from an incident on 3/14/08, driving by him as he was on routine patrol.  He immediately engaged his red lights and sirens and attempted to stop the individual.  The suspect refused to stop and continued at a moderate speed, disregarding the siren and red lights.  Another officer attempting to assist was rammed by the suspect, causing disabling damage to the squad and injury to the officer.  The pursuit continued at higher speeds with the suspect disregarding numerous stop signs and signals.  The suspect drove on numerous residential streets attempting to lose the officers at speeds between 50 to 70 mph.  During this pursuit, a Sergeant attempting to follow the suspect was rammed, disabling the squad and causing injury to the Sergeant.  The suspect continued eluding officers until he crashed on Marston Ave. and was taken into custody. The suspect was interviewed by Detectives. The Officer and Sgt. were treated for non-life threatening injuries and released.

Hamer was struck while working in a construction zone at the intersection of Erin Street and S. Park Street. The vehicle was turning off of Erin Street to go inbound on S. Park Street in heavily populated construction zone which contained numerous traffic barrels.  Hamer was suffered minor injuries and was conveyed to a local hospital for minor injuries where was treated and released. The driver was not cited.

properties.Suspect: Karen S. John, 32 of Madison
properties.Details: John was operating a motor vehicle eastbound on N. Walbrige Avenue when she lost control and struck a street in front of 201 N. Walbrige Avenue.  John's 5 year old daughter was the only other passenger in the vehicle with her and both were unbelted. John suffered facial injuries as a result of hitting the windshield. Her daughter suffered a fractured jaw. John was cited for Causing Injury While Operating a Motor Vehicle while Intoxicated. Both are mother and daugher are being treated at a local hospital.

properties.Victim: A 43 yr old area resident, pedestrian
properties.Details: Officer Russell Pollard came upon a motor vehicle versus pedestrian crash on W. Washington Ave at S. Park St near Brittingham Park as dispatch was just starting to take 911 calls from people at the scene.  The officer found a 43 yr old area resident who had apparently been attempting to return to Brittingham Park from the grocery store across the street who had been struck by an older Ford Taurus traveling westbound on W. Washington.  The pedestrian hit the windshield and was carried some distance until the driver was able to get the car stopped, at which time the pedestrian hit the ground.  The pedestrian was conveyed by Fire Rescue; his injuries are still being assessed, but appear to be non-life and limb threatening.  A 13 yr old boy who was a passenger in the front seat of the car also suffered some cuts on his arm possibly from the broken windshield glass. The vehicle was impounded for inspection and the investigation is continuing.  The driver of the car voluntarily took a breath test and was found to have no alcohol in his system.

Madison Police assisted Maple Bluff PD with an motor vehicle crash in the 1600 block of Huxley Street.  A Maple Bluff officer conducted a traffic stop.  The vehicle feld from the scene of the stop.  After a brief pursuit the vehicle crashed.  MPD assited by investigating the crash.  All other actions were completed by Maple Bluff PD.  Contact Maple Bluff PD for information.

properties.Victim: Michael P. Hankes, age 22, MadisonVictim was killed instantly upon contact with pickup truck.
properties.Details: On July 3, 2008 at 6:48 p.m. Madison Police responded to a fatal crash that had just occurred at the intersection of U.S. Highway 51 and State Highway 30. Witnesses report the victim was on a motorcycle, and that he struck the rear quarter panel of a pickup truck after it turned into the cyclist path. Mr. Michael Hankes, age 22, Madison, was killed instantly. The crash is under investigation. The motorcyclist was not wearing a helmet, although a traffic investigator is not sure whether one would have made any difference in this case.

properties.Victim: Female, age 21, MadisonBicyclist suffered serious injuries. They are not thought to be life threatening.
properties.Details: Just before 9:00 a.m. Wednesday morning a bicyclist was seriously injured on West Washington Avenue after being run over by the rear tires of a truck that was delivering jugs of drinking water to downtown businesses. Witnesses report the cyclist and the truck were both outbound on West Washington Avenue when the truck began to make a right turn onto Henry Street. The cyclist hit her brakes to prevent striking the truck. This caused her to go over the top of her handlebars and slide beneath the truck. She was taken to a local hospital with serious injuries.  The initial investigation indicates the truck's driver was not at fault in the accident.

properties.Victim: Woman, age 37Motorcyclist suffered serious, but not life threatening injuries.
properties.Details: On August 6th, just before 7:00 a.m., Madison Police got a call about crash in the 2500 block of Fish Hatchery Road involving a motorcycle and a mini van. A 37-year old woman was driving her bike northbound on Fish Hatchery when a 27-year old van operator cut in front of her, causing her to lay the motorcycle down. The crash is under investigation.

properties.Suspect: N/A
properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Address: Beltline Hwy 12/18 and John Nolen Drive
properties.Victim: 1 male2 femalesUnknown details of victims minor injuries
properties.Details: On 8/25/2008 at 11:48am, The Madison Police Department, with assistance from The Town of Madison Police, were dispatched to an injury accident near Hwy 12/18 Beltline Hwy and John Nolen Drive.  From preliminary reports, a metal piece of furniture had possibly fallen off of a vehicle and occupied one of the EB lanes.  A SUV, thought to be a Trailblazer, attempted to avoid striking the metal object by swerving left.  This resulted in the Trailblazer striking a Town & Country Van.  The impact of the two vehicles would send the van crashing into the guardrail, and the Trailblazer would end up in a flipped position.  Madison Fire Department quickly arrived on scene to deal with medical issues of all parties.  No one suffered any significant injuries in this accident, but this accident could have been much more serious.  The roadway did have to be closed to allow emergency vehicles and tow trucks access to the scene to deal with this situation.  Vehicles were extracted promptly and the roadway was opened up shortly after 12:30pm.The Madison Police Department reminds all drivers carrying items inside of vehicles to make sure all items are securely fastened, and that there is no possibility of any cargo falling from your vehicle.  It is the responsibility of all to keep roadways as safe as possible, and taking precautions such as securing your cargo is just one step in decreasing the number of accidents that occur on an annual basis.

properties.Suspect: N/A
properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: Male - Early 20's Critical Condition StatusMale - Early 20'sFemale - Early 20's
properties.Details: On 8/27/2008 shortly after 1:30am, The Madison Police Department, with assistance from The Madison Fire Department, responded to a single vehicle accident involving a tree.  From the preliminary investigation, the involved vehicle was traveling northbound on S. Midvale Boulevard near the 200 block, when this vehicle appears to have lost control and impacted a tree.  As a result of the accident, 2 occupants were pronounced deceased, and 1 occupant remains in critical condition at a local hospital.  Seatbelts were used by at least 2 of the occupants.   Questions regarding alcohol are also being investigated at this time.  This accident remains under investigation by The Madison Police Department Traffic Specialists, and names of occupants are not being released pending notifications of family and the submission of the Coroners’ report.

On 8/28/2008 at approximately 11:15pm, The Madison Police Department was dispatched to the 300 block of N. Lake Street reference an MV/Pedestrian accident.  The Madison Fire Department immediately attended to the medical needs of a 19-year-old female after she was struck crossing N. Lake Street at University Avenue.  Officers that responded to the scene determined that a 1999 Audi was traveling north bound on N. Lake Street, and when this vehicle approached University Avenue the 19-year-old victim happened to be in the crosswalk and was struck.  Officers on scene conducted interviews of witnesses that all verified one contention that the pedestrian was illegally crossing the street and the vehicle had no negligence in this matter.  The victim was conveyed to a local hospital, and preliminary information stated that the injuries sustained were non-life threatening.  Citations were issued to the pedestrian for both an alcohol violation and failure to yield to vehicle.Upon review of video surveillance cameras at this intersection several hours after this incident occurred, additional charges may be pending as this investigation continues.  The Madison Police Department feels that this is yet another example where video surveillance cameras aid both the public from a safety standpoint, and bolsters our ability to uncover crucial details that helps determine what actually occurred at scenes such as this.PO Howard Payne

properties.Suspect: Jose Carlos Perez-Mendez, M/H, 01-26-1987, MadisonCharges: Injury by Intoxicated Use of a Motor Vehicle             OMVWOC             Failure to Render Aid To Injured             OAR
properties.Victim: Jason A. Hogan, 32 years old, Madison,Injuries: Serious, but non life-threatening.
properties.Details: Officers were dispatched to MV/Motorcycle with injuries. Upon arrival they noted an SUV parked on top of a motorcycle. The operator SUV fled on foot. The operator of the motorcycle received serious, but non life-threatening injuries. The operator of the SUV was arrested nearby.

The victim was travelling westbound on Hoepker Rd and failed to yield to a second vehicle northbound on N. Stoughton Rd.  The crash resulted in a fatality and the male operator of the second vehicle was conveyed with non-life threatening injuries. The crash remains under investigation.

On Sunday, just after 4:30 p.m., a Madison Police officer was involved in a crash at the intersection of Milwaukee Street and Stoughton Road. The officer was responding to a physical domestic dispute when his squad car struck a delivery truck. It was turning from Stoughton Road onto Milwaukee Street, and the officer was heading outbound on Milwaukee Street. The truck flipped over, but its driver was not injured. The officer was transported to a local hospital with non-life threatening injuries. The crash is under investigation.

Officers responded to a report of an injury accident involving a motor vehicle and motorcyle. The motorcyle operator, a 24 year old male was wearing a helmet. He was conveyed by fire rescue with serious injuries. A traffic specialist responded and the crash remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: None
properties.Details: Officers were dispatched to the Arby's lot just off Highway 51 and Broadway ref a man in a vehicle apparently in cardiac arrest.  Police Officers Jamar Gary and Matthew Kenny arrived to find the 49 year old victim being assisted by his wife and a passerby.  The victim's wife said her husband had been experiencing some arm pain and reported not feeling well as they drove to Madison from Racine.  He collapsed as they pulled off in the Arby's lot.  Officers Gary began rescue breathing on the victim as Officer Kenny prepared his AED.  The citizen assisted with chest compressions.  Officer Kenny delivered one shock to the victim using the AED.  Rescue efforts continued until Fire Rescue arrived and transported the victim to University Hospital where he was eventually revived by medical staff.  The attending physician credited the quick response by the officers and citizens for making the victim's rescue possible.

properties.Victim: 66 year old male resident of the City of Madison, diner at The Prime Quarter; stable
properties.Details: Quick and effective action by citizens and police resulted in the successful rescue of a 66 year old Madison man who had been dining with a friend at The Prime Quarter when he began to choke on a piece of steak.  The restaurant manager, Albert Sanger, immediately attempted to assist the victim by performing the Heimlich maneuver and trying to clear his airway.  The victim collapsed and was assisted to the floor by the restaurant staff and another diner, Timothy Murphy, who continued the Heimlich manuever.  Police Officer Dave Dexheimer was less than a block away when the 9-1-1 call came in and when he arrived on scene, the victim was not breathing and had no pulse.  Officer Dexheimer began CPR and began breathing for the victim while employee Toccara Kimball did chest compressions.  They also continued to attempt to clear the victim's airway.  As the AED was attached to the victim, Officer Dexheimer was successful in getting the victim breathing again.  The victim also regained a pulse.  Fire Rescue transported the victim to St. Mary's Hospital for further assessment and treatment where staff indicated the patient was stable and doing well.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 4/30/05 at approximately 11:59 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 500 block of W. Mifflin St for an individual who had fallen off a balcony.  This individual was transported to a local hospital and his condition is unknown at this time.  Alcohol does appear to be a contributing factor.

properties.Arrested: None
properties.Details: A neighbor called 9-1-1 after witnessing an 80 year old woman collapse.  The 9-1-1 dispatcher began giving CPR instructions over the phone to the neighbors who rushed to assist.  Officers Ken Mulry and Bob Veatch were investigating a burglary nearby and immediately ran through the backyards with AEDs they grabbed from their squad cars.  When they arrived, they determined the woman was not breathing and had no pulse.  The officers deployed an AED, administering a shock to the victim, and continued rescue efforts until they were relieved by paramedics.  Paramedics continued rescue efforts until they got a pulse back.  The victim was tranported to St. Mary's ER where doctors credited the quick response of neighbors and the successful deployment of the AED for the survival of the victim.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: At approximately 5:44 a.m., officers responded to a report of a man down in an apartment building in the 10 block of North Webster Street.  Upon arrival, they located a blood trail from the first floor of the building to the third floor of the building.  On the third floor of the building, they located an intoxicated twenty-four-year-old male with a significant laceration to the back of his head.  The subject was conveyed to UW Hospital, where he was treated in the emergency room.  It is believed that he was admitted to the hospital.  At this time, the circumstances of this situation are undetermined.  The subject had an IL ID, but officers were able to determine he had some Madison contacts, which led them to believe he may live in Madison.  There is no additional information at this time.

properties.Arrested: Suspect:Asian Maleapproximately 55approximately 18 years old
properties.Details: On 3/11/05 at approximately 9:13 pm Madison Police Officers were dispatched to the 6700 block of Schroeder Rd reference a stabbing that occurred.  Upon arrival officers learned that the victim had been stabbed by an unknown suspect who fled in a vehicle.  The victim was transported to a local hospital for a non-life threatening wound.  Investigators are still trying to determine the motive for this incident.  If anyone has information regarding this incident they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and can be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: 16 yr old male: weapons violations15 yr old male: juvenile capiasSarath Rim 21 yr old male:  Possession of THC with Intent to deliver
properties.Details: On 3/9/05 at approximately 11:15 am Madison Police Officers responded to the 7700 block of Radcliffe Drive reference a juvenile in possession of a firearm.  The caller advised the suspect was not using the weapon in a threatening manner.  Responding officers contacted the above individual and confiscated an assault type semi-automatic 9mm handgun with a silencer and loaded magazine.  A subsequent investigation related to this case involved Madison Police Detectives contacting a number of additional individuals, which led to further arrests.

On 3/23/05 at approximately 11:18 a.m. nine Madison Police Officers responded to several citizen reports of individuals with guns on top of a parking ramp.  There had been previous reports during the morning of other individuals with guns in Madison.  Immediate compliance of officer commands saved what could have been a tragic incident, as the fake guns that were used appeared real.  After investigating what transpired it was learned that the individuals were making a movie for a college class with pellet guns.  The "actors" involved all received disorderly conduct citations.  This incident is the second time in two weeks where Madison Police responded to gun situations in which it turned out to be film production with artificial guns.  In fluid circumstances a fake gun can appear very real and could lead to tragic circumstances.  The Madison Police Department encourages those using fake guns during film productions to alert us to the fact ahead of time and follow proper procedures prior to filming.

properties.Arrested: Marco Gomez-Vazquez Age 27 of Madison
properties.Details: On July 22,2005 at 6:20 am Madison Police officers assisted Middleton Police by looking for a vehicle that was driven by Gomez-Vazquez. Gomez-Vazquez was armed with a handgun and was threating to shoot police and kill himself.  Gomez-Vazquez led officers on a vehicle pursuit.  At University Ave. and Eagle Dr. Gomez- Vazques's vehicle got stuck in a muddy portion of a grassy area.  Gomez- Vazquez who already displayed a handgun to officers was attempting to accelerate his car in order to free up his car and continue the pursuit.Officers observed that if Gomez-Vasquez was be able to free his car he would be driving against traffic on Highway 14 at a time where morning commuting traffic increases. Officers also already observed his weapon and his highly dangerous driving behavior. Officers knew of his violent threats to shoot police and himself. Officers knowing this feard that if he was able to free his car and continue the pursuit that death or seroius bodily harm was a high probability to motorists, police officers present and Gomez- Vazquez. With this infomation Madison police officers present shot out the tires of Gomez- Vazquez's vehicle in order to prevent him from continuing this highly dangerous conduct. This action did disable Gomez- Vasquez's vehicle. At this point contact was made with Gomez-Vazqez and he was ultimately taken into custody. This incident ended without any injuries to citizens, police or Gomez-Vazquez.  Madison Police prelimary investigation indicates that officers present used proper use of force consistant with Madison Police policy to end this dangerous situation and to prevent injury or death to others.Gomez-Vasquez was taken into custody under a emergency detention. He is presently being held at Mendota Mental Heatlth institute. Upon his release he will be arrested on various criminal charges from this incident.

A description of the vehicle was broadcast and Monona officers located the vehicle in Monona.  The Monona officers followed the vehicle onto the Interstate and were joined by city officers.  When officers attempted to stop the vehicle, the vehicle accelerated.  The vehicle continued on the Interstate and then returned to the city on East Washington Avenue at an extremely high rate of speed.  At this time, the pursuit was terminated by MPD officers.  A short time later, in the area of North Lawn Avenue, the vehicle attempted to make a sharp turn and ended up striking the curb.  This crash disabled the vehicle.  The driver fled the scene on foot.  Officers called in a K-9 search dog who tracked the suspect.  The officers were not able to locate the subject.  The incident remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: Five juvenile Males (ages 13-15)Charges: Disorderly Conduct and Possession of Dangerous Weapons on School Grounds
properties.Address: 201 South Gammon Road (Madison Memorial High School)
properties.Details: Due to the fact that students at area high schools are involved in exams the week of January 17th-20th, Memorial High School recessed on Friday at 10:00am.  Five juveniles rode a Madison Metro Bus to Memorial High School with the intention(s)of confronting other individuals they took issue with reference previous incidents that occurred at both Madison Metro West Transfer Point and West Town Mall.  It was reported to Police that a disturbance involving up to 50 people occurred in the common area of West Town Mall on January 18th, 2006.  A very similar scenario occurred on January 19th, 2006 where 20-30 juveniles were allegedly fighting at the Madison Metro West Transfer Point; some allegedly with baseball bats. Based on intelligence information developed by Madison Police, a plan was devised to use additional resources in the effort of alleviating any potential problems that might arise at the school.  Five juveniles were arrested on charges ranging from disorderly conduct to possession of a dangerous weapon on school grounds, which are misdemeanor offenses!  Two facsimile firearms, edged weapons, and pepper spray were recovered in the arrests.  The behavior that has been describe above has been a recurring theme of violence that the Madison Police Department would like to see come to an end.  The police department will continue to investigate this matter and seek any information that might lead to more arrests in all of these events.

properties.Arrested: Donald Buchanan, male, 18, Madison:  Endangering Safety by Use of a Dangerous Weapon.Male, 16, Madison: Endangering Safety by Use of a Dangerous Weapon. Colin Hill, male, 20:  Endangering Safety by Use of a Dangerous Weapon.
properties.Details: On 2/10/06 at approximately 8:23 p.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to a road-rage incident off of Milwaukee Street, in which it was believed the victim's windows were shot out.  In contacting the victim vehicle, it was learned that they were inbound on Milwaukee Street, near Fair Oaks Ave, when they came across a vehicle stopped in traffic and the occupants were talking to a pedestrian.  The victim vehicle had to go in another lane of traffic to avoid this hazard and honked its horn at the stopped vehicle.  Shortly after passing the vehicle, the victim’s rear window shattered and another window was "spider-webbed", causing the victims to believe they were shot.  The victim vehicle fled to E. Washington and the offending vehicle continued to follow as the victims contacted the 911 Center.  Eventually after turning on a few other streets, the victims and offending vehicles separated.  A description of the offending vehicle was aired over police radio.  An astute officer heard the aired description and noticed the vehicle traveling in-bound on E. Washington Avenue and initiated a traffic stop.  There were five persons in the vehicle.  Subsequent to an investigation, officers recovered a "BB pump air rifle" and an "air powered bb handgun" inside the vehicle.  Additionally, officers were able to identify the parties involved who shot out the windows.  Hill and Buchanan were transported to the Dane County Jail, while the 16 year-old was transported to the Juvenile Reception Center.

properties.Arrested: Cassandra Graffee, female, 17, Madison:  Dangerous Weapon other than Firearm on School Premises, Disorderly Conduct While Armed, Disorderly Conduct, Unauthorized Presence on School Property, Underage Person Carrying ID of Another
properties.Details: On 2/21/06 at approximately 4:11 p.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to Memorial H.S. for an incident involving an “airsoft” pellet gun.  Dispatched advised that several people were running from the school grounds to the Tree Lane area.  Officers learned where the suspects were due to a school principal following them after the incident. Officers made contact with the suspect, Graffee, several other juveniles and the victim who remained near school.  It was learned that Graffee, who wanted to fight outside school near the bus stop, confronted the victim.  After a brief struggle, Graffee and the victim parted ways and the victim went back into school.  Approximately 3-4 minutes went by and as the victim started to leave the school, Graffee confronted her.  This time Graffee took out a pellet gun and shot the victim with approximately 20 pellets in the chest, stomach, and head and neck area. Graffee appeared to run out of pellets, so a 12 year-old boy, who was with Graffee, took out a pellet gun and shot the victim approximately four times. The victim stated it "hurt a little bit".  The victim stated she believed the guns were not real from the beginning as they looked like plastic.  In arresting Graffee, officers recovered a container of "softair" 6 mm pellets and collected the spent pellets near the scene.  She was transported to the Dane County Jail without incident.  The 12 year-old boy was turned over to his mother.

properties.Details: Officers responded to the 2400 block of Allied Drive for a fight involving subjects armed with baseball bats.  A large crowd began to scatter as officers arrived. While officers were investigating the incident, a female threw a fish tank into a parking lot from a 2nd floor apartment.  As officers subsequently took her into custody, she resisted and bit an officer. A crowd gathered around the officers and attempted to intervene in the arrest, grabbing at the officers.  Officers later observed one of the suspects in the original incident and attempted to arrest him. He began resisting, and a crowd gathered around the officers, attempting to intervene in the arrest.  A female struck one of the officers in the face, and later attempted to disarm another officer.  Investigation showed that during the initial disturbance, all of the windows to an apartment at 2414 Allied Drive had been broken by a subject with a baseball bat (Hall).  Hall and Hill (ID'd above) then forced entry into the apartment armed with a baseball bat and a broken mop pole.  Hall swung at a victim with one the bat, nearly striking him.  Close to 20 officers responded to this incident and were required to control the situation.

Officers learned the victim had walked into the bar for help after being stabbed during a disturbance on Schlimgen Ave.  Officers went to Schlimgen Ave and were able to contact Todd Brown who was arrested on the above charges.  Brown and a family member, the victim, were drinking alcohol for most of the afternoon/evening and engaged in a verbal argument.  That argument led to a stabbing of the victim's throat. properties.Details: At 4:34 p.m. officers responded to several reports of shots fired in the 5800 block of Balsam Rd. Apparently no one was injured in an exchange of gun fire between an individual at 5821 Balsam Rd and a group of five individuals who were seeking a confrontation with the shooter. Though there were dozens of small children in the area, both sides recklessly fired several rounds in this otherwise peaceful neighborhood. One shot fired from 5821 ended up lodged in the wall of an apartment a block and a half away after narrowly missing the resident of that apartment.Many area residents called police and provided information to the investigating officers. However, several subjects who had been in close proximity to the first shooter refused to identify themselves or give statements to the police. According to a resident this was the fifth recent shooting incident in the area.

properties.Details: Police responded to the Allied Drive area on 6/30/06 at approximately 11:27am reference a disturbance involving a 1984 Two-Tone Green Pontiac Grand Prix & Blue Chevy Caprice/Buick.  Since there was reliable information given to dispatchers advising officers that it was highly probable that weapons were in one or both of the vehicles, a high risk felony stop was conducted on the 1984 Pontiac stopped in the 4800 blk of Lovell Lane.After all subjects were ordered out of the vehicle at gunpoint, a subsequent search of the vehicle by officers uncovered a fully loaded .38 caliber revolver.  It should also be noted that one of Madison's Canine Handlers responded, and through use of that resource more than 15 individually packaged baggies of Cocaine Base (weighing 2.9grams) were confiscated.  Based on reliable information, a solid tactical response by police, and police canine involvement, this turned out to be a case where further violence was foiled in its infancy.  We want the community to understand that officers look to act on a moments notice to keep this community and the rest of the city a safe place for all to live.PO Howard Payne

properties.Details: At approximately 11:39 p.m. on 8/11/06, Madison Police responded to the 5700 block of Hammersley Rd. on a report from Madison Metro that somebody had just shot a BB at a bus.  Upon arriving, officers were able to determine that the bus had been southbound on Whitney and made a left turn onto Hammersley Rd. when a BB gun was fired from a vehicle.  The vehicle, which initially had been parked, then followed the bus and pulled in front of it at which time more shots were fired at the bus.  It is estimated that four shots from the BB gun were fired at the bus.  One of the shots broke a window that was behind the driver.  Another shot hit the front window right in front of the driver's position, chipping the window.Madison police located a suspect vehicle in the area.  The vehicle was occupied by the above-arrested parties.  A BB gun and BB's were located inside the vehicle.  The suspects were arrested and the dispositions are as noted.  No injuries were reported.  The bus was occupied by the driver and passengers.

They learned the above-arrested party had produced a handgun and shot multiple rounds in the direction of the front door.  Several rounds struck the front door, other rounds struck the building. properties.Details: On 10/16/06 at approximately 12:16 pm, police officers were dispatched to 30 Ash St. (West High School) reference a man outside shooting students.  Initially upon arrival to the scene no victims or suspects were found.  After a witness was interviewed it was established that a verbal confrontation had occurred between the suspect, who was near a vehicle on the south side of Regent St., and four white males walking in front of West High School (north side of Regent St.).  Following this shouting match the suspect pulled what appeared to be a weapon and started shooting at the males.  The suspect then left the area in that vehicle heading eastbound on Regent St.  The vehicle was later stopped and five occupants were detained.  A weapon was recovered from the vehicle and identified as a pellet gun replicating an automatic handgun.  After a thorough investigation the shooter was identified and arrested.  Another of the occupants of the vehicle was also arrested for a probation hold.  It is believed that no one was injured, that the school was not the target nor was the student population at risk.  The investigation is still ongoing.

properties.Details: On 04/02/2007 at approximately 10:18pm, The Madison Police Department was dispatched to the 2900 block of Todd Drive reference a Weapons Offense (Shots fired).  After officers arrived on scene, they would interview a number of witnesses that reside in the area that reported multiple shots being fired near Churchhill Drive & Greenway View Drive.  Area residents reported broken glass and the smell of gasoline, and officers would later find evidence of such along with multiple 9mm bullet casings near the 2900 block of Todd Drive.  One vehicle of interest was described as 1980’s Crown Victoria or Chevrolet boxy styled car that was seen in the area during the time area residents reported hearing the shots.  There may have also been a van in the area at the time.   Broken glass at the scene may be suggestive of damage to windows of the involved vehicle(s).  It is also thought that the odor of gasoline could be a result of damage to a vehicle as well.Madison police officers worked through inclement weather to preserve evidence at the scene after this matter was reported, but we are asking that anyone with information about this incident contact the The Madison Police Department as soon as possible.  No known victims or suspects have been developed in this case, and any information would prove to aid in our investigation.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: 2 Hispanic Males
properties.Details: On Saturday April 28, at 8:19 p.m., officers responded to a report of a woman who was shot in the face. The incident occurred in the 900 block of Engelhart Dr on the sidewalk next to Indian Springs Park. The victim, a 23 year-old female, who was walking with six family members and four dogs, had a wound below her lower lip. From the size of the wound and the statements of witnesses, it was thought that she was probably shot with a pellet gun. Fire Department Paramedics treated the victim at the scene.Witnesses reported seeing a white mini-van pass the group once and they heard popping noises. When the van passed them again, witnesses again heard popping and the victim was struck in the face. The van was described as an older model mini-van, possibly a 93 or 94 model, with a protruding engine compartment. There were two Hispanic males in the in the divers and front passenger seats.This is believed to be a random attack. Neighbors report seeing the van in the area on previous occasions and report incidents of pellet damage to garage doors and windows dating back to the fall of 2006. Please call Madison Police if you have any information about suspects or are the victim of other attacks. Police are also interested in sightings of the vehicle or suspects in the Moorland Rd – Indian Springs area.

properties.Arrested: . Male, Age 11, MadisonArrested for Disorderly Conduct while Armed
properties.Details: On Sunday afternoon, around 4:30 p.m., a Madison Police officer was driving along Milwaukee Street when he witnessed two young men sitting on lawn chairs in front of a residence. One of the boys had a handgun, and was holding it in front of him with both hands on the weapon. Based on training, the officer recognized the boy’s stance as being one of a possible threat. The officer called for back up, and approached the residence in a tactical manner, using a tree for cover. The boys ran inside the residence, and later admitted they had been playing with an air gun. It looked just like a real weapon. The replica gun and ammo were taken as evidence. Madison Police urge parents to realize officers must make split second decisions when dealing with weapons, and it's impossible to quickly determine which are real, and which are facsimiles

properties.Details: On 8/30/07 Madison Police learned of a vehicle possibly carrying a firearm.  More specifics about the vehicle, location and suspects were developed through good police work.  Eventually the vehicle was discovered empty in the 3100 block of Muir Field Rd in a parking lot.  Officers maintained surveillance of the car and were able to effectuate a traffic stop once Watson and a companion entered and drove away.  A high-risk traffic stop was performed in the 2100 block of Muir Field, due to the information concerning high-powered weapons inside.  A high-risk traffic stop is one in which numerous officers convene on a vehicle for the occupant's and officer's safety.  Through the course of the investigation officers found an AK-47 assault rifle and a .44 magnum Ruger handgun with a 10.5-inch barrel.  Along with these weapons were several rounds of ammunition.

Shortly after 5:00 p.m. on Thursday October 11th Madison police were called to Allied Drive for a report of shots being fired. A staff member at the Childhood Learning Center indicated approximately 80 students had been placed in lock-down status. The Learning Center employee said shots were at first heard, and then a suspect was spotted outside carrying a long-barreled handgun. Responding officers determined the suspect had likely exchanged fire with someone inside a passing car. One round appeared to have broken an upper glass window in the foyer area of an apartment building, but no one was injured. A Sgt. requested the assistance of Madison K-9 Ivan, a one-year-old German Shepard, so that apartment building could be checked for possible weapons. Ivan is able to search for fresh human scent, and it was thought a weapon that had just been fired would have such a scent. Ivan did not detect anything on the upper floors, but upon entering the basement he showed great interest in an area of a storage locker where an air conditioner had been placed. Ivan's partner then found a long-barreled handgun next to the air conditioner. Outside of the building Ivan put his nose to work and found a bullet casing.

properties.Details: On November second around 2:28 a.m. Madison police were dispatched to the area of W. Earlier in the morning, around 1:56 a.m., a squad car being driven by a Madison police officer along John Nolen Drive had been hit with a similar paint round. It left a yellow splatter of the squad's windshield. Dispatch also aired reports of people being fired at in the 700 block of W. Dayton Street.  During this time period, Madison officers, and UW police were actively looking for the suspect vehicle, and it was UW officers who pulled it over in the 1200 block of Regent Street. Around 3:57 a.m. the suspects were arrested. A paint ball gun, and paint balls were seized from the car, which was a silver '96 Honda Accord. A treating physician told the female victim (the one hit in the head) that she could have lost an eye had the paintball struck a little lower.

properties.Suspect: Major T. Lemon (44 yrs of age)
properties.Details: Officers were dispatched to the West Towne Mall Food Court reference a man with a gun.  Officers arrived dressed in full military-style police uniform and observed a male matching the suspect description standing in the middle of the Food Court.  Officers attempted to contact the suspect (later identified as Lemon) and escort him from the crowded mall area.  The suspect had his hand in his pocket and began to physically resist, at that point officers took control of the suspect's other arm.  The suspect then made statements that he was going to punch an officer.  Based on the weapon information and the suspect's physical resistance, officers attempted to take the suspect to the ground.  Because of the wet, snow-covered tile, they were unable to take the suspect to the ground.  An additional officer responded, observed the physical struggle, and deployed their assigned electronic control device.  One of the probes struck the suspect and the other probe struck the suspect's wife.  Both the suspect and the suspect's wife were secured in handcuffs (the suspect's wife was later released with no charges or injuries).  The suspect made statements that he had a heart condition, therefore Madison Fire Department responded and later conveyed the suspect to St. Mary's emergency room, where he was evaluated, cited for resisting/obstructing, and released.

He is identified above and will be incarcerated in the Dane County Jail.    If anyone has information regarding this incident, you are asked to contact the Madison Police Department at 266-4275.

At 7:00 p.m. Sunday night a citizen reported two subjects with guns inside a storefront in the 1700 block of Monroe St. It was also reported that another subject had his hands tied behind his back. At least thirteen officers from the Madison Police Department responded to the weapons incident involving a possible hostage. Several of the officers were members of the MPD Emergency Response Team (ERT). UW police also assisted. Upon arrival a perimeter was established and traffic on Monroe St was redirected. An officer positioned across the street from the store confirmed that a subject inside was carrying a shotgun.While officers were on scene, one subject emerged from the building and was taken into custody. In response to the commands issued to this first subject, three others left the store and were promptly detained. From these subjects it was learned that six other subjects were still in the building. It was also learned that all were members of group known as Strollers Theatre. They were rehearsing a play involving guns and a hostage. As one cast member remarked about the prop guns, “They’re suppose to look real.”While the outcome of this incident seems humorous, it is worth noting that the officers responded “lights and siren”, real rifles and handguns were directed towards citizens and a peaceful neighborhood was disrupted and disturbed by the sight of armed subjects both real and imagined. The four subjects who emerged from the building were subjected to the brusque professionalism required of officers in these situations. They were ordered to back toward the voices of the armed officers, handcuffed, searched and at least one was placed in a squad.The director and crew were urged to cover the windows and inform the 911 Center when rehearsing scenes that might be misunderstood if observed out of context. It is not unusual for dramatic groups and filmmakers to use Madison as a backdrop for their productions. MPD asks such groups to consider public perceptions and work with us to assure that everyone is safe and that reality doesn’t intrude. The building in this case is a vacant store that was being used by the theater group for rehearsals. All subjects were released without charges.

properties.Suspect: Justin B. Goodwin, age 17, MadisonWade E. Smith, age 17, MadisonMr. Goodwin and Mr. Smith were both arrested and tentatively charged with Going Armed with a Pellet Fun, & Underage Person Consumes/Possess Alcohol Off of Licensed Premises.

properties.Details: On Sunday the 20th a 16-year-old young man reported to Madison Police that he had been shot in the hand with a BB gun between 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. the night prior.
