One, the 16-year old victim, was knocked to the floor during the dispute, and is believed to have lost consciousness. Another student is accused of battering the victim while she was down. The victim suffered abrasions, but did not require hospitalization. The incident is under investigation.

properties.Suspect: Cruz Banuelos, age 41, MadisonMr. Banuelos was arrested and tentatively charged with Domestic Battery to an Elderly Person, Intimidation of a Victim/Witness, and Domestic Disorderly Conduct.
properties.Victim: Male, age 82, MadisonVictim suffered two black eyes, and facial cuts.
properties.Details: On Sunday evening, around 9:56 p.m., Madison Police were summoned to a residence just off of Packers Avenue. At the location officers learned an 82-year old man had been punched several times in the head the night prior while he was inside his own home. The victim said he had recently rented a room to the suspect. The suspect was also buying food for the victim, and helping him prepare meals. The victim says on Saturday night, around 10:00 p.m., he asked the suspect to turn down the television so he could go to bed. He says this erupted into a fight, one where he was both chocked and punched. During the attack the victim's eyeglass frame was bent, and one of its’ lenses popped out. The victim says the suspect also threatened to kill him. After the battery the victim says the suspect unplugged the phones so that he could not immediately call police.

On 3/23/2005 at approximately 12:49 pm Madison Police Officer Andy Slawek was on routine patrol in the Olbrich Boat Launch.  Officer Slawek noticed a dog that had jumped into Lake Monona after a duck decoy.  As the dog struggled to get out of the water, the dog's owner dove into the water to render aid.  Officer Slawek noticed now that both the dog and owner were struggling in 10 foot, frigid water.  Nearby was a Martin-Glass company vehicle with a ladder.  Employees of Martin-Glass and Officer Slawek used the ladder to help save the citizen and dog. It was estimated that the dog and citizen were in the water for 5-10 minutes.  Madison Fire/Rescue also responded to the scene.  The Madison Police Department suggests that citizens use extreme caution near the lakes as the warmer weather thins the ice.

properties.Arrested: Suspect:  Michael D. Streiff  m/w  06/29/82  5'2"  145# br/blu and has beard.          (may be riding a bicycle)
properties.Details: Streiff is suspected of going door to door soliciting donations for different charities and keeping the money.  Streiff is also suspected of stealing money from at least one residence where he was allowed entry.  Streiff is believed to not be associated with any valid charity effort.  City of Madison general ordinance 9.14 requires all door to door solicitors to register with the City Clerk's Office and hold a solicitors permit.  The Madison Police Department encourages citizens contacted by a solicitor to request to view the individuals solicitors permit.  The Police Department also reminds citizens to use good discretion allowing any stranger into their home.

properties.Arrested: Male, 24, Madison
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is investigating a financial crime at a local east side restaurant chain in which over $200 was stolen from various customers.  An employee of the restaurant would alter the tip amount on the receipt slip for additional money.  Forty altered receipts have been collected by the Madison Police Department, dating back to October 7, 2005.  The dollar amounts altered ranged from $2 to $10 per transaction.The Madison Police Department reminds both customers and store/restaurant managers to be mindful to the accuracy of receipts.

properties.Arrested: Michael D. Streiff, White Male, 23 years-old, 5'2, 120 lbs.
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is seeking the community’s help in apprehending Michael D. Streiff.  Streiff is wanted for multiple counts of forgery and theft.  Streiff has been going door-to-door soliciting money from the elderly on the Westside of Madison representing himself as a church volunteer collecting money for charities. Streiff has recently shaved his head and currently drives a gray 4-door vehicle with damage to the rear quarter panel.  Anyone with information as to Streiff’s whereabouts is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Black male, 40's, dark winter coat, approximately 5'08.
properties.Details: On 12/1/05 a Madison Police Officer took a report from a victim who was reporting a theft of her wallet.  The victim's credit card company called the victim to report suspicious behavior on her account.  Particularly gift cards were purchased at four west side stores, totaling over $500.00.  The victim recalled shopping on 11/30/05 and as she was leaving the store, being approached by the above mentioned suspect.  Thinking back, she believed the encounter was strange because the male had distracted her.  While leaving the foyer, the suspect cut in front of her with a shopping cart and made her focus her attention to the wheels.  In doing so, the suspect also asked the victim for help with this cart, which seemed odd because the victim's hands were full of bags and the suspect's hands were empty.  For a brief moment the victim was turned from the suspect and it is believed the wallet was stolen at this juncture.  The Madison Police Department advises people to be mindful of their belongings, secure their purses and wallets and pay attention to distractions that could have wicked intentions.

properties.Arrested: Driver of a blue pickup truck with a plow on the front end and sand bags inthe back.
properties.Details: At approximately 9 am on 01/30/06, a member of the UW Hoofers Club called MPD to report the theft of a sail kite.  He indicated that members of the UW Hoofers Club had been practicing with the sail kite at Vilas Park on Sunday, 01/29/06, when the kite became stuck in the tree.  The Hoofers Club memmber indicated he returned to the park at 7:00 am this morning to retrieve the kite, but needed to leave in order to get some equipment.  He stated he returned at 8:00 am, and discovered that the kite was gone.  He was advised by park employees that a subject in a blue pickup truck with a plow on the front end and sand bags in the back had taken the kite.  Suspect accomplished this by driving the pickup truck under the tree, standing on the top of the truck and pulling the kite down.  The kite is described as a 12 foot green and black flexifold kite.  The words "flexifold" and "bullet" appear on the kite.  The kite is new and the value is approximately $600.  Hoofers Club would like the kite returned.  Anyone with information on this case can call Crime Stoppers at #266-6014.

Workers wanted to prepare the snow blowers for this week's large storm and were unable to locate them.  The Toro snow blowers had various values between $600-800 apiece.

It is believed that the theft occurred sometime between 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on 03/31/2006.  Anyone with information on this may call Crimestoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Sherry Newell, 52, Madison:  Identity Theft, repeater
properties.Details: On 8/16/06 a Madison Police Officer took a follow-up report for an identity theft case.  In all, it was learned that Newell had stolen the victim's identity and set up an account with Charter Communications.  The victim had lived in the same building as Newell and Newell somehow gained access to the victim's personal information.  The victim now lives in Florida and her father started receiving unpaid bills in his daughter's name.  The father alerted police.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 1/31/07 at approximately 9:30 p.m. a Madison Police Officer took a report from a person who had numerous items stolen from her locker at the Princeton Club (east) while working out. The officer learned further that the keys stolen from the locker were used to get into the person's vehicle.  Inside the vehicle the suspect(s) took an important bag, purse, cash, credit cards, cellphone and other items.  Also taken in the bag was a list of 150 state legislators names and their social security numbers.  This remains an open investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with information about this crime is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: 5 arrested.Arlysa Chatman, female, 19, Fitchburg:  Receiving Stolen Property-Party to a Crime (PTAC)Joseph Billups, male, 18, Chicago: Receiving Stolen Property-PTACTyler Watson, male, 24, Madison; Danielle Gehrt, female 19, Madison; Mark Delao, male, 26, Madison.  All three charged with: Possession of Burglary Tools-PTAC, Entry into locked vehicle-PTAC, Theft-PTAC, Criminal Damage to Property-PTAC, Possession of stolen property-PTAC
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department has made five arrests related to burglary, car break-ins and construction site thefts.  On 2/5/07 an officer took a theft report from a construction site.  The officer alerted several recycling places, as this area has seen a large increase in copper being stolen and sold to recycling businesses.  A short time later a recycling business reported suspicious behavior.  A different officer was dispatched and confirmed that the materials that were trying to be sold to the recycling business, were from the site of the primary officer.  Chatman and Billups were arrested.  Later that day, patrol officers responded to a complaint of three individuals breaking into vehicles.  Those three individuals (Watson, Gehrt and Delao) were contacted and arrested.  As intelligence came in and the investigation continued, the Madison Police Department has learned the five individuals are connected in an unsophisticated way.  No further details are available at this time, as this remains an open investigation.  MPD asks victims of thefts/burglaries to wait to be contacted as officers have property to sort through and are looking for identifying marks.  Additionally, MPD reminds the community (including construction companies) to clearly label, mark or etch their valuables with names and/or driver's license numbers.  This information is the easiest way for law enforcement to track if it is ever reported stolen.

properties.Arrested: Two adult black females, early 20's, both of medium height, one is stockier and the other is a thin build.  One female typically wears a pink winter parka.Included is about 10 black male teenagers.
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is investigating a theft ring at area health clubs.  There has been a pattern of thefts from area health clubs, which investigators believe are connected.  Similar cases have been investigated in the Milwaukee area as well.  Two adult black females have been successful in repeatedly slipping past front desk clerks without being seen and then going into locker rooms to break into lockers with bolt cutters.  To assist in the females gaining entrance into the health clubs, a blitz of black male teenage boys distract the front clerk by asking to use the bathroom, borrow a basketball, etc.  The suspects then enter the locker rooms and begin cutting locks and stealing property from within.  The suspects steal car keys, purses, wallets, cell phones and credit cars, etc.  When keys are stolen the suspects use the remote access in the parking lot to then gain entry into vehicles, to steal the car and/or valuables inside.  The suspects are believed to have also made a practice of watching the parking lot for members who arrive to work out and are seen bending down to conceal their purses or wallets under the seats.  The suspects then target those particular vehicles, breaking in car windows and grabbing what they can before fleeing.  In addition, when credit and ATM cards have been stolen, the female suspects have been known to call back the club and purport to be "fraud alert bank employees" needing to speak to the unassuming victim still working out.  The victims are paged and are told there is an active fraud going on, by the suspects.  The suspects tell the shocked victim that they need their PIN (personal id number) in order to shut down the account.  After the PIN is given, the suspects use that information for purchasing items via the internet, cash withdrawals from ATMs and other purchases.  The victims often do not think as to how the "bank employee" knew they were at the Health Club, until days later.  Also, the victim doesn't bother to cancel the account until several days later, because they already spoke with who they believe was a "bank employee".  The female suspects are very mobile and the trail of fraudulent withdrawals and purchases suggest they leave town within an hour of the thefts and continue making illegal transactions on victims' accounts in towns and cities across southern WI for the rest of the day.The Madison Police Department reminds citizens to never give out personal information over the phone, particularly if you are at the victim of a theft.  Also, it is advisable not to leave valuables in vehicles or lockers.

properties.Arrested: Male, black, early 40's, 5'9Male, black, late 20's, 6'
properties.Details: On 4/12/07 Madison Police took a theft report from the victim.  According to the victim, he was looking to purchase a Nintendo Wii and found a seller on "Craig's List" from the internet.  It was agreed that they would meet downtown for the exchange.  Upon meeting the victim went to an ATM to withdrawl cash for the purchase.  Originally the victim wanted to make sure the equipment worked, so the two went to an apartment and knocked on a door.  No one answered the door, so the victim trusted the package contained the Nintendo and that it worked.  After the money was exchanged and the two parted, the victim opened the package to find a wrapped up telephone book. It did not plug into a Nintendo.

Someone stole a copious amount of fishing equipment from a boat parked in the street on 5/7/07 after midnight and before 8 a.m.  Someone went under the cover of the boat and stole Lawrence fish finders, musky poles, musky reels, multiple boxes of fishing tackle, navigation chip, Kodak camera, life jackets and other items.  In all it is estimated that over $5,000 worth of equipment was stolen from the boat.  If anyone has any information about this crime, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

On Friday, May 25 at 4:16 p.m. Madison Police responded to the Sunset Memory Gardens. The cemetery's manager indicated that 50 bronze vases that had attached to burial plaques had been stolen. She believes the vases are worth in the neighborhood of $7,500. It's believed the thefts happened between May 21 and May 24.Anyone with information is urged to call Crimestoppers at 266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and maybe eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: n/a

properties.Details: On 6/9/07 it was reported to Madison Police that "Diamond" was stolen from a fenced in backyard.  The owner of Diamond had fenced in Diamond and two German Shepherds and secured the fence with a garden hose.  The owner was positive that the fence was secure and that someone had to have stolen Diamond; particularly with the German Shepherds remaining inside the fence all day.  Diamond answers to his name Diamond and anyone with information to his whereabouts should call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Black Male19-20 years old5'7" to 5'8"Slim BuildWearing a white t-shirt
properties.Details: On Monday afternoon, around 2:30 p.m., Madison police responded to a gas station on Britta Parkway for a theft report. The responding officer found a woman, visibly shaken, and holding onto her purse. She says a thief had smashed out the passenger side window of her car, and run off with her purse. Asked how she got it back she pointed to a man who was in the process of fueling his motorcycle. The 21-year-old Dubuque resident told the officer he witnessed the crime and chased the thief on his motorcycle. He told the suspect, whom he says was bleeding from one of his arms, to drop the purse or her would get off of his bike. The suspect complied with the directive. The officer thanked the Dubuque resident for his heroic efforts.

properties.Address: 100 block N. Thornton Ave.  & 1400 block E. Main St.
properties.Details: On July 12th Madison Police took a report from a manager of several apartment complexes. He indicates thieves dismantled several air conditioner units in order to steal copper wire from within. Copper thefts from apartment AC units were reported on both Thornton Avenue, and East Main Street.Also this week, Ft. Atkinson Police report they had a large copper wire theft from a local utility company. Thousands of feet of bundled copper wire was pulled from beneath a fence.Across the country similar thefts are being reported as scrap metal prices for the not-so-rare precious metal remains relatively high.In some areas recycling companies are paying $3.95 a pound for copper according to a report in The Tampa Tribune.

properties.Arrested: Female, white, 20's, 5'6", long blonde hair in a ponytail, last seen wearing jean shorts & a tank top.
properties.Details: On Monday July 30th around 6:25 p.m. Madison Police were dispatched to East Towne Mall for a report of a purse theft. A 55-year-old shopper says a younger woman approached her as she was leaving the mall and said she needed a ride to a nearby motel. The suspect stated she was pregnant, and it was too hot for her to walk. The victim says the suspect looked disheveled and "down on her luck." She was reluctant to provide transportation but the victim just hopped in to her car. She then proceeded to drive her (the suspect) to the motel. Once there, the suspect told the victim she wanted to give her a hug. As she leaned over for the embrace she (the suspect) instead reached into the back of the car and swiped the woman's purse. The victim gave chase, but the suspect was able to run away.The crime is similar to one recently reported in Monona, and could be linked to another in the City of Madison.

properties.Arrested: Richard E. Borousk, Age 36, PardeevilleTentative Charges: Theft, Disorderly Conduct, and a Probation Hold
properties.Details: On Saturday, August 11, around 1:27 p.m. Madison Police responded to the Wal-Mart on Nakoosa Trail for a report of a fight occurring inside the store. The caller said several shoppers were holding down a wallet thief. After arresting the suspect listed above officers learned that a 41-year-old woman had been shopping with her husband and son. As she eyeballed a potential purchase she detected someone walking past her cart, inside of which was her open purse. Her pocketbook had been visible inside the purse and was now missing. The woman saw the suspect moving quickly away and she yelled out, "Stop! I know you have my wallet!" Her husband, who had been pushing their son in another cart, was in a nearby aisle and he took on the suspect. Two other shoppers came to his aid, and the three of them held on until police arrived.

properties.Arrested: Annette Dorenzo, 48, Sun Prairie:  Theft, Criminal Trespass to Medical Facility, Warrant-Tresspass
properties.Details: On 8/27/07 at 11:34 a.m. Madison Police responded to a report of a theft in an administrative office of Meriter Hospital.  A former employee and Dorenzo were in the hospital with the intent to steal wallets.  Dorenzo entered an office in a secured environment, with a receptionist.  Dorenzo went into an office in which the employee was in the bathroom.  Upon return, the employee found Dorenzo in the office rummaging near the trashcan.  The surprised employee asked Dorenzo her business and why she was in her office.  Dorenzo left and security was called.  Police arrested Dorenzo without incident.  Dorenzo explained it was her intent to go to the hospital to steal money/wallets from offices.  Police are looking for her accomplice.

properties.Arrested: Ralph F. Howland, IIIAge 36, MadisonDavid L. EnglishAge 40, MadisonBoth were arrested and tentatively charged with:Party to a Crime of Theft Moveable Property in excess of $2,500, and Obstructing Police
properties.Details: Early in the morning of Wednesday September 5th a Madison Police officer on routine patrol pulled over a pickup truck that was pulling a construction trailer. The officer, earlier in his shift, took a report in which a similar truck may have been involved in a theft from a construction site. At the time of the traffic stop the driver of the pickup truck, Mr. English, jumped out and began running. Backup officers were able to set up a perimeter and take him into custody in a couple of minutes. Passenger Howland was taken into custody at the scene of the traffic stop. A check on the construction trailer's registration revealed it belongs to Parisi Construction. The officer's earlier call was to the home of a north side businessman. He told police two men sold him an air compressor that the businessman believed might have been stolen. He called police and provided a detailed description of the suspects and the truck in which they were traveling. That information led to the traffic stop.

properties.Arrested: Elder J. Nunez, Age 19, MadisonTentative charges: Receiving Stolen Property, Criminal Damage to Property, and Entry into Locked VehicleJorge V. Ramirez-Flores, Age 28, MadisonTentative Charge: Receiving Stolen Property
properties.Details: On Wednesday morning a Madison Police officer from the South District, who has been working a number of car break-in cases, followed leads that took him to a beltline area motel. Contact was made with occupants of one of the motel rooms. A subsequent search of the room resulted in a large number of items, likely stolen, being recovered. They included car stereos and video equipment, construction tools, and Wisconsin photo ID's. Detectives believe the arrests of those listed above will clear up a large number of theft cases, some of these involved break-ins to cars housed at various beltline area businesses.

properties.Suspect: David Brooks, age 43, MadisonMr. Brooks was arrested on a probation hold.Male, Age 16, MadisonTentatively charged with BurglaryMale, Age 15, MadisonTentatively charged with Burglary
properties.Details: On Saturday morning around 6:52 Madison Police responded to an apartment complex where a van was parked. Strapped to the top of the van were five boxes of aluminum siding. The siding was stolen that morning from a home being built on Avalon Street, which is the new Veridian Homes Heather Glen neighborhood. Mr. Brooks was located living in an apartment near where the van was parked. He and two juveniles were arrested for the theft. Many Madison construction sites have been the targets of similar crimes this year. A detective has been assigned to this case, and additional charges are possible.

properties.Suspect: Male, black, age 14, MadisonSuspect was booked into the Juvenile Reception Center on a tentative charge of Theft.
properties.Details: On December 17th at 12:36 p.m. Madison police were called to East Towne Mall for a purse snatching. Dispatch advised the suspect was being chased by a witness who turned out to be an off-duty Columbia County Sheriff's deputy. The deputy had been shopping with a friend when the purse-snatcher reached into the friend's shopping cart and took off running. The 56-year-old deputy was unable to catch the 14-year-old suspect, but did help direct officers to an area near the mall into which the suspect had gone. A second witness told responding officers that the suspect was now in a nearby video game store. The deputy arrived as the suspect was detained by Madison police. The suspect initially denied culpability, but the deputy said, "You're a liar. I saw you there (in the store) and I'm the one that was chasing you." The young man later admitted to his crime. The victim's purse was found in a trashcan, while her money was in the suspect's pocket.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, 5'8", with an average build. He spoke with a heavy Australian accent.
properties.Details: On 12/19/2007 Madison police were called to St. Mary's to take a report on a theft that occurred on Saturday December 15th at around 2:00 p.m. Following an internal investigation hospital security staff concluded more than $100,000 in high-tech surgical equipment had been stolen. A man, who appeared to be very knowledgeable about Synthes made surgical sets, convinced staff he was, in fact, a representative of the manufacturer. Sythes makes sterilized surgical equipment out of titanium and stainless steel. The perpetrator, utilizing a thick Australian accent, used the ruse to get to the area where Synthes sets are housed. Hospital staff say it is not unusual for representatives of certain high-tech companies to arrive on location to inspect their equipment. During this visit the perpetrator also passed himself off to other hospital employees as a new operating room doctor. Following his review of several Synthes sets it was discovered many items were missing including one compete set. The bogus company representative/phony doctor left quickly and was carrying a backpack. Anyone with information is asked to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Suspect: Vestee M. Adams, age 17, MadisonTheft (party to a crime, 2 counts), Retail Theft, Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent (OMVWOC)Female, black, age 12Theft, Trespassing, Retail Theft, OMVWOCFemale, black, age 16Arrested & tentatively charged with same crimes as 12-year-old listed above
properties.Details: On Wednesday January 9th shortly before 2:00 p.m. a Waunakee woman pulled into a disabled parking stall near Jo-Ann Fabrics. Utilizing her cane she walked into the store. As she did so she noticed several young people, one male and two females, watching her. Once inside the fabric store the male approached and asked the woman for directions to a nearby department store. The woman, who had placed her cane and purse inside her shopping cart, pointed out the window in the direction of where he needed to go. As she did so the two females grabbed her purse from the cart. The victim screamed. Madison Police were called as the suspects ran towards East Towne Mall. Responding officers nabbed all three. They had in their possession clothing that is believed to have just been stolen from the Burlington Coat Factory, and keys to a stolen car. The keys had been in a purse that was stolen from East Towne Mall on December 27, 2007.  The male suspect is believed to have had the car (2001 Nissan) until Tuesday January 8th when police recovered it. It was found parked outside the school he (the 17-year-old) attends. The 12 & 16-year-old suspects are banned from East Towne Mall because of prior retail thefts, which is why they were charged with trespassing. The purse that was stolen from the cart at the fabric store was returned to the owner.

properties.Suspect: One suspect has been identified but not yet arrested. The identity of a second perpetrator is being sought.
properties.Details: On Saturday January 12th Madison Police were called to an address on Carling Drive to take a theft report. A very distraught 63-year-old woman from Madison was at the residence. According to a police report, the victim was "extremely emotionally upset and crying ... having a hard time speaking." In between her bursts of tears the responding officer was able to take her statement. The woman reports that she had gone to the Dane County Humane Society on Voges Road on Friday afternoon January 11, 2008. She went armed with reward fliers as she hoped to find her missing dog. She handed these out to many people who were also at the Humane Society. The victim says the next morning (Saturday) she received a call around 9:30 from someone claiming to know who had her dog. The woman agreed to rendezvous’ with the caller. They met up at a convenience store on Maple Grove Road. The caller had brought with him a second individual. The duo told the woman they would take her to the "guy." He purportedly lived at the address on Carling Drive. Once on location one of the two suspects went into the residence with $80 in reward money, which had been given to him by the victim. He came back out and said the "guy" would not even let the woman see her dog for $80, that more cash would be needed. She then consented to go to an ATM machine where she withdrew $400. A suspect took the money inside never to be seen again. The victim called the Humane Society to report what was happening. She got a call back from a 911 dispatcher who told her police were on their way. The second suspect then also departed.

properties.Suspect: Suspect #1: Male, age 16, MadisonSuspect #2: Male, age 16, MadisonSuspect #1 was arrested and tentatively charged with Robbery (Party to a Crime).Suspect #2 was arrested and tentatively charged with Robbery (Party to a Crime), and Possession of Drug Paraphernalia.
properties.Details: On Monday, March 10, 2008, a 21 year-old Madison man was operating his laptop computer while seated inside a Madison Metro Bus, which had stopped at the West Transfer Point. He says a teenage suspect slapped or punched him in the face, grabbed his laptop, and took off running. The victim says the thief had an accomplice and he pursued both teens as they took off toward South Whitney Way and Odana Road. He was unable to catch the culprits, but a responding police officer was successful. The suspects were taken into custody near Vitense Golfland on Schroeder Road. The computer was recovered and returned to its owner.

properties.Suspect: Gordon E. Walker, age 65, MadisonMr. Walker was arrested and tentatively charged with two counts of Theft.
properties.Details: On Tuesday around 2:16 p.m. Madison Police were called to Associated Physicians on Regent Street after two employees reported money had been stolen from their purses. A suspicious man had been seen in the building and was later spotted getting on a Madison Metro bus. Armed with this information MPD officers caught up with the bus near UW Hospital and were able to make contact with the suspect. He was taken back to Associated Physicians where he was identified as the man who had been in the building at the time of the thefts. A roll of cash was found in the suspect's pocket.

properties.Suspect: John T. Voelz, age 41, MadisonMr. Voelz was arrested and tentatively charged with Obtaining/Possession of a Controlled Substance by Fraud, and a Probation Violation
properties.Details: On April 29th, around 8:30 a.m., Madison police arrested John Voelz at the Wisconsin Department of Correction's Probation & Parole office on West Badger Road. Mr. Voelz has been identified as the man who perpetrated a ruse against several residents of Oakwood Village this past winter. On March 10th, around 4:35 p.m., Mr. Voelz contacted approximately ten residents. He was going door to door claiming he worked for a pharmacy, and saying he needed to check expiration dates on medicines. Several residents let Mr. Voelz into their apartments and one said medicine, a bottle of Hydrocodone, was missing. Oakwood staff were notified of the suspicious man and quickly found someone matching the description on the center's grounds. The suspect claimed he was looking for an apartment, and gave an address that did not exist. Staff followed the suspect at a safe distance as he left, and provided police with information that later led to his arrest.

properties.Suspect: Jeffrey L. Dietzman, age 28, MadisonMr. Dietzman was arrested and tentatively charged with Entry into a Locked Coin Box (3 counts), & Possession of Burglary Tools.
properties.Address: 711 West Badger Road (Whale Of A Wash)
properties.Details: Early Monday morning, around 12:33 a.m., Madison Police officers responded to a burglary in progress call after a witness saw someone breaking into the locked coin boxes of a West Badger Road carwash. A suspect was found inside one of the wash bays. He dropped a bolt cutter as an officer approached him. Three coin boxes were damaged.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, black, 40's, 5'9", thin build, no glasses, clean-shaven, short hair with a tint of gray. He was last seen wearing an un-tucked shirt with an orange background with green small squares in a checkered pattern.
properties.Details: A woman who lives on Williamson Street says a man forced entry into her apartment early this morning and grabbed her buttocks. The victim repeatedly told the perpetrator to leave. After a short while, the suspect did get out, and it was at that time the woman discovered her wallet, and some other personal items were missing. A short time later her credit card was used at an area business. The victim was not injured. The perpetrator is at large, and a detective has been assigned to the case.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a female, black, 30's, thin build, long hair, wearing a grey shirt, and a "flashy, rhinestone" type belt. She fled in a silver colored SUV with a temporary license plate.
properties.Details: On Thursday afternoon, around 2:57 p.m., Madison Police responded to the parking lot of Sam's Club, 7050 Watts Road, after a woman's purse was stolen from a shopping cart. The victim provided a description of the thief, and the vehicle in which she fled. Please see the above portion of this incident report.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a female, black, late 20's to early 30's, wearing a pink shirt, and driving a gold colored SUV, possibly a GMC product with no front plate and a temporary tag on its rear.
properties.Details: Thursday evening, around 7:28 p.m., Madison Police were called to the parking lot of the Cub Foods store on Nakoosa Trail following a purse snatching. The victim said she was just securing her child, and getting groceries loaded into her vehicle when she heard footsteps. The next thing she knew a woman had grabbed her purse from a grocery cart. The Madison mom says the thief jumped into a nearby SUV, hit the pedal hard, and left skid marks in the parking lot.

properties.Suspect: (UPDATED)Elizabeth R. Bell, age 29, FitchburgMs. Bell has been arrested and tenatively charged with Substantial Battery and two counts of Theft.------(ORIGINAL RELEASE)Perpetrator is described as female, black, 40's, driving a silver SUV with a temporary tag in the rear.

properties.Details: (UPDATED MONDAY JULY 28, 2008)On July 23, 2008 members of the Madison Police Department's West District Community Police Team stopped a 1998 Chevy Tahoe near the Verona Road Walgreen's around 5:00 p.m.These officers had been advised to be on the look out for a vehicle similar to the Tahoe, as it may have been involved in several crimes that had taken place on July 17th.Inside the Tahoe was Elizabeth R. Bell, age 29, Fitchburg.She has now been tentatively charged with Substantial Battery and Theft for a strong-armed robbery that took place in the Woodman's parking lot on the 17th (original Incident Report is posted below). She has also been tentatively charged with Theft for a similar crime that took place on the 17th at Sam's Club, 7050 Watts Road (there is an Incident Report on this crime posted on the Madison Police website).A third theft that took place at Cub Foods, 4141 Nakoosa Trail, on July 17th remains under investigation, and Bell has not been ruled out as a suspect in that crime (more details can be found on a separate Madison Police Incident Report).(ORIGINAL RELEASE)-------------------------------------------------------------------On Thursday night, at 8:58 p.m., Madison Police were called to the Woodman's grocery store parking lot on South Gammon Road for a purse snatching. The victim says the thief swiped her purse from the shopping grocery cart she was using. The 38-year-old responded by giving chase, which resulted in the crook punching the victim in the face. Madison Police are investigating whether the same perpetrator was involved in Thursday night's purse snatching incidents.Anyone with information is urged to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and maybe eligible for up to a $1,000 reward.The Madison Police Department would advise shoppers not to leave purses in shopping carts.

On July 18th a Madison resident got into her car, turned the ignition key, and discovered the gas tank she thought to be half-full was in fact empty. The motorist got out and walked to the rear of her Honda CRV to discover that someone had pried open the gas cover door. She spotted her gas cap on the ground. The woman had left the CRV parked on the street in front of her home. She called the Madison Police Department's Self Report Unit to report the crime, which she says cost her about $20 worth of fuel.

On July 18th a Madison Police Officer working in the MPD’s Self Report Unit took a call from a 70 year-old Madison man who had recently been victimized by a thief - a thief the man suspected was stealing aluminum that could be sold for cash. In his case the culprit made off with the 24-foot mast, and the eight-foot boom, which had been strapped to his 19-foot sailboat. He had the boat parked in the lot of a friend's business on Seiferth Road. The sailor said it would cost approximately $1,200 to replace the stolen gear.

properties.Suspect: Daniel J. Aiken, age 20, MadisonMr. Aiken was arrested and tentatively charged with Theft, and Battery.
properties.Details: On Thursday evening, around 7:35 p.m., Madison Police responded to Pierce's Market, 2817 N. Sherman Ave. A dispatcher advised that market employees were outside and holding down a purse thief. He was quickly handcuffed and arrested. The victim said she was in the meat section when the suspect grabbed her purse from a shopping cart and sprinted for the exit. She yelled for help. A female cashier was the first out the door. She was able to catch up with the suspect, and the two tussled over the purse. During this encounter the suspect used it to hit the cashier a couple of times in the head. Within seconds more employees were involved. They took the suspect to the ground, and held him until police were on scene.

properties.Arrested: Phillip Schaeffer29 years oldNo permanent address-Criminal trespass to dwelling-Possession of THC (warrant)-Resisting/Obstructing (warrant)
properties.Details: On 3/25/05 at approximately 4:30 a.m. Madison Police were dispatched to the 500 block of Russell St. for an unwanted person inside of a residence.  When police arrived they made contact with the elderly homeowner who had suspected that someone entered the home and had come into the victims bedroom.  While the investigating officer was taking a statement from the victim and airing on the police radio a description, another officer noticed an individual matching the description, walking nearby.  The individual, identified as Schaeffer, apparently was walking home from a downtown bar and needed a place to stay warm.  It was discovered that the back door to the residence was unlocked, allowing Schaeffer to enter without permission.  The Madison Police Department is reminding people to lock their doors to prevent unwanted persons in their residence.

properties.Arrested: Suspect at large:Male/Black, approximately 6'00", slender build, dark blue shirt, shaggy black hair
properties.Details: A woman was cleaning her home when she was startled by a male/black standing behind her. He was holding what appeared to be a black hand gun.   She ran into her bedroom and locked herself in.  The suspect left out of a rear door and ran in an unknown direction.  The female was not hurt and nothing was taken from the residence.  This appears to be a random event however, the suspect is still at large.  The investigation is ongoing.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, 20-25 years old, 5'11", 180 lbs., blonde - possible dyed - hair, facial stubble, wearing dirty white t-shirt, baggy blue jean shorts. He was smoking a cigarette, and seen leaving in a bluish or grey 4-door, older, beat-up car.
properties.Address: Home in the McKenna Blvd./Hammersley Road area
properties.Details: On April 23rd, shortly after 8:00 p.m., a Madison resident (a woman in her 50's) contacted the MPD after finding a prowler peering into her rear patio door, which is very close to a daughter's bedroom window. The woman confronted the prowler and he claimed to be waiting for a friend. The victim then recognized this person as being the same man she caught peeping in the same daughter's bedroom window in the fall of 2007. She did not report the first incident to the MPD.  This time, after putting two and two together, the woman grabbed her cell phone, called 911, and followed - at a safe distance - the prowler as he began to run down Jacobs Way. She saw him get into a car and speed away. The perpetrator's description is somewhat similar to that of a man who exposed himself to a woman who was running on a bike path near Hammersley Road on Tuesday, April 22nd (see prior incident report); however, it is not known if the cases are connected.

properties.Suspect: Juan A. Pacheco, age 19, MadisonMr. Pacheco was arrested and tentatively charged with Lewd and Lascivious, and Unlawful Trespass.
properties.Details: On Tuesday night, shortly after 10:00 p.m., two women living in separate residences on Waunona Woods Court called Madison Police for help after spotting a peeping tom outside of their homes. One of the witnesses, a woman in her 40’s, said neighbors had been concerned recently about someone lurking around in the darkness of night. The second witness, a woman in her 50’s, said the suspect had exposed himself to her, leaving her "terrified and scared" - fearing she was going to be sexually assaulted. Responding officers began searching the area and were able to track down a suspect. He was positively identified by one of the victims.

properties.Arrested: Joann R. Hill, 26 year old female from Madison was charged with 1)Disorderly Conduct While Armed 2)Second Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety

properties.Details: On March 28, 2005 around 12:05am, officers responded to the above area for a report of a disturbance.  Apparently the victim went to Hill's residence to retrieve some CD's.  While the victim was attempting to retrive the CDs, Hill came at the victim with a baseball bat and eventually a knife.  Hill began swinging the knife around and struck the victim in both his leg and hands.  Hill left the immediate area and officers eventually caught up to her.  Hill was placed under arrest and confined to the Dane County Jail.  No further information is available.

properties.Details: At approximarely 9:20 am, Madison Police responded to a local hospital emergency room reference a male subject who was seeking treatment for a stab wound.  Officers contacted the individual and he indicated that he had accepted a ride from downtown Madison to the Allied Dr area at approximately 2:00 am this date.  He told Officers he was dropped off on Allied Dr.  After being dropped off, he told Officers he got into a conflict with the suspect on the sidewalk.  He stated the conflict escallated, and the suspect pulled a knife from his waistband and stabbed him in the head.  His injuries were non-life-threatening, and the victim was treated and released.

Mifflin St.  It was learned that suspects were still inside a building and may have been armed.  Officers took precautionary measures to deploy and secure the area to prevent further injuries. Mifflin St.  Three individuals have been arrested for the incident which can be described as recklessly endangering and battery and are currently in the Dane County Jail.  The victim is recovering at a local hospital in stable condition.  The police department is continuing its investigation into this incident and does not believe there is a continuing threat to the community.

properties.Details: On 7/12/05 Madison Police Officers and Detectives arrested three individuals for their role in the Alison Lane shooting on 7/8/05. Additionally, two search warrants were executed related to this shooting.  The individuals have been taken into custody and are currently in the Dane County Jail.

properties.Details: On 4/24/06 at approximately 9:00 p.m. officers had arrested an individual for retail theft at Cub Foods on Verona Rd.  During the course of their conversation, officers learned that the male suspect had actually been shot approximately one week prior while on Allied Dr.  Records confirm there was a report of gunshots the day the suspect alleged it occurred; yet officers at that time were unable to locate a suspect or victim. The victim indicated he did not go to the hospital to treat his wound.  This remains an open investigation. Anyone with further information about this crime is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Former boyfriend of victimJONATHON LOVE, male, 43, Madison: Probation Hold w/ further charges pending
properties.Victim: 41 year old female, stable condition at UW hospital
properties.Details: Location of this incident is the Expo Inn Motel.  A subject described as a "former boyfriend" forced his way into the victims room, then strangled, battered and stabbed the victim.  Victim was able to break away and run to the Motel office where employees called police.  Suspect was arrested at the scene and is in police custody being questioned.  Victim sustained two serious stab wounds, a broken nose and was conveyed to UW hospital where she is currently undergoing treatment for her injuries .  Names and more info to follow as it becomes available. *** UPDATE ***Further information has now been made available.  The Madison Police Department has learned that the victim, who had been living at the Expo Inn, had a verbal agrument with Love.  As a result of that argument, he attacked her.  Love stabbed the victim one time in the neck and the victim suffered other injuries consistent to being battered.  After the incident Expo Inn employees helped take Love into custody prior to police arrival.  Love had been arrested prior to this incident for violence against the same victim.  This remains an on-going investigation by the Madison Police Department.  The victim is still in the hospital recovering from her injuries.

On 8/23/06 at approximately 1:38am officers responded to the 2300 block of Allied Drive for a report of shots fired.  Responding officers located one victim - a 16 year old female who had sustained a single gunshot wound.  The victim was conveyed to a local hospital with a non life-threatening injury.  Investigation continuing.Earlier in the evening (8/22/06 at about 9:40pm) officers had responded to the 2300 block of Allied Drive for a report of two groups exchanging gunshots.  No injuries were reported in connection with that incident, but shell casings were recovered.  It is not clear if these two incidents are related.

properties.Victim: Male, Hispanic, Age 19, MadisonVictim was taken to a local hospital with several, non-life threatening stab wounds
properties.Details: On Friday evening, July the 27th, Madison Police were called out around 7:25 p.m. to the 1900 block of Scott Lane. Dispatch had indicated there was a fight involving baseball bats. Once on the scene officers found a stabbing victim facedown on the ground. En route to the hospital the victim indicated he and his girlfriend has just gotten out of their car on Scott Lance when the knife-wielding suspect, with whom he was previously acquainted - thanks to a past dispute, jumped out of another car and stabbed him. He also told investigators that three associates of the first attacker exited the suspect vehicle and hurled beer bottles at him (the victim). The victim suffered wounds to both the back and front of his body. Doctors determined all to be superficial cuts and no surgery was necessary.

Officers were dispatched to the above address reference a motor vehicle - pedestrian accident. On arrival, Officers located the injured pedestrian and vehicle involved. Based on the investigation thus far, it appears that the vehicle was southbound on Coho St. and intended to strike the pedestrian. The occupants of the vehicle fled the area and were only described as two males and one female. The victim was transported by MFD to a local hospital for a non-life threatening leg injury. The investigation continues.

properties.Details: At the above date and time MPD officers were contacted by an eye witness who had observed JOHNSON intentionally drive his conversion van onto the sidewalk in the 400 block of N. Frances St., and strike WILLIAMS & MORRIS. Witness statements indicate a verbal altercation had occurred shortly before the incident. Officers report the eye witness followed the van by running after it on foot, and by taxi cab until flagging down officers on Langdon Street where the vehicle was eventually stopped. JOHNSON was accompanied by a passenger who was also arrested on unrelated charges. Investigation continues.

properties.Arrested: Jukenda L Thomas21 years oldMadisonOperating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated
properties.Victim: 2 males, both 20 years old1 female, 19 years old
properties.Details: On 3/12/05 at approximately 2:45 am Madison Police responded to a motor vehicle vs. pedestrian crash on Park St. at Regent St.  Three pedestrians from this crash were taken to the hospital.  Since that time one individual remains hospitalized in stable condition and the two others have been released.  As a result of a lengthy and on-going investigation, Jukenda Thomas has been charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated.

properties.Arrested: George Simon49 years oldWaunakeeOWI/Resisting
properties.Details: On 6/5/05 shortly before 2 a.m. Madison Police Officers were conducting field sobriety on Simon for suspicions of driving a motor vehicle while impaired.  Upon notifying Simon that he was being arrested, Simon fled on foot.  Simon crossed six lanes of traffic on E. Washington Ave while two Madison Police Officers chased him on foot.  Simon went through back alleys and yards before falling on the ground.  Officers gave verbal commands to stay on the ground, at which point Simon refused and approached officers.  An officer deployed her taser to stop Simon who was then immediately arrested and taken into custody without further incident.

properties.Arrested: Fidel M GuerraTina Conners
properties.Details: On 06 28 05 at 2:29 am, officers responded to the report of a disturbance at 431 W Main St. A complainant reported that he had been confronted by two persons, both known to him.  He reported that one of those persons was armed with a handgun.  Although both suspect's departed prior to the arrival of police, they were quickly located by police officers.  The suspects were stopped in their vehicle within a few blocks of the incident.No firearms were located. No shots were fired.  No injuries were reported.The driver of the vehicle, Fidel M Guerra, was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct, violating terms of probation and operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated (5th offense). 5th time OMVWI is a felony traffic offense.  Guerra was booked into the Dane County jail.The other occupant of the vehicle, Tina Conners was arrested on charges of disorderly conduct.  She was cited and released. PO David J Dexheimer

properties.Arrested: Wesley Moore, M/B, 36 yrs old, MadisonCharges: OMVWI, 2nd Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety, Failure to Obey Officers Signal, Operating After Suspension.  Charges from Dane County Sheriffs Office: Hit & Run-attended vehicle, Failure to Maintain Control, Failure to Report accident.
properties.Victim: Victim: M/U, 29 yrs old, Madisonvehicle damaged
properties.Details: Moore was involved in a hit and run accident on the south side of Madison that wsa being investigated by the Dane County Sheriff's Office.  Immediately after that, he exited from westbound Hwy 12/18 at Verona Road.  He then disregarded officers signals for him to stop as they were investigating a fatal accident at Verona Rd/Hwy 12/18.  An officer observed Moore as he drove down the ramp and it appeared that Moore was asleep with his hands off of the steering wheel.  Moore then ran over flares and a cone before entering the on ramp to westbound Hwy 12/18.  Officers ran after the vehicle to try and stop it.  Moore then began to veer off of the onramp and once he hit rough pavement he seemed to realize what was happening and corrected his driving.  Moore then accelerated quickly to get onto the beltline.  Officers stopped Moore at the end of the Whitney Way off ramp where he was placed into custody for operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated.  The investigation is ongoing.

properties.Arrested: Ignacio Zelhua-Montes, 27 years old, resident of Madison.Charges: Operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated 5th offense, obstructing an officer, 2 outstanding warrants.
properties.Details: At approximately 1:17 a.m. on 2/4/2006, Madison Police responded to an accident on Aberg Avenue at Shopko Drive where a vehicle had struck a light pole. Officers were able to identify the above arrested party as the driver of the vehicle. After investigation, he was placed under arrest for the above charges and conveyed to the Dane County Jail where he was incarcerated.

properties.Arrested: Herbert Sallis, 48, Madison.  OWI, Resisting, Criminal Damage to Property
properties.Details: On 2/11/06 at 9:32 p.m. a Madison Police Officer was assisting a Maple Bluff Police Officer on a traffic stop.  The Madison Police Officer was out of the police vehicle and in contact with the Maple Bluff Officer and the vehicle originally pulled over.  The Madison Officer heard a loud squealing of tires and noticed a 1991 Chevrolet headed right for the rear end of the Madison police car.  The Chevrolet crashed into the unoccupied Madison police car.  Sallis, the driver of the Chevrolet, was contacted and subsequent to an investigation was arrested for the above listed charges.  During the investigation, Sallis resisted officers, spit in an officer's face and kicked out a squad car window while being transported to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Kevin R. Ohalloran, 37 yr old City of Madison resident
properties.Details: A citizen witnessed Ohalloran driving his Chevy Blazer all over the road on Highway 94 westbound about 25 miles outside of Madison.  Oholloran's driving was so erratic and dangerous that the citizen continued to follow, calling in for assistance, all the way into the city, onto Highway 30 and finally onto Milwaukee St where Oholloran was driving completely against traffic.  Officer Tracie Jokala caught up to Oholloran after the citizen pointed out a house Oholloran had entered on foot.  Officer Jokala contacted Oholloran as he was coming back out of the house and found him extremely impaired.  Oholloran was subsequently placed under arrest for OMVWI, Possession of Controlled Substances, and Possession of THC.

properties.Arrested: Georgyi V. Los, 49 yr old City of Fitchburg resident
properties.Details: Madison Police and Fire were dispatched to a rollover accident on Raymond Rd at the curve near Verona Rd.  They found Georgyi V. Los in his new Nissan SUV after the SUV had flipped and rolled over several times.  Los was uninjured and was subsequently placed under arrest for OMVWI.

properties.Arrested: Lewis C. Jackson, 32 yr old City of Madison resident
properties.Details: Citizen witness called for help after seeing Jackson all over the road on Highway 12/18 in a Chevy Malibu.  Jackson reportedly swerved across multiple lanes and exited onto Whitney Way, turning onto Schroeder Rd and almost hitting two other cars on Schroeder Rd.  He continued, bouncing off the curb three times and finally driving into the oncoming traffic lane.  He then attempted to turn into an apartment complex where he plowed into a snowbank and got stuck.  Officer Veatch contacted Jackson and subsequently placed him under arrest for OMVWI and Operating After Suspension.

properties.Arrested: Thomas Skoyen, 32, Bristol, WI:  OWI-5th offense, Eluding a Police Officer, Probation Hold, Speeding Above Fixed Limits, Operating After Revocation
properties.Details: On 4/18/06 at approximately 9:48 p.m. a Madison Police Officer was running laser on southbound Hwy 51 near Milwaukee St.  The officer tracked a vehicle traveling approximately 75 m.p.h.  The officer pulled over the vehicle without incident and made initial contact with the driver, Skoyen, who shut off his engine.  The officer made contact with another officer who arrived on scene.  As the original officer went back to re-contact Skoyen, the he fled in his vehicle at a high rate of speed.  Both officers pursued this vehicle, with their emergency lights and siren activated, southbound on Stoughton Rd.  Skoyen turned westbound on Buckeye Rd and crashed his vehicle on a sidewalk.  Skoyen fled from the scene on foot and officers pursued.  Skoyen had enough of a lead in the dark to escape from the foot chase.  Skoyen went to the Buckeye Inn and eventually called police to turn himself in.  Skoyen was booked into the Dane County Jail without further incident.

properties.Arrested: Male, 37, Charges pending include:  OWI-6th offense, Resisting, Intimidating a witness, Failure to obey officer's signal, Operating while revoked, Failure to notify owner of property damage
properties.Details: On 6/12/06 at approximately 3:10 a.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to a traffic crash and road rage incident.  Officers learned that the suspect driver was traveling northbound on Fish Hatchery Rd and stuck a traffic light at Ann St.  After crashing into this traffic light, causing it to fall over, the suspect began to follow a witness on Fish Hatchery, who also was in a vehicle.  The witness reports that for unknown reasons, the suspect followed him and was taunting him.  The witness was followed down eastbound Badger Rd to Park St.  This continued on Park St all the way to Regent St in which the suspect continued to pull along side the witness vehicle and taunt him.  The witness turned around on Park St and went southbound back to Badger Rd.  Once on Badger Rd. the witness turned on Catalpa and Cypress to again try to avoid the suspect who was still following him.  A Madison Police Officer then spotted the suspect vehicle on Badger Rd and initiated a traffic stop.  Upon activating the emergency lights, the suspect vehicle sped to 30 m.p.h. and did not immediately stop.  The vehicle continued on Badger Rd, eastbound before turning onto Catalpa LN where the suspect eventually stopped at Magnolia LN.  Once the vehicle stopped, the suspect immediately exited his vehicle.  The driver was verbally ordered to return inside his car.  The suspect did not and put his hands in his pockets.  The officer believed that the suspect could have a weapon in his pocket, as he was noncompliant. Because the suspect was not returning to the inside of his car, the officer then ordered him to the ground and to take his hands out of his pockets.  The suspect did not follow the officer’s commands.  The officer continued verbal commands for the suspect to comply until other officers responded.  As other officers arrived for coverage, the initial officer warned the suspect multiple times to get to the ground and comply or he will be tased.  The suspect got into a defensive posture and pointed his finger at the officer.  To prevent an unpredictable physical encounter, the officer deployed the taser to the suspect.  Upon deployment the suspect immediately fell backwards.  In falling backwards the suspect hit his head on the ground. Officers were concerned for this person’s safety that was now momentarily unconscious.  Fire/Rescue was dispatched to the scene for potential injuries that this person incurred.  At this point the suspect is still hospitalized for injuries and charges are pending.

properties.Arrested: Lawrence Keller, 44, Madison:  OWI-7th offense, Probation Hold, Warrant for non-support
properties.Details: On 8/21/06 at approximately 7 p.m. a Madison Police Officer noticed a maroon pick-up traveling in the Bashford St./Ohio Ave area.  The officer recognized this truck belonging to an individual who had a suspended driver's license through past professional contacts.  From the officer's view, it did look like the driver was indeed the owner of the vehicle, so the officer performed a traffic stop.  The officer learned that the driver was not the owner, but someone looking like the owner and furthermore smelled a strong odor of intoxicants coming from the vehicle.  The driver of the pick-up, Keller, was contacted, tested and was arrested for his 7th drunk driving offense.  He was taken to the Dane County Jail without incident.

properties.Arrested: Kelvin Eskridge, 50, Madison:  OMVWI (10th offense), Operating with a prohibited alcohol concentration, Operating After Revocation, Safety Belt Violation, Possession of Drug Paraphernalia, Probation Hold, Dane County Warrant (OAR)
properties.Details: On 12/16/06 at 9:01 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to a disturbance in the 600 block of W. Washington Ave.  Officers were able to ascertain that the incident involved a male & female and a blue Dodge vehicle.  A traffic stop was performed in the 600 block of W. Washington Ave based on this information.  Through the course of the stop and field observation, the officer believed Eskridge to be under the influence of alcohol and to be the driver of the vehicle.  In the passenger seat was a female friend of Eskridge.  On her lap, unrestrained, was a three-month old child.  Eskridge was arrested for his 10th OMVWI and taken to the Dane County Jail without incident.

properties.Arrested: Jane Rudow, 48, Deerfield: OWI-1st offense
properties.Details: On 4/4/07 at approximately 6:32 a.m. the 911 Center received a call from a motorist observing a vehicle driving all over the road and possibly being a drunk driver on the Beltline.  A nearby Madison Police Officer responded as the vehicle exited on to John Nolen Drive.  The vehicle was eventually stopped after the officer observed dangerous driving behaviors (swerving, etc.).  Rudow was contacted, field tested and eventually provided a breath sample registering .30 after the arrest.

properties.Suspect: Michael Alfred Murray, age 53, MadisonTentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle while Intoxicated, Sixth Offense, Operating a Motor Vehicle with a Prohibited Alcohol Concentration, Sixth Offense, and Intoxicants in a Motor Vehicle.
properties.Details: On Saturday night at 8:11 p.m. Madison police received word that a concerned driver had called police dispatch after seeing a car driving into the city, from the Sun Prairie area on Portage Road. The concerned driver reported that he had to hit his brakes as the suspect driver was going way under the speed limit. He (the concerned driver) next noted that the suspect driver was weaving back and forth out of his lane and into oncoming traffic. The concerned driver decided he must call 911 after witnessing this a half-dozen times He (the concerned driver) feared someone would be killed. The concerned citizen continued to trail the suspect driver and says at one point the suspect driver appeared to pass out while at a stop sign. He (the concerned driver) last saw the suspect vehicle going south on Stoughton Road. Madison police picked up the trail shortly thereafter.  An officer also observed the suspect motorist driving poorly and pulled the Ford Taurus over. The driver said he had a glass of Chardonnay at dinner. However, a Madison police sergeant, who was now standing at the passenger side of the Taurus, observed an open pint-sized bottle of vodka on the passenger seat. The driver did not perform well in a field sobriety test and was arrested.

properties.Suspect: Ricky Joseph Guillen, Age 39, MadisonArrested on a charge of Operating a Motor Vehicle While under the Influence, Sixth Offense, & Operating after Revocation.
properties.Details: On November sixth at 5:42 p.m. Madison police were dispatched to the intersection of Northport Drive and Sherman Avenue for a report of a possible disabled car. Responding officers were then advised that Madison Fire Engine #10, with its emergency lights engaged, was now trailing the vehicle and that firefighters believed the driver to either have a medical problem or to be driving while impaired. Fire personnel observed the car swerving and nearly striking an oncoming car, and later going up and over a grassy median. This pursuit started when the crew on Fire Engine #10 came upon the "disabled" car. They made their way in heavy traffic up to it, and were advised by dispatch that there maybe a man passed out inside. Firefighters observed a passerby leaning into the passenger window apparently trying to talk with the driver. At that moment the driver sat up and drove off. The crew on #10 followed until the car turned onto Northridge Terrace. The driver killed the engine and got out at the end of the dead end street. Firefighters then used their rig to block the street, and any possible escape route if the motorist tried to drive off again. Madison Police officers arrived and were directed to an apartment building into which the driver had entered. The above subject was located and identified by firefighters as the driver of the car. He was arrested for his sixth offense drunken driving. Madison Police would like to thank Madison Fire personnel for their assistance in the apprehension.

properties.Suspect: Michael A. Glynn, Age 42, MadisonMr. Glynn was arrested for his seventh offense of Operating a Motor Vehicle While Under the Influence (OMVWI), Operating after Revocation, Domestic Disorderly Conduct, and a parole hold.
properties.Details: On November 22nd at 5:27 p.m. Madison police stopped a Chevy Blazer on Roth Street and arrested the driver for drunken driving. The suspect had been involved in a disturbance with a woman earlier in the afternoon, because of that he was also tentatively charged with Domestic Disorderly Conduct. While inspecting the Blazer an officer discovered an open beer on the center console of the SUV. It appeared to have come from a 12-pack that was behind the driver’s seat. A small bottle of vodka, which had mostly been depleted, was retrieved by police from a pocket on the backside of the driver’s seat.

properties.Suspect: Jason A. Kubitschek, age 20, MadisonMr. Kubitschek was arrested and tentatively charged with Attempting to Elude a Police Officer, Resisting/Obstructing, OMVI, Speeding, Operating while Suspended, Casual Possession of Marijuana, Possession of a Schedule II Narcotic (likely Oxycodone)
properties.Arrested: Shani Nana Coleman, Age 18, MadisonMs. Coleman was arrested and tentatively charged with Possession of a Schedule II Narcotic
properties.Details: On January 7th at 8:43 p.m. dispatch advised Madison Police that a concerned citizen was following an erratic driver in the 2200 block of Aberg Avenue. The citizen followed a silver 2005 Chevy van inbound and into the downtown area. Officers were able to intercept the van on Campus Drive. Red lights and siren were turned on in an attempt to get the van's driver to pull over. Instead the driver accelerated reaching speeds estimated at around 65 to 70 miles per hour. After a few seconds the pursuit was terminated because of wet pavement and heavy fog. However, officers were already in possession of the van's plate number thanks to the work of the concerned citizen. Officers responded to a residence on Chamberlain Avenue, which corresponded to the registered driver's address. They found the van parked at the residence, which is where Mr. Kubitschek has been staying. He had borrowed the van from the home's owner. He was arrested on the above charges. One of two female passengers in the van was also arrested. When it comes to pursuits Madison police are instructed to balance "the public interests in the apprehension of violators of the law," with "insuring the safety of all persons who might potentially be endangered by the pursuit." In this situation it was the officer's determination that postponing apprehension was the best way to protect the public.

properties.Suspect: Ignacio Xelhua-Montes, age 29, MadisonMr. Xelhua-Montes was arrested and tentatively charged with OWI-Sixth Offense, Driving While Revoked, and a Probation Violation
properties.Details: On Tuesday around 11:40 a.m. a 50-year-old Madison woman was stopped for a red light at the intersection of Park Street and Hughes Place when her '94 Ford Taurus was struck from behind by a '96 Chrysler Sebring. Following the collision two men, who had been in the Sebring, took off running. A witness saw the men enter an apartment building in the 2400 block of Cypress Way. Responding officers found them, and arrested the driver for his sixth drunken driving offense. Inside the Sebring several open beers were discovered including a 40-ounce bottle that had some of the fermented beverage dripping from its top. The victim was taken to a local hospital for treatment of neck and back pain.

properties.Suspect: Pedro Ocotl-Jimenez, age 20, MadisonMr. Ocotl-Jimenez was arrested and tentatively charged with Eluding, Resisting, OMVI, Intoxicants in Vehicle, Operating without a valid Drivers License, and Underage Person in Possession of Alcohol. He also was wanted to two warrants. One was for Failure to Report to Jail. The other was for Aggravated Battery.
properties.Details: Early Friday morning around 1:41 a.m. dispatchers alerted the MPD to the possibility of an intoxicated driver.  A witness had spotted a white Grand Am weaving and driving the wrong way on John Nolen Drive. A Madison police officer spotted the suspect car as it headed eastbound on East Washington Avenue. The officer also observed erratic driving and attempted to pull the car over. The driver did not immediately respond, but did eventually pull over to the shoulder; however, he did not stop. After driving slowly along the shoulder the driver then sped up. The officer pursued the car as the driver increased his speed to around 85 miles per hour. The police officer about to terminate the pursuit when the driver spun out of control – doing a complete 360 at the intersection of E. Washington Avenue and Milwaukee Street. The driver fled the car and started running. He fell over, fought with the officer, and was eventually arrested. An open beer can was found in his car, and the suspect vomited inside a Madison Police squad car.

properties.Suspect: Jesus Urzua Pacheco, age 28, MadisonMr. Pacheco was arrested and tentatively charged with OMVWI-Sixth Offense, Operating a Motor Vehicle with a Prohibited Alcohol Concentration-Sixth Offense, and Operating after Revocation.
properties.Details: On Saturday morning, around 3:40 a.m., a concerned citizen contacted Madison police after witnessing a minor collision that had just occurred in an apartment building parking lot. The citizen says the suspect drove a car into a parked vehicle. The witness led police to an apartment where the suspect was located and arrested.

properties.Suspect: Eric B. Fenne, 19 yoa, Rhinelander WICHARGES: Eluding a Police officer, Resisting a Police Officer, Probation & Parole Warrant, OMVWI 1st offense..More traffic charges
properties.Details: At the above date and time, Madison Police were requested at Taco Bell located at 3002 E. Washington Ave  due to a disturbance. Officers pursued the vehicle on Madison's East Side, and through Maple Bluff where the driver lost control and the vehicle went off the roadway on Novick Drive causing the vehicle to become hung up on tree stumps. During the pusuit FENNE operated his vehicle at speeds in excess of 75 MPH. FENNE was charged with the above charges and remains in Dane County Jail.

The officer pulled the driver over and noticed that he smelled of intoxicants. The driver subsequently did poorly on field sobriety tests and was arrested on tentative charges listed above.

properties.Suspect: Dominago R. Cardenas Male, White, DOB: 05/01/1955 Last known address in Madison. Mr. Cardenas was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle While Under the Influence of an Intoxicant, Controlled Substance, or Combination of Both-4th Offense, Operating after Revocation and non-support warrant.
properties.Details: Officers responded to a report of a one vehicle crash involving a rollover and pin, on the beltline near Todd Drive. The suspect was the sole occupant and was conveyed for medical treatment with what appeared to be non-life threatening injuries. Further investigation led to the above charges.

properties.Suspect: Michael J Archambault, 23 yr old maleMadison residentcharged with 1st offense Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated and 2nd Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety
properties.Arrested: Andrea M. Hall, 22 yr old femaleCharged with 1st offense Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated and 2nd Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety
properties.Details: Madison Police were sent to the 4600 block of E. Washington Ave. when a call came in about a multiple vehicle crash at the IHOP.  Two vehicles were racing each other on Zeier Road headed towards E. Washington Ave.  They ran the stop light, crashed into each other and both became airbone.  The vehicle driven by Hall struck IHOP on E. Washington Ave, and the vehicle driven by Archambault landed in the IHOP parking lot.  No injuries were reported at the time of the crashes.  Vehicle traffic on E. Washington Ave. was inturrupted for a short time while evidence was collected from the street.Both were arrested on scene.  The investigation is ongoing at this time.

properties.Suspect: Joseph D. Deang, age 45, MadisonMr. Deang was arrested and tentatively charged with Causing Injury by the Intoxicated Use of a Motor Vehicle.
properties.Details: On Friday evening, at 7:54 p.m., Madison Police Officers were dispatched to a rollover crash that had just happened after the driver of a '93 Isuzu Trooper lost control on an exit ramp that connects eastbound Highway 30 with Thompson Drive. Officers found the suspect outside of the Trooper looking for items that had fallen from his vehicle at the time it rolled. Inside the SUV were two children, a three-year old boy, and a six-year old girl. Both were transported to a local hospital with non-life threatening injures. Several empty beer cans and an equally empty bottle of brandy were found at the crash site. The driver was arrested for causing injury by driving drunk.

properties.Suspect: David J. Spangler, age 21, MadisonSpangler is tentatively being charged with his third offense Operating a Motor Vehicle While Intoxicated, Operating after Revocation and Operating an Unregistered Vehicle.
properties.Details: On 07/13/08 at approx. 2:45 am, Madison Police responded along with Madison Fire Rescue to an injury accident.  Witnesses stated that Spangler lost control of a motorcycle he was operating and crashed into the garage door of a residence in the 3600 Blk of Tulane Ave.Spangler was transported to a local hospital where he was admitted for non-life threatening injuries.
