Ascher, age 22, MadisonMr. Ascher was arrested and tentatively charged with Causing Injury While Operating a Motor Vehicle While Under the Influence (3rd offense OMVI), Reckless Driving (Bodily Harm), Operating While Revoked, Causing Injury While OMVI with a Prohibited Alcohol Concentration (3rd offense).
properties.Victim: Female, age 21, MadisonVictim & suspect were taken to a local hospital with non-life threatening injuries.
properties.Details: On August 1st, at 1:15 a.m., Madison Police responded to a rollover crash in the 1300 block of North Wingra Drive. A Jeep Grand Cherokee was found, resting on its roof, on the front lawn of a home. The driver and his passenger were taken to a local hospital with non-life threatening injuries. Officers determined the SUV struck a parked car, cut across - and dug up – several homeowners’ front lawns before rolling.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: Adult female resident of the west side of Madison.
properties.Details: On 03/31/2005 the victim contacted Madison Police regarding a fraud that occurred on the Internet.  She advised MPD that she recently had made an Internet transaction on Ebay.  She indicated that on 03/30/2005 in the morning hours, she received an email message that appeared to be from the Internet payment service, Pay-Pal.  The message indicated that she needed to update her account, and asked for personal and financial information including the victim's social security number.  The victim indicated she attempted to email the response without her social security number, and the email was not accepted.  She further indicated that after inserting the social security number, the email was accepted and sent.  She indicated later, in the evening hours, she received a phone call from her credit card company regarding suspicious transactions on her account.  She was told that three unauthorized withdrawals had been made on her account.  The unauthorized withdrawals took place at ATM machines in Romania.  The account from which the withdrawals had been made was held in a Madison, WI credit union.  The complainant believes that the email she received was a 'look alike' to an official Pay-Pal email. This is another example of people having their identity stolen and being defrauded by someone using the Internet.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department has received several reports of another scam circulating the Madison area.  In various incidents, whether subleasing an apartment, selling something on the Internet or performing another monetary transaction, people have lost money with fake money orders.  The scam takes place when the suspect agrees to purchase an item or sublease and sends the victim a fraudulent money order that appears real.  The money order is for an amount OVER the cost of the item.  The victim then informs the suspect that he/she overpaid.  The suspect then comes up with an excuse as to the overpayment and asks to be sent the balance back in the form of a money order. The Madison Police Department encourages citizens to be careful in making their financial transaction and take measures to verify the money is legitimate.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department continues to investigate financial crimes where citizens are sending large amounts of money to a scam.  Recently a citizen believed they had won money from a lottery and followed the instructions listed in a letter.  These instructions stated that taxes needed to be paid on the winnings and that a check from the winnings would be sent to the victim.  The victim is then to take the artificial check to the bank, cash it and withdraw a money order to return to the fraudulent company in increments.  In all, this victim lost over $10,000 believing that lottery money would be returning.Specifically the scam operated with some of the following language: After numerous attempts to reach you through phone have failed we are pleased to inform you through this letter that our network system shows you as a winner of an unclaimed winning prize money in the amount of $50,000 USD.  Our system indicates that you were selected as a winner on February 14, 2005.  The letter also states that it is part of our job to inform you of the international law guiding the fair personal collection of cash prizes.  The international law requires that a winner pay a processing/clearance fee before funds are released.  The law also prevents you from paying with your personal money but from your winning money.  As part of our security protocol, your file as been assigned to an international claim agent furthermore should there be any change of address do inform your claims agent as soon as possible . . . "As the Madison Police Department investigates this and other financial fraudulent cases, we urge citizens to use extreme caution in any "get rich" fast schemes.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: The complainant reported that on 04/10/2005, she attempted to check her ATM bank account online.  She was unable to access the account.  Later the next day, she received an e-mail that appeared to be from the bank.  The e-mail told her there had been some "uncommon activity" associated with her account, and that per her account agreement, access to the acccount was being restricted.  The e-mail then directed her to provide additional information and linked her to another webpage.  Once on that page, she was asked to provide personal information including her bank account number,  PIN number,  and her social security number. This information was provided online.  The following day, the complainant checked her account information online, and learned that her bank account had been drained of all funds.  The loss was in excess of $3,000.  Once again, this is an example of people providing personal/financial information over the Internet to people who use the information to defraud and steal.  Frequently, people provide this information in response to what appears to be an official e-mail messsge from a bank, business, or other type institution.  The e-mail messages are not legitimate and the information is often used in identity theft cases.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: Adult male resident on the east side of Madison
properties.Details: On 05/05/05, a complainant reported that he had been defrauded.  He indicated that on 04/26/05 he received a debit card from his bank.  He indicated that on 05/02/05 he received what appeared to be an official email from his bank advising him that access to his account had been restricted because of some sort of suspicious account activity.  He was then advised he would need to update his information in order to access his account.He went to the new website and provided his name, social security number, account number, and PIN number.  After providing the information, he was contacted by his bank related to his account being overdrawn.  He learned that his account had been drained of $658, leaving a zero balance.  He indicated withdrawals had been made at ATM machines outside of the United States.  This case is very similar to another report of identity theft.  For details on that case, see the press release related to MPD case 2005-41091.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: Adult male resident on the south side of Madison.
properties.Details: The complainant reported to Madison Police that in April he received an e-mail from what appeared to be an E-Bay website advising him there was some suspicious activity on his account.  The e-mail requested that he verify his account information with his account number, password, and PIN number.  He provided the requested information.  He learned from his bank that on 4/18/05, $1,858.80 had been removed from his bank account at ATM machines in Moscow, Russia.  This is similar to earlier cases involving internet fraud and identity theft.  People should not provide any personal financial or banking information in response to an e-mail request from what appears to be a bank, business, or institution of some kind.  People should always call the bank before providing any information over the internet.

properties.Arrested: n/a

Shortly after having done so, her account was emptied of $1,696.60. Five withdrawals were made from an ATM machine in Korea using her account information.

properties.Arrested: White male in 20s, fair complexion, 6 feet tall, wearing T-shirt and shorts.
properties.Details: Victim called MPD and said he'd been the victim of a fraud on 5-28-05 at approximately 3:00 pm.  He said the above suspect came to his door in the 1900 block of E Main St at approximately 3:00 pm.  The suspect said he lived down the street and that he'd locked himself out.  He further said he had called a locksmith who was on the way, but the locksmith required a pre-payment of $30.00.  The suspect told the victim he would like to borrow $30.00 and would re-pay it as soon as he got into the house.  The victim provided the suspect with $30.00 and has not seen him since.  The victim believes he has been the victim of a fraud and would like to make others aware of this scheme.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: This is another report of phishing on the Internet.  The complainant reported to the Madison Police Department that he responded to what appeared to be an e-mail from E-bay.  He indicated he provided personal information reference his bank account.  A short time later, he learned $294.44 had been withdrawn from his bank account at a location outside of the United States.

properties.Arrested: Suspect: Female
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department warns of another scam surfacing in Madison.  It has been reported to the Madison Police Department that at least 2 citizens who are trying to sell their vehicle in the newspaper are called by the suspect/"buyer".  The suspect offers to pay by credit card and in one case offered to pay $2000 more without even seeing the vehicle.  When the skeptical seller states that a credit card would not be feasible, the prospective "buyer" reads a fictitious credit card number and states that they will have a bank call the seller.  A third party identifying himself or herself as a bank employee makes a three-way call to the seller indicating that the credit card is legitimate. So far no transactions have been made.  The bank indicates that the transaction would never occur via phone and furthermore would not happen after normal business hours.

properties.Arrested: M/B,Approximately 25years old, 6'03, 170-180lbs (skinny build)F/O,(Heavy accented voice - possibly asian)
properties.Details: In recent weeks, a number of theft by fraud cases have been reported to the Madison Police Department.  The suspects utilize local newspapers and find individuals that are attempting to arrange for their vehicles to be sold & then contact the potential seller(s).  The suspect(s) (Female voice with heavy accent claiming to be from the State of Michigan in some instances) would call the owner(s) of the vehicle(s) and usually negotiate the price that they would like to pay the seller (usually offering more than the seller was originally asking), and all parties agree to the sale.  The suspects then, to make the seller more comfortable, would make a conference call to an alleged banking institution where a third party (usually a male voice - Caribbean sounding) would allow the seller to hear that there were ample funds within an account to cover the price of the vehicle that would be purchased.  There would be discussions that the seller would be privy to hearing about fund verification at the banking institution under a specified account number (later determined to not be valid) and the suspect would then set up a meet place for the vehicle to be delivered.  The suspect would arrived at the meet location (M/B, Approx 25yrs, 6'03, 170-180lbs) and give the seller a piece of paper advising the seller to go to the specified banking institution and retrieve the sale amount of the vehicle from the account, while the suspect would then take possession of 1. The vehicle/keys & 2. The title of ownership of car.  The suspect would sign this paperwork as if it were a legal document and would require the seller of the vehicle to do the same.  After the car had been turned over from the legitimate seller, they would find out later that there were no funds at the banking institution under the account number that was stated on the paper!People should know that there were no legitimate calls made to any banking institution, and the suspects in this scenario are taking full advantage of people who are not utilizing conventional means of transferring property.  Please use care when entering into any agreement with anyone, and be extremely careful in the transfer of any property without adequately determining whether or not funds are absolutely secure!  The Madison Police Department is continuing to investigate this matter.

properties.Arrested: M/W, 35-40 years old, 5'10" with average build.  Has a large bluish tattoo on his forearm elbow area.
properties.Victim: Adult female who lives in the 1900 block of Winnebago St
properties.Details: Ths case occurred on 06/24/05 at approximately 12:30 am.  The complainant indicated suspect was knocking on her door, and when she answered it he told her that he lived down the block and had been locked out of his house.  He also told her that he needed to call a locksmith and that he was $20 short of the money needed.  The complainant indicated she went to an ATM machine and got the money for the suspect.  Suspect came back and told her that the locksmith charged more than expected and he was still $20 short.  The complainant provided him another $20.  The complainant attempted to watch the suspect.  She did not observe any locksmith in the area, but did notice the suspect ride by on a bicycle.  This is a fraud.  There have been a number of similar reports from the Winnebago St area.  A previous press release was done regarding this type of crime.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department took another internet fraud case in which the country of Nigeria is mentioned as a mailing address by the suspect.  A 34 year-old female reports she was contacted via the internet as she tried to sell her valuable sewing machine.  The suspect, acting as a third party, stated that the buyer sent a check for $3,000 over the cost of the machine.  The victim then sent a return, valid check, back to the suspect for the overdue amount . . . only to be never heard from again.  This is yet another reminder of the internet scams that people are falling victim to.  There has been a Nigerian connection to some, especially involving writing a legitimate check for overpaid purchase money.  The Madison Police Department cautions those involved in sales to be leery of overpaid purchase amounts in which the victim needs to return money.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: A report was made to the Madison Police Department via self-report form.  The complainant reported that she responded to an e-mail that appeared to have been sent to her by Pay Pal, an internet payment service.  She indicated she responded to the e-mail and in doing so provided personal account information.  The complainant reports she lost in excess of $5,000.00, which was withdrawn from her accounts by someone using the information she provided online.

properties.Arrested: white male in his 30's
properties.Victim: A resident of the 2800 block of Gregory St.
properties.Details: Madison Police received a report from a resident of Gregory St who believed he'd been a victim of a fraud.  He reported that a male came to his door at approximately 05:30am on 09/25/05, and indicated that he was locked out of his residence and needed money for a locksmith.  The caller reported that he provided money to the subject.  Over the last few months there have been a number of cases where a subject knocks on the door of a residence and tells people he is a neighbor who lives down the street and is locked out of his house.  He then indicates that a locksmith is on the way but the locksmith requires payment in advance.  He asks if he can borrow the money and that as soon as he's in the house he will get his money and return and repay the neighbor. In the past this scheme has taken place in the Williamson St. area.  In the cases reported to the Madison no one has ever been repaid.

properties.Arrested: Brent E. Fowler31 year old Madison residentArrested:Attempted TheftPossession of drug paraphernaliaProbation Violation
properties.Address: 2800 Blk. of Gregory St. & 2100 Winnebago St.
properties.Details: On Oct. 2 MPD officers arrested Fowler in regards to several complaints of him giving false statements to residents in order to reveive money from residents in various residents throughout the city. (See Previous release under same case #) Additional charges are expected.

properties.Arrested: 6 individuals from New Jersey
properties.Details: On 10/03/05 Madison Police Officers were alerted by another law enforcement agency to suspicious activity at an east side hotel in the 4200 block of East Towne Blvd.  Detectives witnessed several individuals leaving the hotel and going to the WI Dept of Transportation.  Detectives eventually made a traffic stop after this occurred several times.  It was learned that these individuals from Brazil had come to New Jersey.  From New Jersey they paid over $1,000 to come to Madison with their passport to obtain a valid WI driver's license.  The individuals, along with their passports, received actual utility bills and put their names on it before going to WI DOT.  Once at WI DOT they tried to obtain driver's licenses using their passports and now the altered utility bill.  The individuals knew that WI is one of 11 states where a driver's license is issued with a proof of residency (utility bill) and photo id (passport).  No arrests have been made and no charges have been filed.  This incident is still under investigation.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: The complainant reported  to the Madison Police Dept a suspected Internet fraud.  He indicated over the weekend, he had been looking on E-Bay, and looked at items on an E-Bay auction.  He reported that the auction site listed higher ticket items, such as audiovisual equipment, copiers, and bicycles.  He also observed that the items for bid did not appear to be the primary business of the seller.  The complainant indicated that he bid on several of the items and noticed that someone else always bid higher, driving the price up.  He became suspicious and contacted E-bay. He learned that an unauthorized entity had attached items for auction onto legitimate E-Bay sites.  He  noted that the unauthorized sites have very sophisticated graphics that were nearly identical to the legitimate sites.  He also noted that the unauthorized sites asked people to send a cashier's check or certified check to a specific address rather than use the PayPal system for payment.  The complainant finished his statement by writing that he should have recognized the old maximism, "If it's too good to be true, it probably isn't true!"In another Internet fraud that Madison Police learned about  a citizen living outside of the City but in Dane County advertised two puppies for sale.  The asking price on the puppies was $375 each.  She received an email response from someone who indicated they wanted to buy the puppies and would send travelers checks for payment.  $4000 in travelers checks arrived at the seller's address without any return address.  The seller was then  told by email to cash the travelers checks and send the overpayment by Western Union to a specific address.  The travelers checks turned out to be counterfeit.  The seller determined this by contacting the company that was listed on the travelers checks.  The perspective buyer was told via email that the Madison Police Dept had been notified of the situation and all correspondence stopped.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 12/10/05 a Madison Police Officer took a report from a female regarding a Nigerian fraudulent check issue.  It was learned that the female befriended a male, via the internet, indicating he was from Nigeria.  After months of "chatting", via the internet, the male sent the female a check worth $29,925 to deposit in the United States because he "couldn't" in Nigeria.  In exchange for cashing the check, the female was going to receive $1,500.  Additionally, the check appeared valid from the U.S. Treasury.  A few days after depositing the check and having the money wired to the suspect, the bank notified the victim saying she had deposited a fraudulent check.  The bank indicates the female now owes $29,925 back to the bank.  Madison Police have also learned that suspects in this type of scheme are targeting "divorce type chat rooms" to befriend someone and then ask for this type of "help" in depositing money.  The Madison Police Department strongly urges people to be on guard of claims to give you money for cashing checks . . . especially from a stranger in Nigeria or any foreign country.

properties.Arrested: n/a

properties.Details: At approx. 10:30 a.m. this date, a female in her 60's who lives on the west side of Madison reported she received a phone call at home from a male subject.  The subject identified himself as someone who works with identity theft and told her that someone had just stolen $299 out of her checking account.  He then asked for personal information related to her checking account so he could verify this and return the stolen money to her account.  The woman correctly identified this as an attempted fraud and ended the phone call.  She then reported the matter to her bank and the Madison Police Department.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Associated Bank is working with the FBI and Madison Police on a telephone fraud case.  Approximately 60-70 people have called Associated Bank today curious to know if their account is in jeopardy.  These individuals have not given their private information away, but the fear is that numerous others have.  At this point it is too early to tell.  At issue is an automated phone call to citizens indicating there is trouble with their bank account.  The automated call gives the citizen a number to call and upon calling that number asks for the customers account number and pin.  Citizens should know that banks will never ask for an account number and pin and providing that in this fraud case could be extremely costly.  Victims of this fraud won't know until funds have been drained or access is denied on their credit cards/accounts.  This is a sophisticated scam and citizens with accounts in other financial institutions should also be aware of this scam and alert to not to give their private information away.

properties.Address: 2302 Fish Hatchery Road (Dane County Highway Garage)
properties.Details: On June 19, shortly after 7:00 in the morning, Madison Police took a call from a Dane County Highway Department supervisor reference a stack of $100 bills discovered by one of his employees. The worker was on the job the prior afternoon around 3:00 p.m. when he noticed the bills, folded in half, and lying in the grass near the intersection of Park Street and Badger Road. The bills turned out to be counterfeit. In fact, the responding officer reported the seven were of very poor quality. They had the same serial number, and were actually comprised of two pieces of paper. The front part of the bogus c-note, and the back were glued together.

properties.Arrested: Female, Age 45-50, 5'6", Moderate to heavy build, straight reddish-brown hairFemale, Age 45-50, 5'6", Moderate to heavy build, curly brown hair
properties.Details: On July 6th, at 3:57 p.m., Madison Police responded to a Westside grocery store after a victim reported that she had just been duped into giving out $12,000.The victim said she was approached while loading groceries into her car by a woman who claimed to have just found the victim's purse. The victim said she had not lost a purse. A second suspect, who pretended not to know the first, then showed up with a purse. In the ruse, it was stated $100,000 was in the purse. The first suspect indicated the money was likely from some type of criminal enterprise, but said they should split it between the three of them. In order to keep the money however, the first suspect insisted each of the other two women (1 the victim, 1 suspect #2) withdraw $12,000 each from their bank accounts. The suspect indicated serial numbers from the windrawn funds could be mixed with those in the purse. The victim was confused by this logic, but after suspect number 2 appeared to withdraw funds from her account, she (the victim) did the same. The first suspect took the money saying she would be back as soon as she recorded the serial numbers. She did not return. The second suspect also left. The victim stood in the parking lot, and when police arrived she was very shaken by the ordeal

properties.Arrested: Suspect #1: Male white, 5'06", 170 lbs., early 20's, black-short hair, last seen wearing white polo shirt.Suspect #2: Male white, early 20's, 5'5", 165 lbs., black-short hair, last seen wearing a plaid shirt.
properties.Details: On Wednesday evening July 18th Madison Police responded to the 1600 block of Fordem Avenue to talk with an 82-year-old woman.  She believed she had just been duped, and maybe a victim of fraud. The woman reports that at 7:30 that evening there was a knock on her door. Suspect #1 was in the doorway wanting to sell the victim magazines. She let him in. A short time later there was a second knock. Suspect #2 (sales partner to suspect #1) came in. While the woman was doling out $55 cash to suspect #1 for selected periodicals, suspect #2 asked to use the facilities. After the magazine team departed the victim realized some of her medications had been stolen. Neither she, nor police, have been able to reach "Universal Subscription Agency," the Las Vegas based firm the sales team claimed to be representing. Other neighborhood residents also reported to police that they had also been contacted by the sales crew.

properties.Arrested: Julio C. Melendez-Valladares:  65 years of prison, 25 years of supervised release.
properties.Details: On July 14, 2005 Julio Melendez-Valladares was sentenced to 65 years in prison for a sexual assault that occurred in the 600 block of E. Johnson in 2001.  Through DNA evidence investigators were able to identify Melendez-Valladares as the suspect in a stranger sexual assault case that occurred in the early morning hours of December 7, 2001.  A 22 year-old female had been walking home when Melendez-Valladares pulled her into a remote area behind some buildings and brutally sexually assaulted her.  At the time, this incident received widespread media attention.  The DNA "hit" on Melendez-Valladares occurred while he was already serving prison time in Indiana for a similar crime in 2003.  In 2017, when Melendez-Valladares completes his prison time in Indiana, he will then be transported to Wisconsin to serve 65 years for this case and then 25 years of supervised release.  After the combined 90 years, Melendez-Valladares will be turned over to the federal government for being a repeat, illegal-alien offender.    Essentially this has become a life sentence.  The DNA evidence collected from the victim was entered with the state crime lab.  That information is then continuously checked nationally in the "CODIS" system to compare with other DNA entered daily.

properties.Details: On 11/29/06 at approximately 8:00 p.m. an 18 year-old female, UW-Madison student was walking in the 1500 block of Observatory Drive. properties.Details: On 3/10/07 at approximately 4:06 a.m. a Madison Police Officer was dispatched to a report of a sexual assault. The victim ended up in a van being driven by the suspects who the victim had never seen before.  The suspects drove the victim to an unknown place.  The victim attempted to reach friends, via her cellphone, to no avail.  The van came to a stop and one suspect went inside a residence.  The other suspect stayed in the van, agreeing to take the victim home. Instead, the suspect drove elsewhere, stopped the vehicle and violently sexually assaulted the female victim in the vehicle.  The suspect then drove the victim back downtown and dropped her off in the 500 block of E. Wilson.  This remains an open investigation.  Anyone with information should call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Details: On October 17th, shortly after 10:30 in the evening, a 48-year-old woman reported to Madison police that a young man, armed with a box cutter type knife, tried to sexually assault her outside of a fast-food restaurant. She convinced the suspect to go with her into the restaurant where she said they could go into a bathroom. The ruse worked and she instead called for help. The suspect got away.On October 18th, around 2:34 p.m., a young man (matching the description of the perpetrator from the day prior) confronted a 63-year-old woman with a box cutter knife. This time the scene played out inside the Northport Laundry, 1417 Northport Drive. The suspect tried to get the victim to go into a bathroom. Instead she ran out of the business and yelled for help. The suspect ran off.A Madison police officer had a hunch he might know who the suspect was in these two cases based on past contact he had had with a 16 year old. He gave a name to detectives, and the suspect's photo was picked out of a line-up by one of the victims.Around 7:20 p.m.  Thursday evening (October 18, 2007) detectives made contact with the suspect at his residence and he was arrested.

Jones (22 year old male of Madison) who had allegedly threw a chair and glass object striking a 17 year old male victim.  The victim sustained a severe laceration to the side of his head requiring 20 stitches at a local hospital.  Jones was arrested on charges of Substantial Battery, Disorderly Conduct, and Felony Bail Jumping.A Wayner D. Black (29 year old male of Madison) was also arrested for disorderly conduct charges for spitting blood at both police and Jones (whom he alleged struck him to the head).  A Lorraine  Dorenzo (25 year old female of Madison) was charged with Battery To A Police Officer, Disorderly Conduct, and Resisting A Police Officer after she was given directives from multiple officers to leave the scene but refused.  Dorenzo continued to create a disturbance inside of the establishment as officers were attempting to de-escalate tempers.  Officers made the decision to take her into custody and she retaliates by swinging and striking an officer.   She resisted being taken into custody.  She yelled obscenities and spit on officers before and after she was arrested, and she could not understand why she was taken into custody.Francisco Herron (32 year old male of Janesville) was cited and released for Disorderly Conduct for his active involvement in this disturbance as well.This investigation is ongoing and could result in additional arrests being made. The 4 suspects were swearing loudly, rough housing and disturbing other passengers.  The Metro driver pulled over at MATC, Truax to ask the suspects to stop swearing and disturbing people on the bus.  The driver took a picture of one of the suspects using his cellular phone.  While the driver was asking them to behave while on the bus and to respect others, the 4 decided to leave.  As they did so, one of them knocked the driver into a support pole inside the bus.  The Metro driver told the suspect that act was an assualt and said he had his picture on his phone.  The suspects then re-entered the bus and demanded the driver's cell phone.  The driver held onto the phone and two of the suspects tried grabbing it from him while punching and hitting him in the head.  Witnesses on the bus called police and the suspects all fled.  The driver turned down medical treatment on the scene.  The investigation is ongoing.

properties.Arrested: A 15-year-old male resident of Madison. Subject was taken into custody and referred to the District Attorney's Office on charges of substantial battery and disorderly conduct.
properties.Victim: A 22-year-old male resident of Madison.  Subject received facial lacerations and was conveyed to a Madison hospital by Fire Rescue.  It appears that the lacerations will require stitches.
properties.Details: At approximately 12:57 p.m. on this date, officers responded to the West Transfer Point on Tokay Blvd. reference a fight.  Upon arrival, they located the victim who had noticable facial injuries.  The victim indicated he had become involved in a verbal confrontation with the suspect on a Madison Metro bus.  The confrontation became physical, and the suspect struck the victim in the face.  Numerous witnesses indicated that the fight started on a Metro bus and ended in the parking area of the West Transfer Point.  The suspect, upon learning the police had been called, boarded another bus and left the area.  Officers located the suspect on a bus at the intersection of Tokay and Midvale and took him into custody without incident.  The juvenile was conveyed to the Dane County Juvenile Reception Center.  No further information at this time.

properties.Arrested: 16 year-old Memorial H.S. student.  Charge: Restrictions on use of facsimile firearms (941.2965(2).
properties.Details: On 6/6/2005 at approximately 3:30 p.m. the Memorial H.S. Education Resource Officer learned that a student had a gun in his backpack.  As the officer contacted the student and investigated this incident it was learned that the student had brought a facsimile pellet air gun to school, along with 2,000 rounds of pellet ammunition.  The pellet gun appeared to look exactly like a real gun, especially from a distance.  The student was arrested and processed at the West Police District without incident.  The use of realistic looking facsimile guns can be dangerous for officers and owners, as they have to make split second decisions as to whether or not it is real.

properties.Details: At approximately 12:09 p.m. on 03/11/2006, Madison police responded to Darbo Worthington Park regarding a fight involving juveniles. As the first officer arrived, people pointed out a van that was fleeing the area as being involved in the incident. The van accelerated at a high rate of speed as the officer attempted to stop it. It then crashed into the curb and a fire hydrant at the intersection of Clyde Gallagher and Union Street after failing to negotiate a curb. The 4 occupants of the vehicle are listed above.They all fled the scene on foot. The driver was identified as a 14-year-old male. He was located later in the day by officers at a relative's residence. He was taken to a hospital and treated in the emergency room because he complained of head pain related to hitting the steering wheel. The 2 younger juveniles were apprehended and then released to parents. A 15-year-old from Minnesota remains at large at this time. The battery charge was related to the fight that occurred in the park. The victim in that incident received a minor injury. The vehicle involved was a 1997 Dodge minivan. It suffered extensive front-end damage and a snapped front axle. It appears the vehicle was traveling in excess of 80 miles per hour in a 25 mile per hour zone.

properties.Details: On 2/2/07 at approximately 12:34 p.m. Madison Police responded to a theft report at Schwoegler Bowling.  Officers learned that a 78 year-young female was entering the bowling alley for her typical Friday bowling league.  As she was entering with her purse and bowling ball, the two suspects were leaving as they were attending bowling class.  Upon leaving, they opened the door for the victim.  The victim had put down her bowling ball to originally open the doors.  She thanked the suspects for opening the door for her, but quickly noticed that her purse was missing.  The juveniles left the area as she questioned if they had her purse.  They denied it.  The theft was called out to police.  Officers quickly spotted the suspects in the fields behind Schwoegler, heading back to school at Memorial.  They were contacted and arrested.  The purse and belongings were eventually found in the field area.

properties.Arrested: Female, 14, Oregon: Obstructing, Failure to Pay Cab FareFemale, 14, Brooklyn: Obstructing, Failure to Pay Cab Fare

Unable to locate anyone, the cab driver took them to Moorland Rd for another relative that could pay; again no such luck.  One youth fled on foot and entered an idling bus nearby, which then left.  The cabbie essentially followed and stopped the bus and the spoke with the driver.  The driver kicked the youth off.  The cabbie offered a ride to the two youths, who agreed.  The cabbie placed the child locks up on the door, preventing them from fleeing, and immediately brought them to police headquarters.  While waiting for a police officer, the juveniles did attempt to flee . . . but couldn't open the door.  Eventually, after the above charges, both females were released to their mothers.

properties.Address: 2900 block of N. Sherman Ave ***8/23/07 UPDATE-11:20***
properties.Victim: Lakisha Dancy, 28 Madison, Deceased.   Maya Reese, 2, Madison, Deceased(Dancy's daughter)Demetrius Dobbs, 22, Madison, Deceased
properties.Details: In the form of a horrific, tragic event, three people lost their lives due to an accidental electrocution.  Three individuals were waiting for a bus on N. Sherman Ave.  As the bus approached, an electrical utility pole was struck by lightening, causing a live wire to touch the ground. That wire ended up in a flooded portion of the curb, that was very deep in water. A female and her child were electrocuted.  A small child standing to get on the bus tried to enter the water, but was spared life.  A hero on the bus witnessed what transpired and got off the bus to render aid.  That hero also was electrocuted.  The heroic bus driver also attempted to perform a rescue by exiting the bus, but was shocked and fell back into the bus.  Taken to the hospital were the child and bus driver and their condition is unknown at this time.  Several officers were on scene immediately.  Other people were on the bus and they were uninjured.  The coroner's office is handling the autopsy, identification of the bodies and the notification to survivors.  There were numerous heavy hearts on scene trying to comprehend this tragedy. ***UPDATE***  For those interested in helping with this devastation to the affected families, contributions can be made to ANY Heartland Credit Union.  Please use the "Bus Tragedy Fund" to help support these families and the survivors.  It has been learned that the deceased were traveling together and were friends.  An engaged couple were traveling with a mother and the mother's two children.  When the heavy rain fell and the bus arrived, everyone made a dash for the bus.  As previously stated, lightening struck a utility pole, causing a live wire to lay on the ground in deep water.  The seven year-old child went through the water, following Dobbs and his fiance and received a survivable shock.  The engaged couple saw the child shocked and Dobbs heroically assisted the seven year-old boy onto the bus.  Dobbs saw Dancey fall into the water, with the toddler, and attempted a rescue.  As Dobbs went into the water, he was electrocuted as well.  The seven year-old attempted to go and save his mother, but Dobb's fiance, who was still on the bus, pulled the seven year-old back.  The bus driver also attempted a rescue, was shocked and fell back into the bus.  The bus driver secured the doors, so no one else would go into the water.   The seven year-old is expected to be released from the hospital today or tomorrow.  The seven year-old has an eight and twelve year-old sibling.  They are being taken care of by relatives.

properties.Victim: Apt. building in the 2300 block of Allied Dr.
properties.Details: At approx. 10:58 a.m., Madison Police responded to the 2300 block of Allied Dr. reference a report of a male with an arm injury.  Upon arrival, officers located a 47-year old male from Madison with severe lacerations to his right arm.  The subject was transported by Fire Rescue to a hospital emergency room where he is being treated at this time.  Officers investigated and learned that the male, who appeared to be intoxicated, was inside an apt. building without permission in the 2300 block of Allied Dr.  He was asked by a resident to leave the building, and had to be physically escorted out.  After being escorted from the building, the subject picked up a grill and used it to smash out eight windows in the building.  In the process of doing this, the subject received the severe lacerations to his right arm.  At this time, charges of Criminal Damage to Property are pending against this subject.  His name will be available when he is released from the hospital.Note:  The windows that were damaged were brand new, and both the outer and inner panes were damaged.

The residents were out of town and a neighbor who was watching their place contacted police. Over $40,000 worth of damage was committed inside the house. Officers observed eggs thrown on the walls, cranberry juice thrown all over and a general state of dissarray.     This remains an open investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with information regarding this case is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department has taken numerous reports of vehicle windows being broken on the west side of Madison.  Windows have been broken in unoccupied vehicles parked in driveways, city streets and in a mall parking lot.  No arrests have been made.  In one incident, a witness saw a large, black SUV vehicle use a wrist rocket slingshot to break two windows in separate vehicles at a mall parking lot. In other cases it appears a pellet gun may have been used. At this time there is not a count as to how many vehicles have been hit as most victims were given self-reports to fill out.  Because of the mobility of the suspects and how quickly property is damaged, this is a difficult crime to catch someone in the act of committing.  The Madison Police Department advises that citizens report license plate numbers and vehicle descriptions of suspicious behavior to assist in our investigation.  Anyone with information is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Details: On Tuesday night, around 11:37, employees of the Great Dane Brewery contacted Madison Police after a man broke the glass of a entrance door to the establishment. A witness says the man punched the pane after a bartender refused to serve him anything more than a glass of water. When police arrived the suspect offered up some derogatory words and was identified by his Department of Corrections photo ID.

On Wednesday night at 10:47 p.m. Madison Police were sent to investigate a report of shots being fired at a Madison Metro bus. It was traveling in the 2900 block of Muir Field Road when back window glass shattered. Upon further review it was determined damage was caused by concrete chunks being flung at the bus’s rear – not gunfire. There were no injuries to the driver or passengers, and none onboard were able to give a description of the culprit/culprits.

properties.Suspect: Male, age 15, MadisonMale, age 16, MadisonMale, age 14, Madisonsee updated release below for potential charges
properties.Details: UPDATED INFORMATIONThree teens were arrested yesterday in connection with vandalism caused to the Bridges Golf Course. New damage estimates, stemming from that crime spree, are being placed at around 100,000.Madison Police Detectives have also connected the three young men to vandalism incident at East High School. It occurred this past weekend the same morning as the Bridges vandalism. In the East High case, the suspects were able to get inside the school, and one of the three – the 16 year-old suspect – is believed to have scrawled graffiti, which was racist in nature.The trio is also the focus of a vandalism investigation being conducted by the Dane County Sheriff’s Department.The Madison Police Department MPD would like to thank citizens who helped identify the suspects, including the father of one.Last evening, after viewing surveillance footage broad on local news stations, he called the MPD and said one of the persons of interest seen on a broad is his son.The Madison cases are still under investigation, but it is probable the MPD will ask the District Attorney to file several charges against each teen including: Burglary, multiple counts of Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner’s Consent, and multiple felony Criminal Damage to Property counts.As for the East High graffiti it is likely the MPD will ask that suspect be charged with Graffiti, with a Hate Crime enhancer.ORIGINAL RELEASEOn Saturday morning, and 5:39 a.m., Madison Police were dispatched to the Bridges Golf Course, 2702 Shopko Drive, after employees discovered significant vandalism had been done overnight. Criminals took a John Deere tractor, and a bobcat from the maintenance shed and drove them onto the course. Several trees were uprooted, and extensive damage was done to the 17th tee, par four, and to the 16th hole. Employees estimate damage to these two areas at 25,000. In addition, at least two irrigation heads were damaged, two vehicles - that had been parked by the maintenance shed - were overturned, and a golf cart taken for a joy ride. Golf clubs and a couple of golf bags were also stolen during the crime spree.

properties.Arrested: Ronald Osborne, 33, Madison:  Strong Armed Robbery, Resisting
properties.Details: On 12/22/05 at approximately 7:37 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 2100 block of Allied Drive for a strong-arm robbery.  It was learned that cash was taken from the victim who suffered minor injuries after being strangled by Osborne.  The victim gave a description of the suspect and his known direction of travel.  A responding officer noticed Osborne walking westbound on Raymond Rd just before Lewon Lane.  The officer confronted Osborne verbally and told him to stop for questioning.  Osborne took off running westbound on Raymond.  As he approached Lewon Lane Osborne hit a taxicab that was stopped in the crosswalk.  Osborne continued running, this time out into traffic on Raymond Rd where a car stopped and Osborne jumped over the hood.  He then reversed and went northbound on Lewon and turned eastbound on Black Oak Drive, where he suspiciously reached into his pocket/waistband.  No weapon is seen at this time.  Once on Black Oak Drive, Osborne squares off on the officer still pursuing him on foot.  Osborne continued to refuse orders to stop and get to the ground.  The officer used a baton and struck Osborn on the knee to attempt to apprehend him.  Osborne continued to defy orders and another responding officer deployed a Taser.  Once the Taser was deployed Osborne was immediately taken into custody without further incident.  He was transported to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Details: On 4/18/06 at approximately 1:26 a.m. Madison Police were dispatched to an armed robbery that had occurred in the 200 block of W. Gilman. Those males were contacted, arrested and processed without further incident.

He also indicated that at one point one of the suspects was driving his car and had an accident with a pizza delivery vehicle. The vehicle that was taken has not been located. It is described as a 1992 maroon Pontiac Bonneville with Wisconsin plates. If anyone is aware of a collision involving a pizza delivery vehicle between the hours of 12:30 a.m. and 1:30 a.m. on 04/30/2006, they are encouraged to contact the Madison Police Department.

properties.Details: At approximately 1:27 a.m. officers were dispatched to University Hospital Emergency Room where they contacted the victim in this case. The victim indicated he was in the 200 block of Langdon Street  walking to a car when he was approached by the 3 suspects. He indicated they posed a question to him. Before he had time to answer, he was struck in the face. He indicated he was knocked to the ground and punched and kicked several times. A friend who was waiting in a vehicle saw a group of suspects leaving the parking lot. The friend indicated he believed there wree 6 to 12 males on foot leaving the parking lot area where the incident occurred. The friend located the victim unconscious in the parking lot. The friend and several other individuals conveyed the victim to University Hospital where Madison police were contacted.

properties.Victim: 44 year-old male, stab wound to the hand.
properties.Details: On 5/10/06 at approximately 2:53 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 400 block of W. Gilman for an armed robbery.  Officers tended to the victim, gained suspect information and effectuated an arrest.  Officers learned that the male victim was approached by Sullivan and Brodell who demanded money.  Initially the money was taken, but the victim took it back.  Threats were made with a knife and during the disturbance, Sullivan stabbed the victim on the hand before fleeing the scene.  Officers quickly disseminated the suspect information and spotted them nearby.  Sullivan and Brodell were arrested without incident.  This case remains under investigation.  There is no reason to believe that this case has any connection to the recent string of strong-armed robberies in the downtown area.

properties.Arrested: Eugene J. Walker
properties.Details: The victim was giving the suspect a ride home. At one point near the above intersection, the suspect displayed a handgun. The victim struggled and was struck in the face with the weapon. The suspect fled in the victim's vehicle. Officers located the vehicle and the suspect was taken into custody a short time later.**** UPDATE ****A Madison Police Officer/K-9 Unit was blocks away when this original call for service came in.  The officer responded and checked on the victim's condition and assessed that he would be ok, with minor injuries.  The officer and K-9 followed the direction of travel for the carjacked vehicle.  Monona Police made a traffic stop on the stolen vehicle a short time later and the suspect fled on foot.  The Madison Police Officer and K-9 engaged in a track.  The K-9 led the handler to an area where the suspect was hiding in some bushes.  Several verbal commands were given to the suspect who did not comply and at one point said he was passed out.  The officer was concerned that the suspect did not show his hands because there was a report of the suspect having a firearm.  After several commands and no compliance, the officer released his K-9.  The K-9 went into the bushes, bit the suspect on the shoulder and dragged him out of the bushes where he was arrested without further incident.  A gun was located on the ground at the scene.

properties.Details: On 5/28/06 around midnight a Madison Police Officer took a report of an attempted strong armed-robbery that had just occurred at the intersection of Park St/University Ave.  The victim was walking on Park St, approaching University Ave and was talking on his cell phone when he noticed a car approach him with the suspects yelling at him.  The suspects got out of the car and blocked the path of the victim, not allowing him to leave.  They grabbed his cell phone to see who he was talking to and then demanded money.  The victim told the suspects that he did not have a wallet or any money on him.  Originally the suspects did not believe him and continued to demand money.  Eventually the victim instead offered his cigarettes and lighter to the suspects who took it and left.  A very short time later the cigarettes and lighter were returned to the victim.

properties.Details: The Madison Police Department continues its investigation into the Anchor Bank robbery earlier this morning (see previous release).  During the course of the investigation, detectives believe the suspect maybe tied to other crimes occurring today.  A suspect matching a similar description entered the Speedway Convenience store located at 2810 Fish Hatchery Rd at 2:12 a.m. today displaying a weapon and demanding money.  Additionally, at 5:21 a.m. today a suspect, matching the same description, entered the Super 8 Motel at 4506 Lake Circle (Town of Windsor), displayed a weapon and demanded money.  In all three cases the suspect fled with an undisclosed amount of cash.  Detectives are actively working this case and sharing information.  If anyone has additional information about these crimes, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Details: At approximately 7:54 a.m. Madison Police responded to an alarm at the Cash Express Store located at 2010 Red Arrow Trail. The suspect pushed the clerk back into the store and produced a handgun.  An alarm system was actived and the suspect fled on foot.  A short time later, police arrived.  Officers searched the area and were unable to locate the suspect.  The clerk was not injured.  Anyone with information on this case should call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Male, White, very tan, 5'6-5'8, 160 lbs, medium build, black curly hair, white t-shirt and khaki pants.
properties.Details: On 7/29/2006 at approximately 9:30 p.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to Orchard Street, near the railroad tracks for an armed robbery.  The victim told police that he was trying to push his car, that was heavily damaged by the recent flooding, when he couldn't push it up the hill any further.  He noticed a passerby on foot and asked for assistance in moving the vehicle.  The passerby agreed and helped out.  Once finished the citizen, turned suspect, asked for $5 for helping out.  The victim pulled out his money and gave him $2.  When the suspect saw more money, he pulled out a sharp instrument, made a jabbing motion and demanded more money.  The victim jumped away and ran on foot.  This remains an active investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with information about this case is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: Michael Caldwell, Male, White, 32 years old, Madison:  2 counts of Armed Robbery.
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department has made an arrest in two robberies that occurred in the downtown area during the past weekend.  The arrest comes from good patrol work and details in the reports, followed by detective’s hard work in determining who was responsible for these robberies.  Caldwell was arrested on Monday, July 31 at approximately 4 p.m.  Caldwell has been charged for armed robbery in the incidents that occurred on 7/29 at 9:30 p.m. (see news release) and 7/29 at 11:15 a.m. on W. Dayton in which a victim was robbed at knifepoint and money was taken.  This arrest does not appear to be connected to the downtown robberies involving several suspects and associated acts of violence.

properties.Details: On 8/28/06 at approximately 2:07 a.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to a disturbance in the downtown area, in which a handgun was involved.  Dispatch advised the one suspect was armed with a handgun.  The victim was robbed of his wallet at gunpoint in the Buckeye parking lot off Gorham St.  The suspect with the gun then pistol-whipped the victim, causing substantial injury.  The armed suspect then pointed the handgun at the victim and pulled the trigger, two to three times.  The weapon did not fire.  The victim and witness then chased the armed suspect and eventually caught up to him at Henry St. and Gilman.  The victim was able to recover the wallet from the suspect.  The suspect was later located by responding officers and was conveyed to a local hospital for injuries he sustained during the incident.  The Madison Police Department is actively working this case and is encouraging anyone with additional information to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Details: On 9/20/06 at approximately 1:00 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to an armed robbery at the Ace Hardware Store on Park St/Olin. Helskov had come into the store, acted suspicious, engaged an employee briefly and then went to the counter and demanded money. properties.Victim: Male, 56, McFarland, no injuryMale, 29, Madison, no injury
properties.Details: On 9/26/06 at approximately 11:44 p.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to a robbery in the 5700 block of Russett Rd.  Officers were familiar with the fact that there have been other recent robberies of food delivery and taxicab drivers in the last few weeks.  The officers learned that a taxi had pulled into the 5700 block of Russett Rd to pick up a customer.  One additional customer had already been picked up elsewhere and was inside the vehicle.  The suspect entered the taxi, held a knife to the driver and demanded money.  The other customer was then confronted and also gave up his money.  The suspect fled on foot and officer/K-9 attempts to locate this individual did not yield an arrest.  Officers continued to investigate this incident throughout the night and gained potential suspect information through good police work.  At approximately 5:01 a.m. on 9/27/06 Police Officers were alerted to another taxi pick-up on Balsam Rd.  Several officers responded to the area and set up in order to see if the suspect, as described previously by the earlier victims, would appear.  The suspect, Patton, did appear and was arrested without incident by Madison Police Officers.  This remains an on-going investigation by MPD.

One of the males asked him a question and before he could answer,the group surrounded him. One of the males placed a sharp instrument against the victim's back.  The subjects then demanded money and the victim turned over his wallet and its contents to them.  The group of males then walked north towards Lake Mendota from the scene of the incident.  The victim was not injured.

properties.Arrested: David Bracey (deceased), Sven Heilskov, Bradley Tolson, Georgianna Smith and a fifth person yet to be arrested, as described below.
properties.Details: On 9/16/06 David Bracey was involved in a shootout with police in Lake Delton, WI.  Since that time, information was obtained by the Madison Police Department implicating Bracey in several crimes in the Madison area.  Specifically Bracey was involved in the following robberies:8/2/06:  Dollar General Store, 2006-912148/4/06:  Heartland Credit Union, 2006-920918/11/06: Chase Bank, 2006-954958/18/06: Guaranty Bank (Monona) 2006-50348/22/06: Associated Bank 2006-1007558/30/06: M&I Bank 2006-1045369/13/06: Days Inn, WI Dells9/16/06: Home Depot, Lake DeltonThrough the course of the investigation surrounding Bracey’s involvement, Detectives learned of a ring of individuals who he conspired with.  Detectives learned that Sven Heilskov, Bradley Tolson and Georgianna Smith were also involved in robberies in the Madison area.  All three have been arrested and are in the Dane County Jail.  On 9/20/06 Heilskov was taken into custody after robbing a hardware store on Park St.  Through the course of interviews Heilskov admitted participating in the following robberies:8/22/06:  Associated Bank 2006-1007559/3/06:    Shopko 2006-1065189/14/06:  Kelley’s Market 2006-1116279/16/06:  Pinkus McBride 2006-1127409/17/06:  Supreme Pizza  2006-1130709/17/06:  Supreme Pizza  2006-1131709/20/06:  Ace Hardware  2006-114320Investigators are still looking for a fourth person believed to be involved in these same robberies in the area. The person is described as:  Male, Black, 50-56 years old, 5’10, 165-175 lbs., with a rough voice, mustache, goatee and an observable bump on his forehead.   Anyone with information about the whereabouts of this individual is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers may be eligible for a cash reward and can remain anonymous. “I am proud of the detectives who worked so hard to make these arrests,” stated Chief Noble Wray.  “With a crime ring as large as this, with so many reports, witnesses and evidence to examine, this clearly illustrates the competence and thoroughness of our detectives.”

properties.Details: The victim was unloading groceries in the driveway of his home when he was approached by suspect #1 who asked for directions to the downtown area.  Almost immediately, the suspect displayed a black handgun and demanded money from the victim.  The victim refused to turn over any money and a physical altercation began with the suspect beating the victim in the head with the gun.  The two other suspects appeared during the attack and joined suspect #1 in the attack and were unsuccessfull in removing the victim's wallet from his pants pocket.  Ultimately, the 3 suspects disengaged from the victim and fled the scene on foot in a westerly direction.  The victim received minor injuries and refused medical treatment at the scene.  The suspects were not located and are still at large.

properties.Details: On 3/4/07 at 6:42 p.m. officers were dispatched to the 500 block of Northport Dr reference a strong-armed robbery.  In contacting the victim, it was learned that the victim and a friend were playing videogames inside their apartment.  A casual acquaintance knocked at the door and one victim allowed her to come in.  The female opened the door slowly and was followed by three male suspects.  The suspects confronted the two victims and began to batter them.  During the struggle, one suspect broke a liquor bottle to threaten it as a weapon.  Punches were thrown and minor injuries were reported.  At one point a victim reported that a suspect pistol-whipped him on the head.  Eventually the suspects fled the apartment and police were notified.  This remains an open investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with information about this crime is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

A witness had observed this, first believing it was playful fighting and followed the suspects.  The citizen followed the suspects to the south side of Madison and saw both suspects exit the car. properties.Arrested: Elector TylerAge 24, MadisonTentative Charge:Armed Robbery
properties.Details: *********************UPDATE****************At around 7 p.m. Monday evening a Madison Police Department Parking Enforcement Officer was dispatched to an illegally parked vehicle in the 4300 block of Lilac Lane. The PEO immediately recognized the illegally parked van as matching the description of the van being sought in the Loan Max armed robbery. As the PEO was contacting police dispatch about his find the suspect showed up and attempted to get back into the van. At the time the PEO did not know this was the suspect, but he informed the woman she could come no closer to the van because it was now the subject of a police investigation. She left. MPD Officers arrived to back-up the PEO. A short time later the suspect was found, and arrested on Allied Drive. It should be noted Lilac Lane and Allied Drive are not far apart.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------At approximately 4pm today, Madison Police responded to a report of an armed robbery at the Loan Max, 3066 E. Washington Ave.  The clerk reported being robbed by the above-described subject who was armed with a knife.  The suspect's face was covered at the time of the robbery.   No one was injured and the suspect fled the store with an undisclosed amount of cash.  Investigation continues

properties.Details: On Saturday night September first Madison Police were on routine patrol in the Allied Drive neighborhood when they made contact with, and later arrested, a man who matched the description of a suspect who had robbed three people in separate incidents earlier that evening.Around 7:00 p.m. a 51-year-old man was in line to make a purchase at the Speedway gas station (4902 Verona Road) when a man ran past him and grabbed his wallet. The victim told police "with a corn dog in my mouth, I began to chase him (the suspect) across the parking lot." He did not catch him, and called police. At 8:35 p.m. a woman sitting at a picnic table outside of Bennett's bar (2009 Freeport Rd.) reported that a man grabbed her purse and ran off down the nearby bike path. Then at 10:54 p.m. a woman told police she was attempting to buy some coffee at the drive-thru window at McDonald's (4687 Verona Road) when a suspect grabbed money from her hand. When Hollweck was arrested officers found a crack pipe in his pocket

properties.Details: Around 11:14 a.m. on September 28th Madison Police responded to Fraboni's for a report of an armed robbery. Witnesses told police the suspect indicated he had a gun. Following the hold-up an employee of the delicatessen gave chase. Police learned the suspect had been on a bicycle. The bike was found not far from the original crime scene. A citizen witness next led investigators to the UW's Administration building at 21 North Park Street. It is located directly behind Fraboni’s. The citizen had spotted someone acting suspiciously on an upper floor of the building. The building was evacuated. UW and MPD officers then systematically went floor-by-floor clearing the building. During this search the person spotted by the citizen witness was located. He has been detained. Madison Police would like to commend several citizens who provided very good descriptions and/or information about the suspect in this case.

properties.Details: On Saturday morning September 29th around 1:45 a.m. Madison police responded to an apartment complex on Schroeder Road after a witness called and said she was observing an armed robbery. When police arrived they found four men arguing and yelling. It was later determined that one of the men was the victim of the armed robbery, that two of the men were his friends, and that these friends had arrived on the scene just as the crime was culminating. The fourth man was identified as the armed robber. The victim told police he was waiting for his friends to meet up with him when he was held-up. He reports that the suspect pointed a gun at his head, and then hit him in the head with the gun. He was knocked to the ground, gave the suspect money, and just then his friends showed up. He told them he had just been robbed. The friends tackled the suspect. The gun, which turned out to be a CO2 pistol, was wrestled from him. Police arrived right around that moment.

properties.Details: Shortly after 10:00 p.m. on Tuesday October 2nd Madison police responded to a University Avenue convenience store for an armed robbery. The clerk reported being held-up by a knife wielding masked man. Patrol officers utilized Madison Police K-9 Greg to try to track the suspect. First K-9 Greg led officers across University Avenue and down Norman Way to an area where a knife believed to be used in the robbery was "sniffed" out. Next K-9 Greg led officers to an area near Norman Way and Greening Lane where the suspect was found.

properties.Details: On October 3rd, 2007 at 3:42 p.m. Madison police officers responded to a University Avenue jewelry store for a report of an attempted armed robbery. An employee told police the suspect had attacked him with a hammer, and he believes that had he not ducked he would have been hit in the head. During this confrontation the victim says the suspect continued to swing the hammer and threaten his (the victim's) life. He went on to explain that he and the suspect ended up wrestling on the floor, and that he (the victim) eventually ran out of the store to seek help. As he did this the suspect fled. The victim saw the suspect run and seek refuge in a nearby apartment building. He (the victim) called 911. Officers utilized the skills of Madison Police K9 Johnny to search the apartment building. In a laundry area K9 Johnny stuck his nose into the crack of a bathroom door. K9 Johnny began to growl. A voice from inside the bathroom said something to the effect of, "get your dog out of here." The suspect was then arrested.

properties.Details: On November 15th at 11:04 p.m. Madison police were dispatched to Carrington Drive where a resident reported four young men had just attacked her. The victim says she was outside of her apartment and in her car when the four perpetrators approached. They asked for a ride. She said no. Then she says the oldest of the foursome produced a handgun and ordered her out of the car. She obliged, but was then attacked. The victim says she was struck multiple times in the head and back with hands, feet, and with a stake typically used in parking lots to designate snow removal boundaries. Fearful for her life she fought back. She was able to grasp the weapon and determine that the gun was plastic and likely a fake. While struggling she was also yelling loudly. A neighbor witnessed the commotion and called 911. The young men fled. The victim was taken to a local hospital where she was treated for her injuries.

properties.Details: Around 6:26 p.m. on December 20th Madison police responded to the 2300 block of Eton Ridge to meet with a robbery victim. A 16-year-old told police he had just finished basketball practice and was crossing Regent Street when he observed a group of approximately seven individuals. The victim walked from Regent Street to Virginia Terrace to where his car was parked on Eton Ridge. As he neared his vehicle he says three from the group he had noted moments earlier came up quickly behind him. He says perpetrator #1 grabbed him and demanded money. He did not have any money. The victim says #1 next rummaged through his pockets and stole his iPhone. No weapon was seen, and it is not known whether this robbery and another (case #152841) that happened on N. Mills Street two hours later are connected.

properties.Details: On 12/26/2007 Madison police responded to Access for Independence, 2345 Atwood Avenue, to speak with the victim of a strong-armed robbery. The victim, who suffers from cerebral palsy, and is confined to a wheelchair, says the crime took place around 9:30 p.m. on Christmas Eve (December 24, 2007). He says he was in need of medication and on his way to a drug store when his wheelchair became stuck in the snow. He says a woman, who at first appeared as a Good Samaritan, helped set him free. But, after the favor she demanded money. The victim went with her to an ATM machine where he provided his code numbers so she could take cash from his account. The victim feels he was targeted because of his diability, and wants the perpetrator caught so this does not happen to someone else.

properties.Details: Early Sunday morning, around 12:41 a.m., Madison Police responded to an attempted robbery on American Parkway. An employee of a snow removal business reported that he was moving snow with a bobcat when his plow rig jammed. He dismounted the bobcat and went over to his pickup truck to retrieve what he needed to remedy the situation. Upon returning to the bobcat he was startled to notice that a stranger had assumed the driver's seat. The perpetrator asked the victim how much money he had, and then attempted to approach the victim. However, while disembarking the bobcat it appeared the would-be robber tweaked an ankle or knee; nevertheless he continued towards the victim who, in turn, punched the stranger in the head. The perpetrator fell to the ground. He got up and walked off with a noticeable limp. The bobcat driver called police, and then got back to work.

properties.Details: (UPDATED: Friday April 25, 2008)On Thursday evening, April 24, 2008, around 8:45, Madison Police arrested Mr. David Blank at his Madison residence for Armed Robbery. Descriptions given by the victim and another witness led to his apprehension.It should be noted that the victim in this case, a 26-year-old Madison woman, was very traumatized by this crime. While trying to put groceries in her car the suspect is believed to have slashed one of her car tires, and then point a knife very close to her chest. He demanded her purse, and she thought she might die if she did not give it up. She told a responding officer, "It's traumatic. It's going to stick in my brain. I'm going to wonder when something like this is going to happen to me again."---------------------------------(ORIGINAL INCIDENT REPORT)Report of a purse snatching at knifepoint in the parking lot of Woodman's East. The suspect was described as a white male, 20-30 years old, 5'10", 190 lbs, brown hair, wearing a red shirt and blue jeans. The suspect fled in a maroon vehicle after slashing the victim's vehicle's tire and snatching her purse. No injuries reported. Investigation continuing.

properties.Details: On Tuesday afternoon, shortly before 5:00, a 51-year-old Cross Plains woman arrived at the West Town Mall parking lot near JC Penney with plans to meet her daughter for a little shopping. The victim opened her car door, but before she could get out a man pulled a pistol on her and threatened to shoot if she did not give up her purse. The woman says the handgun was placed "right on my ribs." She thought she was going to be shot no matter what she did, and responded to the threat by blowing her car's horn. The suspect took off, and she observed him fleeing with an accomplice. The woman followed the men - at a safe distance - while police were called to the scene. Her bird-dogging efforts paid off, as she was able to provide the MPD with a solid direction of travel. The two suspects were located behind a restaurant near Flower Lane. The weapon turned out to be a BB gun but officers agreed with the victim that it looked like a real weapon. It was located in the waistband of Mr. Thompson's trousers.

properties.Details: On Tuesday night around 11:00 p.m. a pizza delivery driver drove to a home in the 4900 block of Violet Lane. He had with him two large pizzas, and was about to approach the house when he realized no lights were on. At this moment he had opened the driver's side car door, but he had not exited. Perpetrator #1 walked up armed with what the driver believed to be a handgun. #1 ordered the victim to give up "the money." The driver said o-k, and pretended to be digging around inside the car for cash. Instead he placed the vehicle in reverse and gunned the engine. The open door struck #1 knocking him to the ground. The driver sped off, and looked back to see #1 and an accomplice (perpetrator #2) running after him. The victim drove a bit farther and called for police.

properties.Details: Late Saturday afternoon several Madison police officers responded to the Walgreen's pharmacy on Cottage Grove Road following an attempted armed robbery. A pharmacist said a suspect claimed to have a gun, and was demanding narcotics. The suspect then pulled out a wooden baseball bat and attacked the pharmacist. The victim was struck in the arm, and defended himself by grabbing for the suspect's knee and pushing on it as hard as he could. The suspect fell over, and the pharmacist was able to gain control of the bat. The suspect decided to run, and the victim threw the bat - "like a tomahawk" - hitting the suspect in the upper back. The suspect fled out of the store. One of the responding officers found him walking along Hermsmeier Lane and he was he was arrested.

properties.Suspect: Corey L. Holly, age 18, Fitchburg WisconsinCharges: (1) Robbery 943.32
properties.Victim: Mobil Gas Station (3505 East Washington Avenue, Madison Wisconsin)
properties.Details: On June 16th, 2008 at approximately 9:15AM, Madison Police were dispatched to an Armed Robbery at the Mobile Gas Station (3505 E. Washington Avenue).   Police would arrive obtaining a good description of the suspect and information that the suspect fled on foot just north of the robbery scene with an undisclosed amount of cash.  Officers would canvass the area and based on a good description of the suspect, a driver for Madison Metro Bus Company would pick up an individual matching the described likeness just blocks away.  The driver did an outstanding job in alerting Madison Metro of this information, and Police would respond to the 1600 Block of S. Stoughton Road to contact this potential suspect.A male subject identified as Corey L. Holly attempted to exit the bus as Officers were converging to contact him, but after a minor struggle Holly would be detained at 10:32AM.  Pending further investigative measures by both Officers and Detectives, Holly would be placed under arrest at 11:01AM for the robbery.  It should be known that this Mobile Gas Station has been robbed on two other occasions (May 9th 2008 & June 6th, 2008), and Detectives continue to investigate this matter to determine a possible connection involving Holly.  This case reflected astute actions on the part of the Bus Driver, and solid work on the part of police/witnesses to make an arrest in this matter.  If it were not for citizens remaining vigilant in their observations of this suspect, it would have been much more difficult for police to effect an arrest in this scenario. Holly was arrested in August of 2007 on Armed Robbery charges and extended a one-year sentence with Huber; which he began serving in February of 2008. PO Howard PayneMadison Police Department

properties.Details: Late Thursday morning - around 11:50 a.m. - Madison Police were called to the Badger Campus Credit Union following a robbery. The initial alarm went to the UW Police Department, which is just a couple of blocks from the credit union.  Responding UW officers were flagged down by a citizen a couple of blocks from the crime scene near the intersection of Mills and Milton Streets. The citizen is a member of the Badger Campus Credit Union. He was coming into the credit union just as the suspect was running out. Staff alerted the citizen to what had just happened, and he decided to take it upon himself to follow the suspect while maintaining a relatively safe distance. As UW police rolled into the area the citizen alerted them to the suspect's location. He was taken into custody. Stolen money was recovered. The suspect made threats while committing the robbery, but did not display a weapon.

properties.Details: Officers were sent to an armed robbery at East Gate Cinemas.  It was learned that two suspects entered the cinema with one going to the ticket counter and one going to the concession stand.  Suspect #1 took the cash drawers and ran from the cinema towards American TV.  He was tackled by two MPI security guards, cinema employees and an off duty deputy who went to watch a movie.  A loaded gun was recovered.  Suspect #2 attempted to grab the cash drawer from the concession area, but was stopped and by cinema employees and some citizens.  He was then arrested by Madison Police Officers.  Both suspects were taken to the Dane County Jail.  All of the cash was recovered and no serious injuries were reported.  The investigation is ongoing.
