properties.Details: Early Tuesday morning, at 1:11 a.m., Madison Police officers were sent to an apartment complex parking lot on Dexter Street after a man was shot during an armed robbery. The victim says he had met a woman while parked outside of a bar on Roth Street. He and the woman conversed for a time before she asked for a ride home. She directed him to the parking lot where he would be shot.  When he stopped, two men approached the car. One was armed with a handgun. He was at the driver's side window, and demanded the victim's wallet. Just as the victim was about to hand it over he was shot in the shoulder. Next he realized the woman had taken off, and that there was now a second perpetrator at his passenger side door. He ended up losing his wallet, and car keys.

properties.Details: On September 16, 2008, at 11:53 a.m. Madison police were notified of a robbery that had just taken place at the Anchor Bank, 333 S. Westfield Road. The suspect threatened a teller and took off on foot with some of the bank’s cash. A bank customer followed the suspect and provided direction of travel information to responding officers.  As they picked up the suspect’s trail there was a brief foot chase before he was captured. John B. Kowal, age 23, Madison, has been tentatively charged with six counts of robbery, as he has been connected to a string of area bank heists committed this year. The Middleton Police Department, Monona Police Department, the Madison Police Department, in conjunction with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have collaboratively been working these cases.The office of Erik C. Peterson, United States Attorney for the Western District of Wisconsin will prosecute Mr. Kowal.

properties.Details: On October 2, 2008, just before 9:00 p.m., Madison Police were called to the 2200 block of Cypress Way for a robbery. A 55-year-old man, in a wheelchair, told responding officers that a man who had offered to get him a new wheelchair had just robbed him of his money and cell phone. The victim said the perpetrator started off as a Good Samaritan in that he helped the victim get his suitcase into a West Beltline area motel. The victim had expressed that his wheelchair was not working well, and he needed a new, used one. The perpetrator told him he could get him one for 35. The victim ended up going with the perpetrator to an apartment complex. The perpetrator went in, came out, and told the victim the person who had the wheelchair wanted more money. The victim now believed he was being led on, and refused to ante up. The perpetrator then got the victim's wheelchair the one he wanted to replace out of the trunk of his car, and the victim got into it. The two men continued to argue, and the victim says he ended up getting hit in the face one or two times. He says after being struck, the perpetrator took his remaining money and his cell phone. Area residents came to the victim's aid, and called police.

The suspect was able to get just several feet away when the victim's friend was able to stop him and detain him until police arrived.  Victim and friend were not injured.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, black, 20 years old, clean-shaven, wearing a dark-colored hooded sweatshirt with the hood up.
properties.Details: On Sunday night, around 8:26 p.m., Madison Police were dispatched to the 800 block of West Washington Avenue for an armed robbery attempt. A 57-year old man indicated he was at a bus stop, waiting for a bus, when a man approached. The man asked the victim what time the bus was due to arrive, and then pulled out a handgun. The gunman demanded money. The victim reached in a pocket and pulled out his cell phone, and the perpetrator walked away.

properties.Suspect: John J. Olson, age 28, MadisonJohn A. Olson, age 36, MadisonDaniel W. Rymer, age 27, MadisonAll were arrested and tentatively charged with Armed Robbery.
properties.Details: This morning, on October 13, 2008, members of the Madison Police Department uted a pair of search warrants in connection with armed robbery investigations, which are being conducted in partnership with the Dane County Sheriff’s Department.Members of the Madison Police Department’s SWAT team set-up to help ute the first search warrant at an address in the 800 block of Brandie Road very early this morning. While observing the property, and prior to going in, the team saw a vehicle pull up and drop off two men. Their arrival followed the third in a series of recent bar hold-ups. Around 1:55 a.m. this morning, Dane County Sheriff’s deputies responded to the Kountry Keg Tavern, 6259 Portage Road, for an armed robbery.Earlier this month, on October 2, 2008, Bailey’s Bar, 601 N. Fair Oaks Ave., Town of Blooming Grove, was struck, and the Packers Inn, 300 Cottage Grove Road, Madison, was hit on October 7, 2008.   After the men were dropped off at the Brandie Road address, officers did proceed to ute the warrant. Arrested at the residence were John J. Olson, age 28, and his uncle John A. Olson, age 36. Both have been tentatively charged with Armed Robbery.Following the apprehensions, Madison Police next uted the second search warrant at a residence in the 700 block of Herndon Drive. Arrested at that location was Daniel W. Rymer, age 27. He has also been tentatively charged with Armed Robbery.Investigators believe the suspects are responsible for the three tavern robberies.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator #1 is described as a male, black, 30 years old, 5'10"- 6'00" , 170-185 lbs., medium build, right eye is entirely white, wearing blue jeans and a brown jacket.Perpetrator #2 is described as a male, black, age 17, wearing a dark brown hat.Perpetrator #3 is described as a male, black, age 17.
properties.Victim: Male, age 36, MadisonVictim suffered a swollen wrist and some scrapes.
properties.Details: On Sunday, October 12, 2008, around 6:31 p.m., a Madison man reported being robbed the night prior. The 36-year old victim says he was walking in the 1600 block of Troy Drive around 9:30 p.m., on October 11, 2008, when a black Cadillac pulled over near his location. He says two men got out and pulled him into the car. The victim says he was punched and robbed before being pushed out of the car near the Lakewood Gardens Apartment complex on Sherman Avenue. The perpetrators took money, a cell phone, and the victim's keys. The victim does not speak English, and said he did not report the crime immediately because he did not know he should call the police.

It was reported a female was robbed at gunpoint at the front door of her apartment. The suspect was described as a black, male, 6'1" to 6'2", thin build, wearing a white hoodie and black jeans. The suspect was also described as having green or hazel colored eyes. The suspect displayed a chrome handgun and took the victim's wallet. He then took the battery from her cellular phone threw it on the steps by the front door. The Town of Madison had an armed robbery about the same time, in the 2200 block of Woodview Ct. The female victim in that incident gave a very similar description of the suspect and it is believed the same suspect was responsible for both armed robberies. The investigation is continuing.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as male, black, 22-26 years old, 6'6", thin build, wearing a dark colored "hoodie."
properties.Details: On October 14th, just before 7:00 in the evening, an 18-year old downtown resident contacted the Madison Police Department to report a robbery that had happened last week. The victim says she was walking alone in the 100 block of East Gilman Street around 1:30 a.m. on Friday, October 10, 2008, when a man approached.She says he asked her for money, then started touching her legs. He took money that was in one of her pockets. The victim says the robber walked away, and was in the company of two other men. They were also described as black males, 22-26 years old, and very tall - 6'6" to 6'7".The woman says she was hesitant to report the crime at first because she did not wish her family to find out what had happened to her.

An employee reported two suspects entered the store, displayed a black semi-auto handgun. Suspects then fled after taking cash and the employee's cell phone. Suspect #1 described as a black, male, 16 years old, medium height and build with braids, wearing a black SOX baseball cap and displayed the handgun. Suspect #2 described as a black, male in his late 30's to early forties, light skinned, medium build, mustache, brown cap and dark colored leather waist length coat. Neither suspect was wearing a mask. No injuries reported

The victim a 69 year old male was out for a walk. The suspect described as a white male, 16-20 years old, 6 feet tall,brown shaggy hair, wearing a white tee shirt and jeans reached into the victim's front pocket and took his wallet. The suspect fled and the victim ran after him. A witness in a vehicle followed the suspect for a while but then turned around to check the welfare of the victim. No injuries reported.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, black, late 20's,  6', short hair, goatee, medium build, wearing a green polo shirt and jeans.

properties.Details: On Thursday night, October 23, 2008, a Madison Police detective arrested a suspect in connection with an armed robbery that occurred on October 12th. Two victims had come from the Montello area to Madison with hopes of procuring some marijuana. They had a contact that put them in touch with Mr. Rodney Harris. The suspect and victims got together in the 2400 block on Monterey Drive shortly before 1:00 a.m. on the 12th. Mr. Harris had indicated he could deliver on the marijuana, but later reneged. Instead he pulled a gun on the victims and took their drug money. He's also accused of striking one  in the head with his gun.

properties.Arrested: 14 year-old male: -Knowingly fleeing an officer-Operating After Suspension-Failure to have control-Red Signal Violation-Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner Consent
properties.Details: On 5/3/05 at approximately 12:12 a.m. a Madison Police Officer on routine patrol observed a vehicle traveling erratically on McKenna Blvd, near Elver Park.  As the officer followed the vehicle he noticed traffic violations by the offending vehicle, which lead to the officer attempting to stop the vehicle.  The vehicle did not stop for the officer and took off at a high rate of speed going north on McKenna Blvd.  Other officers also engaged in the short pursuit, which reached speeds of at least 70 m.p.h. and lasted less than one minute, 30 seconds.  The vehicle attempted to turn west on New Washburn Way and jumped the curb, crashing into some shrubbery.  Officers arrested the juvenile.

properties.Arrested: ALEJANDRO NIGRON REYES, 25 years old, 1932 University Ave.  CHARGE: Speeding over fixed limits.  Cited & released.
properties.Details: At approximately 8:50 a.m. on 05/29/05 an officer was running radar and clocked a southbound vehicle in excess of 60 mph on Park Street.  By the time the officer was able to catch up to the vehicle on Park Street at Badger Rd., it had accelerated to over 80 mph.  The driver indicated he was frustrated about being detoured and trying to get out of Downtown Madison while the Madison Marathon was going on.  The driver received a citation for speeding.  The  citation was for $412 and 6 points.   Park Street is posted  30 mph.

properties.Arrested: Two, 14 year old females were arrested ref. this incident
properties.Victim: 44 year old male sustained multiple facial fractures, a compound fracture of the lower eright leg and at least five lacerations to the face/head
properties.Details: The victim was crossing S. Park St. when he was struck by a vehicle.  The vehicle then fled the scene.  Witnesses on the scene were able to give a vehicle description to police. Officers later discovered the vehicle and eventually arrested the driver and passenger for operating a motor vehicle without owner's consent.  The driver was charged with leaving the scene of an accident as well.  The victim, who reported that he was from New Orleans but was displaced by hurricane Katrina, was transported to a local hospital.  He was listed in stable condition.

properties.Details: On 1-25-2006, the Dane County Narcotics and Gang Task Force and the Dodge County Drug and Task Force were working collaboratively on a drug investigation in the S. Park St./ Fish Hatchery Rd. area, when the suspect of the investigation fled in his vehicle to avoid arrest. Officers pursued, as the suspect fled through portions of the south side of the City of Madison, and portions of the Town of Madison, Fitchburg, and Verona. The pursuit concluded shortly after successful deployment of tire deflation spikes to suspect vehicles tires. The suspect and passenger were taken into custody without further incident. A third passenger, who exited suspect vehicle during pursuit, was treated at local hospital for injuries sustained while being battered by driver.

properties.Arrested: Keith Hopkins, 44, Madison:  Operating a Motor Vehicile Without Owner's Consent (OMVWOC), Battery to a Police Officer, Operating While Impaired (OWI), Resist/Obstructing x 2, Possession of Drug Paraphernalia.
properties.Details: On 2/20/06 at approximately 9:45 a.m. a Madison Police Officer was on patrol in the Allied Drive neighborhood.  The officer noticed a stolen vehicle ahead and followed it to make a traffic stop.  The driver of the stolen vehicle, Hopkins, noticed the officer and turned into an apartment building parking lot in the 4700 block of Crescent Rd.  The officer followed the suspect vehicle and noticed Hopkins quickly run out of the vehicle.  The officer pursued Hopkins on foot and engaged in verbal commands for him to stop.  Hopkins and the officer began to physically fight, as Hopkins did not stop running.  The officer deployed several active counter measures as Hopkins continued his aggression.  Eventually the officer deployed the Taser.  Hopkins went to the ground after being tased and got back up.  Hopkins was tased again, went to the ground and got back up.  Hopkins was tased a third time, went to the ground and got back up.  The officer physically engaged Hopkins again and was able to gain control.  As Hopkins continued to resist arrest, a property owner nearby also came to assist in handcuffing Hopkins.  Hopkins was treated at a local hospital for a head injury and was eventually cleared to go to the Dane County Jail without further incident.

properties.Arrested: Corey J. Chase of Sun Prairie Wisconsin
properties.Details: On March 10th, 2006 at approximately 9:35p.m, a Madison Police Officer working a traffic enforcement initiative, stopped a vehicle driven by Corey J. Chase of Sun Prairie Wisconsin in the 3700 block of N. Stoughton Road for speeding.   The Officer reported that Chase was traveling 98mph, and the posted speed limit was 55mph!  A citation was issued for the offense (Speeding in excess of fixed limits - 346.57(5), and the driver was release on scene.  The Madison Police Department wants to remind the public that they should pay particular attention to their speeds during their daily commutes throughout the city.  Understand that talking on cellular phones or being distracted by anything else inside of your vehicle can put you in danger of not only not being aware of speed, but places you at risk for being involved in an accident.    We ask that drivers be extremely cautious in terms of how attentive they are to all that is going on around them.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: Arrested: Daniel E. Sawyer, M/W, 5-31-67. No permanent address.Charges: Eluding, Operating Motor Vehicle Without Owners Consent, Reckless Driving, Resisting Arrest, Possession THC.
properties.Details: On 3/16/06 at approximately 12:59a, Madison Police officers attempted to stop a reported stolen vehicle in the 4700 block of Verona Rd. The driver attempted to elude officers, entering the eastbound W. Beltline Hwy. at Verona Rd. The driver jumped from the moving vehicle east of Seminole Hwy., and fled into the arboretum. The vehicle continued for several hundred feet, coming to a stop after striking a tree. The driver, Daniel E. Sawyer, was taken into custody after a short foot chase. No injuries resulted from the pursuit.

properties.Arrested: 15 year-old male, Madison: Eluding, Possession of marijuana with intent to deliver
properties.Details: On 7/22/06 at approximately 9:30 p.m. a Madison Police Officer observed erratic driving at the intersection of E. Washington and Zeier Rd.  The officer was originally going to remind the driver of safer driving practices with a verbal statement.  In approaching the vehicle, the offending driver took off at a high rate of speed and now the officer was attempting to stop the vehicle with red lights and siren.  The eluding vehicle traveled on the following roads: Dwight, Portage, Sunbrook, Portage, Hayes, Columbus Ln, Declaration and Anniversary Ln.  At one point the vehicle stopped at the end of Sunbrook and quickly took off as the officer attempted to make contact.The car eventually went to the end of Forest Ridge Rd and enough officers had caught up so as the vehicle could not go further.  The juvenile was arrested on the above charges.  A 15 year-old male passenger was returned to his parents.

properties.Arrested: Suspect- Male, age 12.
properties.Details: On 7/31/2006, at 3:37am, Madison Police attempted to stop a vehicle traveling inbound on Monona Dr. at Cottage Grove Rd. for operating without headlights. The operator of the vehicle attempted to elude officers, accelerating to speeds of 85-90 MPH, while continuing inbound on Atwood Ave. At Atwood Ave. and Winnebago St., the driver lost control of the vehicle and crashed into the facade of the Chase Bank at 1965 Atwood Ave., causing significant property damage. Circumstances of accident remain under investigation.

properties.Arrested: Deundra R. Moore, 31 year old male, arrested on 2-2-07 at 12:16 a.m.
properties.Details: On 2-2-07 at approximately 12:08 a.m., a Madison police officer attempted to stop a vehicle for speeding near Packers Ave. and Aberg Ave.  The driver, Deundra Moore, refused to stop and attempted to elude the officer.  This led to a high speed pursuit which lasted approximately 6-7 minutes and reached speeds of 95 mph.  The pursuit was primarily in the Packers/Aberg Ave. area.  At one point, Moore's vehicle struck a curb; he briefly lost control and drove into a ditch.  Moore then attempted to continue to drive, going into an apartment complex at Aberg Ave. and McCormick Ave.  His vehicle then got stuck and he fled on foot.  Moore was apprehended after a short foot pursuit.  Moore was charged with eluding, resisting an officer, possession of THC, a probation hold, reckless driving and several other traffic citations.  NFA

properties.Arrested: Tosha Krueger, 23, Madison:  EludingMaurice Withers, 37, Madison: Parole Hold, Resisting Angela Frank, 23, Arena:  Operating After Revocation-Warrant, Probation Warrant
properties.Details: On 4/9/07 at 1:56 a.m. Madison Police responded to a disturbance at the Super 8 Hotel on the W. Beltline frontage road.  The Town of Madison Police also assisted in this incident.  Officers learned that there was possibly a male who was threatened with a weapon at the hotel.  Officers noted the three individuals described above, matching the suspect's description, enter a vehicle and leave as officers were approaching and ordering them to stop.  Officers pursued the vehicle which went westbound on the frontage road, to Emil St, to Fish Hatchery Rd, to the westbound Beltline, to the Todd Drive exit, back on to the westbound Beltline, to Seminole before eventually crashing on Nakoma Rd at Odana Rd.  Speeds on Nakoma Rd were estimated to be over 70 mph.  No one was injured to the point of being treated at a hospital.   The entire pursuit lasted approximately four minutes.

This morning the Traffic Enforcement Safety Team (TEST, with the held of South District patrol officers, set up a Speedwave initiative along Olin Avenue near the entrance of the City's Goodman Pool. Between the hours of 10:15 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. 13 people were pulled over for speeding. The zone near the pool is posted at 25 miles per hour. TEST Officers found offenders were averaging 15 miles per hour over that speed limit, with one driver clocking in at 20 over. Officers report that youngsters and their parents were often trying to cross Olin Avenue at the same time some motorists saw fit to speed. This Speedwave was in response to concerns for the safety of these pool patrons, specifically the children. Very young, often unescorted boys and girls frequent the area and cross Olin Avenue unassisted.  The Madison Police Department would ask drivers to remember the pool is now open, and to be cognizant of increased pedestrian traffic.

properties.Arrested: Michael S. Jones, Age 21, MadisonArrested by Town of Madison Police & tentatively charged with Eluding & Operating after Revocation
properties.Details: On August 16th around 1:16 a.m. a Madison Police officer was alerted that two Town of Madison police officers were engaged in the pursuit of a white Chevrolet, and that this car was now westbound on W. Badger Rd. approaching Fish Hatchery Rd. The Madison officer was in the area, saw the speeding car, and was advised Town officers were requesting his assistance. The pursuit route went from Fish Hatchery Rd. onto the West Beltline where speeds were in the 90 to 100 M.P.H. range were noted. The Chevy then got off at Seminole Highway and made its way to Nakoma Road where speeds were clocked between 50 to 60 M.P.H.  As officers approached Monroe Street they were advised to terminate the pursuit. Officers, now driving at the legal speed limit, continued in the direction of the speeding car and found that it had collided with the porch of rental home at 125 N. Randall Ave. It appears cinder blocks from the porch then flew off and hit a legally parked truck. It belongs to a UW student who lives in the home that was hit. The crash woke him up, and he spotted the driver of the speeding car leaving the scene on foot. The student chased and detained the suspect until Madison police could take over for him. The student is in the Naval ROTC and says he is in pretty decent shape from program training. A Madison Sgt., at the scene, is recommending the student receive a citizen commendation for his aid in the apprehension. It should be noted that a desk and a chair that had been outside the home that was struck were demolished in the incident. The ROTC student says he and his roommates were undecided as to whether the items should be kept or tossed and the crash resolved that issue.

properties.Suspect: Female (driver), age 16, MadisonThe suspect was arrested and tentatively charged with 2nd Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety, Eluding, & a Juvenile Absconder Warrant.Nelson C. Jefferson (passenger), age 18, Madison Mr. Jefferson was arrested and tentatively charged with Obstructing.
properties.Details: On Thursday -- shortly before noon -- a Madison Police officer, who was on routine patrol on Allied Drive, witnessed a car strike a Department of Corrections Juvenile Agent. This agent was on foot and attempting to contact the car's 16-year-old driver who is one of his clients. The agent suffered non-life threatening injuries. The Madison officer attempted to stop the 16-year old. This led to a pursuit -- eastbound-- down the West Beltline Highway. Speeds reached an estimated 80 m.p.h. The suspect pulled off at Park Street and ended up striking a Madison Police squad car near the intersection of Beld and Cedar Streets. A police officer was inside the damaged squad, and that officer suffered a hand injury. The 16-year-old did not drive off after the crash and was arrested. Her passenger, Mr. Nelson Jefferson, did run but was chased down and arrested by responding officers.

properties.Suspect: Paul Williams Jr., age 21, MadisonMr. Williams was arrested and tentatively charged with Eluding an Officer, Resisting/Obstructing an Officer, Possession of a Firearm by a Felon, Probation Hold, Failure to Leave Name at an Accident, Operating after Suspension, and Improper Left Turn.
properties.Details: Early Saturday morning a Madison police sergeant attempted to make a traffic stop on East Washington Avenue. Instead of pulling over the driver of a '94 Buick Park Avenue decided to try to get away. The officer pursued the Park Avenue southbound on Thierer Road to Lien Road and back to East Washington Avenue. Speeds of up to 50 or 60 miles per hour were reached. The suspect turned onto Mendota Street, then Hoover Street. Where Hoover Street becomes Ellenwood the suspect lost control while trying to take a turn at 40 to 50 miles per hour. He sideswiped a parked car before coming to stop on somebody's front lawn. The driver and a passenger then took off on foot. A loaded handgun was found inside the Park Avenue. The officer was able to determine the car's owner. It turned out he had loaned the car to Mr. Paul Williams.  With the help of Fitchburg police, the sergeant who had chased Mr. Williams the morning prior was able to take him into custody at a Fitchburg residence early Sunday morning. Mr. Williams’ accomplice is still at large.

The South Community Policing Team ran a speed wave in the 1700 blk of Fish Hatchery Rd in front of Wright Middle School.Thirty citations were issued with from 3p- 5:30p. The top speed recorded was 55 miles per hour in a 30 mile per hour zone. As the school year approaches the South Community Policing team wants to remind you to obey traffic laws in school zones.

properties.Details: During the last two weeks the Madison Police Department has been investigating commercial burglaries on the far east side of Madison.  It appears that the suspect(s) is hiding in the store until closing and after the employees close up, they target the safe and cut security alarms.  Citizens should be mindful of activity around stores after closing and report suspicious activity to the police.  Additionally, store employees should perform a thorough check of their building prior to closing.

Upon officers arriving on scene they observed a car leaving the immediate area. A traffic stop of the vehicle led to the arrest of (5) juvenile suspects. Officers recovered cash, checks and Viagra from the suspects. Examination of the scene resulted in finding considerable damage to fixtures and other items as well.

properties.Arrested: Dallace Beasley, 40, Madison, Wanted for:  4 counts of burglary (south side), Carrying a Concealed Weapon, Resist/Obstructing
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is actively looking for Dallace Beasley for his role in the aforementioned crimes.  Beasley is wanted in connection to four burglaries on Madison's south side.  In addition, Beasley is a person of interest in approximately 30 north side commercial burglaries, including 3-5 church burglaries in the Sherman Ave corridor. If anyone has information concerning Beasley's whereabouts, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Victim: Oak Park Place Senior Community & Assisted Living Center
properties.Details: At approx. 5:09 a.m. Madison Police and Fire units responded to 718 Jupiter Dr.  Officers investigated and determined that the two suspects above had entered the facility in an apparent attempt to burglarize a basement office/break area.  This did not involve the residential part of the facility.  In the process of doing this, the suspects apparently picked up some fire extinguishers and discharged them, causing fire alarms to go off, thus the response from the Madison Fire Dept.  Both subjects were seen fleeing the area on foot.  At this time they have not been located.  Officers at the scene reported that several residents of the facility were awakened and upset by the incident.  Anyone with information is urged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Possibly 2 white males with a driver of a dark SUV possibly being white as well.  The SUV has a spare tire on the back with a cover.
properties.Details: On 7/13/06 at approximately 11:54 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to a burglary at a convenience store on Eastpark Blvd.  Officers observed the front window of the establishment to be shattered out.  They also observed that the ATM cash machine was removed from the store.  Through the course of their investigation it was learned that the suspects had unbolted the machine from the floor and used a dolly to haul it away in an SUV in a very short amount of time.  This remains an open investigation by the Madison Police Department and anyone with further information is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Since early August the Madison Police Department has been investigating two burglaries at Abundant Life Church and School off of Buckeye Rd.  It is believed that a person or persons entered the facilities and stole large amounts of musical equipment, valuing over $10,000.00.  The two separate burglaries were performed late at night or in the very early hours.  This remains an open investigation and police caution other churches in the area to evaluate their security plans/systems.  Anyone with further information is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Justin Moore, 18, Madison: Burglary and a warrant for burglary. Arlena Lee, 17, Madison:  Burglary, Carrying a Concealed Weapon and a warrant for burglary
properties.Details: On 8/30/06 at approximately 1:37 a.m. several Madison Police Officers were dispatched to a burglary in progress at Hamilton School.  Officers learned that multiple alarms were set off as movement was detected inside.  An officer noticed a window had been smashed and it appeared someone had gone inside.  Other responding officers noticed Moore and Lee walking.  They stopped the individuals due to the circumstances (late at night, near a burglary call, no one else nearby, in close proximity to the school) and eventually learned they had been inside the school.  Both were arrested without further incident and transported to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Male, Black, early 20's, 5'8-10, medium build, black stocking hat, black jeans.
properties.Details: On 3/19/07 at 9:19 a.m. Madison Police responded to a report of a burglary/robbery at a business in the 200 block of Junction Rd.  Officers learned that as an employee was opening for daily business she was attacked by a suspect who demanded money.  The suspect bound the woman to a chair and prevented her from leaving.  The actual time of the incident was around 8:30 a.m.  After the suspect fled with an undisclosed amount of money, the victim worked for 45 minutes to free herself and call 9-1-1.  This is an open investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with information about this crime is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Address: 201 S. Gammon Road - Madison Memorial High School

properties.Arrested: 1. Paul B. Harvey, 17 yoa male of Cottage Grove, WI  Charges: Burglary/Operating Motor Vehicle w/o Consent2. Joshua T. Kingston, 28 yoa male of Cottage, WI  Charges: Burglary3. Allison M. Chapman, 28 yoa female of Marshall, WI  Charges: Burglary
properties.Victim: 1. Copart Inc.  2. Valvoline Instant Oil Change (Case # 07-17411)3. A To Z Auto Dismantling & Sales  (Case # 07-14633)
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department, collaborating with other neighboring police agencies (Dane County Sheriff's Office, Monona Police Department, and Cottage Grove Police Department), arrested the above listed individuals for their involvement in a number of burglary cases throughout Dane County.  It seems that many of these cases involved non-residential burglaries of three area businesses (Copart Inc, Valvoline Instant Oil Change, & A To Z Auto Dismantling & Sales) dating back to early February 2007.  The numerous cases that are currently being investigated by Detectives throughout Dane County involved damages to multiple vehicles/buildings thought to be in excess of $24,500.00.  Although charges have been filed against the 3 individuals listed above, there is a continuing investigative effort within several Dane County Police agencies, and additional suspects/charges may be forthcoming; pending Dane County District Attorney review of these matters.On February 21st of  2007, Madison Police Officer Steven Magyera was conducting surveillance based on information that had been developed in this case, and his keen observation of a suspicious vehicle (later determined to be reported stolen) led to the arrests being made.  There have been many Officers/Detectives from many Departments that have played significant roles in this cumbersome investigation, and the communication between the agencies has been the most important factor impacting law enforcement being able to keep all communities safe.  As always, if anyone has any additional information about this matter, they are asked to call any of the respective agencies above or contact the Madison Police Department Crime Stoppers at (608) 266-6014.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: WIlliam Strassburger, 36:  Tresspass to Land, Non-support Warrants
properties.Details: On 4/13/07 at 12:05 a.m. a Madison Police Officer and K-9 unit were working on John Nolen Dr reference another case regarding a towed vehicle.  The officer observed a suspicious vehicle, driving slowly on Lakeside and eventually Sayle St.  This area was not populated at this time of night on this date.  The officer noticed a subject exit a vehicle near the City Garage on Sayle St, noting this to be unusual at this time of night.  The officer believed a burglary may be in progress and called for additional officers.  The City Garage is surrounded by fencing and has buildings on the land.  The officer and police K-9 entered the fenced area and gave several verbal commands that a search would be underway with a dog.  Eventually the suspect, Strassburger, was located outside, hiding behind some equipment.  Strassburger did not have permission to be inside this compound.  The K-9, Greg, bit Strassburger upon finding him.  Strassburger was arrested and taken to a local hospital as per routine after a bite.  No major injuries resulted in this incident.

properties.Arrested: Anthony Garske, 23, Montello:  Non-residential Burglary, Possession of burglarious tools, Probation Violation
properties.Details: On 4/23/07 at approximately 5:41 a.m. an employee starting work noticed a suspicious person inside the workplace.  The employee is generally the first to arrive and noticed the suspicious person rummaging through an office.  The employee left and called police.  Officers gathered information from the employee, as it was believed the burglary was still in progress.  Garske, who fit the description, was captured about 10 minutes later.

On 5/16/07 at 7 a.m. school staff reported to Madison Police that 10 computers and various equipment was stolen from their school.  It was learned that forced entry was used to gain access to the school and steal the computers, that were privately donated.  The burglary happened between 3/15/07 at 3:15 p.m. and 3/16/07 7:00 a.m.  If anyone has information about this crime they should call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers may be eligible for a cash reward and may remain anonymous.

properties.Arrested: 15 Year Old, Male, Madison15 Year Old, Male, MadisonBoth taken to the Juvenile Reception Center (JRC) for Burglary & Criminal Damage to Property. One teen was also charged with possession of burglary tools.
properties.Details: On June 18, just after 9:00 in the evening Madison Police responded to an alarm coming from inside Lakeview Elementary School. The initial officer at the scene looked in through a window to see 2 young men running in a hallway inside of the school. The suspects then ran out of the building and were taken into custody. Police discovered 4 heavy interior wood classroom doors, valued at $400 each, and an outside window, valued at $200, had been kicked-in, broken, or otherwise damaged. In addition, papers, that had been on several teachers' desks, were rifled through and strewn about.

properties.Arrested: Tony J. Popp, 43 years old
properties.Details: Keyholder responded to Sears for an alarm and observed a suspect inside the store.  The keyholder immediately notified police, who ultimately located the above individual inside and took him into custody.

properties.Arrested: Juvenile
properties.Details: Private security responded to an alarm at Engelhart Center and discovered signs of a burglary.  Police were called to the scene.  Suspects were seen pushing a dirt bike in the area.  When confronted suspects fled on foot, one was taken into custody.  Investigation ongoing.

properties.Arrested: Orlando J. Chaumley 09/06/69, ViroquaTentative Charges: Burglary, Attempted Battery to Police Officer, Possession of Marijuana
properties.Address: 2342 S. Park Street (Park Street Mobil Mart)
properties.Details: UPDATE: This burglary took place just about a block from the South Police District. The call came in to dispatch about 12:09. Three officers were dispatched to the scene around 12:10. They arrived at the Mobil station at 12:12.  The suspect was heard yelling something to the effect of "Oh ----". He was detained at 12:14, and arrested at 12:15.Back in the day, all officers were based out of the downtown area.One of the reasons Madison moved to decentralized policing was to improve response time.This case illustrates the value of having a number of police districts.--------------------------------------------------A passerby observed a male kicking in the door to the Mobil Mart and contacted police.  As officers arrived, they observed the suspect exiting the store carrying a box.  When the suspect saw the officers, he dropped the box and a short foot pursuit ensued.  Officers were able to take the suspect into custody after a brief struggle.  Money bags (containing an undetermined amount of cash) and a box containing several cartons of cigarettes were recovered.

properties.Details: Early Thursday morning (2:50 a.m.) several Madison Police officers responded to a clothing store on Atwood Avenue after a citizen reported seeing four suspects trying to break in through a boarded-up window. The window was boarded-up due to an earlier break-in where glass was shattered. Suspect #1 was found with a crowbar in his hand. The other suspects were discovered hiding between dumpsters near the clothing store.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 8/20/07 Madison Police took a burglary report from a business on Femrite Dr.  It was learned that during the previous night unknown suspects broke into the fenced in yard and stole aluminum.  Stolen were:  $500 engine blocks, $2,000 aluminum car rims and $1500 aluminum car radiators.  It appears the suspect(s) cut a line in the fencing to gain access.

On 8/21/07 Madison Police took a report of a non-residential burglary at the Dane County Humane Society.  It was learned that donation money and money from the cash register were stolen.  In addition, $2,000 worth of damage was reported from the forced entry into the building.  If anyone has information to this crime, they are encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Suspect: Basil D. Greene, Age 17, MadisonArrested for Party to the Crime of Burglary
properties.Details: On October 6th at 1:48 a.m. an alert citizen in an apartment near the Zippy Lube on N. Sherman called 911 after witnessing two suspects burglarizing the business. Thanks to the resident's call, which provided suspect descriptions and their direction of travel, Madison police were able to spot the duo on Winchester Street, which is just off of N. Sherman. One suspect (described as a black male, late teens, 5'10", 160 lbs., wearing dark top and bottoms) took off running and was not caught. Mr. Greene (the suspect listed above) also ran a few steps but was stopped by the officer. He claimed to not know the name of his associate. The suspects made entry into the business by smashing a window. Drawers to a desk inside the Zippy Lube had been opened but it did not appear anything was taken. Madison police would like to commend the citizen witness who alerted officers to this crime.

properties.Suspect: Joab Ali Trevino, Age 17, MadisonRoberto Martinez-Barrera, Age 17, MadisonBoth are being held in the Public Safety Building on tentative charges of burglary.
properties.Details: Two suspects (listed above) have been arrested and charged with multiple counts of burglary by the Fitchburg Police Department. The Madison Police Department will also be referring multiple charges of burglary against these two individuals. They are believed to be responsible for several of the recent burglaries committed to businesses on the west side. The Madison Police Department is continuing to investigate reported burglaries in the area, and more charges/arrests are possible. Anyone with additional information can call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Callers can be eligible for a cash reward.

On Monday October 15th around 6:30 a.m. Madison police were called to the Bridges Golf Course after a maintenance worker discovered the clubhouse had been burglarized overnight. Investigators believe the culprit/culprits pried the cover off of a 2' X 2' vent to gain access into the building.  Among items stolen were two heavy safes. It's believed the criminal/criminals used the "pick" cart to getaway with the safes. The "pick" cart is what employees use to pick up balls from the driving range. The suspect/suspects likely loaded the safes on the "pick" cart and drove it across the golf course using a bike/ped path. It looks like they drove the "pick" cart over a bike/ped bridge to an area close to Melvin Court. It's assumed a get-away car was parked there. The "pick" cart was driven into some high weeds in the direction of a creek and abandoned.

properties.Suspect: Lamarcus Darnell Miller, Age 19, MadisonVan Starks, Age 21, MadisonMale black, Age 15, MadisonAll tentatively charged with Burglary, Criminal Damage to Property, & Resisting
properties.Details: On Tuesday night around 9:54 an alert citizen notified Madison police of a burglary in progress near the citizen’s residence. The citizen had heard the sound of shattering glass, and realized the target was a local real estate office owned by Restaino Bunbury. Several officers responded quickly to the scene, and established a perimeter. Suspects were spotted outside of the business. They tried to flee from police, but with the help of a Town of Madison officer and the officer's partner (a K-9) all were apprehended. A laptop computer belonging to an employee of Restaino Bunbury was found on the ground. Across Madison business owners have been enduring a spree of "smash & grab" type burglaries. Detectives will determine if the individuals arrested in this case might be linked with others.In the "press release" section of this website there is a recent posting of tips aimed at helping businesses owners better protect their property.

properties.Suspect: Fernando I. Llamas-Macias, Age 17, MadisonMr. Llamas-Macias was arrested & tentatively charged with Burglary.
properties.Details: On Saturday morning, around 5:47 a.m., Madison police were notified by Dane County dispatchers of a burglary in progress at the Liquor Baron, 2929 E. Washington Avenue. A witness said the suspect had smashed a window and was now outside of the liquor store. The caller indicated the suspect appeared to be carrying 12-packs of beer. He (the caller) also relayed to dispatch that the burglar had tripped and fallen twice, and that upon each trip to the pavement he (the suspect) dropped some of the stolen items. One responding officer found that a jar of nacho cheese dip had been used to break front door glass. The officer discovered broken bottles of beer and hard liquor both inside the store and outside in the parking lot. Additional officers responding to the scene were able to find the perpetrator. They report he was highly intoxicated and that his hooded sweatshirt appeared to be soaked in beer.

On December 10th around 9:25 a.m. Madison Police responded to The Junkyard Bar to take a burglary complaint. An outside entry door had been pried open, as had an ATM machine inside the tavern. Money was taken from the ATM.The Madison Police Department and the Dane County Sheriff's Department have both responded to similar attacks on ATM machines in the past couple of weeks.Three area taverns, including the Junkyard, were hit last weekend, as was an ATM machine at the Heartland Credit Union, 5325 High Crossing Blvd.In some cases the thief/thieves failed to successfully penetrate the ATM machines.Madison officers are being advised to familiarize themselves with locations of small taverns and to conduct extra patrols.

properties.Suspect: David W. Nieft, m/w, 2/2/64
properties.Details: School custodian responded LaFollette High School after receiving notification of an alarm sounding in the building. Upon arrival he contacted MPD and a perimeter was establised. At approximately 8:55 a.m Nieft was seen leaving the building between the Main Office and Activities Entrance. He was apprehended without incident.

properties.Suspect: Male, black, age 14, MadisonSuspect was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary.
properties.Details: In the early morning hours of January 11, 2008 Madison Police responded to an alarm coming from a Milwaukee Street service station. Upon arrival officers noted footprints in the fresh snow, and a back door that appeared to have been pried open. Officers found the footprints to be "very distinct" and they followed them three to four blocks to a residence on Powers Avenue. On the porch of said residence a couple of fairly good clues were discovered -- a pair of snow covered Reebok sneakers, and a long flat-head screwdriver. A Madison Police Investigator later determined the sneaker tread on the Reeboks and the fresh footprints in the snow were an exact match. Police knocked on the door of the home, and the teen's parents called the young man downstairs. He was arrested.

properties.Suspect: Van Starks Jr., age 21, no permanent addressMr. Starks was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, Operating a Motor Vehicle while Under the Influence (OMVWI), Speeding, & Operating after Revocation.Two (perhaps three) other perpetrators remain at large.
properties.Details: Around 3:47 in the morning on Saturday January 12th Madison Police quickly responded to a burglary alarm that was coming from a strip mall at the corner of South Whitney Way and Odana Road. Officers determined that two businesses -- Cosmo Pro Beauty & Factory Card Outlet -- were the latest targets in a recent rash of "smash and grab" burglaries (so named because perpetrators break out glass doors/windows with various objects and then get in and out of businesses in a matter of minutes -- often with stolen merchandise or money in hand). While processing the scene officers observed a '94 Cadillac speeding eastbound on Odana Road. Police followed the car at speeds of just over 40 M.P.H. while attempting to get its’ driver to pull over. Instead of complying the driver drove south on Whitney, then east on Gilbert Road. On Gilbert he pulled into an apartment complex parking lot where he ditched the car. He and at least two co-conspirators took off running. The first officer on scene gave chase. The foot pursuit was about a 100-yard dash, and in the end the officer won taking the driver of the get-away car into custody. Other officers, with the help of a K9's nose, tracked a possible second perpetrator for around an hour and 50 minutes. This took them to a residence on Russett Road. Inside this home a suspect was identified, but as of this writing he has not been arrested.  A look inside the Cady, and cursory search of the area near the chase scene, netted evidence from several recent area burglaries (above and beyond the two that were the basis of this call). The arrested suspect, Mr. Starks, told police he had used heroin prior before getting behind the wheel and that was the basis for the OMVWI count.

properties.Suspect: Tramaine Franklin, age 19, MadisonRaheem D. Blue, age 17, Madison
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department's Blue Net Burglary Task Force is seeking multiple burglary charges against the two suspects who are listed above. West District patrol officers apprehended Mr. Tramaine Franklin on February 9, 2008 after they responded to a burglary in progress at 7633 Ganser Way. Several businesses at this address had doors shattered and electronics stolen. A getaway car was found at the scene. Investigators would recover a variety of stolen electronics -- including laptop computers -- from inside the '98 Mercury Mystique. A subsequent investigation led to the arrest of Mr. Raheem Blue. The MPD is asking that both Mr. Franklin and Mr. Blue be charged with 13 counts of burglary stemming from the Ganser Way crime spree. They (Mr. Franklin & Mr. Blue) are also considered suspects in other break-ins. Detectives working recent burglaries advise that portable electronics – like laptops – are the targets of most break-ins. They advise citizens to record serial numbers on these items, and to store them in safe areas out of easy view.The Madison Police Department set up the Blue Net Task Force in direct response to the escalating number of commercial and residential burglaries in recent months.

properties.Suspect: Travis L. Bender, age 36, MadisonMr. Bender was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary and a Parole Hold.
properties.Details: On Saturday, May 17, 2008, around 8:15 p.m. a citizen called for Madison Police after being approached by someone trying to sell items the witness thought to have been stolen from a neighboring business. The MPD was on the scene in minutes and officers were able to locate the suspect as he was trying to walk away. He is believed to have taken tools, and other items- like a tank of Freon - from Abner Boiling and Heating. The stolen items were recovered near the business where the suspect had attempted to hock them.

properties.Suspect: Rodney Paul Wipperfurth, age 33, MadisonMr. Wipperfurth was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, Possession of THC, & Possession of Drug Paraphernalia.
properties.Details: Early Tuesday morning, around 1:47 a.m., Madison Police responded to Tony Frank's restaurant on Seminole Highway for a burglar alarm. One officer spotted a suspect walking away from the tavern and toward a parked car. The suspect was arrested. The burglar had gained entry by breaking a bathroom window. An electronic game had been broken into, and its’ bill and coin receptacle had been searched for money.

properties.Suspect: Dwayne L. Cooper, age 42, Sun PrairieMr. Cooper was arrested and tentatively charged with three counts of Burglary, and Possession of Burglarious Tools.
properties.Details: Very early Saturday morning - 3:32 a.m. - Madison Police drove quickly to the Applebee's on East Towne Boulevard for a burglary call. The restaurant's manager had - minutes earlier - responded to his place of business after getting a report that a burglar alarm had been activated. The manager spotted a possible suspect walking away. The man was stopped by police and was found to be in possession of items tying him not only to the Applebee's crime, but two other break-ins that had occurred earlier that morning- one at Menards East, 2102 East Springs Drive, the other at Shopko, 2201 Zeier Road.

properties.Suspect: Male, age 16, MadisonSuspect was arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary, Carrying a Concealed Weapon, Underage Person Possess/Consume Alcohol off Licensed Premises, Operating without a Valid Driver's License (2nd offense), & Intoxicants in Vehicle.
properties.Details: (UPDATED WEDNESDAY JULY 23, 2008)Early this morning (July 23, 2008) Madison Police arrested a 16-year-old suspect. He is believed to be one of two burglars involved in this smash-and-grab case. Members of the Blue Net Burglary Task Force became aware of the suspect's name following a citizen tip that came in last night.  The teen was arrested after a traffic stop. It was made at 2:08 a.m. near the intersection of Northport and Troy Drives.   In the trunk of the car he was driving were some of the computers and monitors stolen from Byte Sized Solutions.The investigation is continuing as detectives look to identify a second perpetrator, and recover more stolen items. They would ask anyone who has recently purchased computer equipment from a private party - particularly any teenagers - to contact Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014.(ORIGINAL RELEASE)On Sunday morning, around 7:33 a.m., Madison Police responded to a computer sales and service store on Cottage Grove Road to take a report on a burglary that happened a couple of hours prior. Officers discovered a large rock had been tossed through a double-paned glass door. Computer equipment valued at $30,000 - belonging to both the business' owner and customers - was stolen. It appears the motion sensor on a burglar alarm did not function. If it had it is possible the thieves would have been scared off, as police would have been notified. Anyone with information on this crime is urged to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and maybe eligible for up to a $1,000 reward.

properties.Suspect: Theron Devon Porter, Jr., age 18, MadisonMr. Porter was arrested and tentatively charged with Party to a Crime of Attempted Burglary.
properties.Details: Early Tuesday morning, at 2:17 a.m., several Madison Police officers responded to a report of a burglary in progress at Flow Clothing, 826 E. Johnson Street. A concerned citizen had witnessed three men attempting to break into the back of the business. He described them as having bandanas over their faces and wearing dark clothing. The witness yelled at the criminals, and they took off running. Responding officers located and arrested one of the perpetrators.

On September 18, 2008, at approximately 2:22 a.m., several Madison Police officers - and a police dog - responded to Bruegger's Bagels on Mineral Point Road for a burglary alarm. The officers determined crooks had pried open windows to the bagel shop and a couple of adjoining businesses - including Stitchers Crossing and Bella. The criminals stole computer equipment and some cash. Commercial and residential burglaries, thefts from vehicles, and metal thefts continue to be a problem in Madison, and other areas of Dane County.  The Blue Net Burglary Task Force was organized this past year in direct response to the crime trend, and a coordinated effort by Dane County law enforcement agencies to thwart these types of crimes is ongoing.

properties.Suspect: Dejuante D. Champagne, age 17, MadisonMr. Champagne was arrested and tentativey charged with Attempted Burglary.
properties.Details: Very early Sunday morning, around 2:38 a.m., a concerned citizen contacted Madison Police after spotting two men trying to break-in to David's Jamaican Cuisine, 1616 Beld Street. Officers responded and arrested one suspect. They later discovered that a window air-conditioner had been tampered with, and it appeared that someone was going to try to make entry into the business.

properties.Suspect: Charles Theodore Lindsey, age 41, no permanent addressBill Martin, age 47, no permanent addressMr. Lindsey and Mr. Martin were arrested and tentatively charged with Burglary.
properties.Details: Friday morning, around 8:35 a.m., Madison Police were called to a burglary in progress. The owner of Frieda's Restaurant, 117 State Street, was opening his business when he spotted two men trying to exit another door. They were carrying bags containing several bottles of  his high priced liquor. On the bar of the restaurant was a bottle of Herradura tequila. It was 3/4 empty. The restaurant's proprietor said this bottle was full prior to the burglary, and he valued its contents at 600. The suspects, both of whom appeared intoxicated, were arrested.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is continuing to investigate the motorcycle crash that killed Alexander Fortney.  Indications from the scene of the crash show that speed, weather conditions and traffic movement appear to be factors.

properties.Arrested: CORNELL CLARKDOB: 2-12-71WANTED ON SEVEN WARRANTS INCLUDING ESCAPE.CHARGES: ATTEMPTING TO ELUDE POLICE AND OTHER TRAFFIC CHARGES.
properties.Details: OFFICERS OBSERVED CLARK ON THE BELTLINE AND ATTEMPTED TO STOP HIM AND TAKE HIM INTO CUSTODY. CLARK REFUSED TO STOP AND SPED UP TO SPEEDS OF 90MPH. ATTEMPTING TO ELUDE. OFFICERS WERE AWARE OF CLARK BEING WANTED ON SEVERAL WARRANTS, HE IS USUAL ARMED WITH FIREARMS , AND HAS BEEN INVOLVED IN ONGOING CRIMINAL ACTIVITY. CLARK HAS A EXTENSIVE CRIMINAL HISTORY.  THE PURSUIT TRAVELED WEST ON THE BELTLINE TO MIDDLETON WHERE CLARK TURNED AROUND HEADING EASTBOUND ON THE BELTLINE. ROAD SPIKES WERE ATEMPTED ON 3 OCCASIONS. HIS TIRES WERE PENETRATED BY SPIKES AT FISH HATCHERY AND THE BELT. AND HIS CAR WAS STOPPED AT MONONA DRIVE AND THE BELT. NO INJURIES OR ACCIDENTS OCCURED DURING THE PURSUIT. MPD WAS ASSISTED BY DANE CO SHERIFF, WISCONSIN STATE PATROL, MONONA, AND MIDDLETON POLICE.

properties.Arrested: Jason Smith, 30.  Attempting to elude an officer, Resist/Obstructing an Officer, Possession with intent to deliver THC, Possession with intent to deliver Cocaine, Operating After Revocation, Speeding, Arterial Stop Violation
properties.Details: On 10/20/05 at approximately 10:02 a.m. a member of the Madison Police Department's Traffic Enforcement Safety Team (TEST) was conducting speed enforcement on S. Stoughton Rd when the officer observed a vehicle traveling over 70 m.p.h. in a 55 m.p.h. zone.  In attempting to stop the vehicle, the offending vehicle (driven by Smith) continued to travel southbound, turning west onto Buckeye Rd and eventually north on Camden Rd.  Eventually the vehicle stopped and Smith fled on foot.  The officer chased after Smith through the neighborhood.  The suspect escaped from the officer's grasp and at one point OC was sprayed at the suspect who continued to flee before giving up.  Smith was arrested without further incident.  A search of Smith and his vehicle yielded the following items:  21.4 grams of marijuana, 70 empty sandwich bags, 6.3 grams of cocaine, over $1,000 in cash and a digital scale.

properties.Arrested: 16 yr old Juvenile
properties.Details: Officers responding to the report of a domestic observed a vehicle leaving the area acting suspiciously and attempted to stop to determine if it was involved.The vehicle fled and officers pursued.  The suspect leapt from the still moving vehicle and ran.  The vehicle continued traveling and struck a tree with minor damage.The suspect was later arrested in a near by apartment. It was later determined the suspect was not involved with the domestic.

properties.Arrested: 19 traffic stops, 18 citations issued: speed, following to close, inappropriate lane changes
properties.Details: On 6/15/06 from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m. the Madison Police Department used six officers to work a traffic initiative on the Beltline from Stoughton Rd to Old Sauk Rd.  One officer was designated the "Shadow Car" in which an unmarked vehicle is used to patrol the Beltline.  The officer driving the "Shadow Car" then radios to other officers in squad cars any inappropriate driving behaviors.  Nineteen traffic stops were initiated during this course of enforcement.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Address: Eastbound Beltline Hwy between Fish Hatchery and Park St
properties.Details: At approximately 11:43 am this morning, a truck that was eastbound on the Beltline between Fish Hatchery and Park St dropped a load of corn on the roadway.  Madison Police and the Dane County Sheriff's Dept are on the scene.  The eastbound Beltline is completely closed at this time as a result of this incident.  Please find alternative routes.An additional traffic related issue:Traffic lights on E Washington Ave are out from Ingersol to the east side of the City.  We also have reports of wires down and manhole covers off around the City.  All this is the result of a storm going through the area.  Please excercise caution when going through the area.  Note there are likely traffic signals around the entire area.

properties.Arrested: Joshua Kay, 28, Madison:  Impersonating a Peace Officer
properties.Victim: Male, 29, off-duty police officer outside of Madison
properties.Details: On 1/19/07 at 2:43 a.m. a Madison Police Officer responded to a traffic incident on the eastbound Beltline near Todd Drive.  The complainant, an off-duty police officer from another jurisdiction, told the MPD officer that an older model Honda Civic activated red lights and a siren, while on the Beltline, and motioned for the off-duty officer to pull over.  The off-duty officer, sensing this was not an official police car refused to pull over and called the 9-1-1 Center to verify if an officer was attempting a traffic stop at this location.  Eventually the suspect, later id'd as Kay, sped past the off-duty officer who took down the license plate number. Madison Officers traced the license plate number back to Kay and made contact with Kay at his residence.  Kay, a security guard, was arrested on the above charge and was transported to the Dane County Jail without incident.

properties.Arrested: Nigel Goodwan, male, 29, Madison:  Eluding, Possession of THC, Obstructing, Failure to Notify Owner of Property Damage, Warrants
properties.Details: On 1/30/07 at approximately 8:57 p.m. a Madison Police Officer was on routine patrol traveling west on Aberg Ave, near the ramp for Packers Ave.  The officer heard in the distance squealing tires.  The officer slowed for observance and was approached by a vehicle, later to learn that Goodwan was the driver.  Goodwan indicated he had almost been in a crash due to another vehicle that he pointed out to the officer.  The officer pulled over the other suspect vehicle.  Goodwan followed the officer and was ordered to stay in his vehicle while the officer conducted an investigation.  When asked for id, Goodwan stated he did not have any with him and gave a fake name, arousing suspicion.  Goodwan was told to stay at the scene of the traffic stop of the other vehicle.  Goodwan left the scene and the officer gave chase.  With lights and siren activated, the officer chased Goodwan down Packers to Schlimgen to Loftsgordon.  In the 1800 block of Loftsgordon, Goodwan crashed his vehicle into a tree and then quickly fled on foot.  Another responding officer learned the direction of travel and description of Goodwan and caught him in a residential area. A K-9 was called to the scene to evaluate Goodwan's vehicle, in which marijuana was located.  Goodwan complained of minor injuries.  Fire/Rescue transported Goodwan to a local hospital where he was treated and released to officers waiting to take him to jail.

Madison Marathon Update:Due to the race, travel on South Park Street (between West Washington and Fish Hatchery) is significantly delayed. Please use alternate routes (University Ave. and John Nolan Dr.) to access the downtown area.

OPERATION DUCK"On Tuesday afternoon July 24th members of the Madison Police Department's Traffic Enforcement Safety Team (TEST) implemented "Operation Duck" along Midvale Blvd., across from Hilldale Mall. An undercover officer was used to educate motorists about pedestrian safety. The officer would step out and walk a crosswalk as vehicles approached. Vehicles that did not stop and yield to the pedestrian "duck" were contacted by "chase" officers. These officers were both on motorcycles and in squad cars. A half-dozen offenders were issued $140.50 citations. Failure to "yield the right of way" to a pedestrian is also a four point driving infraction.The following is what TEST officers developed as background for the "Duck" program:Problem: Pedestrians say they are afraid to start crossing the street because either the cars won’t stop or if one car stops- they get stuck in the middle of the road because other motor vehicle operators won’t stop. Pedestrians state they cross mid-block because there are gaps in traffic and they can get across easier than at the crosswalk. Motorists are confused and say they do not stop because they fear they might get rear ended, the car behind them might go around them and hit the pedestrian, or the pedestrian won’t cross when they do stop for them.  Many of the areas from which we receive these complaints do not have the pedestrian traffic volume to make enforcement productive.  Operation Duck is meant to increase that productivity in a manner that is fair to motorists by focusing only on overly aggressive driving behaviors.Goal:  Education, clarification and enforcement of pedestrian safety and pedestrian and motor vehicle laws pertaining to “yielding the right of way”.

properties.Details: On February 14th at around 12:11 a.m. Madison Police attempted to stop the driver of a speeding car on the West Beltline. During the chase a plastic bag --with something white inside -- was thrown from the car being pursued. The bag hit the windshield of a Madison Police squad, and was later recovered. The car in question was westbound and its speed reached approximately 110 miles per hour. Officers --who already had the plate number of the '92 Olds Regency -- determined it was not safe to continue the pursuit and it was terminated. At 12:52 a.m. a Dane County Sheriff's Deputy spotted the ’92 Olds in a ditch along Highway 12 near County Highway K. A Mt. Horeb police officer arrived with a tracking dog, and the suspects were taken into custody shortly after 2:00 a.m. Both were extremely cold.

The Wisconsin State Patrol will be diverting eastbound I-90/94 traffic at Mauston to U.S. Highway 12, and sending the potential for high volume traffic down 12 through Madison via the West Beltline Highway. Commuters are asked to avoid, if possible, the eastbound beltline highway until the situation changes.For more information please contact the Wisconsin State Patrol.

properties.Details: On Thursday evening the Madison Police Department utilized undercover officers -- posing as prostitutes -- to arrest ten males in the Badger Road corridor. The MPD has been working with other city and private agencies/groups (i.e. Public Health Department, Joining Forces for Families (JFF) etc.) to combat the area's prostitution issues. Beyond enforcement this Coordinated Community Response (CCR) to prostitution utilizes a couple of programs to help those involved. A Women's Workshop is held Saturday evenings at the JFF office (2501 Fish Hatchery Road). It is at these gatherings that women can access resources like HIV testing, counseling, as well as securing shelter. The other prong of the proactive approach is the J.O.H.N. course. The Joining and Organizing Healthy Neighborhoods program is for males arrested -- like those from this latest sting -- for soliciting prostitutes.  It is voluntary. If those enrolled complete the course, and have no negative contacts with police for one year, then the $676.00 citation is nullified.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 11/24/05 Madison Police investigated what originally was believed to be an elder abuse investigation.  A 90 year-old female was transported to a local hospital via a private ambulance service, to which she later died due to complications of her health.  Through a lengthy investigation it was learned that the mother had become gravely ill in the midst of her two daughters, ages 53 and 54, who have features of being developmentally disabled.  When officers checked the welfare of the two female daughters, residing on the eastside, they were surprised as to the living conditions that the mother and daughters lived in.  There was exposed wiring, a non-operable refrigerator, broken hot water heater, fecal matter on the floor, floorboards exposed and a house that was layered in dirt.  The television had not worked in decades and there was no radio in the home.  It was learned that one of the female daughters, age 54, had not been outside of the house in an estimated 15-20 years.  She looked forward to a simple wave to the postman everyday as he had the same route for eight years.  Neighbors did not know she existed.  The 53 year-old daughter occasionally went outside to the backyard or periodically shoveled, but quickly ran inside if ever approached by someone else.  It is believed she had not left her home/yard since 1983.  Previously she had resided outside the home, but returned to care for her father, who died in 1985.  Both daughters stated they had never been to the doctor.  The 53 year-old daughter did go to Madison East High School, which would have been her last public contact/record.  The family was able to pay for bills, including groceries and milk that were delivered to the house by Sentry and Golden Gernsey, from the social security payments that were directly deposited into an account.  Officers were careful in approaching the daughters as to not upset them.  It was clear from their very white skin that they had not left their home.  It was also clear that they were unable to care for themselves alone.  Officers worked very closely with social workers to ensure their futures would be safe.  Currently the daughters are in “foster care for adults” and are over stimulated by society’s trends.  They were cautioned not to take them to a grocery store, yet go to a convenience store first to show the wide range of products.  The daughters did not know that they could summon help by dialing 911.  While trying to find placement for the sisters, officers informed them of the use of 911 and then informed dispatch that any calls from this address should trigger an immediate police response.  Before mom fell ill, she had tasks for the daughters to do.  The house became a large storage bin as items and food cans were stored in various areas.  Because the refrigerator was inoperable they stored chicken in the coldest part of the house, a back room, and then rotated other items needing to be kept cool.  Over the years the family paid a neighbor to mow the grass and shovel snow.  This neighbor never called police or social service for a simple “check welfare” call.  A lesson to take from this case is the very basic nature of a “check welfare” call that police routinely perform on a daily basis.  If someone suspects something out of the ordinary or are concerned for someone’s safety, police are more than willing to verify their welfare.  It is our job.  The persistence and heartfelt concern of the officers, supervisor and social worker helped bring much needed aid and attention to these sisters who would not have known what to do.  They had called the private ambulance because they looked “ambulance” up in the phonebook, not knowing of 911.  The 54 year-old female had never been in a car before and was actually excited to ride in one, a police car, to a group home.  Efforts will be made to keep the sisters together after they go through medical evaluations and mental health diagnosis.  Overall the sisters are reported to be in good spirits adapting to the outside world one step at a time.  This case illustrates three points.  If one wants to separate from the outside world, even in a city, it is possible.  Secondly, know your neighbors throughout the years you live next door.  Be aware of those nearby and question either to yourself or others if you haven’t seen someone in weeks, months or even years.  Finally, police are more than willing to check on someone’s welfare if you have suspicions.  While driving past the Holiday light exhibit at Olin Park, the sisters were mesmerized.

In the last week, there have been three arrests, from the Allied Drive neighborhood, where a gun was collected from the person being arrested.  Seized so far have been:  a loaded Glock .40, a .22 caliber Intratec (Tec-Nine look-a-like) and a black handgun.

Shortly before 4:30am on 7/14/06, officers responded to the 2300 block of Allied Drive for several reports of shots being fired.  Witnesses reported hearing 3 to 5 shots; no victim or damage located.

On Saturday evening Madison Police were dispatched to Warner Beach for a report of a recovered handgun. Officers learned that an 11 year old boy, who had been swimming with family and friends, found the weapon 50 to 70 yards from the shoreline. The boy stepped on something while swimming, reached down, and covered in seaweed and sentiment was the long barreled handgun. It appears the weapon had been submerged for sometime. Investigators will now try to determine whether it had been used in a crime

properties.Arrested: Male, Age 16, MadisonTaken to the Juvenile Reception Center (JRC) for Battery While Armed
properties.Details: On June 18, at 5:32 Madison Police were called to Trafalger Place reference a child who had been shot with an air-soft gun. Upon arrival they met a 9 year old boy. He told them he had been playing basketball with a friend when he was suddenly struck in the face and leg. He told officers it really hurt and he began to cry. A neighbor admitted he had been shooting plastic pellets from an air-soft gun, but claimed he did not mean to hit anyone. The pellets left red welts on the victim.Air-soft guns often resemble real weapons and police have cautioned parents about their children possessing them. It is difficult for officers to quickly determine real weapons from fakes, or toys, when responding to calls.

Shortly after 6:00 p.m. on Sunday July 15th Madison Police responded to the 5000 block of Camden Road for a report of a man with a gun. After officers arrived shots were fired. The subject of the man with a gun call was shot. He was taken by helicopter to UW Hospital's trauma center where he was pronounced dead. No officers, or other citizens were injured in the incident. The use of deadly force will be reviewed and investigated by the Madison Police Department, the Dane County District Attorney, and the Dane County Coroner John Stanley. Stanley indicated he is still trying to reach family of the deceased and is withholding the man's name. Names of officers involved in the Camden Road call are also being withheld at this time. An autopsy is scheduled for tomorrow (Monday July 16th.)

properties.Suspect: Male, black, age 11The student was cited for Disorderly Conduct.
properties.Details: On Monday January 14th at 11:13 a.m. Madison Police were dispatched to Sherman Middle School after an 11-year-old student discharged a cap gun inside the boy's locker room. As many as 50 students were coming or going to gym class at the time of the incident and many mistook the cap gun fire for real gunfire. This resulted in some initial panic. The cap gun is made of lime green plastic and evidently looks fake in good light. However many students only heard the rapports and did not see the actual gun. Officer's cited the student for disorderly conduct and left him in the custody of the school's principal.

properties.Suspect: Kevin Lockhart, age 18, MadisonMr. Lockhart is in custody on a Parole Hold.Andre Williams, age 19, MadisonMr. Williams is in custody and tentatively charged with Obstructing.
properties.Victim: Male, age 18, MadisonVictim suffered a non-life threatening bullet wound and was transported to a local hospital.
properties.Details: (UPDATED INFORMATION RELEASED FRIDAY MORNING FEB. 8)Police are questioning Mr. Kevin Lockhart, and Mr. Andre Williams about the shooting. Both have been arrested but neither, at this point, has been tentatively charged with pulling the trigger.  The teens were located inside apartment #6 at 902 West Badger Road. Seized from the apartment was a flat screen television set that had been stolen from a Madison bar, and a large quantity of suspected drugs. Also recovered during a search of the building was a handgun. It had been stolen from a Madison residence during a burglary. ----------------------------------------------------(ORIGINAL RELEASE FEB. 7)Around 10:18 a.m. an off-duty Madison Police Detective was driving near the intersection of Badger Road and Cypress Way when the detective witnesses a shooting. There were two groups of young men involved. One group was gathered on one side of Cypress Way -- the other group was across the street. A member of one group pulled out a gun and fired several rounds across the road. One bullet struck an 18-year-old man. He was taken to a local hospital with a non-life threatening wound. The off-duty detective saw the gunman enter an apartment building located at the corner of Cypress and Badger Road. A perimeter was set up around the building. The Madison Police Department’s Emergency Response Team (ERT) was called in. ERT members slowly and methodically cleared the building around 3:00 p.m. two persons of interest in the shooting incident were taken peacefully from an apartment. Following the shooting nearby Lincoln Elementary School was placed in "lockdown" which --for the students -- meant no outside recess. Other than that normal school activities took place during the ERT call up. Any potential threat to the community was diffused prior to the school day ending.

properties.Suspect: A man in his 50's was taken to a medical facility.
properties.Details: On Wednesday, March 5, 2008, around 9:50 p.m. Madison Police responded to a residence on Waubesa Street after neighbors reported hearing multiple gunshots. Responding officers set up a perimeter and were able to talk the suspect into coming outside. The man was armed with a handgun and -- upon an officer’s command – he dropped it into a snow bank. He allowed the MPD to search his residence and it was determined the suspect had fired several rounds into the ceiling and walls. One bullet appeared to have gone out of a window. Officers were not able to determine if that round had struck any nearby homes, but no injuries have been reported. The investigation revealed the suspect believed there had been intruders -- who turned out to be imaginary -- in his home. He was cooperative with officers and transported to a local medical facility.
