properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: At approximately 10:58 a.m., Madison Police responded to a call of two dogs fighting in the 900 block of E. Johnson St.  Upon arrival officers noted three dogs fighting at the intersection of Paterson and Johnson St. with passersby trying to separate them.  The dogs were finally separated.  OFficers learned that an adult female had left her 14-year-old Dalmation in a vehicle with the window rolled halfway down.  The vehicle was parked with the dog in it when a female walked by walking a 5-year-old female pit bull and a 3-year-old male pit bull.  The DAlmation managed to jump through the partially opened window and attacked the pit bulls.  THe pit bulls responded to this by attacking the Dalmation The 5-year-old female pit bull latched onto the Dalmation's neck and would not let go.  The Dalmation received a significant injury as a result of this but is expected to survive.  Approximately 8 citizens stopped to try and assist.  At least one of the individuals was bitten on the hand by one of the pit bulls.  City Animal Control officers are following up on the incident.

properties.Details: Madison Police responded to a report of a dog bite in the 2000 block of Leland Dr on 6-16-05 at 8:55pm.  Officers learned a 6-year old male had been outside his residence when he was bitten by a pit bull being walked by a 9-year old child.  Apparently, prior to being bitten, the child became fearful of the animal and started to run away from it.  The pit bull was leashed but pursued the child, dragging the 9-year old along.  The pit bull bit the child in his right side area.  He received a minor bite wound.  City animal control will follow up.  It appears vaccination records of the pit bull are up to date.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 8/11/06 at approximately 10:40 a.m. a Madison Police Department Detective was following up on some information that was part of another investigation on N. Oak St.  As the Detective was at the door to the residence, two pit bulls were let out and immediately charged and attacked the Detective.  The Detective, in defense, kneed one of the pit bulls several times.  One pit bull bit the Detective's ankle.  The Detective, while fighting both pit bulls tripped and fell down.  One pit bull continued the attack by biting the Detective in the neck and head area.  The person who had let the dogs out tried to get the dogs off and was eventually successful.  The Detective suffered minor injuries from the bite marks and drove to the hospital.  The Detective is a dog-lover and has had a dog for years.

properties.Arrested: Monkey, Black & White, Approximately 12" to 18" high with a long prehensile tail. Last seen wearing a white diaper & a leash with a chest harness
properties.Address: 603 State Street (State Street Brats) (UPDATED WED. AFTERNOON)
properties.Victim: Female, age 20, MadisonSustained 4 small punctures to thumb
properties.Details: Shortly before 2:00 p.m. (August 8) the monkey was taken into custody in the downtown area. Animal Control Officers have placed it in quarantine for 10 days. The monkey's owner is a Madison woman, and she tells police she loaned the monkey to a friend last night. She also tells the MPD that the monkey is her service monkey, much like a service dog. The owner was on scene in the Dayton Street area, with police and animal control staff, to help bring the monkey in this afternoon.-----------------------------------------------------------------------On August 8th, around 4:45 a.m., Madison Police were dispatched to a local hospital reference an animal bite. A young woman told officers that she had been in the State Street area earlier. While walking near the beer garden area of State Street Brats the victim observed a man, inside the beer garden, who had a monkey on a leash. She further noticed that the man was allowing people to pet his monkey. So, she reached over the beer garden fence to do likewise. However, before she could pet the monkey, the primate bit her thumb. Officers who had responded to the hospital recalled that they had seen a man with a monkey on State Street around 2:15 a.m.  The monkey had been jumping up and down as 3 to 4 women were, once again, petting the monkey. At that point MPD had received no complaints about the monkey and no police action was taken. A treating physician says in light of the biting incident the monkey needs to be found so that it can be quarantined for 10 days to determine if it has any disease. Madison Police did put out an ATL (attempt to locate) around 6:30 a.m., and by 7:15 a.m. the man and his monkey had been found in the State Street area. An Animal Control Officer was to follow-up, but unfortunately the man somehow lost the handle on his monkey and it is now on the lam, presumably still in the State Street area.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Madison Police responded to the 4700 block of Jenewein Road reference an active structure fire at an apartment building. Officers assisted the Madison Fire Department on scene.  No injuries were known of at the time of this release.

Friday, just after the noon hour, a Madison Police officer responded to a report of a structure fire. Neighbors voiced concern that a son of the property's owners maybe inside. Running to the rear of the home, the officer discovered flames in the soffit area of a porch light. Fire from the soffit area had dropped down and also ignited some grilling materials below. The officer used a garden hose to extinguish the flames. Neighbors continued to be concerned that a child maybe in danger inside the home. The officer knocked down the home's door, and remained low as he swept through the home looking for family members. He ended up pulling three pet cats out of the house. Neighbors agreed to watch them while the Madison Fire Department inspected for other hot spots. The property's owner arrived to confirm no children were home. He, the property owner, indicated a bird's nest had been built next to his porch light, and the light likely ignited dried building materials left behind by the former residents.

On Monday night Madison Police Officer Angie Dyhr was on routine patrol when she spotted smoke coming from a Langdon Street fraternity house. Officer Dyhr advised a dispatcher that Madison Fire should been sent to the location. She got out of her police car and saw flames engulfing the back of the residence. Officer Dyhr found the exterior door to the Sigma Phi Epsilon house locked, and started pounding on it until a resident answered. Dyhr saw there was smoke coming from the back of the house, and she began yelling for residents to get out. Officer Dyhr, with the help of fraternity members, was able to make sure all were evacuated. This took place in just a couple of crucial minutes prior to the arrival of Madison Fire. After the first evacuation, there was concern the fire could spread, and Officer Dyhr assisted in notifying and evacuating residents of neighboring buildings.  For her quick actions Officer Dyhr will be nominated for a Madison Police Department Life Saving Award.

properties.Victim: 90 year old male driver.  Not injured.
properties.Details: At approximately 9:15 a.m., Madison Police and Fire units responded to the 3800 block of Winnemac in reference to a motor vehicle striking a building.  Upon arrival, officers determined that a car had crashed into a two-car garage at 3818 Winnemac.  The driver was a 90-year-old male who lives at 3821 Meyer Avenue.  Officers learned that the driver was attempting to get his car out of his garage and got hung up on some garden equipment.  He had to pull forward to get off the equipment and at that point, the vehicle accelerated and crashed through the back wall of his garage and continued through two backyards until it crashed into the garage at 3818 Winnemac.  The back wall of the first garage was taken out, but it appears that the garage is stable.  The second garage that was struck has severe damage.

There is damage to the building and the vehicle.

19 year old male driver was attempting to make a left turn from McKenna Blvd. onto Pilgrim Rd.  He accellerated and went through the yard, and hit part of the garage and porch to the residence.  No damage to the living area of the home and no one inside the residence was injured.  Investigation determined that speed and alcohol were contributing factors to the crash.

On October 2nd around 9:45 a.m. Madison police were called to a home on Ellen Avenue where two brothers had apparently engaged in what could have been some serious shenanigans. The older brother, age 4, showed officers how he was able to climb up on a three-drawer storage cabinet to reach a shelf in his parents' bedroom. On that shelf were keys to his parents' SUV. It was parked in the driveway. Older bro than takes younger bro (age 2) outside for a bit of adventure (Mom thought they were just going into the playroom). The 4 year old then demonstrated for police how he was able to get into the SUV, put the keys in the ignition, start the vehicle, step on the brake, and pull the gearshift down into drive. When this happened, around 8:30 that morning, his mother heard a loud BANG. The SUV pushed the garage door forward, and then pushed a car that was parked in the garage into the house, causing significant damage to a wall. The mother, having heard the noise, hustled outside and was able to turn off the SUV and get the boys out safely. Madison police counseled the 4 year old about how he and his brother could have been seriously injured.

properties.Suspect: Arturo Pratti-Estrada, Age 50, MadisonMr. Pratti-Estrada was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating after Suspension, Reckless Driving/Endangering Safety, and Knowingly Operating without a valid Driver's License causing Damage to Property.
properties.Address: 817 N. Thompson Dr. (Prentice Park apartment complex)
properties.Details: On Sunday evening at 9:14 p.m. Madison police responded to the Prentice Park apartments, 817 N. Thompson Drive, for a report of a crash. A responding officer observed that a passenger car, a 1993 Saturn, was inside a living room of one of the apartments. The driver (the suspect listed above) explained that he lost control while driving southbound on Thompson. The apartment absorbing the direct hit had six people inside. Three were in bedrooms; three were in or near the living room, including a woman who was seated on a couch. Witnesses told police the impact sounded like a bomb had gone off. Madison Metro was notified to send a bus so those displaced would have a warm place to sit. The Red Cross was also notified. There were no injuries. Speed is believed to be a factor in the collision.

properties.Arrested: Crystal Figueroa, 30, Dane County Jail: Federal and County Warrants.
properties.Details: On 8/17/03 at approximately 7:24 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 400 block of Rushmore Lane for a report of a missing 8 year-old girl.  An extensive canvass was done of the area and nation-wide alerts were done in hopes of finding this missing juvenile.   The juvenile was not located at the time.  Continued investigation indicated that it was likely that the girl was with her mother, Crystal Figueroa, who had recently lost full custody of her daughter.  Figueroa took her daughter to Mexico.   On 2/7/07 Figueroa turned herself into the Dane County Jail, after having given her daughter to the girls grandmother. The grandmother was contacted by the Madison Police Department and arrangement made for the return of the girl to her father. The girl and her father have been reunited.  Both are living outside of Madison at this time.

Anyone with information is asked to call 911. For more details about the children, and the vehicle they may be traveling in, please go to the website amberalertwisconsin.org

properties.Details: On 7-20-2005 at 10:24pm, Madison Police received information that a stolen vehicle was being operated on John Nolen Dr. At 10:30pm, Madison Police located the vehicle in operation in the 2300 block of E. Washington Ave. The driver refused to heed officer signals to stop, and fled. Officers pursued as the suspect turned east on Milwaukee St., north on Fair Oaks Ave., west on Atwood Ave., south on Hudson Ave., and east on Oakridge Ave., before stopping in 2800 block of Oakridge Ave at 10:33pm. The driver and one of two passengers fled on foot. The passenger was apprehended shortly thereafter by officers in the area. The driver was subsequently taken into custody after a successful track by a Madison Police canine and handler. The remaining passenger was not charged and was released at the scene. Neither the pursuit nor the apprehension of the suspects resulted in injury or property damage. Speeds of the pursuit reached 65-70 mph.

properties.Arrested: Male, 15, Madison
properties.Address: Oakridge, Lakeland and Miller Rd area
properties.Details: On 7/20/05 at approximately 10:30 p.m. a Dane County Sheriff's Deputy advised Madison Police of a stolen vehicle the deputy was following.  As the deputy initiated a traffic stop, the occupants of the vehicle fled on foot.  One individual was apprehended, while another continued to flee on foot.  A Madison Police Sergeant and K-9 Arno were able to track the fleeing subject.  Over the course of 30 minutes, Arno picked up on the suspect's scent and tracked him through several yards and streets.  Eventually the suspect was caught hiding in some tall grass.  Clearly Arno's ability to track the scent lead officers to the suspect and the suspect was apprehended more rapidly.

properties.Arrested: Robert C. Seymour, 19, Madison: OMVWOC, Recklessly Endangering Safety (Party to a crime), Felon in possession of a firearm, Carrying a Concealed Weapon, Resist/obstruct an officer, Retail theft, Probation Hold, Extradition Warrant for Cook County, IL
properties.Details: On 10/16/2005 at approximately 5:23 p.m. a Madison Police Officer was dispatched to the area of Fish Hatchery and Catalpa for a report of a stolen auto in the area.  The officer cleared from the area as the vehicle was not located.  Shortly after, the officer responded to a convenient store on S. Park St. where a retail theft occurred in which the suspect vehicle matched the same stolen one previously aired.  After the retail theft report, the officer noticed the stolen vehicle operating while on routine patrol.  Eventually the vehicle stopped and the officer confronted the driver who was now out of the car.  The driver, Seymour, ran from the officer who was now chasing him.  A struggle ensued and Seymour fled from the officer again.  The officer continued chasing Seymour and deployed O.C. spray to halt his behavior.  Seymour was then taken into custody without further incident.  During this struggle there was an unfounded report of shots being fired in the South District, which delayed back-up response for the arresting officer.

properties.Arrested: Corey L. Reynolds, 28 year old male of Madison WisconsinChicago Police Case# HM230987
properties.Details: On March 14th, 2006 at approximately 12a.m, Madison Police were dispatched to the 1000 block of Moorland Road to take a report of a stolen vehicle.  The vehicle was described at a 1996 Mercury Sable with Wisconsin registration, and had been taken by a Corey L. Reynolds (28 year old male of Madison).   Reynolds allegedly borrowed the car from the son of the registered owner on March 8th, 2006 in the early morning hours.  Reynolds never returned the car but it was seen in the Madison area days following March 8th.  Reynolds communicated to the son of the registered owner that he expected payment of $800 for expenses related to bail Reynolds had to post on a recent drug arrest.  Reynolds had associated the son of the registered owner of the stolen vehicle to that of his being incarcerated, and refused to return the car unless he was paid $800.00 in a quasi extortion scheme.The Chicago Police Department (Area One Homidice/Gangs/Sex Crimes) reported the 1996 Mercury Sable had been stopped in their city approximately 1:29a.m.,  just minutes after it had been reported stolen here in Madison.  When stopped, Reynolds stated the vehicle belonged to him but could not verify ownership.  Reynolds also claimed ownership of a clear plastic baggie containing what was believed to be Cocaine Base located on the front seat of stolen vehicle; citing he had just purchased it minutes before!   Reynolds was arrested on charges stemming out of being in possession of a stolen vehicle and drug possession.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: Jesse J. Barrym/w, 34 years of ageMadison residentCharges: Disorderly Conduct While Armed         Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent         Carrying a Concealed Weapon         Second Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety
properties.Details: The suspect went for a test drive of a vehicle through Don Miller at 826 E. Washington Ave.  The suspect was accompanied by a sales person.  While driving on the Interstate (I90), the suspect pulled the vehicle over and told the sales person to get out.  The suspect threatened the sales person, suggesting that he had a knife.  However, a knife was not displayed.  The sales person then began to exit the vehicle and grabbed the keys to the car.  A struggle ensued.  The sales person ran away, with the suspect chasing him.  The sales person ran around/between Interstate traffic to get away from the suspect.  The suspect was ultimately taken into custody by the Dane County Sheriff's Department, without incident.  The suspect did have a knife on his person.  Neither the suspect or victim were injured.

properties.Details: On 07-10-2006 a vehicle was stolen from the Citgo gas station on South Park St. The owner left the vehicle running while entering the store. A two year old child was in a car seat inside the vehicle. A M/B in his early twenties got into the vehicle and drove away from the store with the child inside the vehicle. Suspect abandoned the vehicle in the 2000 block of Baird St. MPD officers located a possible suspect and a foot pursuit ensued. A MPD K-9 officer was deployed in the area. The child was not injured in the incident. Suspect is currently at large.

properties.Arrested: Female, black, 5'4, 130 lbs., white hooded sweatshirt
properties.Details: On 2/20/07 at 12:31 p.m. Madison Police responded to a report of a crash in the 5800 block of Balsam Rd.  Witnesses reported that the SUV had gone off the roadway, struck an apartment building and then went across the lawn and hit a light pole.  There was a small child in the window area where the SUV hit the apartment, but no one was injured.  After striking the light pole, the driver fled on foot from the heavily damaged SUV.  Officers learned the SUV was stolen a few days prior from a west side convenience store.

properties.Arrested: Eddie Louis Green 12/08/77 Charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owners Consent
properties.Details: UW Credit Union at 4101 Commercial Ave was a victim of a robbery at 5:17 P.M.  A black male approached an employee inside the Credit Union and demanded money.  The suspect then exited the bank and left the area on foot.  A short time later, officers were dispatched to the Road Ranger at 4102 Commercial Ave reference a stolen auto.  Officers located the vehicle and a pursuit ensued.  The stolen auto suspect was taken into custody without incident after he drove up on the grounds of the State Capitol.  The investigation is on-going to determine whether or not there is a link between the two incidents.  Currently the suspect in the stolen auto has been booked into the Dane County Jail on the charge of operating a motor vehicle without owners consent.

properties.Details: (UPDATE) Victim left car running while she ran into gas station. Prior to departing her vehicle, she remembers seeing a green colored Concord type vehicle parked next to her with a male black inside.  As soon as she entered the gas station she looked back and saw her car driving away. Her 5 year old daughter told police that a man with curly short black hair, wearing a black sweater with orange on it, had gotten into her mom's car and stated, "we're going for a little ride." When the vehicle was recovered minutes later the victim's (mom's) purse was missing.------------------------------------------------------------------------A female customer went inside the BP station to pay after filling her vehicle with gas.  While she was in the store, a male suspect drove off in her vehicle with her 5 and 1 year old children inside.  The vehicle was located a short distance away on Britta Parkway.  The children were safe and uninjured.  Suspect fled the scene and is still at large.  Incident is still under investigation.  Anyone with information regarding this (or any) crime is urged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: Male, black, age 15, MadisonFemale, black, age 15, MadisonBoth arrested & tentatively charged with operating a Motor Vehicle without Owner's Consent
properties.Details: On August 6th, at 5:46 a.m. Madison Police were dispatched to the 1900 block of Cameron Drive. A resident was waiting for officers to arrive so she could report that her car had been stolen. At that very moment her stolen car drove past her residence. A responding officer then spotted the stolen vehicle near the intersection of Raymond and Prairie roads. A short time later he and two other officers executed a high-risk stop. Five young people were in the car, and two of them were arrested on the tentative charge listed above. The car's owner also showed up at the scene to recover their stolen auto. She reports that two child seats were missing and that there had been some damage to the front-end. The teens told police they selected to steal this car because it was unlocked and the key was in the ignition.

properties.Suspect: Warren G. Whitelightning 36 year old maleCharges: Eluding (x2), OMVOC, Recklessly Endangering Safety, OWI (4th offense), Retail Theft and several traffic violations
properties.Details: A delivery driver reported that his Krispy Kreme truck was stolen from the Open Pantry as he was making a delivery inside.  A UWPD officer located the truck and got into a pursuit with it.  During the pursuit the truck stopped and the driver backed the truck into the squad before taking off again.  Another UW officer continued the pursuit for a short period before the pursuit was terminated.  An MPD officer was in the area and observed the vehicle drive past him.  The officer then attempted to stop the vehicle and a second pursuit ensued outbound on University Avenue.  The suspect driver at one point drove against traffic where speeds reached over 80mph.  The driver then crossed over the median and turned into the Village of Shorewood behind the strip mall area where the driver then surrendered in the parking lot of Copps in the 3600 block of University Avenue and was taken into custody.

On 11/25/07, at approximately 7:21 p.m., Madison police responded to a home on Offshore Drive where a resident reported his car had just been stolen. The victim told an officer that he had left the car unlocked and running in the driveway. When he came back out to get in the car he realized it was no longer there, and that it, in fact, had been stolen. As we press on into another Wisconsin winter the Madison Police Department would like to advise people who are looking to travel in preheated vehicles to not leave said vehicles unlocked and running.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, black, 28-30 years old, 5'6", with a thin build. He was last seen wearing a black winter hat and a long black winter coat.
properties.Details: On 12/16/2007 around 7:07 p.m. Madison police responded to a service station on Park Street for a report of an armed robbery. The victim says he was putting air in a car tire when the perpetrator grabbed the back of his coat and pulled him to his feet. He (the victim) says a handgun was poked into his stomach as the perpetrator demanded money. The victim told the gunman he had no money at which point the would be robber jumped into the victim's maroon '96 Ford Taurus --which was still running -- and drove off. The plate is 966-HMG. Anyone with information is asked to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Suspect: Darren L. Goodwan, age 18, no permanent address.Mr. Goodwan was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Consent, Battery, & Disorderly Conduct.A second perpetrator remains at large.

properties.Victim: Male, black, age 42, Madison.Victim suffered a punch to the fact.Male, black, age 9, Madison.Victim was not physically injured.
properties.Details: On December 17th a 42-year-old man reported he was about to prepay for some gas when he heard a commotion outside the service station. He looked out to see a man (see incident report on case # 2007-151545) being punched. The 42-year-old ran out to check on the victim's welfare. He assumed the perpetrators had taken off on foot, but then realized they must have taken his car, as it was gone. He had left the key in the vehicle so his nine-year-old son could listen to the radio. The 42-year-old immediately panicked realizing his boy was now inside a stolen car. He ran to the back of the service station and found his Cadillac -- both the drivers' and passenger doors were open -- and he could see two perpetrators running down Darbo Drive. The 42-year-old called police and tried to follow the thieves. As this was happening one the perpetrators approached the car and was able to deliver a blow to the 42-year-old through a partially open window.  The same perpetrator next kicked at the man's car, and then held on for a short distance (10 to 15 feet) as the 42-year-old tried to drive away. Police were on the scene a short time later and were able to contact a suspect who the 42-year-old identified as the man who punched him. The second perpetrator is still at large.

properties.Suspect: Anthony Bradley (m/b, 17 years of age); charges:  1) Operating a motor vehicle without owner's consent;  2)  Resisting an officer
properties.Details: On 12/25/07 at about 11pm an MPD officer observed a stolen vehicle driving on Atwood Avenue near Olbrich Gardens.  The officer attempted to stop the vehicle, but it stopped and two occupants fled on Dempsey Road.  An MPD K9 team responded to track the driver; the K9 team performed a track and located the susepct hiding in a trash container in the area.  The suspect - Anthony Bradley - was then taken into custody without incident.

properties.Suspect: Gregory Howard, age 17, MadisonMr. Howard was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without the Owner's Consent, & Recklessly Endangering Safety.
properties.Details: On January 2nd at 6:32 p.m. a Madison Police officer was responding to a report of a vehicle that was off to the side of Stoughton Road when dispatch broadcast information on a car that had just been stolen a short distance from the officer’s location.A 49-year-old owner of a '98 Toyota Corolla had left the vehicle running and unlocked outside of a PDQ store. He was inside buying a lottery ticket when he looked out to see his car being driven away. He called 911. The MPD officer was literally on the spot and gave chase. The thief drove a short distance before bailing out at the intersection of Buckeye Road and Maher Avenue. In his haste he failed to put the car in park. It was now rolling diagonally toward the oncoming (eastbound) lane of traffic on Buckeye. The officer ran after the vehicle, opened the driver's side door, jumped in the driver's seat, and hit the brake. Other officers were able to take the suspect into custody. He was told the Recklessly Endangering Safety charge was being recommended to the DA because of the car not being placed into park. The arresting officer informed him that had there been an oncoming car someone could have been seriously hurt or killed.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as male, black, 16 years old (or younger), 5'6", thin build, wearing dark jacket, baggy blue jeans and a dark colored baseball cap.
properties.Details: ***UPDATED FRIDAY JANUARY 25 ****The Mercury Sable mentioned in the original release was recovered in Middleton following a traffic stop. Middleton Police are providing details to interested news media.Joel DeSpain---------------------------------------------On January 23 around 7:41 a.m. a North District Madison Police patrol officer heard dispatch announce that a 2004 black GMC Envoy had just been stolen from a driveway of a home in the 5300 block of Comanche Way. The officer recognized this as being the latest in a pattern of car thefts that have been on the rise ever since the mercury went down -- people are warming up their unlocked, unattended vehicles and thieves are taking advantage of the situation. Shortly before the Envoy was stolen, a '98 blue Ford Taurus was taken from a home in the same general area. Experience and training told the patrol officer that it was quite possible some young person had jumped in the Envoy and was perhaps taking a joyride to school or another destination. Armed with this knowledge the officer set up on one of the main arteries - Packers Avenue - to see if the Envoy might be come his way. It did. The officer attempted to stop the driver near McDonald's on Northport Drive. The perpetrator responded by gunning the Envoy's engine. The Envoy, which had been westbound on Northport, blew across the eastbound lanes before crashing into a snow bank. In those few quick seconds the officer saw two vehicles nearly strike the stolen SUV. Its driver sprinted away into a nearby apartment complex. Officers and a police dog were unable to track him down. Later, in the same area, a beige Mercury Sable was stolen. The three cases (the Taurus, Envoy, & Sable) are likely connected.In the wake of the crime spree North District Captain Cam McLay released the following statement: "On January 23rd, there were 3 cars stolen between approximately 7am and 9am. The common thread in all of these cases was that the cars were left running to warm- up, and were unlocked and unattended. Madison Police officers spotted one of these vehicles and attempted to stop the suspect. The suspect was able to flee and avoid being taken into custody. Two of the three stolen cars have been recovered. This investigation continues at the present time, and we are confident that it will be solved.However, since January 1st, there have been 10 cars stolen in the City of Madison under similar circumstances. Nine of these occurred on the City’s North side, and one on the East side.We are asking all residents to assure that they remain with their vehicles while warming them up, or minimally lock the doors and continue to monitor the vehicle from inside. These are thefts of opportunity, and are easily prevented by these simple steps."

properties.Details: On January 26th around 9:41 a.m. a father of several young children called Madison Police to report that his white 2003 Chevy Suburban had been stolen from his driveway. The 32-year-old victim next saw his SUV around 8:23 a.m. on Thursday January 31st. He called dispatch and began tailing his own stolen vehicle -- continually giving out locations to police as the driver of his Suburban reached an estimated speed of 80 M.P.H. while going out East Washington Avenue. The caller said the driver of the stolen truck blew a red light and headed out Highway 51 to Anderson Street. The Chevy next turned onto Wright Street before stopping in the area of Commercial Avenue. The victim saw two young passengers flee on foot before the driver took off again. At this time officers were on the scene, and the two passengers lost in a foot chase.  They would not give up the name of their driver; however, the now parked SUV was recovered at N. Fifth and Hoard Streets.  Several items were missing from the truck, including three children's seats.

properties.Suspect: Adam D. Leonard, age 29, MadisonMr. Leonard was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent (OMVWOC), Possession of Drug Paraphernalia, and Retail Theft.
properties.Details: On February 5th, around 11:44 in the morning, Madison Police were called to the Speedway on Verona Road after a car was stolen. An Illinois man told officers he had left a '96 Geo Prizm he was driving unlocked -- with the key in the ignition -- while he went inside to pay for gas. He looked out to see a guy driving away in the Geo. The responding Madison Police officer put out -- over the radio -- an attempt to locate the Prizm. The transmission included a description of the thief. At nearby Cub Foods (4716 Verona Road) another Madison Police officer thought the description matched the guy he was just arresting for a retail theft. The officer -- who was at the Speedway -- drove over to Cub Foods and -- low and behold -- there was the stolen Prizm. The suspect would later make admissions against his penal interests.

properties.Suspect: Michael C. Gilson, Age 26, MadisonMr. Gilson will be tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent, Operating a Motor Vehicle While Under the Influence, Casual Possession of Marijuana in a Public Place, & Possession of Drug Paraphernalia
properties.Details: During yesterday's snowstorm Madison Fire & Madison Police were called to an apartment on West Gorham Street for a possible drug overdose. Paramedics and police officers tried to find the subject of the call but their efforts were initially unsuccessful. Upon returning to a parking lot at the rear of the apartment building paramedics were startled to see a man behind the wheel of their ambulance. A police officer ordered him to get out. He turned out to be the subject they had come to help. The police officer noted the man's eyes were red and his speech slurred. The man explained that he had been smoking marijuana and had taken a good deal of allergy medicine. He said he got in the ambulance with hopes of driving himself to the hospital. He put the rig in gear and tried to drive away, but his plan bogged down as the ambulance became stuck in the large dump of snow. At that point he decided to just wait for the paramedics. This second plan turned out to be a better one as the first responders did take him to a hospital for observation.

properties.Details: Information came in that the victim was following his own stolen vehicle that had been reorted to the Town Of Madison earlier. Officers attempted to stop the vehicle at 3:16 pm at Hwy 51 at Hwy 30. A pursuit followed and led to the vehicle driving up into Sycamore Park from the end of Nakoosa, onto the bike path. The pursuit ended at 3:19 pm when the suspects lost control of the stolen vehicle which skidded across soccer fields and received minor damage. The suspects then fled on foot. An Officer's squad also slid out and hit a tree, causing damage to the front end of the squad. The Officer received minor injuries and was treated and released.Officers took off after the passenger who was taken into custody at 3:21 pm. Officers set up a perimeter and the Dane County Sheriff's Office assisted with Deputies and a K9 unit. The driver was tracked to a townhouse on Wayridge Dr. where muddy footprints lead to a kicked in door. Warnings were given and Officers made entry, locating the combative suspect hiding in a closet. The suspect had dumped some of his muddy, wet clothes and had taken sweats from the residence. The suspect was arrested at 4:12 pm. The resident arrived home while Officers were present. The suspect had picked the address at random.

properties.Suspect: Kristopher B. Fox, age 19, MadisonMr. Fox was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent.
properties.Details: A 58-year-old Madison resident, who lives in the 2900 block of Coho Street, says he likely forgot to close his garage door Friday night, and when he awoke shortly before 4:00 a.m. Saturday morning he realized his '93 Honda Civic had been stolen. He had left the keys in the car's center console, and had not locked the Honda. A Madison police officer took a report on the stolen auto and went back on patrol. About thirty minutes later he saw the stolen Honda drive by the intersection of Fish Hatchery and Post roads. The officer turned on his red lights. The driver pulled over and was arrested.

The vehicle was being operated recklessly cutting off vehicles and making rapid lane changes. properties.Suspect: Richard A. Petrick, age 49, no permanent addressMr. Petrick will be tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle Without Owner's Consent.
properties.Details: On Monday morning, around 11:14 a.m., a construction worker working on the State Street improvement project realized his 2003 Chevy Silverado pickup truck was no longer in front on the Chocolate Shop where he had parked it. The worker told a responding Madison Police Officer that it is protocol to leave keys in vehicles, as coworkers often need to move them around in order to keep the project moving along. One of these coworkers saw a guy driving the Silverado, with its emergency flashing lights on, out of the construction area on West Gilman Street. The truck was subsequently reported as stolen. By early afternoon a Clinton Police Officer in Rock County discovered the Silverado in her community and took into custody Mr. Richard Petrick – the man who had driven the truck there. The Madison Officer recognized the name right away. Mr. Petrick is someone the officer knows to have no permanent address, and is somebody who enjoys hanging out at Peace Park. In fact, the officer, that very morning, had seen Mr. Petrick sleeping on a Peace Park bench. The Madison Officer has spoken with Mr. Petrick in the past and has been told by Mr. Petrick that he has relatives in the Rock County area. It appears Mr. Petrick had taken the truck with hopes of visiting with some of those relatives. As a result of this incident Madison Police are recommending Mr. Petrick's name be added to the State Street ban list.

properties.Details: Just past midnight Wednesday Madison Police responded to Kipling Drive for a report of a crime in progress. The caller had caught someone trying to steal his friend's pickup truck, which was parked in the street. The truck was not locked and the keys were inside. The suspect was attempting to pull away, but was having difficulty to getting the truck into drive. The witness approached the open driver's side window and says the young driver punched him. The teen then got out of the truck and wrestled briefly with the witness. Police were on the scene a short time later and an arrest was made.

The vehicle was later located unoccupied near E. Badger road. A K9 track was unsuccessful. The investigation is continuing.

She complied and the perpetrators were last seen driving her black, 2000 Chevy Blazer westbound on Packers Avenue. No weapon was seen, and the victim was not injured.

Officers K. Dunnington and M. Richardson discovered a vehicle in the median of the 1700 block of S. Park St. Officers found the 65 yoa male PNB and attached an AED to the subject and delivered a shock to the subject. Officers Dunnington,Richardson and Town of Madison officer D. Parks then began CPR on the subject. Officers were able to revive the subject who was then transported by Town of Madison Fire Dept. to a local hospital where he is in critical condition.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 10/13/2005 at approximately 12:51 p.m. the 911 Center received a call that a woman had just collapsed in front of the photo area of Woodman's (east).  A retired EMT stepped forward to help render aid.  A Madison Police Officer, Alison Radzicki, was nearby and responded with an AED (Automated External Defibulator).  This device provides a calculated shock to the individual after a reading of the situation.  The officer provided the shock and the female regained her pulse, shortly before Madison Fire/Rescue responded.  The female is recovering at a local hospital.  This illustrates the outstanding benefit of the AED in our community.

properties.Victim: Male, age 22Victim was admitted to a local hospital.
properties.Details: On Tuesday night, around 8:56, Madison Police responded to a report of a pulseless non-breather inside an apartment on Thorp Street. The first officer on the scene found a 22-year old man who appeared not to be breathing. The officer performed chest compressions on the patient for around four minutes until Madison Fire Department EMS arrived. Paramedics administered Narcan on the patient, and he was revived within moments. The patient later admitted to using heroin. The Madison Police officer who came to the patient's aid will be nominated for a MPD Lifesaving Award.

properties.Details: Through a lengthy and on-going investigation, detectives from the Madison Police Department arrested Mull for the aforementioned charges relating to Stellner's overdose death.  Other individuals who may have knowledge of the incident have been listed in the criminal complaint.

properties.Details: On 10/23/05 at approximately 1:48 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the 600 block of N. Frances for a man down.  Officers and members from the Madison Fire Department aided in the resuscitation of the male who had a heroine overdose.  The male was transported to a local hospital where he is expected to recover.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: 18 year old male resident of Madison, in stable condition in a Madison hospital.
properties.Details: At approximately 12:19 am, Madison Police responded along with Madison Fire/Rescue to the report of a pulseless non-breather at a residence in the 400 block of E. Washington Ave.  Upon arrival, they located an 18 year old male who appeared to have overdosed on drugs.  The subject did respond to emergency treatment by Fire/Rescue personnel and was conveyed to a Madison hospital, where he is reported in stable condition.  It appears that this may well be a heroin overdose.  On May 24, 2006 there was a heroin overdose that resulted in a death.  This also occurred in downtown Madison.  There have been several other incidents with very similar concerns that remain under investigation.The Madison Police Department strongly cautions against using street drugs.  The person buying drugs never knows for sure what exactly the drugs contain or may have been diluted with.  Additionally, we strongly encourage anyone who observes a friend or acquaintance in distress related to the ingestion of street drugs immediately call 911 for emergency help.  Immediate medical assistance can save someone's life.

On 7/27/06 at approximately 1pm, severe weather moved through the Madison area creating significant flooding and downed power lines.  By rush hour, the weather related effects of the storm had subsided.  The Madison Police Department thanks those citizens who avoided the roadways through this troubled period.As severe weather can often occur over the summer months, motorists are reminded to avoid driving through standing water as it's depth is often unpredictable.  Downed power lines should always be avoided.

Officers contacted Kreisler a short time later and he complied with requests to drop the weapon at which time he was taken into custody. It was later determined that Kreisler was upset due to the fact that he believed someone had stolen his dog. His dog was found inside his apartment. No shots were fired and no one was injured.

properties.Arrested: Arrested Person:  Joshua J. Bingham (21 y.o. M/W from Madison)
properties.Victim: No reported injuries however the fire did cause damage to the structure.
properties.Details: On 03-27-06 the Madison Police Department responded to a structure fire in the 1000 block of Melvin Ct. Officers arrived on scene and shortly after a firefighter with the Madison Fire Department observed a suspicious subject, later identified as Bingham, running close to the house that was on fire.  Bingham was contacted and subsequently detained at the scene.Bingham was interviewed by a Madison Police Department Detective and ultimately charged with 3 counts of Arson to a Building.  Police believe Bingham was involved with 3 recent fires all on the City’s North side.All three investigations are considered on-going and anyone with information regarding these fires is encouraged to contact the Madison Police Department or the Madison Fire Department Arson Investigation Unit.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: At approx. 7:48 p.m., Madison Police were notified by McDonald's personnel that a fire had been started in one of the trash receptacles inside of the restaurant.  The receptacle and the burning trash had been removed to the parking lot.  McDonald's employees used water to put the fire out.  There was no damage to the interior of the restaurant.  Madison Fire responded to the scene and assisted by venting the restaurant.  Just after the fire was reported, a group of protestors showed up to demonstrate in front of the restaurant.  The protestors belong to a group that was demonstrating against produce purchasing policies of the McDonald's Corporation.  It is not known if the fire is related to the demonstration.

properties.Arrested: Edward W. Helman, M/W - Madison, WisconsinCharges:  Arson - (2 counts)Ref case #2006-153002 & Fire case #2006-42065
properties.Details: On December 28th, 2006 The Madison Police took Edward W. Helman into custody for 2 counts of Arson related to an active fire that was reported on December 24th, 2006 at 6:44pm in 1000 block of Jonathon Drive.  The Madison Police Department has been working in conjunction with the city of Madison Fire Department reference a school bus and motor home that were found burning at that location.  No one was injured in the fire, but damage estimates are approximated at $5000.00.  This investigation initially began with the Fire Department conducting their investigative inquiry, and after it was determined that arson was likely the Madison Police Department combined resources and Detectives followed leads.  Those leads proved to be promising and an arrest was made on December 28th, 2006.  Arson is a serious crime and thanks to the hard work and dedication of both the City of Madison Fire and Police Departments, a step in the right direction was successfully made.  It goes without saying that this is the manner in which departments should work with one another in all situations, and this type of work will keep the citizens of this city safe.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 4/24/07 at 5:33 a.m. Madison Police and Fire responded to a car on fire in the 3300 block of Prairie Rd.  It appears that someone threw a Molotov cocktail through the car to start it on fire.  No one was injured. No other information is available at this time. This remains an open arson investigation.

properties.Arrested: 16 year old maleTentative Charge: Arson to Building
properties.Victim: On Thursday June 7 Madison Police took into custody a 16 year old Memorial High School student. He was taken to the Juvenile Reception Center on a tentative arson charge. The teen is accused of setting a fire inside a bathroom at Memorial H.S. Wednesday (June 6) afternoon. Memorial staff and students were instrumental in helping detectives identify a suspect. The fire, which was contained to the bathroom, caused an estimated $2000 damage.

properties.Arrested: Male, 8 years old
properties.Details: On 8/23/07 at 8:34 p.m. Madison Police and Fire responded to a report of a car being on fire.  The first police officer on scene was able to extinguish the car fire with a fire extinguisher.  It was learned that an eight year-old boy had attempted to start two cars on fire, but was unsuccessful.  A lighter and gas can were obtained and the child started a fire on the third vehicle, causing significant damage to the wheel well area.  The child and a parent were contacted and due to the child's age, he was not arrested.

properties.Arrested: Lewis Tolbert, 47, Madison:  Attempted Arson to a Building
properties.Details: On 8/24/07 at 10:40 p.m. Madison Police responded to an attempted arson to Visions Night Club.  It was learned a patron of the bar had become upset while inside.  The patron, Tolbert, was upset about missing $100 and that staff had refused to serve him any more alcohol.  Tolbert was removed from the bar as he threatened to burn it down.  Tolbert retrieved a gas can and brought it back to Visions, along with a lighter.  Tolbert was contact by police and arrested without incident.  No major structural damage was reported/observed.

On March 18th shortly after 8:00 a.m. a homeowner on Putnam Road contacted the Madison Police Department to report an arson fire. Upon taking the morning trash out the resident discovered someone had placed newspapers in their metal mailbox during the night and set them on fire. Earlier in the morning around 5:49 a.m. MPD officers and firefighters from the Madison Fire Department had been called to another small blaze a few blocks away. This first call was to a home in the 2600 block of Sara Road where paper had been set on fire inside a recycling bin.

properties.Arrested: Gary Meats, 25, Madison:  GraffitiJason Walker, 26, Madison:  Graffiti

Officers responded quickly and caught Meats and Walker on Gorham St. near State St with fresh paint elements.  It was learned that the two individuals had spray painted 15 different buildings in the State St. area.  It is not believed that the graffiti was gang related.

properties.Arrested: Male, Age 12, MadisonCited & Released for Graffiti, Curfew Violation, ResistingMale, Age 14, MadisonCited & Released for Graffiti, Curfew ViolationMale, Age 14, MadisonCited & Released for Graffiti, Curfew ViolationMale, Age 14, MadisonCited & Released for Graffiti, Curfew Violation
properties.Address: Cardinal Lane (Oak Park Terrace mobile home park)
properties.Details: On Monday night, around 11:45 p.m., Madison Police were called to Cardinal Lane for a criminal damage to property complaint. A citizen who had been sitting outside talking with friends noticed a neighbor's motion light had come on. He then saw a group of teens, some in dark colored clothing, running.Using that information, and further intelligence gleaned from a state worker who was painting lines on a nearby street, officers were able to locate four juveniles. Some in the group confessed that they had been out in the area, armed with green spray paint, and had scrawled graffiti on 2-parked vans, and 2 sheds.It should be noted that Graffiti is a City Ordinance violation. A 1st violation carries at $676 ticket. A 2nd ticket, within 5 years, will cost violators $991. Those penalties are for adults. Juveniles must make a mandatory court appearance at which time a judge will mete out the punishment.

properties.Suspect: Francisco Xelhua-Montes, age 21, MadisonMr. Xelhua-Montes was arrested and tentatively charged with Graffiti & Resisting.

Near a PDQ store on Northport Driver he spotted two men matching the description of the taggers. The officer got out of his squad and ordered the suspects to stop. Instead they ran. The officer chased one of the men down. Francisco Xelhua-Montes was arrested, and a can of spray paint was recovered from his jacket pocket.

The suspect was arrested on three counts of Graffiti. He was in possession of a couple of cans of spray paint at the time of his apprehension.

properties.Arrested: Robert Braier, 41, Madison:  Lewd & Lascivious

properties.Arrested: M/W, approximately 55-60 years of age, 6 feet in height, last seen wearing gold rimmed glasses, neutral colored jacket, and clean shaven with gray colored hair.
properties.Details: Madison Police were contacted on March 8th, 2006 reference an exposure incident that occurred on March 7th, 2006 at approximately 8:15p.m.  A 37-year-old female and her two daughters (ages 8 and 11) were shopping at 2602 East Springs Drive (Kohl’s) when the suspect allegedly exposed his genitalia to the juveniles as their mother was shopping in an adjacent isle of the store. properties.Arrested: 25-30 year old white/male, 5'10" average build, short black hair, wearing a dark colored jacket and white shirt
properties.Details: On 03-29-06 at approximately 2:00 PM Madison Police Officers responded to the area of 2100 Pike Dr for a report of a male in the area exposing himself. properties.Arrested: Male, White, approximately 30 years-old, Red SUV or pick-up

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Witnesses have identified a 30 year old white male with short blondish brown hair as the perpetrator committing numerous exposures and sexual assaults throughout the city. The suspect is stalking and following women walking alone, whereupon he asks them for directions or assistance before exposing himself to them from his truck or while inside stores.  The suspect is also following women while pretending to shop inside the malls and then grabbing their breasts and buttocks. properties.Arrested: M/H, 30 yoa, 5'06 in height, heavy build, wearing blue jeans, black shoes, dark coat, and a baseball cap with brown bill.
properties.Victim: 16 year old female of Madison with no injuries reported
properties.Details: On December 28th, 2006 at approximately 11:20pm, Madison Police were dispatched to the 300 block of S. Whitney Way reference a Hispanic male that had exposed himself to a 16-year-old female that was walking on the sidewalk towards her residence.  After police responded, they determined at approximately 10:30PM the female was distracted while using her cell phone (sending text messages) and was approached by the male suspect asking if “Anything was wrong & do you need a ride”.  The female continued on her way but noticed that the male had exposed his genitalia.  The female told the suspect to “Get away” in a loud and convincing fashion, but that did not keep him from grabbing her buttocks.  The 16- year-old had no option but to defend herself, punched the suspect, and proceeded to run towards her residence.  Based on her keen observations, she did remember seeing a Grey colored van (possibly a Dodge Caravan – older model) passing her earlier before the suspect would later contact her.There were no injuries claimed in this scenario, but The Madison Police Department continues to ask citizens to pay particular attention to any suspicious persons or vehicles in their neighborhood.  This was a fortunate situation where no one was harmed, but we ask everyone to make sure they are not so involved with other tasks that they are not attentive to their environment.  We ask that anyone with information regarding this case contact The Madison Police Department or Crime Stoppers at (608) 266- 6014.   PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: Male White, Late 30's, Dark Hair w/ Pony Tail, Driving red 2-door car

On Thursday, March 27, 2008, Madison Police responded to Frank Allis Elementary School, 4201 Buckeye Road, to take a report on an exposure. A 9-year-old student says it happened along Buckeye Road while she was walking to school around 8:15 a.m. Thursday. She believed the man had a shaved head and may have been driving a colored pick-up truck. She says he stopped his vehicle and lifted up his mid-section. Frightened, she ran to school and reported the incident to a teacher. The Madison Metropolitan School District is sending an advisory letter home to parents.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, bald, 30's, wearing a bed bandana & driving a grey/silver pickup truck.

The man was exposing himself. His description, and the vehicle description are similar to an exposure case reported by another student at the school last week. Madison Police will have an increased presence outside of the school in coming days, and school officials are sending information on the latest exposure home to parents.

properties.Suspect: Perpetartor is described as a thin white male around 25 years old.

The victim says while on the bike path she observed a thin white guy with his pants around his ankles. He was exposing himself to the runner. She says he did not try to do anything to her, but she was quite concerned about the man's behavior.

properties.Suspect: Lawrence E. Foy, age 56, no permanent addressMr. Foy was arrested and cited for Unlawful Use of Bus Shelter, Exposure of Person, and Depositing Human Waste. Mr. Foy was also booked into the Dane County Jail on a Parole Hold.
properties.Address: 802 W. Badger Road Madison Metro South Transfer Point
properties.Details: Around 7:50 p.m. on Wednesday night a 17-year old flagged down a Madison Police officer after seeing a man urinating at the South Transfer Point. The victim said children were around when he did this. She pointed the man out, and the officer noticed he appeared to be without his trousers. The officer then saw the man grab a pair of nearby jeans. He started pulling them on, and as he did, the officer could not help but notice that his underpants were wet, and that there was a wet spot on the concrete and dirt where he had been. The officer made contact with the suspect, and determined he was having a hard time walking and that his speech was slurred. The man said he had been hanging out with friends at the transfer point. He was given several citations and taken to jail on a parole hold.Officers from the South District have been giving the South Transfer Point extra attention due to ongoing problems including the illegal use of alcohol, fights, drug issues, and robberies.

properties.Suspect: Dennis J. Welhoefer, age 58, Waterloo WIMr. Welhoefer was arrested and tentatively charged with Lewd and Lascivious behavior.

The victims said they were able to observe the suspect for around 20 minutes, and that his behavior remained consistent during that time period.

properties.Arrested: Male-while, 50's, graying brown hair in ponytail, 5'8-5'10, goatee, black pants, white long underwear top
properties.Details: On 10/7/2005 Madison Police responded to a report of a possible child enticement in the area near Churchill/McDivitt roads around 3:15 p.m.  The child told police that after missing her bus, she was walking home with a friend when she noticed the described suspect following them.  As they tried to evade him by crossing streets and ducking behind trees and homes, the suspect did the same.  Eventually the girls began to run and the suspect ran as well, before stopping and turning around due to others on the sidewalk.  At one point the suspect yelled, "stop" to the girls.The Madison Police Department is investigating this incident and reminds parents to talk to their children about staying safe.

properties.Arrested: n/a

Extra patrol will be assigned to the area for the comfort of neighbors and students.  Parents are reminded to take this opportunity to talk to their children about staying safe and knowing their surroundings.

properties.Arrested: Juan (NMI) Baeza Aguilera, M/H, 11/28/71, of MadisonCharges: Child Enticement, OMVWI,OAS
properties.Details: At appprox. 4:16 p.m., on 4/9/06, Madison Police officers were dispatched to the 6700 blk. of Schroeder Rd. reference a child enticement. After a thorough investigation, it was determined that the victims were offered money for sexual favors as well as the keys to the residence of the suspect. The suspect identified as Baeza Aguilera was arrested for enticing the juveniles as well as operating a motor vehicle under the influence of intoxicants, and operating after suspension. Baeza Aguilera was conveyed to the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: M/W or M/H (Olive skin), approximately 35yrs, blk hair, stubble beard, heavy set (double chin), with indentations in face/acne, last seen wearing a red/grey T shirt.Suspect vehicle:  Newer (1999-2001) midsize 4dr blue in color with blue bumpers, said to be in good condition
properties.Details: At approximately 7:20am on July 3rd 2006, a 12-year-old female was walking southbound on Schenk Street from the East Transfer Point (Metro Bus Stop) to Whitehorse Middle School when the suspect (described above) approached her in a vehicle near the 100 block of Schenk Street. This suspect had circled the neighborhood twice before stopping next to the female and asked, "Do you need a ride - Are you sure"?  The female did the appropriate thing and said "No" and continued to walk towards the school to safety.  The suspect at no point attempted to get out of his vehicle (Blue midsize vehicle in good condition, possibly a 2000 model with blue bumpers), but was persistent in asking if the juvenile female needed a ride.  This is being looked at as an enticement attempt and we are asking the community to be particularly observant of suspicious persons in their neighborhood.  If anyone has any information about this case, please call the Madison Police Department or Crime Stoppers (608)266-6014 as soon as possible.PO Howard Payne

properties.Arrested: White, Male, 5'10, 230 lbs., black tanktop, black leather jacket, black pants
properties.Details: On 7/5/06 a Madison Police Officer took a report of a possible child enticement that had occurred on 6/29/06.  The officer learned that as the two boys were taking a Madison Metro bus from the Camp Randall area to the Middleton area, they were photographed by the above described individual.  As the boys were on the bus the subject started a conversation with them about liking their hair.  The subject asked to take their picture in which the boys refused.  The picture was still taken.  When the boys asked to delete the picture the subject asked for their email address so he can send it to them.  The boys refused and eventually left the bus without further incident.  There was a delay in reporting this incident because the parents wanted to obtain more facts about the case first.

properties.Arrested: Joshua Lynch, 24, Fitchburg:  Attempted Child Enticement, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 8/13/06 at 13:51 p.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to Elver Park for an attempted child enticement.  Officers learned that the victim was walking on Raymond Rd, to McKenna Blvd when a male subject later identified as Lynch approached him.  The victim was walking on Raymond Rd when he noticed a book on the sidewalk.  The victim picked up the sexually explicit book and briefly looked at it.  Within minutes of picking up the book, Lynch pulled up in a white four-door vehicle and began to question the 15 year-old about desires to act out the images in the book.  The victim refused, threw the book to the ground and continued walking as Lynch left the area.  As the victim continued walking, Lynch circled in his vehicle.  The victim, who was now walking on McKenna Blvd closer to Elver Park, was fearful and tried to wave down a motorist to call police.   When this didn't work the victim found people in the Elver Park tennis courts and used their cell phone to call 9-1-1 as he felt he was being followed.  While on the phone, the victim noticed Lynch lurking across the roadway, staring at the victim.  By the time police arrived, Lynch was gone.  The alert victim did give police Lynch's license's plate number.  Lynch was arrested at his residence and taken to the Dane County Jail without incident.

properties.Arrested: Two white males, possibly in their 20's, in a green minivan
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department is investigating an incident that occurred on 11/30/06 in which two boys (age 9) were walking home from school and approached by a suspicious vehicle.  As the boys were walking east on Wyoming Way, a green minivan was driving westbound.  The van stopped near the boys and had the sliding door open.  One of the two males inside the van yelled, "get in".  The boys fled through backyards to safety and reported the incident to police.

Through the use of the media and community, officers have learned that a previous report of a child enticement on Wyoming Way (see previous release, 12/4/06) has been cleared.  It was learned that the green minivan is driven daily on Wyoming Way, with its doors open, in order to deliver newspapers.  The van is occupied by two males and at the time they were engaged in a loud conversation.  All mixed together, the juveniles believed it was something suspicious and performed as advised-by running away and notifying police.

properties.Arrested: #1: Male, Black, 5-10' to 6', 200 lbs, 25-30 years old, splotchy skin on face, blue jeans, stocking cap, blue/green/white plaid jacket.#2: Male, Black 25-30 years old
properties.Details: On 12/28/06 at approximately 8:50 a.m. a female victim told an officer she was attacked in the Highland Ave/Van Hise Ave area.  The female told the officer that she was walking to work and noticed the above-described suspects watching her.  As she walked by the individuals, they made some general remarks about her.  The victim continued walking and was approached by the suspects.  One suspect grabbed the female by the arm and demanded that she come with the two suspects.  The shocked female resisted, broke free and ran from the suspects, who did not chase.  No injuries were reported and property was not stolen.  This remains an open investigation by the Madison Police Department.

properties.Arrested: Suspect:  M/W with gray hair driving a green 4 door sedan

properties.Arrested: Male, Hispanic, approximately 30-35 years old, 5'4, 120, White T-shirt
properties.Details: On 3/12/07 at approximately 7:00 a.m. a 13 year-old female was walking to the bus transfer point from her residence.  While on Magnolia Lane the victim noticed a green SUV approach her and come up on the curb near her.  The suspect exited the vehicle, approached the female and grabbed at her backpack that she had strapped on her back.  The victim spun and was able to get away from the suspect.  The victim walked quickly away as the suspect now began to follow her on foot.  Noticing that she was being followed, the victim began running, in which the suspect went back to his SUV and followed her down Hughes Street.  The victim went into McDonalds and watched the SUV pass.  The victim then went to catch a bus in order to get to school, where she reported this to authorities.  This remains an open investigation by the Madison Police Department.ADDITIONAL INFORMATION MPD CASE No. 2007-26554:On 03/13/07 at approximately 3:30 p.m., MPD investigated a possible child enticement in the area of Traceway Drive.  The suspect is described as a Hispanic male, possibly in his 30's.  He was described as having dark "mohawk" type hair (approximately 2 in. tall by 4 in. wide) with very short hair on the sides of his head.  The suspect was observed driving a GRAY colored older model "Toyota like" vehicle.The Madison Police Department is investigating the possibility that these two incidents may be related.  Anyone having information is encouraged to contact MPD or Crime Stoppers.

properties.Arrested: MALE WHITE OR HISPANIC40-50 Years OldSpiky Hair, Sun GlassesWearing Button-down shirt with diagonal orange striping, covered with numerous small green squares. Greenish-brown shorts. Driving red Honda Civic
properties.Details: On Friday afternoon shortly before 3:00 p.m. Madison Police were called to Glenn Stephens Elementary school for a reported child enticement. properties.Arrested: Male, Asian, wearing blue shirt & driving a red car
properties.Details: On Wednesday night, July 18, Madison Police were contacted about a possible attempted child enticement. A Lodi father reported that his older son, and the older son's girlfriend, had taken the caller's younger son (age 6) to Best Buy on the East Side. The boy was left in a running car while the older couple shopped for about ten minutes. Upon their return they found the boy sobbing, and holding his head in his hands. The boy reported that while he was alone an Asian male in a red car pulled in next to the car he was in. He says the suspect offered him a piece of candy, and he (the boy) feared the man was trying to take him. The boy was able to lock the car's door. His father says he is not the type of lad to make up such a story. The responding officer let the older brother know it is not a good idea to leave a child alone inside a parked, running car.

properties.Arrested: Male, Middle Eastern, full beard & moustache, driving gold or tan 4-door Ford Taurus with damage to passenger side
properties.Details: On Monday, July 23rd, shortly after 5:00 p.m. Madison Police responded to the Northport Drive area for a reported child enticement.
