She had gone to the area to see if a friend could go with her to the library.  Later, as she walked along Northport, she says the same driver pulled up and asked if she wanted a ride. She said no, and reports that the car sped off very quickly. She told police the experience, "creeped her out."

properties.Arrested: Larome B. Kingcade, age 41, MadisonTentative Charges: Armed Robbery, Kidnapping, Burglary, Battery, Possession of Drug Paraphernalia, Probation Violation
properties.Address: 1900 block West Beltline Highway (house assoicated with St. Joseph Catholic Church)
properties.Details: On August 14th, around 9:18 a.m. Madison Police received a call reference the kidnapping of a Catholic Nun. The victim told police that around 8:20 a.m. on August 14th a suspect came in threw the window of a home (located in the 1900 block of the W. Beltline Highway) associated with St. Joseph Catholic Church. The man, who was armed with some type of weapon, reportedly pushed the nun and demanded money. She told him she is a nun and that she had no money. He then forced the victim to drive him around in her car. Eventually he had her drop him off in the area of Taft Street. She then drove to a safe location, St. James Catholic School, and called police. A description went out and citizens in the Taft Street area helped police locate the suspect. He has been arrested on the tentative charges listed above.

properties.Arrested: Male, black, late 20's-early 30's, wearing white t-shirt, white baseball cap, driving older red sports type car
properties.Details: On August 16th at 10:47 a.m. a Madison Police officer took a report from a 14-year-old girl about a possible child enticement. The girl says she was walking her dog along Jade Lane about 15 minutes prior to the officer's arrival. She reports that while on that walk a man in a red car pulled up next to her. She says he asked if he could take her dog for a walk. She said no, he sped off, and she quickly reported the incident to her mother who in turn called police.

properties.Suspect: Suspect: Male black, 25, 5'3", average build, short-cropped hair or bald, last seen wearing white sweater, & blue jeans
properties.Details: On October 16th around 7:40 a.m. Madison police were called to the area of a bus stop on Beld Street. A 17-year-old woman reported that she was on her way to the bus stop when a man grabbed her from behind and tried to drag her off. Citizens in the area came to the woman's rescue, and the suspect ran. A detective has been assigned to investigate.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator: Male white, 20-30 years old, brown hair, buzz hair cut, no glasses, no facial hair, medium build, driving white pickup truck with some rust and no topper.
properties.Details: On October 12th around 3:26 p.m. Madison police took a report from 12-year-old girl. She says she had gotten off a bus on Muir Field Road and was walking up Cimarron Trail when the driver of a pickup truck stopped to ask her where Star Cinema was located. The girl gave him the information. She says the driver left, but then came back moments later asking her once again about the location of Star Cinema. She gave him the information again. He then told her he did not know the area well and asked her to "come show me." The girl told the man her mother was on her way at which time he said, "Oh your mom is coming? Then I better go."

properties.Suspect: Sean C. Lynch, Age 17, MadisonTentative charges: Operating while Suspended, Improper use of Registration, Child Enticement
properties.Details: On October 26, 2007 a Madison police officer, who was on routine patrol, pulled over Mr. Lynch around 5:15 p.m. in the 3100 block of Muir Field Road. The officer recognized the vehicle Mr. Lynch was driving (a black Toyota 4Runner) as possibly being the same SUV that had been observed by several women who had been approached in recent weeks by a man seeking directions.Madison police have arrested Mr. Lynch on a tentative charge of Child Enticement. This charge stems from a 12 year old who was contacted about directions to the Star Cinema on October 12th. (There is an earlier incident report on our website about that case.)Mr. Lynch is also under investigation for other contacts with area west side women, and additional charges are likely.

properties.Suspect: Victim describes man as a White male, 55 years old, balding on top with grayish white hair on the sides, chubby, wearing a brown jacket and blue jeans. She says he was driving a bright red 4-door car with wood paneling stripes that ran horizontal from front to back.
properties.Details: On November first, around 3:29 p.m., Madison police took a report from a 13-year-old girl about an attempted child enticement. The victim says she had been walking home from school with friends, but split off to get to her house. While walking southbound on Hanover Street she says a man in a car slowed down and stopped next to her. She says he rolled down the passenger side window and asked if she wanted a ride. She said no. He said, "No, I insist." The girl says the man then opened up the passenger side door and told her to get in the car. She instead ran.

properties.Suspect: Child describes man who enticed her as a male Hispanic, 30's, short hair, goatee, wearing a white t-shirt. She describes his van as being light brown with dark brown and light brown horizontal stripes. She says the van had tinted windows in the back with curtains over the windows. There was some rust, and a rear taillight may have been broken.
properties.Details: On November 5th at 3:27 p.m. Madison police took a report from an eight-year-old girl about a child enticement. The victim says she was on her way to school that morning, walking along Camden Road near Linda Vista Avenue around 7:40 a.m., when a man driving a van stopped near her. She says he stated that he knew her mother, and that her mother had told the suspect to give the girl a ride to school. The girl told the man she was not going to take a ride. She ran. The man drove off.

On November fourth at 9:31 p.m. Madison police were sent to South Randall Avenue to speak with a female Madison Middle School student about some suspicious men. The student says that on more than one occasion, she has observed a vehicle parked in the neighborhood and that the driver stares at her as she walks by. On this night, the child was walking with a parent when the car was spotted. The parent approached the vehicle at which point the driver left the scene. The car was occupied by 2-3 males, possibly Hispanic.The suspect vehicle is described as an older white Monte Carlo with tinted windows and a loud muffler. A helium balloon was tied to the trunk. Madison Police have assigned a detective to the case.

On November 7th at 6:10 p.m. Madison police were dispatched to the Lakeview Library (2845 North Sherman Avenue) in the Sherman Plaza. A 14-year-old girl reports that she had run back to the library after two men tried to get her into a car. The victim says she was walking home from the library, and was on Elka Lane when an older grayish white, four door vehicle with two black males inside stopped by her. The girl says one of the men told her to get in the car. She started running back to Sherman Plaza and says the car backed up and started following her. She returned to the library and police were called.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as dark skinned male in his 50's, 6' tall, with a thin long graying beard and mustache. He was last seen wearing a white turban, dark jacket, brown pants and shoes.
properties.Details: On January 8th around 9:34 a.m. Madison Police were called to Marquette Elementary School to take a report from a 15-year-old student who is attending an alternative learning program at the school.The girl says after getting off a bus in the 2000 block of Jenifer Street she observed a car following her. The driver, the lone occupant, repeatedly suggested that she approach the car because he had something to show her. At one point the driver got out of the vehicle and motioned for the girl to get in, but he did not make any attempt to physically grab her. The man followed her until she entered the school.The suspect vehicle is described as: A white 4 door with a car top carrierThe Madison Metropolitan School District has sent an advisory letter home to Marquette parents.If you have information regarding this case, call the Madison Police Department Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, 35-40 years old, short dark black hair, with no glasses or facial hair. He was wearing a dark navy blue zip-up jacket with hood and white on the sleeves. His vehicle is said to be a newer red or maroon four-door Cadillac SUV with no rear bumper, and no license plates.
properties.Address: Raymond Road (from near Mckenna Blvd. to Whitney Way)
properties.Details: On Tuesday January 15th around 9:24 Madison Police were called to Toki Middle School to take a report of an attempted child enticement. Two girls, ages 13 and 11, said they were followed by a man in a car as they walked to school along Raymond Road from Mckenna Blvd. to Whitney Way. At a couple of points in time the students say the man spoke to them through an open passenger's side window. First he told the girls, "You guys are going to be late for school." Following this comment the students quickened their pace. The man in the car continued to follow slowly behind them. After another block or two the man said, "I know your Dad, it's okay, I can give you a ride ... hop in." One of the girls replied, "You don't know my Dad." They walked even more quickly eventually crossing from the south side of Raymond to the north side at Whitney Way where they cut in to the Walgreen's parking lot. They then observed the man in the car speed up and continue eastbound on Raymond. The girls immediately contacted a guidance counselor

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, 50's, graying hair, and possibly some facial hair like a goatee. He was driving newer looking silver or white bubble shaped car -- perhaps a VW Passat.
properties.Details: On February 3, 2008 around 11:30 a.m. Madison Police were called to a home on Gladstone Drive to take a report on a possible child enticement. Parents of an 11-year-old girl told the MPD that their daughter had a 10-year-old friend over for a sleepover Saturday night. The girls walked outside that evening (February 2nd) around 7:15 p.m. A man in a car stopped and rolled down his window while they were standing at the corner of Gladstone and Muir Field Road. He asked them if they needed to cross the street. The girls said no. The man then stated, "Are you up to no good?" One girl asked him what he meant. He stated the question again. The girls said nothing. The man declared, "I'm an old man and I'm up to no good tonight." This frightened the girls and they ran back to the house. The parents decided to call police the next morning.

properties.Suspect: Suspect Unknown:  Male, Black (dark complexion), early 30's, mustache, goatee, operating a newer model blue 4-door Ford car.
properties.Details: On 5/7/08 at approximately 6 p.m. a Madison Police Officer took a report from a juvenile regarding a possible child enticement that had occurred around 3 p.m.   During the course of the interview, the officer learned that the same female was approached by the same male, on April 2, 2008.  The suspect followed the female and made verbal advances to suggest the female should come into his car.  At one point the victim tried to walk away and the suspect maneuvered his car in an attempt to keep talking to the female. The female fled on foot as another car, not involved, honked at the suspect vehicle to keep moving.  The female was concerned and told responsible adults about this incident.  The suspect stayed in his vehicle the entire time.

properties.Suspect: (UPDATE TUESDAY 10:52 a.m.)Mr. Anthony Steele has just been arrested, and the victim is safe..------------(ORIGINAL RELEASE)Suspect at LargeAnthony SteeleM/B, 48 yo5'02'-5'03' 170-190 lbs
properties.Details: Madison Police responded to a report of an abduction that had occurred from a residence in the 4600 block of Atticus Way at 9:47pm.  A person who resides at this residence reported that a male suspect had just entered the home armed with a knife and forced a female into a dark colored, older and smaller station wagon with a loud muffler, and fled in an unknown direction.  (Possibly similar to the Ford Escort Wagon or older Subaru wagon)The suspect may be armed with a hunting style knife with a 4-7inch long blade.  Madison Police are currently looking for Anthony Steele, a 48 year old M/B, described as 5’02’’ – 5’03’’ tall, 180-190 pounds, short dark hair and seen wearing a dark-colored parka.  Steele is currently wanted on a warrant through the Department of Corrections and is considered a suspect in this investigation.  Madison Police believe that the suspect and the victim know each other and that this was not a random incident.The victim is described as a F/B, late 40’s, 5’09’’ tall, 130 pounds.  Madison Police ask that if anyone sees a vehicle matching this description, a person matching Steele description or appearance, or a person matching the victim’s description, that they call the police immediately.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator #1 is described as a male, black, 5'11", "chubby with big eyes", 30 years old, braided hair with pink beads on the end. He was the driver.Perpetrator #2 is described as a male, black, 25 years old, wearing a big white t-shirt, black jeans, and a do-rag.
properties.Address: 102 W. Corporate Drive Madison Metro East Transfer Point
properties.Details: On September 12th, at 12:45 p.m., two 16-year old girls reported they were approached by two men at the East Tranfer Point, 102 W. Corporate Drive. The young women said the men had - minutes earlier - driven slowly past them as they walked across Schenk Street at Milwaukee Street. At that point one of them offered them a ride. The men then did a u-turn and parked their SUV near the transfer point. It is described as a black or dark blue, boxy looking four-door similar to a Durango or Jeep Cherokee. The young women say the men attempted to engage them in conversation with perpetrator #1 asking them if they were 12 or 13 years old. He also rubbed one of the girl's leg. When the young women didn't respond to the overtures the men got back in their vehicle and drove away.

properties.Arrested: Devindra Bhagwandwin, male, 41, Madison:  Neglecting a Child
properties.Details: On 10/17/05 at approximately 12:41 a.m. Madison Police Officers responded to the Green Room Bar reference a child locked in a car.  Private security personnel had noticed the child shivering in a car in the bar's parking lot.  It was learned that the child was left in the car for over three hours while his father was inside drinking at the bar.  Officers noticed the temperature at the time to be 47 degrees.  The arrested father did not find fault for what had occurred and thought the temperature was warmer.  The child was returned to a safe relative, while the father was booked into the Dane County Jail.

properties.Arrested: Rachael Daramola, 26, Madison:  Child Neglect
properties.Details: On 8/22/06 at approximately 4:30 a.m. a Madison Police Officer was servicing another call when a concerned father of one of his children approached him.  The person told the officer that two children were left alone in the apartment, overnight, and one being his child.  The female children are nine and one years old.  Through the investigation, the officer learned that the children were alone, in their apartment, while their mother, Daramola, was sleeping at another person's apartment off of Northridge Terrace.  Daramola was arrested for child neglect and the children were placed in safekeeping.

On 1/29/07 a Madison Detective was investigating a report of child neglect.  While talking with the suspect, the detective noticed an IV tube and inquired about it.  The person ripped out the tube in a quick motion.  While taking out the IV, blood came out of the tube splattering on the detective's face, including the eye area.  The detective was treated for a significant exposure at a local hospital and eventually released.

properties.Arrested: Arrested:  Krystal R. Sanchez, 24YO, MadisonCharge: Neglecting a Child SS. 948.21(1)Status:  Dane County Jail
properties.Victim: Children ages 6, 3 and 1No injuries, however 1 year old child was ill with fever and rash
properties.Details: MPD officers responded to the report of a 1 year old child observed playing in the 4700 block of Milwaukee Street.  Upon arrival, officers located three children ages 6, 3 and 1 unattended and alone in the home.  Approximately 1 hour later, the mother returned home and told officers she had left the children alone while attending a baseball game in Fitchburg.  The children were later taken to an area hospital for a medical clearance and released to Dane County Human Services for placement.

properties.Arrested: Four 8-year old males
properties.Details: At approximately 2pm this date Madison Police received several calls from motorists related to four young male juveniles running across the Beltline in the 7300 block.Madison Officers located four 8-year old males near the Wal-Mart store on Watts Rd.  They apparently had parked their bikes on one side of the Beltline and ran to the other side.  It appears they made several trips.  There was some indication that the youngsters were trying to shoplift from area stores.  Officers released the juveniles to parents or guardians.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: As previously mentioned in a prior news release, Giancana has now been identified as the person who fell and has a head injury.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 1/28/06 at approximately 9:50 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to 2 Langdon for a report of a 5 year-old child who fell from the 5th floor apartment.  It was learned that the child was playing with another child in the apartment.  After a few minutes the adults looked for the children and saw that the screen to the window was missing.  It appeared the five year-old boy had opened the window and later pushed on the screen.  The family recently moved to Madison from another country to attend UW-Madison.  At this point the child is in stable condition.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Victim: 14-month-old male, extent of injuries unknown. Conveyed to the trauma center at UW HOspital by Madison fire/rescue.
properties.Details: At approx. 9:43 a.m. this date, officers responded to a residence in the 2300-blk of  E. Johnson St. regarding an infant that had fallen from the second floor balcony.  On arrival officers located the infant that was being attended to by fire/rescue personnel.  The child was conveyed to UW Hospital.  It appears the child was able to get out on a second floor balcony.  He then got to the railing where he was able to get threw the slats and then fell to either the porch or ground below.  A parent was home at the time.  No additional information at this time.

properties.Arrested: 49-yr old male resident of Madison
properties.Details: At approximately 9:37 am this date,Madison Police responded to the intersection of Whitney & Odana reference a disturbance.  Upon arrival, they located a 21-yr old female who was waiting for a bus.  The female was with a developmentally disabled adult for whom she is a caretaker.  The female told officers she had been approached by a male subject who was making threatening comments.  The subject approached her, grabbed her and threw her into a traffic lane as a bus was approaching.  The female was able to get out of the street and the subject attempted to throw her back into the traffic lane.  The male subject then left the area on foot.  Madison Police searched the area and located the male subject who was then taken into custody.  Madison Police are currently in the process of completing an emergency detention .  The subject will be conveyed to a secure facility when this is completed.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: At approximately 8:45 a.m. this date Madison Police responded to the downtown MATC campus reference a bomb threat.  Two calls were received by the school indicating there was a bomb set to go off.  School officials decided to evacuate the building.  The building was checked by school personnel and Madison Police personnel. Nothing was found in the building that was suspicious or out of order.  Students were allowed back into the building at approximately 9:36 a.m.  The incident remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: na
properties.Details: Madison Police are investigating an apparent explosion at the Dane County Ramp.  No persons were injured.  More details will follow at a later time.**UPDATE** Officials have determined that an improvised explosive devise did detonate at the Dane County Ramp.  No persons were injured.  A vehicle was damaged.  No known suspects.  No further information is available.  The investigation is continuing.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 1/12/06 at approximately 7:51 p.m. both Madison Police and Madison Fire personnel responded to an explosion that occurred on the porch of a residence in the 1300 block of Reetz Rd.  Officers learned that someone had place an explosive device on the front porch of an individual, rang the doorbell and fled.  As the female victim opened her door, the device exploded and some agents landed on her.  The victim called 911 immediately and did not seek medical attention.  At this point, there is not a connection to the comprehensive pipe-bomb investigation surrounding the downtown parking-ramp.  This case remains under investigation by the Madison Police Department.  Anyone with further information is encouraged to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.  Callers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Arrested: 14 year-old, Male, Juvenile Reception.  Charges:  Bomb Scare, Disorderly Conduct
properties.Details: On 1/17/06 at approximately 1:34 p.m. Madison Police responded to a report of a bomb scare at Hoyt School.  Officers learned that a student became disruptive in class after his antics with another student.  The teacher told the student that he would need to go home and his mother was called.  As the student was being escorted away he became more disruptive and eventually pulled the fire alarm.  It was at this time that the student threatened to bring a gun to school and shoot three teachers.  The student also stated he would bring a pipe bomb to school to blow everyone up.  The student went home with his mother.  On 1/18/06 officers went to re-interview the student at his home and was subsequently arrested on the above charges and taken to Juvenile Reception Center.  Threats to injure or kill school staff are taken seriously.

properties.Arrested: NA
properties.Details: At approximately 12:50 p.m. Madison Police responded to West High School for a report of a bomb threat.  School authorities made the decision to evacuate the school.  The school was checked by school staff and nothing suspicious was located. Students were brought back into the building at approximately 2:00 p.m. No additional information at this time.

properties.Arrested: Suspect(s): At large
properties.Details: On April 16, 2006, at approximately 3:39pm, a caller reported that a bomb was on a Madison Metro bus.  At approximately 4:08pm, a second report was made that advised that a bomb was under a Madison Metro bus.  As a precaution, two Madison Metro buses were evacuated and searched without incident.  This matter remains under investigation.  Anyone with information on this incident is urged to call the Madison Police Department at 266-4923 or Crimestoppers at 266-6014.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: At approximately 11:29 am this date, East High received a bomb threat.  As a precaution, it was decided to evacuate the school.  East High students are walking to nearby Emerson School.  Madison Police are assisting school officials.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 11/07/06, at approximately 10:36 a.m., Madison Police officers were dispatched to East High School reference a bomb threat. The school have received the threat earlier in the day around 9 a.m. Taking the threat very seriously and following safety procedures the decision was made to evacuate the school at 11:40 a.m. This decision also affected a polling station for today's elections which had to be temporarily closed. The City of Madison Clerk's office had a contingency plan which dealt with the situation.Madison Police officers as well as Madison Metropolitan School District officials dealt with the threat. Additional resources were requested and the Dane County Sheriff's Office Bomb Squad responded to the scene. After their assessment, the school was cleared and determined to be safe. Nothing was found. The school population was returned to the building by 2:45 p.m.The investigation is ongoing. If you have any information about the suspect or suspects in this incident, please call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Callers to Crime Stoppers can remain anonymous and may be eligible for a cash reward of up to $1000.

properties.Arrested: Sam Hinter, 17, Madison: Bomb Threats.Female, 16, Madison: Bomb Threats
properties.Details: On 11/13/06 at approximately 10:30 a.m. the Madison Police Department Education Resource Officer at West High School was alerted to information of a bomb threat at West High School.  After reviewing information, evidence and witness accounts Hinter and a female were arrested for Bomb Threats.  The Madison Police Department takes such threats seriously and investigates these cases to their full extent.

properties.Arrested: Male, 15, (East H.S. Student) Madison, Arrested and charged w/:  Bomb Scares. A feloy punishable up to $10,000 fine or imprisonment not to exceed 3 years and 6 months, or both.
properties.Details: On 1/22/07 at approximately 9:27 a.m. Madison East H.S. staff became aware of a bomb threat to the school. Madison Police were notified and established protocols were followed to evacuate students and search the building.   Nothing suspicious was located. The building was secured and students and faculty were allowed to return.   Further investigation led to an East H.S. student being identified as a suspect.  That student was contacted , interviewed and subsequently arrested. The individual stated it was meant to be a prank, but is now facing the above-listed felony charge. The Madison Police Department and the Madison Metropolitan School District want to stress the seriousness of this offense and will continue to aggressively investigate future incidents of this type to identify and hold those responsible accountable.

properties.Suspect: Avery I. Moore, age 18, MadisonMr. Moore was arrested and tentatively charged with three counts of bomb scare. ss. 947.015.
properties.Details: On May 13th, shortly after 10:00 a.m., Madison Police were notified of a bomb threat that had been phoned into East High School. Staff believed the same person who had made two similar calls in the past month had made this latest threat. They also believed they now knew the name of the student who was making the threats based on voice recognition. Officers found the suspect, and he later confessed the crimes to a detective. The suspect indicated these calls were only pranks, and he had no bomb making materials. The detective told the suspect just how serious threats like these are taken by school staff and police, and that they consume a great deal of time and resources.

(UPDATE AS OF 6:40 P.M.)The backpack, and any items in or around it, were rendered safe by the Dane County Bomb Squad. Madison Police Detectives, with assistance from agencies previously mentioned in the orginal incident report, will be investigating this case.---------------------------------(ORIGINAL RELEASE)At 1:53 p.m. Madison Police were called to the 10 block of East Main Street for a report of a suspicious package. A backpack was discovered hanging from a tree in front of the Walgreen Drug Store on the Capitol Square. This backpack had been on fire, and a U.S. Postal Carrier was able to put flames out utilizing a bottle of Gatorade. Madison Firefighters were called to the scene initially, and since that time more agencies have become involved in the investigation. Joining Madison Police and Fire are agents from the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms, and members of the Dane County Sheriff's Department Bomb Squad. Bomb Squad leaders determined there is reason to be suspicious of items in or near the backpack, because of that - as a precaution - an area of the Capitol Square has been cordoned off. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd. borders this area blocked to traffic on one side, while Main and King Streets mark the boundary on the other. Citizens are asked to stay away while the Bomb Squad can determine whether there is a real safety risk. Anyone who observed someone acting suspiciously in the area of the Capitol Square early this afternoon is urged to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014.

properties.Suspect: David R. Floyd, age 67, no permanent addressMr. Floyd has been taken into custody, and the Madison Police Department will recommend that the Dane County District Attorney charge him with Felony Bomb Scare, and Disorderly Conduct while Armed.
properties.Details: UPDATED 3:30 p.m. July 30th)Mr. David Floyd was taken into custody shortly after noon this afternoon. Construction workers observed Mr. Floyd attaching objects to a tree in front of the Walgreen's yesterday (see previous incident report), and were told by Madison Police Detectives to call immediately if they saw him again. They did see Mr. Floyd return to the Capitol Square, and he was quickly taken into custody. During this process Mr. Floyd threatened a Madison Police Detective with a straight-edged weapon.  Items of concern were found on Mr. Floyd's person, and on a bicycle that he was using. Because of this an area of the Capitol Square (between the Inn on the Park, and Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd.) has been shut down so the Dane County Bomb Squad could investigate these items. This process should not impact the Concert on the Square, and that festive gathering is on for tonight. One of the items Mr. Floyd is believed to have attached to the tree yesterday did appear to be some type of improvised explosive device. Whether or not it had any capability of actually exploding will be determined as its contents undergo forensic testing. Once again, the Madison Police Department would like to thank observant citizens - in this case the construction workers - for assistance in keeping Madison as safe as possible.-----------------------------------------------ORIGINAL RELEASEMPD Is currently investigating a suspicious package near this address on the Capital Square. Pending this investigation, the Capital Square and Capital are closed to public access. More information to follow soon.

A Madison Metro bus driver reported someone telling him there was a grenade in the bushes near the Woodman's gas station.  Upon further investigation, an apparent grenade was located and disposed of by the Dane County Bomb Squad.  The surrounding area was searched and no other explosives were located.  3800 Milwaukee Street and the surrounding areas are now open.  The investigation is continuing.

properties.Arrested: 35 year-old male, Madison
properties.Details: On 12/1/05 at approximately 12:38 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to an apartment in the 2000 block of Londonderry Dr. for an individual attempting suicide.  When police arrived the individual was holding a knife and threatened to die via police. A Madison Police Officer shouted verbal commands to the male to dropped the knife as he was actively cutting himself.  When the male failed to drop the knife, he was hit with the less-than-lethal beanbag.  The individual still maintained possession of the knife in his hand and was shot with the Taser, which yielded immediate compliance.  The male was taken into protective custody without further incident.

Officers responded to an address in the 1800 block of Boyd ave. reference a subject attempting to commit suicide by cutting himself.  When officers responded, they confronted the subject who was hiding behind a shed.  He came into view of the officers holding a large knife over his head in a threatening manner saying something similar to "what are you going to do, shoot me?"  Officers, who were approximately 15 feet away, directed him to drop the knife and then deployed the taser on the subject.  As a result of the taser deployment, officers were able to take the subject into protective custody without further incident.

properties.Arrested: Female, White, Age 22Taken to a local hospital with several self-inflicted knife wounds
properties.Details: In the early morning hours of Friday July 27th Madison Police responded to an apartment on Schroeder Road for a report of a suicidal subject. Officers found a 22-year-old woman near her infant child inside her apartment. She was bleeding from several self-inflicted wounds, and was now holding a knife over her head and pointing it at responding officers. She refused orders to drop the weapon, and instead stepped backward toward the infant who was on the floor in a bouncy chair. An electronic control device (the officer was using a taser brand ECD) was deployed and the suspect dropped the knife defusing the rapidly evolving situation before deadly force was needed to stop the threat. Earlier, the suspect was involved in a domestic fight. It escalated into the suicide attempt.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 12/5/2005 at approximately 7:58 a.m. both Madison Police and Madison Fire/Rescue responded to a report of a male falling through the ice in Monona Bay.  It was learned the male was walking across the bay from the south end and nearly made it when he fell through the ice about 100 yards from Brittingham Park.  The male was taking a shortcut in his walk to work.  Fortunately as the man screamed for help, two ice fishermen heard him and called 911. The male dug a sharp instrument into the ice to prevent him from falling further into the water until rescuers arrived. Two Madison Firefighters wore their wetsuits and rescued the individual through the use of ropes and clamps.  The male was transported to a local hospital where his condition is unknown at this time.  He was in the water for approximately 15 minutes.  It is apparent that although cold temperatues exist, not all the ice is safe enough to walk on yet.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 1/9/2006 at approximately 7:58 p.m. several Madison Police Officers responded to a report of a bomb going off in the parking lot of an address in the 6900 block of East Pass.  Witnesses described hearing a large "boom", seeing smoke and smelling chemicals.  There were not any injuries associated with this incident.  At this time, there does not appear to be any connection to the pipe-bomb investigation currently happening in the downtown area.  Evidence collected at the scene appears to be inconsistent with previous incidents downtown.  This incident remains under investigation.

properties.Arrested: Kathleen Brown, 25, Madison:  2nd deg Recklessly Endangering Safety, OMVWI (2nd offense), OMVWI/Prohibited Alcohol Concentration (2nd offense)
properties.Details: On 12/6/05 at approximately 12:18 a.m. Madison Police responded to a bar in the 700 block of S. Gammon Rd reference an intoxicated female who left her son unattended in the car, while she was drinking alcohol inside.  Officers learned that Brown was inside the bar drinking while her four year-old son was outside in the car, unrestrained in the backseat.  It was estimated the child was left in the car for approximately 30 minutes and the officers noted the temperature to be zero degrees outside.  An unknown male noticed the child in the car, which was not running and was unlocked, and brought him inside the bar.  Employees and the male were able to link the child to the mother (Brown) who had been going in and out of the bar checking on her son.  Brown was arrested on the above charges and brought to the Dane County Jail, while her son was released to the care of a relative.

properties.Arrested: M/W 40'S WEARING A DARK "BOMBER", BLUE DEMIM SHIRT WITH TAN SLEEVES, 509,175
properties.Details: ON 3-14-2006 OFFICERS WERE SENT TO A BUSINESS IN THE 3000 BLK OF EAST WASHINGTON AVE. THERE WAS SOME CONFUSION WHEN A EMPLOYEE OF THE BUISNESS MADE CONTACT WITH THE SUBJECT. SHE THOUGHT HE HAD SOME TYPE OF INJURY TO HIS ABDOMEN. HE HAD LEFT THE AREA PRIOR TO THE POLICE ARRIVAL. POLICE SEARCHED THE AREA FOR OVER AN HOUR AND LATER LOCATED HIM NEAR S.MARQUETTE ST. AND EAST WASHINGTON AVE. WHEN THE POLICE LOCATED HIM, HE DID NOT HAVE ANY INJURY AT ALL, BUT SIMPLY HAD BEER SPILLED ON THE FRONT OF HIS SHIRT. IT WAS A BIG MISUNDERSTANDING. THE SUBJECT WAS INTOXICATED AND CONVEYED TO HIS RESIDENCE.

properties.Arrested: Lamar Williams, 46, Madison Wisconsin
properties.Details: Police were dispatched to 1002 Spring Street reference a man who was yelling and screaming for anyone to let him into the apartment building.  Police arrived and spoke with residents that gave descriptions of the suspect, and after canvassing the building found Williams (who was not a resident) in the parking garage level of the building.  Williams had a sleeping bag in his possession and had placed his personal items around in such a way that he was going to get comfortable for the night and use the hallway as a place to sleep!  Williams was contacted and arrested on separate and unrelated charges.  Officers did find a security locked door that either had a malfunctioning lock or was not completely closed by residents of the building (entering or exiting).Residents of apartment buildings or single/multi-family dwellings should pay particular attention to security doors, and make sure they are securely locked when they enter or exit a building.  Incidents such as what has been described above happen frequently, and the safety of all residents could be at risk if these simple measures are not adhered to.  Security locked doors exist for the safety and protection of all individuals that reside within the confines of that particular building and The Madison Police Department wants you to know that safety is the business of everyone!

properties.Arrested: Kevin F. Howard, age 56, MadisonArrested on 2 counts of Disorderly Conduct
properties.Victim: Male White, Age 22, UW Madison StudentMale White, Age 22, UW Madison Student
properties.Details: On Monday evening, September 24th, around 10:33 p.m. Madison Police responded to the 1200 block of Spring Street. A UW student reports that he was in his residence when he heard a tap on the window. He looked out and saw man with "silver hair". The student went to the door, at which time the suspect asked if he was interested in having recreational sex. The student slammed the door. One of his roommates, also a UW student, then got on his bicycle and followed the suspect. The second student reports that while doing this the suspect also propositioned him. The suspect was located in the area by police and charged with two counts of disorderly conduct.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, late 20's-early 30's, 5'10", average build, brown hair that was spiky in the front, facial stubble, chest hair sticking out from top of green t-shirt, also wearing blue jeans.
properties.Details: On Thursday January 17th at 6:34 p.m. a 23-year-old mother contacted Madison Police about a disturbing event that transpired inside her apartment between 7:30 and 8:00 p.m. the night prior. She says she left her door unlocked while running downstairs to do a load of laundry. When she returned to her residence she says her six-year-old son, and her two-year-old daughter were seated in the living room, both wide-eyed and staring into the kitchen. The mom looked that way and was shocked to see a stranger. She told officers he looked "high". The man ran her way. She punched him a few times, and also delivered a kick. The guy said nothing and ran off. The woman reports seeing him get into an older model maroon car. It sort of looked like a Ford Taurus to her. She said she waited to report the incident because she was shocked and unsure what to do. The responding officer advised her to immediately contact 911 in situations like this one.

properties.Suspect: Byron M. Mitchell, age 19, MadisonMr. Mitchell was arrested and tentatively charged with Disorderly Conduct (2 counts), and a Probation Hold.
properties.Details: On Monday, around 10:30 a.m., Madison Police officers were called to an area near West Gate Mall after employees of the shopping center had been chasing a man who had been in a women's bathroom. Mall staff had received a complaint from a woman who had been using the bathroom around 9:40 a.m. The woman was in a stall and observed a man peeping over the top of it from an adjoining stall. The employees decided to conduct a sting wherein a female staff member went into the bathroom and pretended to be "using" it. She was aware someone was in a stall, but she could not tell who it was. When the staff member rattled the toilet paper holder the suspect's head popped up above the stall. Startled, the employee ran out and informed a male colleague of her encounter. A few seconds later the suspect came running out of the restroom, and ran out an exit door. The employees chased the man eastbound on Tokay Boulevard, but lost him. One of the responding officers saw a suspect matching a description given by those who had been involved in the initial pursuit. The employees later identified him as the man who was peeping in the bathroom stall.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, white, mid-30's, slender build, 6'0", short brown hair, acne scars on face, wearing a navy blue pullover and blue jeans.
properties.Details: Early Sunday morning, around 4:15 a.m., a woman in her 20's called for help after she was awakened to the sounds of a man banging on her apartment door. The victim says he also tried to open the door. She looked out a peephole and said the man appeared to be a person she had seen a few times in her neighborhood and that this person had once tried to follow her into the building. On another occasion she said he appeared to be passed out in front of her home.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, black, 40-50 years old, 5'7", 190 lbs., wearing sunglasses, baby blue skullcap, white t-shirt, dark blue athletic shorts, and a pinky ring. He also had some type of tattoo on his left forearm.
properties.Details: Shortly before 3:00 Wednesday afternoon a City of Madison lifeguard contacted the Madison Police Department after a man showed up at Esther Beach and started playing with his private parts. The guard said the man did this while grabbing himself on the outside of his shorts. She says this went on for 10 to 15 minutes while children were in the water. She told the man to leave, but he refused. Officers canvassed the area but were unable to find the offender. The guard did not think any of the children observed what he was doing.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Address: 113 S. Henry Street-Capitol Square South Ramp (Dane County Ramp)
properties.Details: SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY/OBJECTS IN PARKING RAMPS The Madison police Department, in conjunction with County, State and Federal Agencies, are conducting investigations into the recent incidents at the Dane County Parking Ramp. In November two suspicious objects were located and on Saturday, 12/24 an object explode in the ramp damaging a car. All of these objects were in plain view.The Law Enforcement agencies involved recommend the following precautions when using public parking facilities from the City, County and/or private sector:1.  Be aware of your surroundings when working, parking or walking in the ramps or area around them.2.  When you leave your vehicle, make sure it is locked.3.  After your return, check around and underneath your vehicle for any suspicious objects.4.  If you observe a suspicious object:    a. DO NOT TOUCH THE OBJECT    b. MOVE AWAY FROM THE OBJECT TO A SAFE DISTANCE (300-600ft.)    c. CALL 911, GIVING LOCATION AND DESCRIPTION OF OBJECT AS WELL AS ANY      INDIVIDUALS/SUBJECTS AROUND IT.5.  If you observe any suspicious activity, call 911.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: The Madison Police Department along with the FBI, ATF, DCI, Dane County Sheriffs Office and other local law enforcement agencies are continuing to investigate recent incidents at the Dane County Ramp, 113 S. Henry St.  Two suspicious objects were found in November and on Dec. 24, an object exploded in the ramp.Law enforcement recommends everyone adhere to the following precautions when using any public parking facilities:1.  Be aware of your surroundings when working, parking or walking to the ramps or areas around them.2.  Lock your vehicle.3.  After you return, check around and underneath your vehicle for any suspicious objects.  If you see a suspicious object:  a: DO NOT TOUCH THE OBJECT  b: MOVE AWAY FROM THE OBJECT TO A SAFE DISTANCE (300-600 FT.)  c: CALL 911, GIVE THE LOCATION AND DESCRIPTION OF THE OBJECT AS WELL AS ANY INDIVIDUALS AROUND IT5.  If you observe any suspicious activity, call 911.There will be heightened patrols of all downtown public parking ramps and other facilities.Madison Police are continuing to investigate the incidents.The FBI and ATF have authorized a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons responsible for the pipe bombing incident on December 24, 2005.If you have any information related to this incident, call Madison Area Crimestoppers at 266-6014, ATF at 1-888-ATF-BOMB, or 911.

properties.Arrested: Under investigation
properties.Details: On March 07, 2006 at 4:35pm, The Madison Police Department was dispatched to the 400 block of West Doty Street reference a possible kidnapping/abduction.  A witness to the event stated she saw approximately three male subjects involved in kidnapping a person.  One of the suspects was holding a black semi-automatic handgun.  The witness stated the gunman made gestures to the victim to get into a dark colored car, and the vehicle pulled away.  Officers from the Madison Police Department checked the area in an exhaustive search to find the vehicle/victim, but nothing developed as a result of those initial efforts.  Upon further review by a Madison Police Detective, it was determined that there were additional facts that explained what really transpired.  A black handgun was recovered (Glock facsimile), and the investigation is continuing.Several students had in fact staged this entire event as part of a filming project, where they would duct tape an alleged victim and put him in the trunk of a vehicle at gun point.  This was allegedly a scenario done for entertainment purposes, and was done based on information regarding another incident occurring within our city where a kidnapping had been staged in the last year. The Madison Police Department does understand the academic value that a project of this nature might bring, but individuals that are thinking of involving themselves in projects such as this should notify the proper authorities (local police).  The public should also understand that without proper notification of such activities, people are subject to the risk of an adversarial contact with a responding police officer.  We want to maintain a harmonious relationship with the community, especially when it involves activities of academic enrichment.  We do not want police officers to be placed in a compromising position of making a deadly force decision when communication could have prevented any such problems.  PO Howard Payne

Officers responded to the Dane County Parking Ramp after a suspicious item was located on the third floor.  The ramp was cleared and the streets surrounding the ramp were closed for approximately 2 hours.  Dane County EOD (bomb squad) was called to the scene and later determined that the item was not a bomb, but possbily a windchime or similar looking object.

On Tuesday morning, not long after sunup, Madison Police began receiving complaints from many city residents who had awakened to find flat tires on their parked vehicles. On the windshields of at least some were notes like, "happy fossil fool's day - drive less." It should be noted that this is April Fool's Day. So far more than 30 such calls have come in from citizens who live along -- or near -- Monroe Street, Williamson Street, and Langdon Street. It appears air was let out of tires overnight. No permanent damage has been discovered.

properties.Victim: MISSING/POSSIBLY ENDANGERED ADULT: Chong Thao22 Years Old
properties.Details: ******************** UPDATED JUNE 15TH ********************* Mr. Thao was found deceased in Nevada. His death has been ruled a suicide.***************************************************************On 5/19 family notified MPD that Chong Thao, age 22, has not been in contact with them since Thursday, May 17. Family reports it is very unusual for Thao not to at least check-in with them. Thao lived at home with his parents and just graduated from college. It's believed Thao was going to spend time with friends celebrating his college graduation at the time he went missing. Anyone with information is asked to call Madison Crimestoppers at 266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and maybe eligible for a cash reward.

The Madison Police Department has located several people who were out in the downtown area in the early hours of Saturday morning (June 23rd) who are believed to have had contact with Kelly Nolan. These people are providing detectives with information, as are a number of new callers to the Crime Stoppers tips line (266-6014). A team of detectives is checking out all leads. The Madison Police Department is also releasing a photograph of a handbag that is similar to the one Nolan is believed to have been carrying at the time of her disappearance.At this time, no evidence has been found that would indicate foul play. This remains a missing persons case.The MPD is appreciative of the community’s efforts in helping find Kelly Nolan.-------------------------------------------------------------------------It is believed Kelly Nolan may have been wearing a green, sleeveless, scooped neck shirt and blue jeans at the time she went missing. She may also have been carrying a handbag. Madison Police are doing routine checks of areas in the downtown in an effort to find Kelly. These have included calling hospitals, and walking shorelines. The Dane County Lakes Patrol is also assisting. Dive teams have taken a look at areas along Isthmus shorelines. Nolan's family last heard from her early Saturday morning. At that time it's believed she was in downtown Madison. That is why those areas have received some concentrated efforts.*****************************UPDATED INFORMATION (AROUND THURSDAY NOON) ***********************A printable missing poster of Kelly is accessible at facebook.com. Kelly's family is looking for help in distributing the the flier. If you would be willing to assist, please go to www.facebook.com . Once you are on the site type in "Kelly Nolan", and you will find the printable poster. The family, in advance, would like to thank those assisting in this search.________________________________________________________________The Madison Police Department is seeking citizen help in locating a 22-year-old Madison woman. Kelly Nolan was last heard from in the early morning hours of Saturday June 23rd.   Nolan is 5’5”, 125 pounds, with brown eyes and brown hair. Anyone with information is urged to call Crimestoppers at 266-6014. Callers can remain anonymous and maybe eligible for a cash reward.

properties.Suspect: ****UPDATE****JESSICA AND DOMINIK HAVE BEEN FOUND ( NOVEMBER 13TH AT 2:00 P.M.) AND ARE WELL ...THANKS EVERYONE FOR HELPING GET THE WORD OUT******** A photo of Jessica & Dominik was attached to this release on November 13, 2007 *****
properties.Details: On November sixth a housemate of Jessica A. Wyman, age 23, reported to Madison police that Ms. Wyman and her five-month old son Dominik Wyman, had not been around the Lakeview Avenue home since the afternoon of November fifth. Ms. Wyman is described as being 5'04", 120 pounds, with brown hair and hazel eyes. She drives a red Dodge Neon with Wisconsin license plate number THU-333. Anyone with information about the mother and child is asked to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014.

On Friday January 11, 2008 at 6:34 a.m.  Madison Police received a report of a missing woman. Gloria Hoplite, age 58, was last seen by a family member when she left her home on Monday January 7, 2008. The family member says she was walking and did not take a car. Mrs. Hoplite is described as being 5'3" and 160 pounds. She has brown eyes and gray hair. Her home is near the Woodman's Grocery Store on Milwaukee Street. Anyone with information about Mrs. Hoplite is asked to call Crime Stoppers at 266-6014. Her family has indicated it is out of character for her to be away this number of days.As of 7pm, Madison Police received information that Gloria Hoplite had been located, uninjured.  Mrs. Hoplite stated she left her home on her own accord.  No other information is available at this time.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 2/12/06 at approximately 10:12 a.m. the Madison Police and Fire Department were dispatched to the 4400 block of Prairieview Drive for a report of a truck backing over their 15 month-old child.  Both mother and father were leaving their driveway in separate vehicles when the accident occurred.  As she was backing, the mother thought the child was already in the father's vehicle's car seat.  The toddler walked behind the mother's vehicle as she was backing and was completely run over.  Miraculously there was no apparent injury to the child.  Paramedics who also did not find any injury checked the child.

The east and westbound beltline is currently shut down from Rimrock Rd to Verona Rd.  Numerous traffic crashes are reported and continue to come in, including a 15 car pile up, a jack knifed semi and a six car pile-up to name a few.  The Beltline is slick due to the weather and drivers should use extreme caution in travels today.  Officers report high speeds, inattentive driving and lack of distance between vehicles as some reasons for these crashes.

Motorist was approaching roundabout near this address when his accelator stuck causing him to lose control and collide with a house on Rustic Ridge.  Vehicle struck house, going completely through the structure, emerging on the backside of the house.  While damage to the house was significant, it does not appear that the house is in danger of collapse.  The investigation regarding this incident is continuing.

properties.Suspect: Michael N. Bentz, age 44, MadisonMr. Bentz was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle while Under the Influence - sixth offense, Inattentive Driving, Operating a Motor Vehicle with a Restricted Controlled Substance.
properties.Details: On Saturday, April 26th around 1:11 a.m., Madison police responded to a two-car crash in the 2900 block of Irvington Way. Officers discovered a Cadillac, that had been legally parked on the street, was now partially up on the curb on the south side of the road. The driver's side of the car was heavily damaged. Just beyond the Cadillac there was Mazda - facing westbound - and it was stopped in the oncoming lane of traffic. It had damage to the front left driver's side area. Inside the car was Mr. Bentz. He told police he had reached down for a cigarette when he believed he struck a moving vehicle - possibly a truck. The officer directed Mr. Bentz' attention to the parked and damaged Cadillac. Mr. Bentz agreed it was possible that was what he had struck. Bentz told the officer he had taken four Ambien sleeping pills approximately a half-hour before driving.

Madison Metro bus driver inadvertently released the parking brake of the bus while going to the rear of the bus to check the back door. The bus rolled forward and up on to the curb where it struck a utility pole; causing it to fall on top of the bus with live wires on the bus as well as the ground. The driver told to remain on bus until the arrival of MG&E. Road was blocked off by patrol units for approximately 2 hours for saftety reasons.  The driver was utlimately cited for inattentive driving. There were no injuries.

The east bound lanes of the Beltline were shut down for approximately one hour this afternoon due to a multiple vehicle accident.  A Town of Madison Police Officer was struck, causing a chain reaction, while conducting a traffic stop.  Minor injuries were sustained by one involved party.

properties.Suspect: Jeremiah J. Hoefle, age 20, WaunakeeMr. Hoefle was arrested and tentatively charged with Operating a Motor Vehicle While Under the Influence, Reckless Driving, and Underage Person Consumes Alcohol Off Licensed Premises.
properties.Details: Early Wednesday morning, around 1:50 a.m., Madison Police responded to North Lake Street and Lake Mendota after receiving information that a car had just driven in to the water. A responding officer discovered there was a 1999 Buick Century about 75-feet from the shoreline. The officer could see about two feet of the rear of the car, which was still above water. The rest of the Buick was submerged. A man wearing wet clothes approached the officer and said this was entirely his fault, that he "must have taken a wrong turn." The driver said he was not injured and was able to swim safely to shore. A motorcyclist told officers the car had nearly hit him at the corner of State and Lake Streets just before it entered the lake. The wet driver told officers he was alone in the Buick, but the Dane County Sheriff's Department Dive Team was called in just to make sure that was the case. It was.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 2/5/06 at approximately 4:45 p.m. Madison Police Officers responded to several 911 calls about a dog fight in the courtyard of 661 Mendota Ct.  When officers arrived, they learned that a 6-month dachshund had been killed by a three year-old pitbull.  Three pitbulls were out in the courtyard without a leash when the owner of the dachshund (on a leash) entered. A care-taker of the pitbull had a brief conversation with the dachshund's owner about the pitbull not liking other dogs.  It was at this point that the pitbull attacked the dachshund and people tried unsuccessfully to save the dog.  The pitbull was quarantined and the owner and care-givers were issued citations by an Animal Control Officer.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 2/5/06 at approximately 4:00 p.m. Madison Police responded to an animal complaint in the 1600 block of Golden Oak Lane.  It was learned that a pit bull named "psycho" ran out of the house and attacked a Labrador.  "Psycho" has a history of running out of the house, but in the past had never attacked another dog or human.  The owner of "psycho" stated that the dog couldn’t be restrained in the house, as he is too strong and would pull away from anything inside.  Once outside, the pit bull attacked the lab, biting it on the neck several times and bringing it to the ground multiple times.  The lab was taken to the emergency animal hospital for immediate care.  An animal control officer was summoned and took the lead in this investigation.

On 4/7/06 at approximately 4:45 p.m. two Madison Police Officers were dispatched to a residence in the 5800 block of Barton Rd for a motion detector alarm.  The officers observed that one of the front windows was broken out, yet the rest of the exterior was secure.  As officers entered the home they heard a noise in the kitchen.  As they approached the dark kitchen, an enormous bird flew at them and it turned out to be a wild turkey.  Officers came out of the house to compose themselves of what they learned . . . a viscous wild turkey was tormenting the house.  Officers reached an Animal Control Officer who stated that there have been a number of wild turkey complaints in Madison as it was mating season.  Animal Control advised to get a large blanket and coax the turkey from behind into leaving out the door.  That failed.  The turkey was standing in the corner of the room with its beak pressed into a corner and it didn’t appear to be injured.  Now the bird was pecking its beak into the corner, relentlessly.  The officers obtained a small cup of water and threw it on the turkey’s head, but it didn’t move, only stopped pecking.  Officers then arranged furniture in the room to funnel the turkey out the door.  That failed because the turkey ran down the funnel, but continued upstairs.  The turkey went behind a couch in the study upstairs.  The officer did not want to continue to have the turkey damage the room to the large extent it had downstairs, so the officer used a taser to subdue it.  The first shock to the back of the turkey only froze it in place.  The turkey then flew around and broke the light fixture.  A second deployment of the taser worked as the turkey flew down the hallway, stairs and out the front door.

properties.Arrested: Marcus Hamilton, 25, Madison: Mistreating Animals
properties.Details: On 8/22/06 at 3:20 a.m. Madison Police responded to an animal complaint.  Officers learned that a house cat had died due to strangulation.  The cat's owner had called a veterinarian after learning of the cat's trauma.  Originally the cat's owner believed the cat died of different means.  After an investigation and calls to the veterinarian, it was learned that Hamilton had actually strangled the cat for defecating on the carpet.  In being upset with the cat, Hamilton strangled the cat's throat with his hands for 1-2 minutes.  Hamilton was arrested on the above felony, where he was transported to the Dane County Jail.  The cat was a gray and white, mixed breed.

properties.Arrested: -Kale Bodendein, 19, UW student from Lone Rock, WI-Eric Anderson, 19, MATC student from Lone Rock, WI-Kyle Cozine, 18, from Plain, WI-Jacob Leeck, 20, Madison Media Institute student from Plain, WI-Morgan Bascom, 20 from Middleton, WICitations included:  Noise complaint, Procuring for or furnishing alcohol beverages to underage person, Dispensing alcohol without permit, underage drinking
properties.Details: On 2/4/06 at approximately 11:30 p.m., the Madison Police Department was dispatched to 621 E. Johnson St. reference a disturbance.  Once officers arrived, they found a male victim who is a Madison resident.  The victim and witnesses told the police that approximately eight white males had exited from 621 E. Johnson St., pushed the victim to the ground and kicked him.  With this information the officers tried to make contact at 621 E. Johnson St. to identify suspects and/or witnesses.  The officers could hear a large party occurring inside the residence.  When officers attempted contact at the door, they were told to go away and that they could not come in.  No one answered the door to an obvious party inside.  The Central Community Police Team assisted Patrol Officers with the incident and subsequent investigation.  Residents were not cooperative with the investigation.  As a result of the investigation into the house party, a total of $54,000.00 in tickets were issued to the persons hosting the party.  The battery complaint remains under investigation.  The victim was treated by Madison Fire/Rescue and refused any further medical treatment.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: At approximately 10:45 p.m. on 03/03/2006, Madison police responded to a report of a large house party and disturbance in the 800 block of East Gorham Street.  Officers responded and located a party in a residence.  They noted some of the participants out on the street.  Officers were able to contact 61 underage drinkers and 7 underage individuals who had not been drinking but were attending the party.  It appeared a majority of people at the party were high school students from Memorial High School.  Officers made arrangements for parents or adults to pick up the individuals involved so that they would get home safely.  One individual was taken to the juvenile detox center at University Hospital because of his level of intoxication.  The investigation of this matter is continuing.  No other information is available at this time.

properties.Arrested: Cindy A Fraser, 21 year old female of Madison
properties.Victim: 16 year old male taken to U.W.ER/Detox for excessive alcohol consumption
properties.Details: On March 3rd, 2006 at approximately 11:45p.m, Officers were dispatched to 811 E. Gorham Street in reference to a naked woman running in the area.  It was also reported that people were running out into the street playing “Chicken” with the cars driving past.  A 16-year-old male from Madison was found passed out on a fence near this residence and had been consuming alcohol at this location.  He would later be transported to U.W.ER based on medical concerns of excessive alcohol consumption.  The 16 year old reported to officers that the party at 811 E. Gorham contained 50-100 James Madison Memorial Students and that there was at least one keg of beer in the party.Officers stood by at the residence for approximately 3 hours before a resident arrived home and gave them permission to enter.  The amount of time that was expended was based on information that Madison Officers had about juveniles on location that were in potential danger; with no responsible adult monitoring activities at the residence.  A number of Officers identified approximately 70 students from James Madison Memorial High School; all of which had been drinking in the party with the exception of only 9!   The names of the students involved will be shared with school officials.The adult throwing the party was Cindy A. Fraser, 21-year-old female from Madison.  Officers found three empty ½ barrels of beer in the house.  All activites were directed by a Madison Police Seargent of the Central Community Policing Team.  Hard work and resilient effort by all members of the Central CPT brought about proper investigation of this matter.  This investigation is ongoing, and charges/citations could be forthcoming as the Madison Police Department works with The City Attorney’s Office on an appropriate course of action.PO Howard Payne

On Saturday night, August 11th, Madison Police, with the help of some young volunteers,  randomly went to 10 convenience/liquor stores. None of the young volunteers had IDs, and all were under 21 years old. They attempted to buy alcohol. They were successful in doing so in three places. In those cases the alcohol was returned after purchase. Police got their money back, and the establishments received $361 tickets for violating a city ordinance (Procuring for, or, Furnishing Alcohol Beverages to Underage Person.) The following establishments refused to sell to the young people:Zimmer's 4217 W. Beltline HwyParadise Liquors 3179 Muir Field Rd.Part Port, 2901 University Ave.Steve's Liquor, 8302 Mineral Point RoadMobile, 4601 Verona Rd.Kelly's Market, 901 S. Gammon Rd.BP gas station, 6202 Schroeder Rd.----------------------------------The following three establishments were cited:El Mercadito, 916 S. Whitney WayCitgo, 6702 Mineral Point RoadSpeedway, 1402 Verona Road

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 2/14/06 at approximately 8:15 a.m. the Madison Memorial High School Educational Resource Officer was alerted to a locker in the school, as it was reported that a gun was found in a locker.  The officer stated in the report that it was a very realistic looking gun and had the imprint “Smith and Wesson” and a magazine clip attached.  The officer ascertained that the weapon was not real as it is considered an “airsoft” gun.  Police confiscated the weapon and it is not known who the owner is.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: Each day Madison Police Officers respond to reports of stolen and found property.  On 6/19/06 an officer responded to an account of found property in which two sisters (age 4 & 5) became very thoughtful and generous.  An officer took a report of a found wallet in the backyard of a residence in the 3100 block of Thorp St.  The mother of the two children stated the wallet must have been thrown in their yard recently as they generally play back there and did not recognize the wallet previously.  Other than the ID of the owner, there was not anything left in the wallet.  The two daughters suggested they should contribute their own money, from their piggy bank, to the person who apparently had their wallet stolen.  Mom also that this was a good idea and contributed money.  In the end, they donated $20.76 back into the wallet before it was turned over to the police officer who returned it to the victim.  The wallet had been stolen the previous day.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 6/15/06 around 3 p.m. a Madison Police Officer took a report of found property in the 300 block of North St.  A concerned citizen witnessed a suspicious person place a brief case in the bushes along the parking lot side of the "Sand Lot Tavern".  The item turns out to be a very expensive label maker.  No one has claimed the label maker and the Madison Police Department would like to return it to the rightful owner.  The claimant can provide a detailed description of the item to the Madison Police Property Room at 266-4955.

properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Details: At approximately 1 pm this date, an honest citizen turned in some cash to the Madison Police Department.  The money has been placed into the property room of the Madison Police Department.  Anyone wishing to claim the money should contact the Madison Police Department property room at 266-4955.  Any callers will be expected to identify themselves, and the exact amount of money that was lost. The money was found at the intersection of Mound and Randall St.

properties.Address: 4000 Commercial Ave. & Stoughton Rd. at Hwy 30 (UPDATED THURSDAY AUG. 2)
properties.Details: Following the initial press release Madison Police received a call from a Jefferson County Detective Sgt., and it appears the mystery of the quarters has been solved.It turns out a Loomis armored truck going from Milwaukee to Madison on July 23rd lost some of its load, and not all in one spot. The Jefferson County Det. Sgt. reports they responded to mile markers 270-271 of westbound I-94, just east of Johnson Creek, on the 24th of July following a tip from a semi-driver about a large number of quarters in- and along- the highway. The "I" had to be shut down as deputies, working a 100-yard long stretch of road, picked up the cash; some of which was in rolls, some of which was now loose. A total of $3,200 in quarters was recovered, and the Det. Sgt. reports $500 in quarters was destroyed from being hit by passing traffic. He says Loomis was cited for failure to prevent a leaking load. On the 29th of July the same Det. Sgt. reports an additional $199.75 (in quarters) was recovered (in Jefferson County) from along I-94 near mile marker 268 of the westbound lanes.Loomis reports a total of $8,000 was lost on the 23rd, and that $4,500 worth of quarters has been found for return to the company. ----------------------------------------------------------Madison Police are not offering a penny for citizen’s thoughts, but are seeking help in solving a case involving hundreds of dollars in spilt quarters. Detectives do not know if they were stolen, or dropped, but they were discovered in two locations on consecutive days last month. First a fellow riding a bicycle called police shortly before 11:30 p.m. on July 23rd saying he had just spotted a large number of quarters on the roadway in the 4000 block of Commercial Ave. Many were in boxes, others were just scattered about. Those scattered about looked as if they had been packaged in rolls, but the rolls had likely burst after being run over. This first batch of quarters tallied $303.50. The very next day, on July 24th, around 5:35 a.m., a second batch of quarters was discovered at the intersection of N. Stoughton Road and Highway 30. These were also packaged in boxes and rolls similar to those recovered a night earlier. The tally with on this find was $499.75. The quarters - $803.50 worth - are now in an MPD property locker.

On Saturday, August 11, at 3:17 Madison Police were called to Good Will Industries after an employee found a handgun inside a metal donation cart. The cart had been left outside the building, and a Good Will manager tells police someone made the donation sometime between 11:30 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. that day. Police took custody of a .38 Special revolver, as well as the box it came in. In addition, a box of .38 caliber ammunition had also been given to Good Will.

properties.Suspect: N/A
properties.Arrested: N/A
properties.Victim: Contact: Terry L. Gerrits - Madison Wisconsin
properties.Details: On 6/16/08 at approximately 2:38pm a concerned citizen called Madison Police reference some paper blowing in the street.  Upon further inspection, Gerrits discovered that the paper was actually a large amount of cash bills.  He immediately got out of his vehicle, as he had been traveling westbound on East Washington Avenue between East Springs Drive and Zeier Road, to secure the currency.  He made sure the police were immediately contacted and stood by for their response.  Suddenly random vehicles started to stop at his location to make claims of the money.  One subject actually got out of his vehicle and approached Gerrits stating, “I lost my money”.  Gerrits remained calm and told this subject to standby for police and they would deal with his concern.  Gerrits advised that this subject immediately left the scene and never returned!  Just minutes later, a different vehicle would stop by this location and a female would approach the curbside where bills were still blowing in the wind & would grab some of the money from the ground.  Police would arrive on scene to secure $890.00 in cash.Many of the releases that are completed reflect negative situations that occur in our city daily, but Gerrits personified the very essence of what a “Good Samaritan” is all about.  Gerrits stood by with the funds and did the appropriate thing by contacting the police in this matter.  Gerrits placed himself in danger by way of vehicular traffic and concerns about individuals that wanted to make street-level claims of these funds that they had no right to.  All serial numbers were reflected from all bills recovered, and appropriate protocols will be followed with the security of the currency.PO Howard PayneMadison Police Department

properties.Address: East Wilson Street near South Hancock Street
properties.Details: On Thursday morning, a husband and wife - both in their early 50's - came to the Central District of the Madison Police Department wishing to turn in some found property. The woman said she was walking along East Wilson Street around 4:45 p.m. on Wednesday afternoon when she spotted something in the street - very near the curb. That something was a bundle of cash. The woman says another passerby had just gone strolled by the stack of 20-dollar bills, but evidently did not see it. She picked up the red rubber band bound wad and took it home to show her husband. They decided they should turn it over to authorities. A Madison Police officer sat down with the couple and counted the bills. There were 45. They looked fairly new. They were crisp. They did not have any dye on them that might indicate they were taken in a bank robbery - anything like that. The officer made the observation that drug money would not typically be in this type of order or condition. He praised the couple for their honesty and high ethical standards in bringing in the $1,000. They have asked to have their identities not made public.

properties.Arrested: Billy Goat Gruff, still at large
properties.Details: Officer Scott Sachtjen was sent out to check on an ill-tempered stray goat on the Schoenstatt Sisters of Mary property.  Officer Sachtjen confirmed that the goat was still wandering the property and giving him the "evil eye" when he approached.  The Dane County Humane officer arrived to try to take the goat into custody, but the goat successfully evaded capture.  There have been similar goat sightings in the area mostly in the early morning.
