AN IMMIGRANT FROM COSTA RICA, MILLIE THE GATA (CAT) HAD GONE MISSING FOR TWO WEEKS.POSTERS WERE POSTED AND SIDEWALKS WERE WALKED LOOKING FOR THIS MADISONIAN .... TO NO AVAIL ... UNTIL A CITIZEN, STANDING ALONGSIDE A SEWER GRATE PICKED UP ON THE DISTRESSED MEWS IN THE SEWER BELOW.THIS FINE CITIZEN ALERTED THE POLICE WHO CONTACTED THE STREETS DEPARTMENT AND MILLIE WAS RESCUED.HOW MANY LIFETIMES MILLIE CASHED IN DURING HER ABSENCE IS UNKNOWN.MILLIE IS RESTING COMFORTABLY AT HOME AND CERTAINLY HAS CAUSE TO BE GRATEFUL AS SHE CELEBRATES A WARM THANKSGIVING.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Details: On 1/3/07 around 8 p.m. some pranksters put a life size lawn deer ornament in the 4900 block of Buckeye Rd.  Numerous vehicles halted at the sight of a real looking deer standing in the roadway.  There were attempts to move the 200 lb., concrete deer, but each time it was removed or pushed to the side, the pranksters returned to set up the deer in the roadway.  Swift thinking solved this problem:  A tow truck company was called in and they whisked away the 200 lb concrete life size BAMBI to MPD storage. . . oh, when does school ever resume???

CITY SLICKERS CORAL HORSEAt 7:30 a.m. Madison Police Officers were dispatched to a stray horse galloping throughout the east side of Madison.  Several officers tried to help this stray horse, who ran away from her stable owners. The horse was in danger of colliding with vehicles. Officers chased the horse down Buckeye Rd toward Hwy 51 until losing site of it.  Eventually the horse was relocated on Acewood traveling to Buckeye; then was chased down Buckeye to the Town of Cottage Grove, to Hwy AB to the Beltline.  During the spectacle, officers and several citizens attempted to coral the horse with cars, but the horse slipped through each time.  A water life-saving device was also thrown in attempt to lasso the frightened, cold horse.  The owner of the horse followed police and the horse during the course of events.  Eventually with the help of citizens, the officers were able to coral the horse near Hwy 12/18 and Hwy N and return her to her rightful owner.  The horse suffered some minor injuries throughout the almost hour-long event.

properties.Arrested: n/a
properties.Victim: Poncho-11 month old Chihuahua19 year-old female
properties.Details: On 5/21/06 at approximately 7:51 p.m. Madison Police responded to a theft from auto in the Wal-Mart parking lot.  Initially the victim returned to the store indicating, frantically, that her baby was stolen.  Employees and customers pitched in to help.  In calming the victim, it was learned that along with several electronic items stolen from her car, her 11 month-old Chihuahua was stolen from her car while the victim was shopping inside.  Since the original report, MPD has learned that the Chihuahua named Poncho, was returned to the Dane County Humane Society.

properties.Arrested: 1) Ebrel Mabriel-Duron, Male, Hispanic, 17, Theft-Party to a Crime, Entry Into Locked Vehicle-Party to a Crime2) Norlam Duron Carias, Male, Hispanic, 22, Theft-Party to a Crime, Entry Into Locked Vehicle-Party to a Crime3) Douglas Barela Carias, Male, Hispanic, 26, Theft-Party to a Crime, Entry Into Locked Vehicle-Party to a Crime, Probation Hold
properties.Details: On 7/25/06 at approximately 2:20 a.m. a witness reported to police that a theft from a vehicle was in progress.  Officers responded to the 200 block of S. Hancock St and observed the described individuals above near a car that had been broken into.  Officers detained the individuals for questioning and throughout the investigation learned that they had broken into a vehicle and removed several items.  This is an example of a witness seeing suspicious activity and alerting officers to it.  In the end, three individuals were arrested and the items were returned.

properties.Arrested: Peter Schmucki, 17, Marshall:  Theft from Auto-Party to a Crime, Obstructing.  Christopher Long, 17, Marshall: Theft from Auto-Party to a Crime, Obstructing. Male, 14, Theft from Auto-Party to a Crime, Curfew Violation
properties.Address: 700 block of East Village Green Lane
properties.Details: On 8/1/06 at approximately 12:46 a.m. Madison Police Officers were alerted by a citizen of some people possibly breaking into cars.  Officers arrived and located the individuals mentioned above.  Conflicting stories as to what the individuals were doing in the area arose the officers suspicions.  Through the investigation officers recovered items from multiple cars that were broken into in the area.  Some of the items recovered were numerous CD cases, stereo equipment, amplifiers, speakers and 2 "slim Jim" lock defeating devices.  The witness helped with this case in contacting police with suspicious behavior.

properties.Arrested: Male
properties.Victim: . Multiple Car Owners on Mayfair Ave., Mendota St., & Northport Dr.
properties.Details: Early in the morning on July 3rd Madison Police responded to an apartment building in the 3600 block of Kipling Drive after a citizen had followed suspects from a car theft to the location. Inside a hallway of the building police discovered a large quantity of car stereo equipment including CD players and speakers. Earlier that night a number of cars,  that were parked on streets listed above, were broken into. A couple of those victimized by the thefts responded to the Kipling Drive scene and recovered their property. Suspect information is still being developed

properties.Arrested: Fredy Allenda Rosales, Age 22, MadisonUriel Salome Milpa, Age 19, MadisonHector Mojica Morales, Age 18, MadisonAll tentatively charged with:Possession of Burglary ToolsEntry into Locked VehicleCriminal Damage to Property
properties.Details: On Saturday afternoon, July 21st, Madison Police officers were dispatched to Cypress Way following a tip that suspects were breaking into vehicles, and that they were now fleeing. One officer stopped the trio listed above, and discovered they were in possession of burglary tools, which included screwdrivers, and that one of the suspect's was carrying a bag, inside of which were three car stereos. Officers found one car on Cypress which had its front passenger window broken out. The car's stereo was gone. A witness reported seeing the same three men eyeballing cars in the area a couple of weeks ago, and that a friend of the witness had his car stereo stolen around that time.

properties.Details: On August 8th, around 8:50 p.m., Madison Police were sent to East Towne Mall to take a theft from auto complaint. A man, whose car had been broken in to, met the responding officer near the food court area of the mall. While he was describing what happened a woman drove up and stated she had been following a suspect car she believed contained occupants she suspected were breaking into vehicles parked on the other side of the mall. The officer then drove off to look for an older maroon car that she described. He found it, still in the mall parking lot. Inside were the above suspects, and a couple of car stereos. Victims told police windows to their cars had been broken during the crimes, and police are checking to see if the suspects maybe linked to similar thefts.

properties.Arrested: Javier (no middle name) Martinez-Garcia, Male Hispanic, Age 27, MiddletonTentatively charged with: Party to the Crime - Entry to Locked Vehicle, Possession of Stolen Property, Operating after Revocation, Driving against Traffic, Operating a Motor Vehicle while under the Influence of an intoxicant.Erick G. Ramos, Male Alaskan Native, Age 20, Nunapitchuk AlaskaTentative Charge: Entry into Locked Vehicle.
properties.Victim: Male White, Age 22, Oak Creek WIsuffered bruises
properties.Details: On Tuesday morning, September 25th, at 5:17 a.m. Madison Police responded to John Nolen Drive (between Lakeside Street & Olin Avenue) for a traffic crash. Witnesses told officers that the driver (later identified as Mr. Martinez-Garcia) of a white, 1996, Cutlass had been heading at a high rate of speed in the northbound lanes of John Nolen when he crossed over the median into the southbound lanes of John Nolen. According to witnesses a couple of southbound drivers were able to swerve and get out of the way of the Cutlass, but not the driver of a 2008 silver Honda. That driver (the victim listed above) was hit head-on. Inside the offending Cutlass Madison Police Officers discovered a large amount of car stereo equipment. One officer wrote that the back of Mr. Martinez-Garcia's vehicle was "as full as Santa's sleigh." Also at the crash scene were three subjects who turned out to be victims of car break-ins. All live in an apartment complex on Moorland Road. Some neighbors, who live at that complex, were, around 5:00 a.m. that morning, were bearing witness to a series of car break-ins. Some victims of the break-ins became aware of what was happening.  Three men ran from their apartments to confront the suspects. The suspects made a hasty retreat, even leaving some stolen stereo speakers in the parking lot of the complex. They (the suspects) took off in the in the Cutlass, and the three apartment complex residents, who had originally thought to confront the suspects, decided to give chase, with hopes of jotting down the license plate of the Cutlass. They ended up being witnesses to the crash. Its believed Mr. Martinez-Garcia was aware that he was being followed by the victims.

properties.Suspect: Male Hispanic, Age 16, MadisonMale Hispanic, Age 16, MadisonFemale White, Age 15, MadisonThe males were arrested for Entry into Locked Vehicle, Damage to Property, and Theft.The female was arrested for Party to a crime for Entry into Locked Vehicle, PTAC Damage to Property, and PTAC for theft.
properties.Details: On October 8th around 3:16 a.m. a resident in the Maywick Drive area alerted police to suspects who were breaking windows of vehicles and stealing contents from within. The caller described the suspect vehicle as being a smaller white car. The caller also said he saw three people, including one white female, one Hispanic male, and another unknown male. Officer’s responding to the area found that three vehicles had had windows smashed. Around the same time other officers spotted what looked to be the suspect car inbound on Cottage Grove Road coming over the Interstate. As the suspect car traveled it appeared the driver noticed one of the Madison squads, which was parked, and waiting near Thompson Drive. The driver of the suspect car evidently saw the officer, and decided to make a right-hand turn. He perhaps did not realize he had turned into the Police Department's East District Station. The suspects were arrested, and stolen items were recovered

properties.Suspect: Perry Bernard Williams, Age 49, NPATentatively charged with Entry into a Locked Vehicle, Criminal Damage to Property & a Probation Hold
properties.Details: On October 12th around 8:00 p.m. a private security guard called Madison police to report that a man, who was on West Washington Avenue, had just broken into a SUV. As a Madison police officer pulled up he spotted the suspect. The officer observed the suspect was now peering into another parked car. The suspect told the officer he thought the car belonged to his sister. The officer asked where the sister lived. The suspect said Chicago. The officer pointed out the car in question had Iowa license plates. While frisking the suspect the officer detected two large, heavy items in his coat. The suspect suggested they were parts to his computer. Upon further review the "parts" turned out to be ski bindings. The officer asked Mr. Williams if he attached ski bindings to his computer. Mr. Williams stated that he did. The officer then located the owner of the Chevy Blazer that had been broken in to a short time earlier. That man identified several items found on the suspect including his sunglasses, his cell phone, and the ski bindings he had just purchased off of E-Bay.

properties.Suspect: Jeffrey M. Davis, Age 23, MadisonArrested on a warrant for Operating after Revocation (2 counts), a warrant for Theft of Movable Property, and a Parole Violation
properties.Details: On October 18th at 2:18 p.m. the above suspect was taken in to custody at his girlfriend's apartment on Madison's north side. Madison detectives say Mr. Davis is a suspect in recent thefts of catalytic converters. A scrap dealer, from outside of Dane County but in Wisconsin, identified Mr. Davis as the person who had brought a large quantity of catalytic converters to his business. Investigators believe Mr. Davis may have been working in concert with at least one other individual; however they caution that other people, completely unrelated to Mr. Davis, may also be involved in what has become a national theft problem. In Madison alone a couple of hundred catalytic converters have been stolen since March of this year. The Madison Police Department, recognizing the trend, has implemented a plan to catch thieves. In this case patrol officers and detectives worked hand in hand to pick up Mr. Davis.

properties.Suspect: Perpetrator is described as a male, black, 19 years old, 5'6", 165 lbs., thin build, wearing a black skullcap, black hooded jacket with a gray liner & black slacks.
properties.Details: On January 7th around 7:33 p.m. Madison Police responded to the 5200 block of Summer Ridge Drive for a robbery call. A resident said he looked out of his home to see someone inside his car, which was parked in the driveway. He chased the perpetrator but was unable to catch him. He then hid in some trees to see if the perpetrator might come back. He did. The victim jumped out, and the perpetrator responded by pointing a handgun at the victim's face. The victim then turned a sprinted into his house. He saw the perpetrator get into a getaway car. Three black zippered notebook style CD containers were stolen. They contained a couple of hundred CDs.

properties.Suspect: James E. Grant, age 18, MadisonMr. Grant was arrested and tentatively charged with Entry into Locked Vehicle and Criminal Damage to PropertyDashawn A. Amy, age 17, MadisonEdward Fultz, age 26, MadisonMr. Amy & Mr. Fultz were arrested and tentatively charged with Possession of Stolen Property.
properties.Details: On Monday evening, around 6:53 p.m., Madison Police were called to East Towne Mall after a stereo was ripped out of a parked car. Unbeknownst to the thieves there was a witness to the crime. The witness not only contacted police, but also informed the car's owner of those responsible. She (the witness) pointed out a blue and silver conversion-type van, which was still in the parking lot. The victim jumped in his car -- prior to police arrival -- and attempted to intervene with the suspects of the getaway van as they traveled along East Towne Boulevard. He pulled in front of the van and was able to get it stopped. But as the occupants of the van began to get out -- he (the victim) strongly considered the downside of the situation and drove away. Officers were on the scene minutes later and were able to pull the van over on Parkside Drive near an Arby's restaurant. The victim was contacted by dispatch and also responded to the scene. He was able to identify his stolen stereo. It was among several car stereo components recovered from the van. Investigators will now look to see if other items were stolen. The victim reports that besides the theft, the perpetrators broke his driver's side window and caused considerable damage to his vehicle's dash.

On Saturday March 1, 2008 Madison Police took reports of several thefts after a thief, or thieves hit an underground parking garage in the 300 block of N. Hancock Street. In most cases windows were broken and items like car stereos were taken. One car -- a red '96 Chevy Corsica -- was also stolen. Its’ owner had locked the vehicle, but had left a key in the ignition. Investigators believe the crime spree occurred between 2:00 a.m. and 6:30 a.m. on March 1, 2008.Madison Police responded to a similar scene in the 500 block of Moorland Road around 3:00 p.m. on February 29th.  In that case eight vehicles parked in an apartment complex lot had windows broken and items stolen.It is not known if the two cases are connected.

The Madison Police Department continues to receive new reports on thefts from vehicles. Between Tuesday and Wednesday of this week nine separate cases came in from residents of the East District. Most involved car windows being broken and items taken from parked cars/trucks. Reports were taken from people living in the 2900 and 3100 blocks of Milwaukee Street, the 1200 block of Mendota Street, the 300 block of N. Thompson Drive, the 200 block of N. Fair Oaks Avenue, and the 5500 block of Camden Road.

One suspect, Mr. Jones, was found lying face down near a retaining wall in the 3100 block of Dorchester Way. Mr. Jones put up a brief struggle, but was taken in to custody. More footprints led officers to the hiding place of Mr. James. It was not far from where Mr. Jones was found. Money, a laptop computer, a digital camera, and other stolen items were recovered. The investigation indicates the suspects had been entering unlocked cars.

properties.Suspect: Anthony J. Hirsch, age 32, MadisonMr. Hirsch has been arrested and tentatively charged with one count of Possession of Child Pornography.
properties.Details: On Friday, December 28, 2006, members of the Madison Police Department (MPD) arrested Anthony J. Hirsch, age 32, Madison, for Possession of Child Pornography.  MPD detectives also executed a search warrant at Hirsch’s S. Stoughton Road residence.  This action was based on information that was provided to the MPD by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.  Madison detectives learned that Hirsch was a subject of interest in the investigation of a commercial child exploitation website involving member-restricted access to at least 18 different child exploitation websites.  Hirsch is currently employed as an educational assistant for special education children at Waunakee Middle School. He formerly worked in a similar capacity at Madison La Follette High School.  Following his arrest MPD detectives immediately contacted the Waunakee School District.  The Madison Metropolitan School District has also been notified. Computers seized in the search of Hirsch’s residence are being examined for evidence of child pornography by the Computer Forensic Shared Resources partnership. This is a joint effort between the Dane County Sheriffs Office and the Madison Police Department.  This is an open and ongoing investigation and more charges are possible.If you have any information about this case, please call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at (608) 266-6014.

properties.Details: On February 4th and 12:22 a.m. Madison Police were called to a residence on West Wilson Street after a neighbor reported hearing a woman screaming and crying as a man yelled at the woman. Responding officers could also hear the woman screaming, "Get off of me!"  Officers were prepared to force entry, but instead were greeted by the suspect who, from behind a closed door, told police he had a gun. He threatened to use it, and was refusing to come out of the home because he was aware of outstanding warrants for his arrest. Many were for outstanding child support. At the time of this dialogue there were three young children -- and their mother -- inside the dwelling. Police set up a perimeter and started negotiations. First the mother and one child were allowed to exit, and then a second child was freed. Around 3:20 a.m. negotiators were able to bring the entire situation to a peaceful conclusion as the suspect came out and was taken into custody. Officers discovered the children were living in very poor conditions. Proper authorities (a social worker etc.) were notified.

properties.Details: On 10/16/06 at approximately 9:16 am, officers were called to East High School reference a threats complaint.  After officers arrived and met with school safety officials, it was established that a serious threat had been made to a student by another individual currently not at the school.  Given the seriousness of a threat and its credibility, the school went into a lockdown mode at 11:00 am.  Additional MPD resources were deployed to the school to handle the threat.  After a thorough investigation the suspect of the threats was identified and resources deployed to locate him.  Later in the afternoon the suspect was located, detained and conveyed to the Juvenile Reception Center.  Charges have been brought against this suspect reference another investigation.  The investigation is still ongoing and the safety of the student population, the school district and the community at large continues to be the focus of our efforts.

On April 22nd Madison Police received information about a hoax/scam that created a good deal of concern for a Madison man who was sent a threatening email Monday morning.The subject matter stated "Matter of Urgent". It was from the name "Mr. G. Hord" with an email address of axa@killer.com.The e-mail starts out stating, “Hello.  It’s a pity that this is how your life is going to end soon as you don’t comply.  As you can see there is no need of introducing myself to you because I don’t have any business with you.  My duty, I am mailing you now, is just KILL you and I have to do it as I have already been paid for that.”It then goes on to state that a friend wants the man dead, and has already paid for the service. The entrepreneurial scammer writes the man can save his life, and get the "hit" canceled by forking over $3,000.The communiqué goes on to say,  “If you are not ready to take my help, then I will carry on with my job, straight up.”  It says not to contact police or anyone or,  “I will extend it to your family, in case I notice something funny.”  A website that tracks urban legends - snopes.com - states the "hit man bribe scam" has been around since early 2006. Infact, the FBI (go to fbi.gov) has issued a couple of warnings over the last couple of years on its "E-Scams & Warnings" web page:(THE FOLLOWING IS WHAT CAN BE FOUND ON THE FBI WEBSITE)NEW TWIST CONCERNING THREAT AND EXTORTION E-MAILS 01/09/07—There is a new twist to the IC3 alert posted on December 7, 2006 regarding e-mails claiming that the sender has been paid to kill the recipient and will cancel the contract on the recipient's life if that person pays a large sum of money. Now e-mails are surfacing that claim to be from the FBI in London. These e-mails note the following information: An individual was recently arrested for the murders of several United States and United Kingdom citizens in relation to this matter. The recipient's information was found on the subject identifying the recipient as the next victim. The recipient is requested to contact the FBI in London to assist with the investigation. It is not uncommon for an Internet fraud scheme to have the same overall intent but be transmitted containing variations in the e-mail content, e.g., different names, e-mail addresses, and/or agencies reportedly involved. See our related top story on the hitman scam. Please note, providing any personal information in response to an unsolicited e-mail can compromise your identity and open you to identity theft. If you have experienced this situation please notify the IC3 by filing a complaint at www.ic3.gov. Due to the threat of violence inherent in these extortion e-mails, if you receive an e-mail that contains personally identifiable information that might differentiate your e-mail from the general e-mail spam campaign, we encourage you to contact the police.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------E-MAILS CONTAINING THREATS AND EXTORTION12/07/06—We have recently received information concerning spam e-mails threatening to assassinate the recipient unless the individual pays several thousand dollars to the sender of the e-mail. The subject claims to have been following the victim for some time and was supposedly hired to kill the victim by a friend of the victim. The subject threatens to carry out the assassination if the victim goes to the police and requests the victim to respond quickly and provide their telephone number. Warning! Providing any personal information can compromise your identify and open you to identity theft. If you have experienced this situation, please notify your local, state, or federal law enforcement agency immediately. Also, please notify the IC3 by filing a complaint at www.ic3.gov.

While conducting this surveillance the officer saw a group of young men standing around a car that was parked at the fast food restaurant. After several minutes it became apparent that they were not there to buy food. The officer went to contact the subjects. One of them ran into and through the restaurant before fleeing out of a different door. He then darted into Park Street traffic causing cars to abruptly hit the brakes. With traffic now stopped the officer chased the suspect into the parking lot of a business (Comstock Firestone Tire) across the street from the McDonald's. A Dane County Sheriff's Deputy was in the area at the time of the foot chase and observed the suspect toss a plastic bag onto the roof of Comstock. properties.Details: On April 18th around 5:07 a.m. Madison Police responded to a downtown apartment building. Three female residents (all in their 20's) had each locked themselves in their respective bedrooms after a stranger had either entered, or tried to enter, the areas in which they slept. The roommates later explained that they were not sure they had locked their apartment door, and there was no sign of forced entry. However, when police arrived they found Mr. Daniel Smith sitting in the living room. Two of the three roommates said they had awoken to find Smith in their bedrooms. The third roommate said she had her bedroom door locked, but heard someone trying to open the door a couple of times.  It was determined that Mr. Smith had been drinking, and he had a difficult time explaining why he was in the apartment. To most questions asked by responding officers Mr. Smith responded, "Chicken do." At one point he did say, "I'll tell you what day it is, it's Tuesday." It should be noted this happened on a Friday.  Mr. Smith was arrested for Trespass, Disorderly Conduct, and Criminal Damage to Property after it was discovered he had urinated in his pants, and that urine was partially absorbed into the fabric of a futon he had been on while sitting/reclining in the women's living room. None of the roommates knew Mr. Smith. The MPD strongly urges residents to lock their doors.

properties.Arrested: "Boom Cars"
properties.Details: In response to increased citizen complaints about vehicles with loud stereos and amplification (known as "boom cars") disturbing neighborhoods, Alder Judy Olson, the City Attorney's Office and the Madison Police Department have worked together in a problem-solving capacity. Neighborhood Officers and officers on the Community Police Teams have received training on writing citations to vehicles in which citizens complain that their amplification was disturbing.  The goal is for neighborhood groups to report to police those vehicles "booming" their stereos, disturbing the peace.  Trained Officers to this initiative will be available to present training to neighborhood association groups on what to observe and how to formally report these disturbances to police.  Neighborhood Associations or concerned citizens should contact their Police District Lieutenant to learn how to receive this training.  The citation issued holds the owner of the registered vehicle accountable if they are not the driver or in the vehicle.  The following is some information regarding the training and legalities of this problem-solving initiative:DISTURBANCE FROM VEHICLES WITH LOUD ELECTRONIC SOUND AMPLIFICATIONOften referred to as Boom Cars, police are seeing a rise in complaints from residents concerning vehicles which park, stand or operate with sound systems so loud, they disturb the peace. This is a difficult violation for police to address because of the transient nature of the incident, yet that does not diminish its negative effect on the quality of life for citizens in areas all over the city.Under what is known as the owner onus principle, the registered owner of a vehicle is liable for loud car stereo violations. Madison General Ordinances allow a citizen to file a written complaint in regard to radios or electronic sound amplification devises audible from a vehicle in excess of 75 feet. Police may issue citations to the vehicle owner regardless of who was operating at the time of the offense.This link will give citizens information on what they can do to be reporters. The law is quite specific in its scope and nature, and it is important that citizens carefully read the information and plan to do the necessary pre-work. USING THE CITIZEN COMPLAINT FORMThe citizen complaint will require you to do some work ahead of time. You will need to prepare a diagramming map with the report, and should make several copies of this ahead of time, since it will require taking measurements. You will also need to pick a place for making your observations, and you need to be able to clearly read the rear license plate of the vehicle from your observation point. The best way to handle this would be to enlist the help of other observers and complainants. It would not be possible to complete an honest report with just one person.To meet the legal criteria, you must identify the vehicle by license plate and description, and give some indications of the driver’s description. The noise coming from the car must be electronic sound amplification and cannot be noise from a loud muffler or squealing tires. You must show that the electronic sound is audible for more than 75 feet, which will require you to measure out a distance from your home or business. The law has specific time lines that must be followed in order to produce a complaint. You must turn in your citizen report within 24 hours of when you made your observations. If you don’t follow this time line, no citation can be issued. It only requires you to call police to pick up the form.

properties.Suspect: Jesus Gutierrez Prado, age 30, MadisonMr. Gutierrez Prado was arrested and tentatively charged with Disorderly Conduct, Possession of Drug Paraphernalia, Obstructing, and two Warrants; one for Operating without a Valid Driver's License, and the second for a Red Signal Violation.
properties.Details: Late Wednesday afternoon, at 5:49 p.m., Madison Police were contacted by an area runner who had just had a bad experience on what should have been a nice afternoon on his route through Vilas Park. He was in the bike/pedestrian lane when a guy with a booming car stereo drove up alongside him. The runner asked the driver to turn down the volume. The driver in turn responded with spewing saliva in the direction of the runner. The spit connected with his leg. Disturbed by this the runner cut his exercise short and returned home to call police. He pointed out the suspect who was now hanging out in the park. The man was arrested on several tentative charges.

properties.Arrested: Austin Cannon, 19, Madison:  Forgery
properties.Details: On 3/21/07 at 3:30 a.m. Madison Police and Fire responded to a structure fire in the 400 block of N. Carroll St.  It was learned that Cannon had left food on the stove, causing an extreme amount of smoke to the building.  No one was injured and residents were eventually able to return to their apartments.  During the police investigation inside Cannon's apartment, with Cannon present, officers learned of his fake identification operations inside his own apartment.  Cannon was making numerous California fake identities to sell.  Cannon was arrested and taken to the Dane County Jail without incident.

Members of the Madison Police Department’s Criminal Intelligence Section indicate there have been several cases of forgery where everyday citizens have been victimized. The case number listed above illustrates one such incident. On September 27th, around 6:00 in the evening, a man tried to make a purchase at East Towne Mall utilizing a bogus $20 bill. The victim (the man with the 20) had gotten the bill from someone described only as a teenage black male. He (the teenager) had approached the victim at the mall and asked if he (the victim) had change for a 20. The victim said “yes” and gave the suspect two $10 bills. The clerk at the store, where the victim tried to use the phony $20, was quickly able to tell it was a fake. Anyone approached by someone trying to change a $20, or other larger bill, might best send the bill holder to a bank or store for change.

properties.Address: Ryan Funeral Home, 2418 N. Sherman Ave.
properties.Details: This afternoon, June 11, at 2:00 p.m., a memorial service will be held for Alphonse John "Jack" Mercier. "Jack" passed away at a local hospital Thursday, May 31, at the age of 82. For the past 18 years "Jack" worked the volunteer desk in the hallway outside of the Madison Police Department at the City County Building. Always armed with a warm smile, and big heart - "Jack", in a fatherly/grandfatherly way,  made officers and citizens alike feel welcome. He was the kind of guy who took great interest in the lives of others, and was always ready to listen,  lend advice, or offer kind words of encouragement. Besides helping at the MPD, "Jack" gave of his time as a volunteer at Marquette Elementary School. He also volunteered for more than 45 years at Badger Boys State and the American Legion Boys Nation. In that role, he was able to shake hands with every President since Eisenhower. A former teacher, "Jack" is survived by his wife Elmay, and two adult children. A World War II veteran, "Jack" epitomized what being part of the "Greatest Generation" was all about. He will be missed by many in the Madison community, including those who protect and serve.

This weekend 2 blocks of Wilson Street will be closed to traffic in an effort to promote pedestrian safety for the "Art Fair Off The Square." Wilson Street will be shutdown between South Pinckney and Carroll Streets between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on Saturday July 14th, and between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Sunday July 15th. "Art Fair Off The Square" is located along Martin Luther King Blvd. and on the Monona Terrace Convention Center Esplanade. In past years Madison Police observed the difficulty, and potential danger, art enthusiasts faced as they tried to cross Wilson Street, which is smack in the middle of the 140 exhibits that comprise "Art Fair Off The Square". There will access to the area hotel for those staying at that location.

properties.Suspect: UPDATED NUMBERS/MONDAY OCTOBER 29THFriday arrests: 55Saturday arrests: 126From the MPD arrest processing center 3 taken to detox. However, others were also conveyed to detox who did not come through arrest processing. Detox center would have complete numbers.
properties.Details: (THE FOLLOWING WAS RELEASED AFTER 2:00 A.M. SUNDAY MORNING)Freakfest 2007 has just culminated and Mayor Dave Cieslewicz and Madison Police Chief Noble Wray want to thank the more than 34,000 who purchased tickets for the way they conducted themselves. Freakfest went extremely well, and another very positive step has been taken in making this a celebration for which the community can be proud. As of 2:00 a.m. 120 arrests had been made, most for alcohol violations.  That compares with 148 arrests during Freakfest 2006, and 334 that were made in 2005 during the Saturday night party.  Combining Friday and Saturday night arrests there were 175 this year compared to 235 in 2006.  No serious property damage or serious injuries were reported as of this writing, and it is hoped the event will continue to improve in 2008. For details, and interviews on Freakfest reporters are urged contact the promoter- Frank Productions. Again a big thanks to the UW students and other revelers who helped make this such a great success.--------------------------------------------------(THE FOLLOWING WAS RELEASED EARLY SATURDAY MORNING OCTOBER 27TH)It is early Saturday morning and Madison police have encountered few problems thus far in the night leading up to Freakfest. As of 1:00 a.m. 25 people have been arrested, most for unlawful possession of alcohol. Unlike the night before Freakfest last year State Street remains open this morning, and no area roads have had to be closed due to pedestrian traffic. Crowds on State Street have been described as "thin" by some in the command post. The most significant event for law enforcement and fire personnel was a battery to a couple of paramedics. They had picked up a drunken person who decided to throw a couple of punches inside the ambulance that was heading to a local hospital. There have also been concerns expressed by some law enforcement officers about the level of intoxication among some revelers. Several women, who appeared to be under the influence, were spotted walking alone in the campus area. That being said, Madison police are generally pleased with how the night before Freakfest has progressed thus far.

Sometime this afternoon between 3:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. Sgt. Joshua Brennan will return to the Madison area with a heroes welcome. Sgt. Brennan was recently killed in action while serving in Afghanistan. Josh's Dad Mike is a Madison police officer, and Josh's dream was to become a Madison police officer after completing his tour of duty. Josh's obituary can be found in this morning's Wisconsin State Journal. The family would like the public to see how a hero is honored. The Madison police honor guard, and a contigent of  other officers will help escort Sgt. Brennan's body from Chicago to the Gunderson Funeral Home on Monona Drive. The media is invited to Gunderson's to photograph the arrival. A member of the MPD will also likely be available for an interview (away from the family). If you are interested in covering the motorcade and arrival, the OIC will try to post an updated release with a more specific time of arrival as it is a bit in flux at this hour. At the funeral home, media can look for Sgt. Jen Krueger-Favour, or Capt. Carl Gloede as they would likely be the ones who would decide who would be appropriate to speak with media representaives.

properties.Suspect: William J. R. Atkins, Age 46, Madison.Mr. Atkins was arrested and tentatively charged with Possession with Intent to Deliver Heroin within 1000 feet of a school, speeding in excess of posted limits, operating after revocation, and warrants.
properties.Arrested: Eric L. Cribbs, Age 39, MadisonMr. Cribbs was arrested and tentatively charged with Obstructing & a parole violation.The special enforcement initiative also resulted in 12 speeding citations, and one loud muffler violation
properties.Details: On Monday afternoon officers from the Madison Police Department's East District conducted a special speeding enforcement initiative along Camden Road. This was in direct response to quality of life concerns that had been brought by residents of the area to the police department. A dozen speeding citations were issued, as well as a citation for a loud muffler. One driver, Mr. Atkins, was clocked going 45 m.ph. in a 25 m.p.h. zone near Lafollette High School. He and his passenger were later arrested on the above charges. Officers found Mr. Atkins to be in possession of several small packages of heroin.

properties.Suspect: There were 438 total arrests for the Mifflin Street party, 383 people were cited and released, 51 went to jail, and 4 went to the detox center.
properties.Details: As of about 8:20 p.m. there were around 400 arrests reported. The block party is winding down and streets in the area are all open. No major incidents were reported during the event. Final arrest numbers/charges will be available in the next couple of weeks.-------------------------------------------------------As of 6:00 p.m. there have been around 350 arrests. A couple of parties have been shut down, or are in the process of being shut down. As has been the case for most of the afternoon, the lion's share of arrests are for alcohol related offenses.----------------------------------------------As of 5:00 p.m.  The crowd is reported to be mostly good-natured. There have been around 270 arrests, mostly for alcohol related issues. Several people have been taken to detox. --------------------------------------------As of 3:00 p.m. Madison Police estimated a crowd of fewer than 10,000 was in the general Mifflin Street area for the annual block party. Around 60 people have been processed at the arrest center, almost all for alcohol related violations. Another 54 people are yet to be processed. There have been no major fights or other serious issues thus far.

On 6/28/08, the Rhythm and Booms event was a success.  There was a short storm interruption, which shut down the event for approximately 1/2 hour during the mid-afternoon.  This storm did not cause any serious damage and the event was able to resume on schedule.There were 10 arrests at the event, which were related to youth disturbances in the Carnival Midway area of the Park.  These disturbances involved large groups of youth, ages ranging from mid-teens to early twenties.  There was gang posturing behavior.  The Madison Police Department Special Events Team was forced to shut down the Midway, and clear the area.  There were several fights leading to a total of 10 arrests including Disorderly Conduct, Battery and one individual charged with Recklessly Endangering Safety.  In addition to these issues, there were 3 individuals taken to the Dane County Detox Center and a handful of citations issued.The bulk of the event was extremely positive and the crowds were generally well-behaved.  The crowd was estimated between 150,000 and 175,000 people.Cameron McLay, Captain of PoliceCity of Madison Police, North District Commander

properties.Suspect: Unwanted person is 29 years old, no permanent address, 6'6" & 250 lbs.
properties.Details: On January 17th 2008 at approximately 6:49 p.m. Madison police were called to McDonald's on Verona Road. The restaurant's manager had become aware of a man repeatedly using the women's restroom. Upon arrival a Madison Police officer spotted said culprit walking out of the restaurant; however, having spotted the officer the man turned around and headed back toward the restrooms. The officer went to the women's room and announced, "City of Madison Police." The officer found the restroom empty. He then entered the men's room and observed the violator seated on a toilet to the rear of the facility. The officer ordered the man out of the stall. Under questioning he admitted his preference for the women's room. The man explained the toilet seats are just so much more comfortable. He was told McDonald's management was not interested in his toilet seat preference, and did not want him on their property. The subject then announced his intention of buying a hamburger. The officer informed him he had no money, something the officer had noted during a pat down search. The gentleman left empty handed, and was then escorted away without incident. He was not cited or arrested.

properties.Suspect: Eton Bentley, age 53, no permanent address (NPA)Mr. Bentley was arrested and tentatively charged with Carrying a Concealed Weapon, Possession of a Switchblade Knife, Menacing Panhandling, and a Parole Hold.
properties.Details: On April 22nd, around 7:22 p.m., a State Street business owner contacted Madison Police about an aggressive panhandler. The caller said the man was getting in the faces of his customers as they tried to enter his store. When an officer arrived the panhandler pulled out a switchblade knife and threw it on the ground. The panhandler proceeded to hurl an array of obscenities at the officer. The MPD will be requesting he be placed on the State Street ban list.

Per Captain Jim Wheeler, on May 15, 2008 at approximately 4:44 am the Madison Police Departments' Emergency Response Team executed two search warrants in the 2500 block of Greenway View and the 2900 block of Todd Drive respectively.  The search warrants were carried out due to information that drugs and stolen merchandise were possibly inside the residences. The Emergency Response Team was used due to information that firearms were possibly inside the residences as well. Since this is an ongoing investigation, the search warrants will be sealed per court order.

On Thursday morning, shortly before 2:00 a.m., Madison Police Officer Paul Fleischauer responded to a residence on Londonderry Drive after a frantic woman reported a suicidal man was hanging from a banister inside the home. Officer Fleischauer went inside and found there was a man (in his 20's) who was indeed hanging - by what appeared to be a bathrobe - from the banister. The man was losing consciousness. Officer Fleischauer hopped on a couch and lifted the man up to prevent further injury, and to try to open his airway. Officer Fleischauer was next able to get the man down from the banister, and the man did regain consciousness. Madison Fire Rescue arrived and the man was taken away for medical treatment. It’s believed without Officer Fleischauer’s quick actions the man would have been dead in a relatively short time. Officer Fleischauer will be nominated for a Madison Police Department Life Saving Award.

properties.Address: Lathrop Street at Van Hise Avenue
properties.Details: Driver was southbound on Lathrop Street and collided with a bicyclist who was eastbound on Van Hise Avenue. The bicyclist suffered a punctured lung and may have a brain bleed as well as numerous scrapes and bruises. She is being treated a local hospital. The crash remains under investigation. Injuries are non-life threatening.

properties.Suspect: Jeffery A. Okafo, age 31, MadisonMr. Okafo was arrested and tentatively charged with Disorderly Conduct, Obstructing a Peace Officer, and Resisting a Peace Officer.
properties.Details: On Sunday, May 25, 2008, shortly after 9:00 p.m., a Madison Police Officer responded to the 400 block of North Frances Street to backup a Madison Police Parking Enforcement Officer (PEO) who was having a pickup truck towed and - based on past experience - thought there could be trouble with the vehicle's owner. When the MPD officer arrived the angry owner did in fact show up and confront the PEO. He stood in the PEO's face and yelled at him. The police officer tried to intervene. The suspect threatened the officer with violence, and then resisted the officer's efforts to make an arrest. The police officer ended using a Taser, and department issued OC spray before compliance could be achieved.

properties.Suspect: (UPDATED TUESDAY JULY 8,2008)The bike has been recovered by its owner.
properties.Details: On July 5th, shortly after 4:00 p.m., the owner of a very expensive and unique bicycle parked his ride unattended, but just a few feet away from an ATM at the Jenifer Street Market. In the couple of minutes it took the victim to use the machine his $8,000 bike disappeared. The bike has a carbon fiber frame, fork, handlebars, seat, wheels, and cranks. There are but a couple of small pieces of aluminum parts on the bike. It has no brakes, and is a "fixed" gear. It does not coast, but works like a "big wheel". If you want to slow down you pedal backwards, or lock your knees. The owner says it would be useless to most riders. If anyone has seen this bike they are urged to call Madison Area Crime Stoppers at 608-266-6014.

properties.Suspect: Male, age 26, MadisonSuspect was taken to detox
properties.Address: 22 S. Carroll Street (Inn on the Park)
properties.Details: Early Tuesday morning, around 7:30 a.m., Madison Police started combing the downtown area for a man who was reportedly wandering around wearing only a towel. Some were on foot and walking the Capitol Square near State Street when several passersby approached saying they had seen the guy, and that he appeared to be a bit out of it. An officer in a squad car radioed that he had a visual on the towel clad pedestrian. He had been spotted him near Bassett and Main Streets. One officer noted the "man was staggering significantly as he walked, swaying from side-to-side and staggering a wobbly and crooked course from margin to margin of the sidewalk." It turned out he had boxer shorts on beneath the towel. When asked what he was doing the man said he was just on his way home. He does have a downtown address. He could not say why he was wandering around, where he had been, or where he had gotten the towel. At one point the man nearly fell over while talking with an officer. The officer grabbed him and placed him in protective custody. His clothes and wallet were later discovered on a table near the whirlpool area at the Inn on the Park. He was not a registered guest.

On July 14th at 7:15 p.m. a Madison woman contacted police about a couple of annoying phone calls. The victim says she got a message to call a Cook County (Illinois) Sheriff's Captain because someone had been in a car crash. A second disturbing call came shortly after the first relaying similar information. The victim was concerned because she has a daughter living in the Chicago area. A phone number she was supposed to call turned out to be bogus.On July 7th another Madison resident, who lives in the 200 block of East Bluff Street, received similar crank calls, including several that were collect from the Cook County Jail. The woman accepted one of the collect calls just to tell the caller he/she had the wrong number. It was at this point a male voice told her that she had a family member who had been involved in a serious crash and that the woman should call “Captain Smith”. The prankster then supplied a phone number with a 312 area code.On July 10th a third Madison woman, who lives in the 1200 block of Iowa Drive, received four calls from "Sergeant James" asking her to call “Captain Smith” at a given number because there had been a car crash involving an injured female. The victim called her daughters to make sure they were OK, and then reported the prank.The Madison Police Department has contacted the Cook County Jail and advised authorities of these incidents. Cook County deputies said they would attempt to track down the culprit and put an end to the annoying calls.

properties.Suspect: Travis Samuel Penny, M/W 20 yrs of Mazomanie WisconsinCharges: Criminal Damage To Property Resisting Underage Person Possess Alcohol
properties.Arrested: Ryan E. Russell  M/W 19 yrs of Mazomanie, WisconsinCharges:Resisting/Obstructing
properties.Details: On 08/23/2008, The Madison Police Department was dispatched to the 700 blk of East Johnson reference a large fight in the street.  Officers arrived shortly after 12:17am, and found a broken window that someone had thrown a beer keg through.  Several interviews were conducted at 753 East Johnson Street, and upon further investigation it would be determined that a nearby truck sustained similar glass damage.  The two incidents were definitely connected, and complainants gave officers on scene good descriptions of potential suspects.Officers would clear this scene, in order to respond to other priority calls, when just moments later a call to the 911 Center would advise of a “Fight in the street” near Blair Street and Johnson Street.  The complainant stated there were approximately 20 people fighting.  Officers would respond to this area, which is close in proximity to 753 E. Johnson Street, and a foot pursuit would begin as officers would attempt to contact the participants in the fight.  The suspects would run through back yards, over fences, and soon thereafter be taken into custody by police on a number of charges.  This entire situation seems to have involve alcohol and an unresolved argument among several individuals at a birthday party which resulted in numerous fights and damage to property.  Another overriding factor was that there were many involved individuals in the disturbance that were not known to the residents at 753 E. Johnson Street.  As a reminder, it is always a best practice to have knowledge of all individuals you might have in your residence no matter what type of gathering you are hosting i.e., birthday party or graduation celebration, ...ect.  Keeping your property and the property of others safe is a paramount responsibility, but making sound decisions helps to prevent occurrences such as this from erupting.

properties.Address: 5117 University Avenue Erdman Real Estate Holdings
properties.Details: On Tuesday morning Madison Police responded to Erdman Real Estate Holdings, 5117 University Avenue, to take a report on a stolen dump truck. An employee believes the 1997 white and red GMC was taken from a warehouse sometime between noon on Labor Day and 7:30 a.m. on September 2nd. Also gone, and presumably transported in the dump truck, was 100 pounds worth of copper wire. As of Wednesday afternoon the truck had not been recovered.Metal thefts continue to be an ongoing problem, and members the countywide Blue Net Burglary Task Force will be looking into this case.
